narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto conducted an unannounced Annual/Required Inspection at the facility on 7/27/21 beginning at 11:00 AM. LPA met with Genie Tinsley, Licensee, and explained the purpose of the inspection. This facility is licensed for four clients and currently serves four clients. The following conditions were observed: The home is clean, safe and sanitary throughout. The kitchen has adequate food and supplies. The backyard is clean and has adequate space. Cleaning supplies and hazardous materials are locked in the laundry room and inaccessible to clients. The water temperature is controlled by tank-less hot water heater that is programmable and is set to 115 degrees. There is a sprinkler system for fire suppression; smoke detectors and carbon monoxide were tested during today's inspection. There is the necessary fire extinguishers and first aid kits. All bedrooms of the home are equipped with adequate linens, television, desk, toys and clothing for clients. The client's have their own private space where they can take space to do their own actives and be creative. All required Licensing forms are posted and were observed during inspection. There is a vegetable garden outside along with fruit trees where the Licensee frequently acquires fruits and vegetables for the clients. LPA observed a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable foods in the kitchen. The food menu is posted on the refrigerator along with personal rights. Refer to page 2.

Client files, staff files, medication logs and schedules were observed in the home and are within Regulation standards. Child files include Personal Rights, immunization records, medical consent forms, and all other required Licensing documents. All child care staff are current in CPR, first aid and records include all required Licensing documents. Record of client's safeguarded cash resources was inspected and up to standard. LPA interviewed clients and staff. LPA observed the children to be safe and happy. The licensee keeps Daily Communication Book with the teachers. The home is well maintained and meets or exceeds Licensing requirements. At this time no Title 22 Regulations are being cited. Exit interview conducted

On July 12, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Caplinger conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of the required inspection. LPA met with Genie Tinsley and Charles Tinsley, Licensees, and a walk through was conducted. The home currently has two clients. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen has adequate food and supplies. LPA observed a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable foods in the kitchen. The food menu is posted. The backyard is clean and has adequate space. There is a vegetable garden outside along with fruit trees where the Licensee frequently acquires fruits and vegetables for the clients. Cleaning supplies and hazardous materials are locked in the laundry room and inaccessible to clients. The water temperature is kept at 115 degrees. There is a sprinkler system for fire suppression; smoke detectors and carbon monoxide were tested during today's inspection. There is the necessary fire extinguishers and first aid kits. All bedrooms of the home are equipped with adequate linens and clothing for clients. All required Licensing forms are posted and were observed during inspection. There are no firearms or bodies of water at the home. Medication is stored correctly and locked. Staff and client files are kept secured. A review of licensing information system was done on 7/5/22 indicating that all staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. The home currently has four staff. LPA interviewed one staff and the one client present is non-verbal. LPA reviewed three staff and two client files. Review of staff files indicate that staff have current training in CPR, FA, AED, disaster preparedness and meet the educational and medical health requirements. Client files contained copies of personal rights, needs and services plans, medical history and consent form. One client file was missing a current authorization for psychotropic medication. This citation can be viewed on the attached form. CARE Tools completed. The following domains were completed: Physical Plant, Operations, Emergency Intervention, Disaster Preparedness, Client Files, and Staffing. One deficiency was noted at this inspection. Exit interview was conducted with Licensee and a final copy of this report will be emailed to the facility.

On July 31,2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn conducted an unannounced inspection of the facility for the purpose of the required inspection Using the CARE tool. LPA met with Genie Tinsley and Charles Tinsley, Licensees and a walk through was conducted. The home is licensed for 4 ambulatory clients and the facility currently has two clients who are regional center clients. The facility has 4 staff. LPA observed the home to be clean, organized, safe and sanitary and had age appropriate activities for the clients. The kitchen has adequate food and supplies. LPA observed a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable foods. The food menu is posted. The backyard is clean and has adequate space.There is a vegetable garden outside along with fruit trees where the Licensee frequently acquires fruits and vegetables for the clients. Cleaning supplies and hazardous materials are locked in the laundry room and inaccessible to clients. The water temperature is kept at 115 degrees. There is a sprinkler system for fire suppression; smoke detectors and carbon monoxide were tested during today's inspection. There are the necessary fire extinguishers and first aid kits. All bedrooms of the home are equipped with adequate linens and clothing for clients. All required Licensing forms are posted and were observed during inspection. There are no firearms or bodies of water at the home. Medication is stored correctly and locked. Staff and client files are kept secured. All staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPA interviewed 2 staff. One client present is non-verbal. The second client was interviewed with respect to developmental ability. LPA reviewed three staff and two client files. Review of staff files indicate that staff have current CPR, First Aid and disaster preparedness training and meet the educational and medical health requirements. Client files contained copies of personal rights, needs and services plans, medical history and consent form. Both clients had an Individual Program Plan (IPP) on file created by the regional center. Clients were current on CHDP medical and dental exams . No citations were given on this date. Exit interview was conducted with Licensee and a final copy of this report will be emailed to the Licensee.

LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility. There were no children and three staff present at the beginning of the inspection and during the inspection two additional staff and two children arrived. Number of staff interviewed two. Number of clients interviewed zero. Toilets wash basin, bath and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature _x Soap and Paper towels __X_ Laundry Facilities(available) __X__ Bedrooms-required linen and furnishings __X___ Motor Vehicle properly maintained, lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts_X__ Facility free of vermin _X__ Bedroom (required bedding/furniture, furniture in good repair) __X___ Disaster Preparedness Fire Drills conducted and documented__x__ Disaster preparedness supplies verified __X___

On 07/23/2025 at 09:15 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Elena Gonzalez-Soto arrived at the facility to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA was greeted by Genie Tinsley, Licensee who assisted with the inspection. LPAs inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant: LPA observed the facility is a one-story home with five bedrooms, two bathrooms and one apartment attachment with one bedroom, one bathroom, a front yard and a backyard. LPA observed posting of personal rights, working carbon monoxide and smoke detectors, first aid kit, fire extinguisher purchased 11/2023, inaccessible cleaning solutions, food menu, appropriate amount of fresh perishable and non-perishable foods, hot water temperature of 115F, Fridge Temperature of 36.1 F, and freezer temperature of 1.3 F. Operations: LPA observed register of clients, posting of license, safeguards for client resources and valuables, Disaster plan and drill log, and plan of operation. Client Records: LPA reviewed three children's files and observed written consent forms, an account of cash resources and personal property/valuables, immunization records, signed personal rights, and individual education plans. Cont. on LIC809-C

Staff Records: LPA reviewed five staff files and observed five out of five staff had a first aid certificate, criminal record clearance, personnel record, signed employee rights, health clearance, and applicable training. LPA conducted interviews with staff, interviewed one client in care and observed two clients in care. The following items were reviewed for compliance: Guardian Roster and LIC500. No citations or advisories were issued related to this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was issued to Genie Tinsley, Licensee.

Confidential interviews confirm that S1’s attempts to de-escalate included attempting to block C1’s hitting and attempting to hold C1’s hand. Confidential interviews report C1 yanked/snatched C1’s hand away from S1 causing C1 to lose C1’s balance and fall to the ground causing a “pop” sound. Confidential interviews report C1 was left in C1’s room to calm down and later was noticed to not be using C1’s arm. Record review revealed on January 3, 2021, C1 was taken to Corona Regional Medical Center Emergency room and was diagnosed with a fracture of the right humerus. Confidential information received was unable to determine if an inappropriate restraint was used. Based on confidential interviews, record review of facility documentation and medical documentation, the allegation facility staff (Staff #1 (S1)) used inappropriate restraints resulting in injuries to a client (Child #1 (C1)), may or may not have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided along with appeal rights to Tomasina’s Small Family Home Licensee, Tomasina Sisco.
investigation_findings: 13On September 2, 2021, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Tomasina’s Small Family Home Licensee, Tomasina Sisco to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator Marlon Williams with Community Care Licensing’s (CCL) Investigations Branch Bureau. The investigation included interviews with Staff #1 (S1), Staff #2 (S2), one client (Child #1 (C1), Physician Assistant with Corona Regional Medical Center (CRMC), Inland Regional Center (IRC) Consumer Program Liaison, Biological Grandparent of C1, IRC Consumer Services Coordinator. In addition, county records, medical records and facility records were reviewed. On January 11, 2021 CCL received an allegation of facility staff (Staff #1 (S1)) used inappropriate restraints resulting in injuries to a client (Child #1 (C1)). Specifically, it was reported C1 was having a behavioral episode and was throwing a tantrum and was hitting the staff member while being restrained. Confidential interviews and record review confirm on January 3, 2021, C1 was having a behavior episode that included hitting S1. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

narrative: On Wednesday September 8, 2021 at 11:19 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside with licensee Tomasina Sisco. The home is a two story residence with four bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and there is one child per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space. Bathroom number one downstairs hot water temperature measured to be 106.5 degrees, bathroom number two upstairs hot water temperature measured to be 105 degrees, bathroom number three is the bathroom that the licensee uses and is not accessible by the clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible. Cleaners and chemicals are locked in the closet in the dinning room. The medications are stored in a locked closet in the dinning room. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked Closet in the dinning room. . Based on the inspection this date, there are no deficiencies being cited. Licensee had a visit with one of the clients in Banning at 1:00. There will be a second visit to complete the annual inspection at a later date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report provided to licensee Tomasina Sisco.

On Monday August 22, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Anne Visaya conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside with licensee Sisco Tomasina. The home is a two story residence with four bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The home is a two story home and consists of: Upstairs: Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and there is one child per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space. Bedroom #1 furnished with 2 twin size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space It sleeps two 16- year old male clients. Bedroom #2 bedroom furnished with a twin bed and sofa for staff. Bedroom #3, furnished with 2 twin size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps a 7-year-old and 22-year-old female clients. Bedroom #4 Master bedroom with a king size bed for Licensee. Downstairs: a dining room with a large table and a locked closet under the stairs, a furnished living room with office, fireplace and a coat/accessories closet, a kitchen, a pantry, a family room, a half bathroom, and the garage.

Bathroom number one downstairs hot water temperature measured to be 112 degrees Fahrenheit, bathroom number two upstairs hot water temperature measured to be 110 degrees F, bathroom number three is the bathroom that the licensee uses and is not accessible by the clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible. Cleaners and chemicals are locked in the closet in the dining room. The medications are stored in a locked closet in the dining room. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked Closet in the dining room. . The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Toys are safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children being cared for. A review of six of six staff records indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances and CPR and first aid is up to date. A review of four of four clients files are noted to have documents required per regulations in file. (b) For each child in the home, the licensee shall maintain a separate, complete, and most up to date record or file that includes the following: (12) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the children… LPA provided the correct LIC 622B as licensee stated that she was not aware of the form. Licensee updated the medication record to reflect the correct form (LIC 622B for Psychotropic Medication). Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to facility Licensee Tomasina Sisco.

On April 3,2024 at 9:04 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Karen Beal and Maya Chavez met with Licensee, Tomasina Sisco who led a tour of the home. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an annual inspection. The facility was toured inside and out with Licensee. There are currently four clients in the facility. No clients were present at the time of this visit. The home is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1- has two twin beds and sleeps Client #1 and Client #2. · Bedroom #2- Has a twin size bed and the a sofa bed for staff use. · Bedroom #3- has a twin and full bed and sleeps Client #3 and Client #4 · Bedroom #4- Master suite that sleeps the Licensee. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for client’s belongings. The fireplace is properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications are locked and stored in a closet in the dining room. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a locked dining room closet. Sharp knives are also stored in locked closet. Per Licensee, there are no guns or weapons in the home. The hot water temperature was tested 105.9 degrees. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The smoke detectors located in the hallways were tested and were in good working order. The carbon monoxide detector located downstairs was also operable. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title 22 Personal Rights, and visitation policies are posted at this time. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no bodies of water on the premises.

Bathroom downstairs hot water temperature measured to be 110 degrees F. There was food available to cover meals for at least 4 days. The first kit was was complete, all required posting were hung on the dining room wall. The house temperature was 74 degrees. A review of 5 staff records indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances and CPR and first aid is up to date. There was one employee that did not have a finger print clearance. A review of four of four clients files are noted to have documents required per regulations in file. For each child in the home, the licensee shall maintain a separate, complete, and most up to date record file that includes a separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the children. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date,

On August 7, 2025 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Cynthia Ramos met with License Tomasina Sisco who led a tour of the home. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an annual inspection. The facility was toured inside and out with Licensee. There are currently four clients placed in the facility. No clients were present at the time of this visit. The home is a two story home that consists of four bedrooms, three bathrooms, garage and backyard. Upon entering the home, there was a formal living room with a television and games for clients. The fireplace was properly screened. There were two closets next to the living room. One closet contained sweaters and the other closet contained client's medications and knives, this closet remains locked at all times per Licensee. The kitchen was also inspected and LPA observed fridge contained enough perishable and non-perishable food. The garage was also inspected, garage contained activities for clients to play and contained one additional refrigerator and freezer with additional food. The home also had a family room with a television and games for clients. A stairway led to the the second floor of the home which consisted of Bedroom #1 which contained two twin beds and sleeps Client #1 and Client #2. Bedroom #2 consisted of a twin size bed which sleeps Client #3. Bedroom #3 consisted of two twin beds which sleeps client #4. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. LPA observed rooms to have adequate bedding and adequate drawer/closet space for client’s belongings. Bedroom #4- Master bedroom is occupied by the Licensee. Bathroom #1 and Bathroom #2 were inspected and were working properly. Bathroom #3 was located inside the Licensee's bedroom. The hot water temperature was tested at 118 degrees F.

All trash cans in the home had tight fighting lids. The smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors located in the hallways were tested and were in good working condition. The home had a total of three fire extinguishers that were operable. The backyard is accessible to clients to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There were no bodies of water on the premises. The first kit was was inspected and was complete. LPA reviewed a total of eight staff files and four client files. There were six cameras in total, three of them were in common areas of the inside of the home and the other three were outdoors, this meets the title 22 camera policy. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

On September 20, 2023, 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White conducted a Component II, Face-to-Face meeting with TruCare Small Family Home Licensee, Michael Gonzales. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the pending Small Family Home application and Program Statement review. The following concerns were discussed: Program Statement: • Treatment • Education • Transportation • Discipline · Emergency Intervention Plan · AWOL/Run Away Plan · Telephone Policy · Mail • Recreation • Protection • Religious Services Report continued on LIC 809C

• Personal Hygiene Items • Personal Allowance/Paid Jobs • Medical/Dental • Record and Reporting FOLLOW – UP: A Pre-Licensing Inspection will be conducted on 9/21/2023 at 10:00 AM. On September 21, 2023 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at TruCare Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Licensee Michael Gonzales who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. Currently living in the home is the Applicant. The home is set up as follows: This is a single-story 2 bedroom, 2 bathroom, home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, a backyard, and a detached garage. Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, a sofa, and a dog cage. Dining room: is equipped with wooden table and four (4) chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at the time of this inspection), and a microwave. Sharp knives are kept over the stove in a magnetic locked kitchen cabinet. Cleaning supplies are kept under the sink in a locked cabinet. The kitchen also has an exit door that leads to the side of the home. Laundry area: is located off the kitchen and is equipped with a stackable washer and a dryer; LPA observe the area to contain the home's hot water heater (Note: Hot water heater needs to have a secured framed separation) . Backyard: contains a Detached garage: LPA observed the garage to be used for storage which remains locked at all times and is made inaccessible to children in care. Bedroom #1: will be used as the client’s room. The beds were not set up at the time of this inspection. The room contains a working light, windows, a closet, and drawers. Bedroom #2: is occupied by Licensee. The room is equipped a queen size bed, dresser, a working light, windows, and a closet. The closet contains personal belongings. (2) Bathrooms: one bathroom is located along the hallway, and the second bathroom is located inside bedroom #2. The bathrooms contain a toilet, sink, and a combination shower/tub. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F) Report continued on LIC 809C.

LPA observed three (3) fully charged fire extinguishers. The hallway has cabinets which store extra linen. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Extra disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked inside the garage. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. LPA observed the applicant to have a large dog. LPA observed the applicant to have current vet record. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Applicant will transport children in 1992 Jeep Cheroke. Applicant has current registration through 11/26/2024 and insurance with LOYA Casualty Insurance Co. Personal rights, grievance process, Disaster Plan, Discipline policies and procedures will be placed in hallway. Prior to licensure the following is still required: 1. Twin Beds in the client room 2. Complete First Aid Kit 3. Lock Box for medications 4. Hot water heater needs to have a secured framed separation A copy of this report was left with the applicant.

On March 15, 2024, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at TruCare Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Direct Care Staff, Amber Mize who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. The home is licensed to provide care and supervision for two (2) children ages 3-17 years old, ambulatory only. Currently the census is one (1). Home overview: This is a single-story 2-bedroom, 2-bathroom, home located in a residential area. On 1/21/22 at 12:57PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Licensee Tiffany Tirado for a post-licensing inspection. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool. There are no clients placed yet, as Licensee is still working with Regional Center of the East Bay (RCEB) to become vendorized. LPA toured the facility site. The first floor is being remodeled, and there is currently no kitchen, dining, or living space. The resident bedroom downstairs is being used temporarily for storage during the remodel. However, the room is otherwise ready (upon removal of storage items and replacement of dresser) for one client. The room only has one bed right now, as Licensee intends to purchase new matching bed frames. Licensee will then have two beds to meet the facility capacity of 2. Licensee agrees to notify LPA Hawkins when the application to RCEB is submitted, when RCEB approves vendorization, and when Licensee has their first placement. Apart from the remodel, the facility is free of obstructions and hazards. The remodel will be complete prior to any placements. LPA went over the requirements, the forms needed for operation, where to find forms on the CCLD webstie, and the CARE Inspection Tool. LPA agreed to send Licensee an email upon return from visit with a link to the CCLD website to view the forms, CARE Tool, and Guardian information. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Tiffany Tirado, whose signature no this form confirms receipt.

On November 22, 2024, at 10 AM, a Component II Office Visit was held to discuss the application received for Unity Home Small Family Home located at 521 N. Orange Street Apt. 801 Glendale, CA 91203 . Attending Component II were the following individuals: Mehran Nazarian, Applicant, Erika Butler, Licensing Program Analyst, and JoAunne Griffin, Licensing Program Manager. The purpose of this Component II meeting was to review and discuss the incomplete application and Program Statement and to resolve any outstanding concerns that may have existed. The following incomplete application forms were discussed at the meeting: 1. Application for a Community Care Facility or Residential Care Facility for the Elderly License (LIC 200). Complete Section 12A and 12B. 2. Applicant Information (LIC 215): Business Experience section A,B,C. 3. Surety Bond (LIC 402) Need Surety Bond that matches your address. 4. Budget Information (LIC 420) Needs to be completed. 5. Personnel Report (LIC 500) Discussion about hours worked. 6. Personnel Record (LIC 501) Adult 1 Health screening report is missing the doctor's stamp. 7. Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610 C) Section III,IV,V, and VI need to be completed. Continued on LIC 809-C

8. Criminal Record Clearance Associated to facility – Live scanned, but still pending. 9. Program Statement a. Program Purpose, Target Population, Intake Procedures b. Education c. Daily Activities d. Recreation e. Unplanned Termination f. Basic Food Storage g. Medication Storage h. Records and Reporting The Applicant was advised of the following revision and/or corrections needed to the application and/or Program Statement: Sections 1-29 of the Program Statement was reviewed and discussed. Revisions are due December 12, 2024, Email revisions to erika.butler@dss.ca.gov. The Pre-Licensing inspection has been scheduled for Friday, December 6, 2024 at 10:00 A.M. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant, Mehran Nazaria.

On July 28, 2025, License Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong conducted an announced visit to conduct a Pre-Licensing Inspection at Unity Small Family Home located at 15106 Martha St. Sherman Oaks, CA 91411. During the visit, LPA met with the facility's Administrator Mehran Nazarian. Currently, there are 1 child in the home. This small family home will be licensed for ambulatory minors between the ages of 6-16. The facility consists of four bedrooms, three bathrooms, one kitchen, a laundry room, and one living room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The facility's exterior was clean and free of debris, with no safety hazards observed. Upon entering the home, the living room is immediately visible. **Living Room**: The living room features a wall-mounted TV, one sectional sofa, and a small coffee table, all arranged in an open floor plan. **Kitchen** The kitchen is spacious, clean, safe, and sanitary. It features a working faucet, one refrigerator, four functioning stove burners, a microwave, a dishwasher, and an island. On the kitchen island, there is a fire extinguisher for easy access. (Report Continued on LIC809C)

The kitchen offers ample cabinet space, and inside the refrigerator, there is a locked box designated for medication storage. The food supply includes both perishable and non-perishable items sufficient for one week. There is a dining table with six chairs available for meals. Additionally, the kitchen wall displays a bulletin board that includes the Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Hotline number, and Facility License. A first-aid kit is also located in the kitchen and is equipped with tweezers, scissors, a thermometer, sterile dressings, and band-aids. The kitchen has a sliding door that leads to the backyard area, along with a small hallway that provides access to the laundry room. Special cabinets are available for securely storing locked chemicals and the medication lock box. **Laundry Room**: The laundry room has a washer and dryer, extra laundry supplies, and will be used to store cleaning supplies. A second fire extinguisher. **Bedrooms**: The property has four bedrooms designated for different purposes. **Bedroom 1** is a client bedroom that is currently unoccupied. It features a queen-sized bed, a closet stocked with clean linens, a warm blanket, and pillows. Additionally, it includes closet space, a small night stand, and a TV mounted on the wall. **Bedroom 2** is the administrator's bedroom, equipped with a king-sized bed, a mounted TV, and a personal bathroom. **Bedroom 3** is currently occupied and contains a queen-sized bed, a closet with clean linens, a warm blanket, and pillows. It also includes additional closet space and a dresser but does not have a TV.-**Bedroom 4** is designated as a storage room. **Bathrooms**: There are three bathrooms in total. One is located in the administrator's room, another is in the hallway between Bedroom 1 and Bedroom 2, and the third is in the hallway between Bedroom 3 and Bedroom 4. (Report Continued on LIC809C)

Each bathroom is equipped with a shower, a working toilet, a sink with a mirror, and a faucet. The hot water temperature has been tested and is between 105 and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. All bathrooms are clean and spacious. **Backyard**: The spacious backyard is free of debris and features a large play area for clients. Access to the backyard is through the kitchen sliding door. A functional dual carbon monoxide alarm and smoke detector are installed in the living room, dining room, hallway, kitchen, and bedrooms. At the time of observation, there were no cameras present, and the applicant confirmed that there were no firearms in the home. The facility is equipped with central air and heating, and the area is free of debris and other hazardous items. Additionally, there is a gas, water, and power shut-off located on the side of the home. The LPA inspected the facility's vehicle. The administrator stated that the closest client rooms will store extra linens, towels, blankets, pillows, sheets, and hygiene supplies. The second closet is locked and is used for storing cleaning chemicals. An Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided to the Administrator.

On June 20, 2023, at 9:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Timika Martin conducted an Annual/Random inspection at the above facility. LPA Martin met with the licensee Jose Vasquez. At 10:15 AM, together with the licensee LPA Martin conducted a complete tour of the inside and outside of the small family home (SFH). This facility has four (4) bedrooms and two (2) bathrooms. There are 3 ambulatory male clients in placement. There are no clients that have special health care needs. The facility is licensed to serve six (6) ambulatory children only, mentally disabled and with non-minor dependents (NMD), ages 0 – 18 plus years of age. There are no bodies of water on premises. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom #1 sleeps client 1 & has bunk beds. Bedroom #2 sleeps client 2, has twin beds. Bedroom #3 sleeps client 3, has bunk beds. Bedroom #4 sleeps the licensee and wife. All bedrooms have adequate closet and drawer space. All exits, and hallways were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstruction. The carbon monoxide/smoke detectors throughout the facility were operable and functioning. Water temperature was tested and was within regulatory guidelines. First aid kit was readily available, complete and stored in a closet. Medications were observed to be stored in a locked closet. Medications that needed refrigeration is stored in the garage refrigerator with a lock. Kitchen was inspected and food supplies both perishable and non-perishable were checked and found to be sufficient. Sharp knives and sharp utensils were made inaccessible.

Per licensee there are no weapons in the facility. Cleaning solutions and toxins were locked in the garage, inaccessible to clients. Copy of facility license, facility sketch, emergency phone numbers, emergency disaster form were all prominently displayed in the home. LPA reviewed two (2) client files, two (2) licensee’s record and one (1) volunteer. Licensee has current CPR and First Aid on file. Licensee is current with ongoing training hours. LPA checked required criminal record and child abuse index check clearance or exemption. LPA interviewed one (1) licensee. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted with the licensee. LPA provided a copy of the following reports: LIC 809, LIC 809C and LIC 811 were provided to Jose Vazquez.

On December 23, 2024 on 9:45 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Veranda Family Home Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Justine Kanyi who led a tour of the entire home. The applicant is applying for a capacity of three children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two- story building with 4 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The downstairs consists of two family rooms with couches and a television and a storage closet storing school supplies, games and crafts. There is a dining table and kitchen with locked knives/ sharp objects, fully stocked refrigerator, pantry, and freezer. There was locked cleaning supplies under the kitchen sink and locked cabinets storing medications and client records. Downstairs also has a hallway that stores first aid kit (with all required elements), fire extinguisher, a lock box for medication requiring refrigeration and posted facility sketch, personal rights, and emergency plan. Bathroom #1 was fully functioning with water temperature at 135.6 degrees- (Applicant understands that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees) and the garage is locked at all times. The second floor consists of a master bedroom for the applicant with a crib and required bedding, a master bathroom, and hallway storing fresh linens and towels. The second floor also has two bedrooms for applicants biological children fully furnished and one foster child bed room containing 1 twin size bed and 1 full size bed with closet space- currently vacant. Applicant understand that dresser storage space is needed for each foster child in foster children's room. There is also bathroom #2 that has a locked cabinet storing laundry detergent and bathroom cleaning supplies. All trash cans have tight fitting lids and bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Inside the facility the fireplace is properly screened. There was no land line telephone service.

There are no guns or weapons as stated by Mrs. Kanyi at this time. The backyard is clean and free of hazards with a latch on side gate. There is no pool or other body of water. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: The water temperature needs to measure between 105-120 degrees. Telephone services to be installed. Dressers were missing in the clients’ bedroom. Obtain a lock box for cash resources. After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant Justine Kanyi.

On 07/14/2025 at 10:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst Gilbert Marquez met with Licensee Valerie Clark for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve four ambulatory children ages 0 to 17 years old. The current census is three children. The facility is current with licensing fees. The facility is a double story dwelling. A physical plant inspection was completed with Valerie and included the following checks: two living rooms, a dining room, a half bath, a kitchen, four client bedrooms, two licensee bedrooms, a hallway bathroom, and one master bathroom attached to the Licensee bedroom. All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattress in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. No bedroom occupied more than one client and not used for other purposes. The water temperature was tested in upstairs bathroom #1 which measured 108.9 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was accessible to all staff and had all required supplies. All required forms are posted including Personal Rights and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in medication cabinet in the kitchen. **Continued on LIC809C***

**Continued from LIC809** Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. All client files are stored in the dining room shelf area. LPA reviewed three client files (C1 – C3) to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. Client files had education records, physical examinations, Individual Program Plans, and mental health notes. LPA also reviewed one client (C1) medication records. All staff files are stored in the dining room shelf area. LPA reviewed four staff files (S1 – S4) to ensure staff had all required documents such as criminal record clearance or exemption, health screening and tb test, drivers license, personnel record LIC501 or job application, and all required trainings. LPA interviewed two staff (S1 and S2). LPA unable to complete client interviews due to developmental functioning of clients being unable to answer basic questions. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. No deficiencies were observed during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted, this report was discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Valerie Clark. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

All three staff interviewed indicated that they searched for a safety pin in C1s belongings and bedding, but no safety pin was found. LIC1 took C1 to have a an x-ray done to ensure he didn’t swallow the safety pin. The results of the x-ray were negative. S1 was present with C1 during the time he supposedly has possession of the safety pin. S1 reported he never saw C1 with a safety pin nor did he hear C1’s parents attempt to get his attention. Based on LPA’s interviews and a records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the above allegation of Minor was not properly supervised while in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED -meaning although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No Interim Licensing Standards or Title 22 Regulations were cited during today’s inspection; exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/19/2020, at 2:25 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley King conducted an unannounced tele-inspection at this facility to close this complaint investigation and deliver the findings--this was done remotely to comply with public health guidelines concerning COVID-19. LPA spoke with Licensee Dona Want with whom the investigation report was discussed. LPA investigated the allegation Minor was not properly supervised while in care. Prior to the investigation, LPA reviewed the facility’s history of relevant incident reports, and complaints. LPA also spoke with the Reporting Party on 09/21/2020. On 09/25/2020 LPA opened the investigation with the facility during which a preliminary request for the following records was made: injury logs, medical logs, client’s face sheet, staff roster and staff schedule. LPA later requested a copy of the x-ray results for C1. During the course of this investigation LPA interviewed three staff in total and the licensee. LPA was unable to interview C1 as he is nonverbal.

narrative: All staff interviewed indicated when C1 was placed on the floor to stretch, he would put his arms up and fall to the side. All staff indicated they put C1 back into his wheelchair in the same fashion, by placing one arm behind his back and one under his legs. Per the notes from the Dr. Hartwick of Lodi Memorial Hospital, C1’s bones appear to be thin. Based on LPA’s interviews and a records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met; therefore, the above allegation of Minor was not properly supervised while in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED -meaning although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No Interim Licensing Standards or Title 22 Regulations were cited during today’s inspection; exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

narrative: On July 22, 2022 at 9:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona conducted an annual required inspection to the above Small Family Home. LPA conducted an interior and exterior inspection of the facility and grounds. The home is a two story and is located on five acres.The first floor has bedroom 1/ nursery, formal dinning area, a bathroom, bedroom 2, bedroom 3, bedroom 4, living room, formal living room, kitchen, and play room. There is a staircases that leads to the second floor. In the second floor there is bedroom 5, a second living room, and one bathroom. All bedrooms are equipped with beds and dressers which are all in good repair. All bedrooms have adequate lighting. There are three dogs, one donkey and two horses on the property. Carbon monoxide, fire alarms, and fire extinguishers are in working condition. Passageways, stairways, and porch are unobstructed. The pantry is fully stocked with a weeks worth of non-perishable foods and the refrigerator has three days of perishable foods. There is one freezers and a extra refrigerator with extra food located in the garage. All the posting requirements were available in a visible area. First aid kit was full stocked and available. The front yard and back yard were clean and maintained. Facility operates within licensing capacity limitations. Adults working and residing in the home have child abuse index checks, DOJ, and FBI criminal records clearances. Children are allowed to use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable home and are treated with respect. Overall, the home was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Children attend school, extracurricular activities, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Exit interview was conducted with the House Manager. The facility was cited during this visit. A copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to the licensee and house manager.

LPA conducted an interior and exterior inspection of the facility and grounds. The home is a two story and is located on five acres. The first floor has bedroom 1/ nursery, formal dinning area, a bathroom, bedroom 2, bedroom 3, bedroom 4, living room, formal living room, kitchen, and play room. There is a staircases that leads to the second floor. In the second floor there is bedroom 5, a second living room, and one bathroom. All bedrooms are equipped with beds and dressers which are all in good repair. All bedrooms have adequate lighting. There are three dogs, one donkey and two horses on the property. Carbon monoxide, fire alarms, and fire extinguishers are in working condition. Passageways, stairways, and porch are unobstructed. The pantry is fully stocked with a weeks worth of non-perishable foods and the refrigerator has three days of perishable foods. There is one freezer and a extra refrigerator with extra food located in the garage. All the posting requirements were available in a visible area. First aid kit was full stocked and available. The front yard and back yard were clean and maintained. Facility operates within licensing capacity limitations. Adults working and residing in the home have child abuse index checks, DOJ, and FBI criminal records clearances. Children are allowed to use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Continue to page 2

Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable home and are treated with respect. Overall, the home was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Children attend school, extracurricular activities, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Exit interview was conducted with the House Manager. The facility was cited during this visit for not meeting reporting requirements and for accommodating more than two children in a bedroom. A copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to the licensee and house manager.

On 3/9/22 at 9:35 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kim Pawlowicz arrived at the facility to conduct an unannounced annual inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Donal (Shawn) Want, Owner's son. The facility cares for non-ambulatory clients up to 17 years old with mild to moderate developmental disabilities. LPA toured the two-story facility, inside and out with the assistance of Kelly (Alex) Perez, Direct Support Professional. The outside of the facility was clean, free of debris, and no safety hazards were observed. The facility consists of five bedrooms and three bathrooms. There are two large living spaces that are used as tv rooms and two additional rooms with couches and space for leisure activities. Smoke/Carbon detectors and fire extinguishers are in working order. Smoke detector is connected to Life Alert response which contacts the facility when activated (LPA observed this during the visit). There are no bodies of water or firearms on the premises. The facility is stocked with food and surplus. Clients have adequate space for their personal belongings. LPA observed rodent droppings in one of the kitchen cabinets. Facility staff cleaned it promptly. LPA reviewed five client files. One deficiency was cited during today's visit. A subsequent visit will be needed to complete this annual inspection. Plan of Correction and appeal rights were discussed. Exit interview was conducted with Dona Want, Owner and Kelly (Alex) Perez, Direct Service Professional.

On 3/17/23 at 11:05 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kim Pawlowicz made a subsequent visit to the above named facility to complete the annual inspection that was initiated on 3/9/23. LPA completed the inspection tool, reviewed five staff files and interviewed two staff that were on site. LPA attempted to interview two clients who were non-verbal. No deficiencies were cited during this visit. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Dona Want, Administrator.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an unannounced visit to the Wauls Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Random Inspection. LPA met with Asilia Wauls who granted access to the home and a tour of the home was conducted together with the licensee. This is a two story, SIX (6) bedrooms, FOUR (4) bathrooms home with living room and fireplace, kitchen, dining area. The home is license to care for FOUR (4) children, ages 3-17, one(1) non-ambulatory and three (3) ambulatory clients LPA observed the follow during the inspection: Bedroom #1: is an extra bedroom and activity space for visiting guests. this bedroom is usually locked an inaccessible to consumers in care. LPA observed twin size bed, lamp, dresser and small table. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by C1. There is a twin size bed, adequate drawer space, closet and lighting. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by C2, There is a twin size bed, adequate drawer space, closet and lighting. Bedroom #4: Is currently C3 . There is one twin size bed, adequate drawer space, closet and lighting. There is also a desk and chair in this room. Bedroom #5: is vacant LPA observe one couch, tv, desk and table with lamps, and a walk in full bathroom. Space is currently being used for employee lounge. Bedroom #6: is occupied by Licensee, LPA observed a king bed and office space. There is no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The home has comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows, all in good repair. The home is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Medicines, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children. Hot water is kept at a safe temperature. Facility has one functioning carbon monoxide detectors that meet the statutory requirements. All smoke detectors were tested and operable at the time of inspection. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the kitchen that was operable at the time of inspection. There are no fire arms or dangerous weapons in the home. Licensee maintains age appropriate first aid supplies in the home. The home operates within capacity and limitations of license. There are no children sharing a bedroom at this time. Adequate supervision is provided for children in care. Licensee ensures three nutritious meals, snacks, and special diets. Children in care are accorded personal rights. Licensee submits special incident reports as required. Needs and Services plans are in children's files for each child in the home, the licensee maintains a separate, complete, and current record on file. Exterior grounds are free unsafe objects and well maintained. All adults residing in the home have Child Abuse Index checks, and have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances. Licensee is current with her foster parent training hours for this year. Licensee has current First Aid and CPR training, and training was obtained from an accredited agency. Per California Code Regulations, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 9.5, there were no deficiencies observed or cited at the time of inspection. Exit Interview was conducted and this report was left with licensee.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward interviewed the facility manager and Client #1 who is the roomate of Client #3. Based on the confilicting accounts obtained by LPA Jones-Steward during the investigation of this allegation, it is resolved as unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights
Clients have the right to be accorded dignity in his/her personal relationships with staff and other persons. Based on information obtained during the investigation, the licensee failed to meet this requirement by allowing staff to yell at clients.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a self directed plan of correction to the Department by 08/16/21

Based on information from confidential interviews, Licensing Program Analyst has determined the finding is substantiated, meaning the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, for a violation of personnel rights, which poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. The facility is issued a citation Type A [See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiency]. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, Confidential Names List and appeal rights were provided/emailed to Facility Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On 09/18/2023 at 1:14pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced inspection to the above listed facility.LPA Wilson was greeted by staff (S10) who provided access to the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to conclude the investigation on the above allegation. The investigation included confidential interviews with, including but not limited to, clients, facility staff members, and administrative staff. Information obtained revealed enough evidence to determine that the allegation took place and staff performed an inappropriate restraint. The child was in his bedroom attempting to regulate. A child shoving a staff person, does not warrant a restraint hold. (Continued on LIC 9099C)

83072	Personal Rights
(6)	To be accorded dignity in his/her personal relationships with staff and other persons.This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA interviews, and observations, the licensee did not ensure the personal rights of the client. Child shoving is not enough to warrant a restraint hold.

Licensee will ensure staff understand and review personal rights regulations.

investigation_findings: 13On March 8, 2024, at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an unannounced visit to WAULS SMALL FAMILY HOME and spoke with Jose Orellano/Facility Manager who granted access and provided the census. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings regarding the above complaint allegations. During the investigation LPA Phillips conducted confidential interviews, reviewed facility files, Special Incident Reports, and staff schedules. Staff deny the allegations: Staff hit minor in care and Staff spoke inappropriately to minor in care. Staff deny that a Gerald works at facility. LPA review of facility files did not find a staff named Gerald having worked at the facility. LPA Phillips was unable to interview Child #1 due to Child #1 nonverbal. However LPA Phillips did observe Child #1 and did not observe any bruises or marks on Child #1. Inconsistent statements and documentary evidence did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations: Staff hit minor while in care, or Staff spoke inappropriately to minor in care. Confidential interviews reveal that Child #1 does not like riding the bus due to the harness required for riding the bus. cont on 9099c

On 10/22/2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kim Dear and Licensing Program Manager Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced visit to the Wauls Small Family Home for the purpose of a Case Management, Annual Continuation Inspection. This is a continuation from the initial Annual inspection conducted on 10/18/2024. On this inspection the following areas were covered: Operations, Staffing Records, Client Records and SHCN. see the LIC 811, Confidential Names form, dated 10/22/24. The Administrative Assistant and Program Manager are present at the facility a minimum of 40 hours a week, as verified by the staff schedule. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. Postings: All licensing posting requirements were met. Facility posts client rights in dining area adjacent to kitchen. Clients are not restricted in telephone use by court order. Clients are treated with dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable home style environment and are treated with respect. Clients can contact licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. LPA Dear reviewed the following during the inspection: Client Records: Facility maintains client cash resource. Client records contain authorization for medical care signed by each client's authorized representative. Client records copies of the original Needs and Services Plan signed by each child and their authorized representative(s). Clients attend school daily, extracurricular activities, cultural and personal enrichment activities. LPA inspected facility van and observed working seat belts, valid registration, insurance, and a first aid kit. Per CA Regulations Title 22, there were no deficiencies observed or cited. met_with: Ailsia Wauls, Licensee and Chary Hallon, Program Assistant
narrative: On March 21, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst, LPA, Kim Dear conducted a Case Management, Incident report at the Wauls Small Family Group Home. A health and safety assessment were conducted upon arrival to the facility. LPA met with Chary Hallon, Facility Administrator and Ailisia Wauls, Licensee in response to the Special Incident Report submitted to the Community Care Licensing Department, (CCLD), to investigate a possible violation of Client personal rights. The incident, which was received by the department, on February 03, 2025, Client 1, (C1) had a crisis and began acting out within the facility and staff, (S1). According to the Incident Report, C1 became agitated after arguing with another resident. As S1 attempted to redirect C1, C1 became physically aggressive toward (2), two staff and began spitting bodily fluids from his, (C1) mouth and kicking the staff. [see LIC811 Confidential Names List form (LIC811), dated 03/21/2025, for names]. LPA Dear interviewed Licensee and the Facility Administrator. At this time, the Department has made no determination on whether a violation has occurred. A copy of this report was provided to the Licensee/ Facility Administrator.

met_with: Chary Hallon, Program Administrator and Ailisia Wauls, Licensee
narrative: On March 21, 2025, at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts. LPA, Kim Dear conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at the above facility. LPA met with Chary Hallon, Facility Administrator (FA), in response to a Special Incident Report that was submitted to the Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), to investigate a possible personal rights violation. The incident, which was received by the CCL Department, on 2/4/2025, involving Client 1, (C1). Incident began on January 31, 2025, when a FA was informed by a North Los Angeles County Regional Center Supervisor, that allegations of restraint, spanking, a client being hit in their chest and told to grab their “privates”. The report received to CCLD has launched a case management, follow- up. [see LIC811, Confidential Names List form. LIC811, dated 03/21/2025, for names]. LPA interviewed Facility Administrator; no other staff nor clients were available at the time of visit. Currently, the CCL Department has made no determination on whether the (4), four violations have occurred. A copy of this report will be provided to the Facility.

The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099-D for violations of Title 22, Section 80065(a) – Personnel shall demonstrate the ability to work cooperatively and ensure the well-being of clients; and Section 80061(b)(1)(H) – Licensees must report incidents that threaten the emotional or physical health and safety of clients. The failure to document and report the altercation, along with the lack of professional conduct by staff, demonstrates a breach of regulatory responsibilities and a failure to protect the dignity and emotional safety of clients. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the licensee. The facility is required to submit a corrective action plan addressing the cited violations to ensure compliance with CDSS regulations and prevent the recurrence of similar incidents.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/16/2025 at 10:50 AM, LPA Dennis Jarmin arrived at Wauls Small Family Home to discuss the findings of a complaint investigation regarding staff failing to report incident(s) involving minor(s) and engaging in inappropriate interactions in the presence of minors. LPAs met with the licensee and explained that the investigation concluded on 03/27/2025. During the investigation, LPAs conducted interviews, reviewed records, and gathered supporting evidence. Confidential interviews and records confirmed that staff engaged in a verbal altercation on facility grounds in the presence of clients. The incident was neither documented nor reported to the Department, as required. This reflects a failure to maintain professional conduct and protect the emotional well-being of clients. Additionally, the facility failed to submit a Special Incident Report (SIR), violating mandated reporting requirements. Based on a preponderance of evidence, the allegation of Inappropriate Staff Conduct/Lack of Supervision is

deficiencies.description:
(1)Regulation Cited: Title 22, Section 80065(a) – Personnel Requirements – All personnel shall demonstrate the ability to meet the needs of the clients and to work cooperatively with others.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, document review, and video footage, it was confirmed that Staff #1 and Staff #2 engaged in a verbal altercation on facility grounds and in the presence of clients. Failure to maintain professional behavior in front of clients, constitutes a violation of supervision and personnel requirements and poses a risk to the emotional well-being and dignity of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The licensee shall submit a written statement by 05/16/2025 to dennis.jarmin@dss.ca.gov detailing how the facility will:
1. Ensure staff maintain professional conduct at all times, especially in the presence of clients. 2. Comply with all mandated reporting requirements related to significant incidents.
3. Prevent the recurrence of similar incidents through monitoring and accountability measures.

deficiencies.description:
Title 22, Section 80061(b)(1)(H) – Reporting Requirements - Each licensee or employee of the facility shall report any unusual incident or event that threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client to the licensing agency.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, document review, the incident was not reported to the Department as required, and no Special Incident Report (SIR) was submitted. This lack of reporting constitutes a violation of supervision and personnel requirements and poses a risk to the emotional well-being and dignity of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The facility must also develop and implement a Staff Conduct and Incident Reporting Plan to include the following:
• Updated internal policy on professional conduct and conflict resolution
• Procedures for timely identification, documentation, and submission of SIRs to the Department • Staff training addressing:
o Appropriate interpersonal communication
o Incident recognition and mandatory reporting
o Conflict de-escalation strategies
• Proof of staff training, including:
o Training agenda/topics
o Name and qualifications of the trainer
o Certificates of completion or sign-in sheets

narrative: The medical report indicates the linear lesions on C1’s thigh is unexplained and could be the result of abuse or could be the result of an accidental injury. Confidential interviews revealed that there is no concern that C1 is being abused while in care. Based on confidential interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the allegation that a lack of supervision resulted in C1 sustained unexplained injury while in care, may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to Licensee Anna L. Carmody for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On October 2, 2020 at 8:45AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted a tele-inspection with Licensee Anna Carmody due to COVID-19. During the course of the investigation, LPA reviewed Client 1’s (C1) file. LPA interviewed two of two staff. LPA interviewed two of three clients and LPA interviewed three witnesses, one regional center worker. LPA was unable to interview C1 because C1 is nonverbal. LPA reviewed C1’s Individual Program Plan (IPP), San Diego Health and Human Services report and hospital medical reports. The Department received a complaint on July 8, 2020 that a lack of supervision resulted in a child sustaining unexplained injury while in care. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 engaged in self-injurious behavior resulted in linear lesions marks on C1’s thigh. Licensee denied C1 was physically abused while in care.

narrative:
On November 2, 2021 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson and Licensing Program Analyst Jesus Cervantes conducted an unannounced annual required inspection. LPA Anderson and LPA Cervantes met with Licensee Anna Carmody. LPA Anderson and LPA Cervantes inspected the small family home (SFH) with Licensee. LPA Anderson and LPA Cervantes inspected both indoor and outdoor areas of the facility. The facility has four clients in care. The facility is set up as follows: Downstairs: Bedroom #1- One client, one twin bed and appropriate furnishing. Bedroom # 2- One client, two twin beds and appropriate furnishing. Upstairs: Bedroom # 3- One queen bed and sleeps licensee’s 28-year-old son. Bedroom # 4- One crib for C4 and appropriate furnishing. Bedroom #5 – Licensee bedroom. The facility has three bathrooms, a family room, a living room and a kitchen. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Inside the facility there was an operable smoke detector located in each bedroom and common areas. There was also an operable carbon monoxide detected located in the dining area. The fireplace was properly screened.

The medications were locked and stored in a cabinet under the stairs. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored the pantry. The First Aid Kit was in the medication cabinet and contained all required items. There were no guns or weapons as stated by licensee at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 107 degrees. Proper storage of all food was noted. The Emergency Disaster Plan posted at this time. A copy of the license was readily available to LPA during time of inspection. Proper storage of all food was noted. The Emergency Disaster Plan posted at this time. A copy of the license was readily available to LPA during time of inspection. The backyard where children have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Toys were safe, clean and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for both inside and outside the facility. Staff 1 did not have tuberculosis test results and health screening in file or ready for review. The following deficiency is being cited and noted in accordance with CCL rules and regulations under Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Anna Carmody.
