On 11/02/2021 at 10:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced to WELLS SMALL FAMILY HOME for the purpose to conduct the Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA met with the Licensee/ Administrator, who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. This facility is Licensed to provide care and supervision for three (3) Developmentally Disabled children ages 12-17 years old, Ambulatory only. Currently residing in the home are the Licensee (A1) the Licensee's adult biological son (A2), and two (2) foster children in placement (C1 and C2). There are no bodies on water on the premises. The Licensee confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. Due to an reported previous scheduled medical appointment LPA will return to the facility at later date to complete the Inspection. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at facility.

On 11/09/2023 at 11:45AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced to WELLS SMALL FAMILY HOME for the purpose to conduct the Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA met with the Licensee/ Administrator, who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. This facility is Licensed to provide care and supervision for three (3) Developmentally Disabled children ages 2-17 years old, Ambulatory only. Currently residing in the home are the Licensee (A1) and two (2) foster children in placement (C1 and C2). There are no bodies on water on the premises. The Licensee confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. This is 1 story Split level, five (5) bedrooms and two (2) bathrooms; two (2) car garage, located in a residential neighborhood. Living room; Dining room, Kitchen, and a Den. There is large window air conditioning unit installed in the window of the Den to help keep the Den and dining area cool. Outdoor Area: The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. LPA observed all windows, screens and blinds from the inside and outside of the SFH were observed to be in good condition. There are retractable bars on the back windows of bedroom #2 and #3. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. There is a two (2) Car garage with a locked pad is being utilized store extra furniture and supplies. There is one (1) facility vehicle parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition (The vehicle car was checked for tires, headlights, tail lights, turn signals, horn and windshield wipers). Make and Model (2012 Honda Odyssey Van). LPA reviewed the Proof of Insurance (AAA 07-24-2024); Car Registration (Expiration 09/18/2022) and current Driver’s License. There is a non-operable vehicle (1975 Volkswagen) locked and covered in the back yard. Bedroom #1 Is currently unoccupied; located on right side entrance of the living room with key lock entry. It is equipped with one (1) twin sized bed, clean linen, comfortable mattress, clean linens, blankets, and pillows, as needed, all in good repair, adequate drawers and a walk in closet. LIC-809-C Page 1 of 4

Bedroom #2 Is occupied by child #with special health care needs and is not shared with another minor residing in the SFH. It is equipped with one (1) twin sized bed, comfortable mattress, clean linen, blankets, and pillows, adequate drawers and a walk in closet. Bedroom #3 Is occupied by 1 child #2 with special health care needs and is not shared with another minor residing in the SFH. It is equipped with one (1) twin sized bed, equipped, comfortable mattress, clean linen, blankets, and pillows, adequate drawers and a walk in closet. LPA observed a Gastrostomy (G-Tube) machine for the child in placement. Bedroom #4 Is currently occupied the Licensee. The entrance is through the den. It is equipped with one (1) twin sized bed, comfortable mattress, clean linen, blankets, and pillows, adequate drawers and a walk in closet. There are two (2) Bathrooms inspected and found to be clean. LPA test the water temperature, bathroom sinks and ensured that all toilets flushed. The water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Bathroom #1 is located in between Bedroom #2 and #3. It is equipped with a one sink, bathtub, a shower, and one (1) toilet. There is adequate lighting and the windows, blinds observed to be in good condition. Developmentally appropriate toiletries and personal hygiene products, for the children are locate in the hallway above the linen closet. Bathroom #2 is located across from Bedroom #4. There one (1) sink, tub (that is selectively not being utilized), and one (1) toilet. There is adequate lighting, blinds and a window with a retractable bar; observed to be in good condition. The Licensees personal hygiene razors used for shaving are kept the bedroom #4. Linen Closet is in the hallway adjacent to Bedroom #2 and #3. LPA observed to have ample clean linen. The Licensee ensure to change the linen 3-4 times a week due the children’s disability. Dining room There is ample lighting large dining table that seats 4 people. There is a portable heater in place of the non-operable, Gas Wall furnish (pilot light not lit for safety purposes). Small Office Space with a computer desk; desk top computer, office supplies, shelves and drawers. There are three (3) First aid kits inside the drawer of the office desk. It has the required items inside (age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. LIC-809-C Page 2 of 4

DEN There is a 4-Step stairway with a rail that leads to the Den. There is locked bar door that leads the outside side entrance of the house. The Den is equipped with furniture, two televisions, toys, book shelf, classic record player and a locked file cabinet for personal files, children’s records,. Kitchen/Dining room Kitchen: Observed to be clean and organized; The Kitchen stove is gas operated with four (4) burners a double door refrigerator and a side freezer; microwave and a toaster. There is door that leads to the side/front house. LPA observed coverage trash cans in the kitchen, and bathrooms. LPA observed ample fresh perishable and nonperishable food in the home in a quantity to meet the needs of the next three meals and the between meal snacks. LPA observed an operable garbage disposal. The sharp knives are also inaccessible in separate box in the top kitchen cabinet. The food preparation area where kitchen equipment has pots, pans and utensils. The Fire Extinguisher is in the kitchen; fully charged. All posting requirements were met (Personal rights and the food menu are posted on the refrigerator) Medication is locked in the upper kitchen cabinet not accessible to the children. The Licensee is responsible for administering medication. Prescribed medications; medication logs, files and are locked key in the kitchen. Medication is also stored in the refrigerator in a locked box. LPA reviewed the Medication Administration Record (MAR) for both children recorded for six months. LPA observed utility shut-off valves for gas and water located on right side of house. The Hot Water Heater is enclosed inside the house in the hallway adjacent to the laundry room. Laundry Room: The Washer and Dryer (White)unit is also located inside a room near bathroom #2. The Licensee selected to do the laundry for the children. The Laundry detergent, cleaning supplies solutions, disinfectants, pesticides and other similar toxic substances stored in a locked cabinet. LPA observed combined Smoke detector and Carbon Monoxide; tested to be operable. The Living Room is fully furnished with one (1) ceiling fan, entertainment center, a music keyboard, China cabinet, book shelf, desk and storage bins. Clients will be accorded dignity in personal relationships with all adults authorized to be in contact with clients. The licensee provides the opportunity for the children to participate in extracurricular activities for children with special needs. LIC-809-C Page 3 of 4

LPA observed that Licensee ensures that all who enter the home wash hands, and alcohol based hand sanitizers and mask are provided if needed, or upon request. The SFH operates within license conditions and limitations of capacity. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to the clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. Client Records: LPA reviewed two (2)clients records for children with Special Needs. Staff Records: Currently there are no staff employed other than the Licensee. LPA reviewed the Licensee’s 30 hours of various training; Certified of Completion (CEU) Continuing Education Units by Colibri Healthcare, CPR, and Crisis Consultant Group (Escape and Evasion Techniques). LPA obtained the Facility Profile and Personnel Report and confirmed that the Licensee have required criminal record clearances. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response; which meet qualification. Staff Interview: LPA conducted a confidential interview with the Licensee; no other staff resides at the SFH. Client Interviews: Clients were unable to be interview due to Developmentally Disabilities. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA-Gray concluded the Annual Required Inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the Small Family Home with the Licensee on 11/09/2023 LIC-809-C Page 4 of 4

On June 6, 2025, at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Aimee Moratalla and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Enrique Hernandez conducted an unannounced case management visit to the above facility to verify the presence of the licensee and clients following concerns that the home was unoccupied. The LPA knocked, and was greeted, and invited into the home by the Licensee. The LPM and LPA conducted a walkthrough of the home and observed that it appeared occupied. Food was present in the kitchen, toiletries were in the bathroom, and personal belongings were found in the bedrooms. The beds were made and appeared to be in use. LPM and LPA observed that the backyard gate is not in good repair, there were metal clutter, unused cans of paint, bottle of dish soap, and a bottle of Clorox. The Licensee was advised to ensure that the chemicals are stored in a lock cabinet, dispose of the sharp metal trash, and to repair the gate. The Licensee put away the bottle of Clorox inside the shed. The Licensee was also informed about the importance of sending incident reports. The Licensee reported that she and the Consumers returned home on May 7, 2025. continuation on LIC809-C

At the time of the visit, two Consumers were present. LPA conducted a visual check of the Consumers and observed no immediate health or safety concerns. LPA will send Licensee a copy of the PIN and other information regarding Guardian. After reviewing facility list from Guardian, an Individual#1 did not have criminal record clearance as of June 6, 2025. Licensee presented a document to LPA from Department of Justice dated on October 3, 2024, regarding DOJ applicant fingerprint response. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Licensee.

narrative: On July 3, 2025, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Aimee Moratalla and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Enrique Hernandez conducted an unannounced Plan of Correction visit from the deficiencies cited on June 6, 2025 to the above facility. The LPA knocked, and was greeted, and invited into the home by the Licensee. Due to a scheduled fumigation of the home, a brief walk through of the house and the backyard was conducted. LPM and LPA observed that backyard gate was not in good repair, LPM gave Licensee 30 days to repair the gate. The metal trash was disposed, unused cans of paints and the bottle of dish soap were stored away in the locked shed. Picture of the area was taken. LPA reiterate to Licensee to access Guardian for any changes with individuals associated to the facility. At the time of the visit, there were no children in the home. During the time of inspection, LPA cleared the citation that was issued on June 6, 2025. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Licensee.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis conducted a Component II at the Monterey Park Children's Residential Regional Office on September 13, 2024 at 2:00pm with the Wiggins Family Home SFH. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to the Wiggins Family Home on September 19, 2024 at 11:30am for the purposes of an announced Pre-licensing inspection. The Department has received application materials from the applicant to become licensed at the site as a Small Family Home licensee. LPA met with the applicant, Kendra Wiggins, and together they toured the home. The home is located in a residential neighborhood and consists of three bedrooms and two bathrooms. Bedroom #1 has two twin beds, two dressers, and closet space. The bedroom is vacant. Bedroom #2 has one queen bed, dresser, and closet space. The bedroom is occupied by the applicant. Bedroom #3 has one queen bed, dresser, and closet space. The bedroom is occupied by the applicant's son Sharp knives, chemicals, and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to children. LPA observed a fully stocked linen closet in the hallway. The living room and dining room areas were observed to be tidy and had sufficient seating. The front yard is enclosed entirely with a gate. The gate is accessible to enter and is not obstructed or bounded by any entrance/exit restrictions. LPA observed two bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. Overall, the facility appeared clean, safe, and sanitary. LPA observed two fully charged fire extinguisher mounted on the wall in the kitchen and hallway areas. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. There is one camera each in the backyard, front yard, and on the side of the home. The cameras are not pointed at or towards the home. There are no cameras inside the home. LPA held discussions with the Applicant about the cameras. LPA observed the kitchen area to be clean and the refrigerator was fully stocked with ample food supply. LPA observed adequate perishable and nonperishable food items in the cabinets and in the pantry. LPA also observed a complete food menu posted on the refrigerator in the kitchen. The applicant has two small dogs on the premises. The dogs are allowed to roam and play in the backyard, but will not do so if children are outside. The dogs do not stay in the home as they are kept in the garage. The garage is kept locked and has a sign posted that says, "Authorized Personnel Only." The applicant

showed LPA copies of the shot records for the two dogs as well as the dog licenses. One license had an expiration date of August 17, 2025 and the other one had an expiration date of September 03, 2025. The applicant stated that there weren't any firearms or other weapons on the premises. There is adequate space for indoor and outdoor activities. LPA observed Emergency information and a facility sketch posted on the wall in the hallway. LPA observed a fully stocked First Aid Kit with an ample amount of bandages and band-aids. The First Aid Kit also contained a thermometer, scissors, tweezers, etc. LPA also observed a fully stocked pantry in the hallway and a fully stocked linen closet in the hallway as well. The Applicant has an adequate laundry area with both a washer and a dryer, respectively. The Applicant stated that there were no swimming pools or other bodies of water on the premises. LPA found no Title 22 deficiencies on this date. Exit interview conducted LPA Davis discussed cooler weather conditions and precautions with the applicant and provided the applicant with the Department's website address (www.ccld.ca.gov). LPA advised Applicant of remaining the steps to become a licensed Small Family Home provider. Exit interview conducted.

investigation_findings: 13On October 15, 2024, at 12:45 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced visit to the Wolff Small Family Home for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and to deliver the findings. LPA met with the licensee, and together discussed the investigation details. Based on the confidential interviews conducted with all parties involved (see confidential name list LIC 811 dated 10/15/2024) the above allegation cannot be substantiated. During the investigation, LPA Hernandez interviewed all relevant parties and accounted for their statements. However, the interviews did not yield sufficient evidence to corroborate the allegation. Even though there were some issues between Client #1 (C1) and FA, FA denied making inappropriate comments or using any form of physical punishment on C1. The interviews revealed inconsistent statements, and no witnesses were present to corroborate the alleged incident. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and due to technical difficulties with the printer, a copy of this report will be emailed.

13On 3/13/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nestor Gomez made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and deliver the findings. LPA spoke with Else Wolff and together, discussed the investigative findings. During the investigative process by Licensing program Analyst (LPA), Nancy O’Connell, all relevant parties have been accounted for. Supporting evidence includes: law enforcement report reflecting no concerns indicated during the time of initial contact to licensee's home, written documentation from Tri-Counties Regional Center confirming receipt of serious incident report, conflicting statments from clients and staff related to the occurance of abuse, lack of eye witnesses avaialble to corroborate statements, and absence of physical markers or signs of abuse on victim's body. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative:
Confidential statements revealed the physical assaults occurred on multiple occasions and/or occurring while licensee was either in their office or napping. Confidential interviews further determined licensee’s acknowledgement of the physical assaults and that there was no clear plan in place to prevent further physical assaults on C1 by C2. Confidential statements revealed admission to not contacting the police as it was believed they would not take action due to C2 being a juvenile. Licensee ultimately requested to have C2 removed from the facility. The investigation revealed licensee was unable to provide the necessary care and supervision solely, leading to multiple incidents of C2 physically assaulting C1. Based on confidential statements and documentary evidence, the allegation claiming Licensee’s neglect and/or lack of supervision led to resident being physically abused by another resident while in care is substantiated. This action poses an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, Chapter 4 regulation 83078(a)(1) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The investigation revealed licensee was unable to provide the necessary care and supervision solely, leading to multiple incidents of C2 physically assaulting C1. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List and appeal rights were provided to Licensee by email.

Confidential statements found denial of allegations concerning sexual abuse and further found inconsistent statements regarding alleged sexual abuse claims. Statements obtained further refute claim that Staff did not ensure minors did not have access to alcohol while in care. Based on confidential statements and documentary evidence, the allegations are determined unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited per the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, at this time. A copy of this report was provided to the Administrator by email.
investigation_findings: 13On July 10, 2025, at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a subsequent complaint inspection at the WOLFF SMALL FAMILY HOME and met with Licensee/Administrator, Else Wolff to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. On March 10, 2025, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging neglect/lack of supervision by licensee as a former client at Wolff Small Family Home, was reported to have been beaten up by another resident while in care at the facility. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigations Branch and investigated by Investigator Jorge Jauregui. The investigation, including confidential interviews, review of facility file history, review of the San Luis Obispo County Sheriff’s report, and related facility records, revealed enough information to support the alleged. Confidential interviews with four clients (former and current), licensee, complainant, and other related parties corroborated that former resident/Client (C2) physically assaulted former resident/Client (C1) while in care. (Continued on page 9099C)

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (1) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in the individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Confidential interviews and documentary evidence revealed corroborating evidence that C2 physically assaulted C1 on multiple occasions while under the care of licensee. This poses an immediate health, safety, and/or personal rights risk to children in care.

Due to C2's behavior Licensee had C2 removed from care. Additionally,
Licensee will submit a written plan of correction describing how licensee will ensure sufficient supervision to residents in care and ensure cited deficiency from reoccurring in the future.

narrative:
At 1PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above over Microsoft Teams to conduct an Regional Office Meeting. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss the home's request for an age exception for one of their clients in care, as well as to discuss the home's plans to submit an application to transition to an Adult Residential Facility. LPA met with Licensee/Administrator Raphael Yambao, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, East Bay Regional Center (RCEB) Case Manager Teresa Lam, and RCEB Case Manager Supervisor Ineko Ito. Currently in care are 4 ambulatory clients. During this meeting, it was discussed that all clients currently residing at Yambao Everyday Milestones have surpassed the home's licensed age of 6-17 years old. LPM Wong stated that Community Care Licensing could not issue age exceptions for all four clients because the home would be operating as an adult residential facility under a children's residential license. In order to avoid interruptions in the clients' care, LPM Wong asked Mr. Yambao to provide a reasonable timeline for their transition to an Adult Residential Facility. Mr. Yambao clarified that his current facility would remain open under the current children's residential license, and he would be opening a new facility, licensed as an Adult Residential Facility, that all clients currently in care would transition to once the application process is complete. Mr. Yambao stated that his son has already attended an Adult Residential Facility orientation, and has completed the administrator certification course. Mr. Yambao is currently working on the program design for the new facility with approximately 25-30% completed, and hopes to submit the application by the end of this month, June 2021. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

At this time, LPM Wong suggested that Mr. Yambao submit both the adult residential facility application and the Regional Center vendorization application at the same time, to help speed the process along. LPM Wong advised Mr. Yambao to submit the application directly to the Sacramento Regional Office, either in person or by certified mail and to keep scanned copies of all documentation in the event that something must be replaced. Mr. Yambao agreed to notify LPA Fremont and LPM Wong when the application for the Adult Residential Facility is submitted, and agreed to include LPA Fremont and LPM Wong on email correspondence going forward in order to receive updates on the process. LPA Fremont will also reach out by email monthly to inquire about updates and provide any needed support to Mr. Yambao. Mr. Yambao has also agreed to submit a written plan and reasonable timeline for this application process and for the transition of clients to the new facility. Plan will be submitted to LPA Fremont and LPM Wong over email no later than 5PM on Friday, 06/11/2021. At this time, all clients currently in care at Mr. Yambao's facility will be allowed to remain in care without age exceptions until the new Adult Residential Facility is licensed and the clients can move to their new home. At this time, no deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee Raphael Yambao to be signed and returned over email no later than 5PM on Thursday, 06/10/2021.

On July 12, 2021 at 9:31 AM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Abdoulaye Traore, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Shanae Pharaoh, began a pre-licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Wilyon Miller who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. The applicant is applying for a capacity of 3 ambulatory developmentally disabled with special needs. The home is a two-story home and consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, the room consist of one twin size bed- it will sleep one child- currently vacant. There was a living room, dining area, the kitchen, the garage, laundry room, and bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, the room was furnished with a twin-size bunk bed- It sleeps two foster children ages 3 and 4. Bedroom #3, the room was furnished with a king-size bed and a crib- it sleeps the applicant and the crib sleeps a 1-year old foster child. Bedroom #4, the room was furnished with a full-size bed - it was vacant. Bedroom #5, the room was furnished with a queen-size bed - it sleeps the applicants 21- year old daughter Bedroom #6, the room was furnished with a queen-size bed - it sleeps the applicants 19- year old son There is a loft that serves as a multipurpose area. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. Bedroom #1 is currently being used to store staff and client files; applicant will move the files to the garage. No bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The was only one set of bedding for the clients, applicant stated she will purchase an additional set for each bed. Bedroom #1 did not have a mattress protector; applicant will be putting a mattress protector on the bed.

Upstairs outside the bedrooms, there was a loft designated game and play area which contained toys. It was observed to be safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for. The smoke detectors were checked, and smoke detector in Bedroom #2 was not working properly, applicant stated she will get the smoke alarmed synchronized. The fireplace was in the living room area and it was properly screened. There is currently no telephone service, apply will obtaining a landline. The appliances were in a working order. Inside of the home, hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are stored in the kitchen and were not locked, applicant stated she will store the medication in a lock box. The first aid kit was stored in the downstairs bathroom. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in utility cabinet located in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and store in the utility cabinet in the garage. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 105.1 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The fire extinguisher was in the kitchen, an additional fire extinguisher was in the garage, in the loft and laundry room. The was an additional refrigerator and freezer in the garage. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan were posted. LPM and LPA did not observe the visitation policy and Personal Rights posted. LPM and LPA observed the back yard to have scrap wood located by the side gate, applicant stated it will be moved to the garage. The side gate was also tied shut with a wire, applicant stated she will remove the wire. There was no pool or other body of water. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: • Smoke detector in bedroom #2 needs to be synchronized • Clients need additional set of bed linens • Medications need to be stored in locked boxes • Staff and client files need to be stored in a separate area from client room • Telephone service needs to be established in home • Visitation plan and personal rights needs to be posted Scrap wood needs to be removed from backyard After the corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA Pharaoh. The component orientation III will be scheduled once the corrections are completed.

The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the component orientation is completed and the corrections have been made. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant on this July 12, 2021.

On August 16, 2021 at 2:03 PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Shanae Pharaoh and LPA Babatunde Aborchie and Licensing Program Manager, Abdoulaye Traore arrived at a Small Family Home and met with applicant, Wilyon Miller who led a tour of the home. The purpose of the inspection was ensuring corrections were made from the pre-licensing inspection dated on July 12, 2021. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Downstairs: Bedroom #1, the room consist of one twin size bed- it will sleep one child- currently vacant. There was a living room, dining area, the kitchen, the garage, laundry room, and bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, the room was furnished with a twin-size bunk bed- It sleeps two foster children ages 3 and 4. Bedroom #3, the room was furnished with a king-size bed and a crib- it sleeps the applicant and the crib sleeps a 1-year old foster child. Bedroom #4, the room was furnished with a full-size bed - it was vacant. Bedroom #5, the room was furnished with a queen-size bed - it sleeps the applicants 21- year old daughter Bedroom #6, the room was furnished with a queen-size bed - it sleeps the applicants 19- year old son There is a loft that serves as a multipurpose area. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. There was an additional set of bedding for each of the clients. Each bed was observed to have a mattress protector.

Upstairs outside the bedrooms, there was a loft designated game and play area which contained toys. It was observed to be safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for. There is was a land line telephone located in the kitchen and upstairs. The appliances were in a working order. Inside of the home, hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are stored in the kitchen and were in locked boxes. The first aid kit was stored in the downstairs bathroom. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in utility cabinet located in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the utility cabinet in the garage. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 105.1 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The fire extinguisher was in the kitchen, an additional fire extinguisher was in the garage, in the loft and laundry room. There was an additional refrigerator and freezer in the garage. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, The Visitation Policy and Personal Rights were posted. LPM and LPA observed the back yard to be free of obstruction and the gate was accessible and free latching without a lock. There was no pool or other body of water. Corrections made: · Smoke detector in bedroom #2 was hardwired and synchronized · Applicant purchased additional sets of bed linens for each client · Medications were stored in locked boxes · Staff and client files were moved to a storage cabinet in the garage. · Telephone service was established in the home · Visitation policy and personal rights were posted · Scrap wood was removed from backyard Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 3 ambulatory clients. All corrections were made, and all requirements are met at this time. Component III was also conducted during this inspection. On January 20, 2021 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Linda Haynes, began a post-licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. The home is a two-story home and consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, the room consist of one full size bed- it will sleep one child- currently vacant. There was a living room, dining area, the kitchen, the garage, laundry room, and bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, the room was furnished with a twin-size bunk bed- It sleeps two children. Bedroom #3, the room was furnished with a king-size bed and a crib- it sleeps the applicant and the crib sleeps a 1-year old child. Bedroom #4, the room was furnished with a full-size bed - it was vacant. Bedroom #5, the room was furnished with a queen-size bed - it sleeps the applicants 22- year old daughter Bedroom #6, the room was furnished with a queen-size bed - it sleeps the applicants 20- year old son There is a loft that serves as a multipurpose area. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. Upstairs outside the bedrooms, there was a loft designated game and play area which contained toys. It was observed to be safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for. The smoke detectors were checked and were working. Inside of the home, hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are stored in the kitchen and are in lock boxes one in the cabinet and one the refrigerator. The first aid kit was stored in the downstairs bathroom and contains needed supplies. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in utility cabinet located in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and store in the utility cabinet in the garage. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Licensee Wilyon Miller. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 120 degrees. All food is properly stored. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The fire extinguisher was in the kitchen, an additional fire extinguisher was in the garage, in the loft and laundry room. There was an additional refrigerator and freezer in the garage. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan were posted. There was no pool or other body of water. There were no deficiencies noted at this time. This report was reviewed and a copy was provided to licensee Wilyon MIller.

On 04/09/2025 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Maryjane Perez and Claudia Aguilera and Licensing Program Manager Abdoulaye Traore conducted an annual inspection at Zainab Small Family Home (SFH) and met with licensee Zainab Jalloh who gave a tour of the entire home. Currently, there was one ambulatory client placed in the home and it is licensed for a capacity of three. The Facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. LPAs and LPM observed that the downstairs consisted of the kitchen, a living room, a formal living room, the garage, two dining areas with large tables and a bedroom #1. The bedroom was utilized for the male client currently residing at the SFH and the room consisted of a full-size bed, a closet space including the adequate bedding. Sharp objects/knives, first aid kit and medications were stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Fire extinguisher was also centrally placed in the kitchen and operable. The water temperature was tested and measured at 120 degrees F. The pantry and refrigerator were fully stocked and had perishable and nonperishable foods. In addition to the downstairs space, there were also one full bathroom fully functioning and hallway closets storing extra household items and client’s hygiene products. A trash can was observed to have tight fitting cover. All required postings were posted at this time. The upstairs consisted of a laundry room that always remains locked. There was a master bedroom #2 for licensee, and it consisted of a king size bed, a crib currently vacant and a bathroom; bedroom #3 sleeps licensee's biological 15-year-old daughter furnished with a queen size bed, bedroom #4 sleeps licensee's biological son and furnished with a queen size bed, bedroom #5 was vacant and consisted of two twin size beds fully furnished and will be utilized for two clients. There was also bathroom #3 that was fully functioning in the hallway. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings.

The outdoor grounds were also inspected, and no hazards or obstructions were observed. During inspection LPAs inspected the client file and licensee file. There was no pool or other body of water. There was no firearm in the home as stated by licensee. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. There was a telephone land line service available in the home. LPAs interviewed licensee and the client. During the visit. there were no deficiencies observed, however, LPAs issued one technical violation (TV) and one technical advisory (TA) explained and given to licensee. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with TV and TA were reviewed and provided to Licensee Zainab Jalloh.

***Continued from LIC 9099*** In regard to the allegations that foster parent touched the child inappropriately; foster parent did not prevent physical altercations between children in care; and foster parent did not prevent minor from inappropriately touching another minor, it was specifically reported that there were concerns of physical and sexual abuse towards. It was further reported that other children in the home have tried to beat FC1 (details unknown). Additionally, it was disclosed that there was an incident in which foster father reached over and touched FC1’s thigh (details unknown). During the investigation, a confidential interview denied all the allegations were false. Other confidential interviews denied that the allegations were true. A confidential interview stated that FC1 was at the dinner table the entire time at the home and when FC1 got up from the table, FC1 collapsed at the bottom of the staircase. Foster parents contacted the paramedics and FC1 was transported to the hospital. FC1 did not return to SFH after discharge. It was indicated that FC1 was placed at the SFH for a very short period. In regard to the allegation that foster parent did not ensure that the home was free of marijuana, it was specifically reported that FC1 found marijuana in the garage, and FC1 did not like the vibes in the home and does not feel safe to go back to SFH. A confidential interview stated that FC1 never went into the garage and never interacted with the other children in care. Confidential interviews denied that marijuana is being used at the SFH. LPA didn’t receive additional information. Based on consistent confidential interviews, the allegations that foster parent touched the FC1 inappropriately; foster parent did not ensure that the home was free of marijuana; foster parent did not prevent physical altercations between children in care; and foster parent did not prevent minor from inappropriately touching another minor may have happened or valid, however, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and the appeal rights were explained and given to Billy Ngamau, Licensee.

narrative: In regard to the allegation that licensee ran over minor’s foot, confidential interview stated FC1 was standing by the car and LS pulled out of the parking lot very slowly and was not sure LS ran over FC1’s foot. Another confidential interview stated FC1 screamed very loudly as FC1 was in pain. The confidential interview added that the car ran over FC1’s right foot, but it didn’t specify the affected spot. Additional confidential interview stated FC1’s foot was run over, and FC1’s foot was sore. Confidential witness did not observe a car running over FC1’s foot, and did not see signs of injury on the right foot and believed licensee was a careful parent. LPA received a conflicting information. Based on the confidential interviews and observation, the allegation that LS ran over FC1's foot may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to the licensee at the SFH.

The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. Upon entry, the downstairs consisted of the kitchen, a living room, the garage, a dining area with a large table, one bedroom, one bathroom, an a small office. Bedroom #1 consisted of a queen-size bed that sleeps licensee. Bathroom #1 was inspected and fully functioning. The medications were stored and locked in cabinet located in the kitchen. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet under the kitchen sink. The First Aid Kit was located downstairs in a cabinet and contained all required items. The garage was inspected and used for storage and one vehicle. The water temperature was tested and measured at 114.6 degrees F. A trash can was observed to be in a pull-out cabinet. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: personal rights, visitation policy, and current menu. The upstairs consisted of a laundry room that always remains locked. There was a master bedroom #2 for administrator it consisted of a Calking size bed and a bathroom; the administrator's bedroom is not accessible to the clients; bedroom #3 sleeps only 18 year old male non-minor dependent client and the room was fully furnished with two twin beds, a closet and plenty of storage space. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for each child’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and working. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room. The upstairs space includes a loft with a large sectional couch, a television and PlayStation, there was an additional bathroom used for the clients. All hazardous items have been properly inaccessible to areas where clients have access. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by caregiver. In regard to the allegations that staff physically restrained and handled a minor in a rough manner, it was specifically reported that there was an incident where S1 and S2 were holding down foster child 1 (FC1) by their arms and legs for 17 minutes. It was further reported that on 08/21/2023, a former HM grabbed minors’ wrists and yelled loudly to FC1, “You don’t fucking touch me! Do you understand?”. During investigation, confidential interviews reported that they would use Crisis Prevention Intervention (CPI) holds to redirect and calm clients down, but they were no more than 5 minutes at a time. Other confidential interviews stated that they had not seen staff wrongly redirecting FC1 but in fact they believe that staff were doing a great job of redirecting. Regarding staff making inappropriate comments towards minor allegation, confidential interviews stated that staff would not use inappropriate language in the process of calming FC1. Other confidential interviews stated that FC1 would be the one to use vulgar language at staff. LPA couldn’t gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegations that staff physically restrained FC1; staff handled FC1 in a rough manner; and staff made inappropriate comments towards FC1 may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. narrative: On December 4, 2020 @ 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced Case Management tele-inspection via FaceTime. LPA spoke with John Dela Torre, TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) Supervisor. Remote "tele-inspections" of facilities are a part of Community Care Licensing Division’s emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). The purpose of the tele-inspection was to follow up on an Unusual Incident Report received by the Department on December 1, 2020 involving C1 and C2. LPA informed Mr. Dela Torre that the case has been assigned to Investigator, Maria Barragan. LPA requested copies of the following documents: - Client records (C1 and C2) - Incident reports re: C1 and C2 - Client roster dated 11/26/20 - Staff schedule dated 11/26/20 - Phone numbers of staff involved - Staff training - Emergency Intervention Plan During the tele-inspection, Mr. Dela Torre showed the surveillance camera that captured the incident and the area where the incident occurred. The facility has saved camera footage of the incident. LPA concluded the tele-inspection at 3:00 PM.

On December 9, 2020 @ 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced Case Management in-person inspection at the above named Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA met with John Dela Torre, TSCF Supervisor. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an Unusual Incident Report received by the Department on December 1, 2020. On December 4, 2020, an initial tele-inspection was conducted to request pertinent documents. During today's inspection, LPA followed up on the requested documents that have not been received by the Department. LPA reviewed the facility's Emergency Intervention Plan and obtain copies of the following documents: - Pertinent incident reports - Staff training curriculum - Training log - Emergency Intervention Plan (Managing Aggressive Behavior-MAB) LPA concluded the inspection at 1:45 PM. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility.

Based upon a review of Special Incident Reports dated September 10, 2021 and September 24, 2021 regarding clients Ref. #1, 2, 3 and 4, although the facility documented the time of the incidents the LPA observed no information regarding the duration of the incidents and cannot tell at what point the staff intervened to separate the clients. The investigation revealed that the facility has not conducted disaster drills. The facility was unable to provide the LPA with documentation of disaster drills. Based upon the above, it is determined that the complaint is substantiated. The complaint is valid because the standard of a preponderance of evidence has been met. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22 Regulation, Plan of Operation, Section 80022(k): The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. (see LIC 9099-D). A copy of this report was emailed to Ms. Martinez and the appeal rights were explained during the exit interview.
investigation_findings: On February 12, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, emailed the complaint findings to Administrator, Terrie Martinez. On September 25 2020, the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Office (RO) received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of, but were not limited to: Group Counselor III, John De La Torre. The LPA reviewed the facility Plan of Operation; Facility Sketch; and Personnel Reports, Client Register, Law Enforcement Contact Reports (LIC624-LE) from September 2020 to January 2021 and Special Incident Reports dated September 10, 2021 and September 24, 2021. The investigation revealed that although the facility is in the hiring process, based upon a review of the Personnel Reports for September 2020 thru January 2021 the facility is not maintaining the six Lead Counselors and 24 Group Home Counselors as outlined in the Plan of Operation. The investigation revealed that the facility can call in extra help and staff from Kern County Department of Human Services in order to meet the staff to client ratio of 1:4. The facility trains new hires according to the Plan of Operation, but has found difficulty in maintaining new staff.

deficiencies.description:
Plan of Operation.  The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.


This requirement is not met as evidenced by: A review of the Personnel Reports for September 2020 thru January 2021 revealed that the facility is not maintaining the six Lead Counselors and 24 Group Home Counselors as outlined in the Plan of Operation.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide CCL with documentation that the facility is low on staff and their plan to meet the requirement, along with Kern County's practices and procedures on hiring when the facility cannot meet the Plan of Operation.  The agency completed a hiring  recruitment and hired one staff with plans to hire six Group Home Counselor (GCI) I & IIs. The facility is in the middle of recruitment for GCIIIs.  The facility will review the Plan of Operation Section F Administrative Organization to determine if amendments to staffing are required.  The facility will provide CCL the Plan of Correction by the POC date of March 11, 2021 via email to karen.mcgee@dss.ca.gov.

met_with: Maria Bermudez, Assistant Director-Child Welfare; Terrie Martinez, Program Director, Darla Munoz, Program Specialist and John Dela Torre, Supervisor
narrative:
On May 3, 2021 at 1:00 PM, Community Care Licensing - Monterey Park Regional Office (CCL-MPRO) conducted a virtual informal office meeting with A. Miriam Jamison Children’s Center (a Temporary Shelter Care Facility, TSCF) via Microsoft Teams meeting app. Remote meetings and tele-inspections of facilities are a part of Community Care Licensing Division’s emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). Present at the meeting representing the Department were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Tira Logan-Shanks and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring. Present at the meeting representing the TSCF were Maria Bermudez, Assistant Director-Child Welfare; Terrie Martinez, Program Director, Darla Munoz, Program Specialist and John Dela Torre, Supervisor. Introductions were made, and the following agenda items were discussed: Summary of Relevant Complaints 1.) On 3/23/21, CCL-MPRO substantiated a complaint against the facility alleging that facility staff failed to follow the Facility's Emergency Intervention Procedures (EIP) to prevent altercation between youth resulting in a client sustaining injuries. The facility was cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) for TSCF, Plan of Operation, Section 84622 (d). (See Complaint Investigation Report, LIC 9099 dated 3/23/21 for details.) 2.) On 2/12/21, CCL-MPRO substantiated a complaint against the facility alleging the following: Staff supervision is inadequate; Staff are not properly trained; There is a lack of staff to meet the clients' needs. The facility was cited for violation of Title 22 Code of Regulation, Plan of Operation, Section 80022(k). (See Complaint Investigation Report, LIC 9099 dated 2/12/21 for details.) (cont...)

Relevant Plan of Correction 1.) On 3/17/21, the facility submitted an addendum to the facility’s Plan of Operation (POO) Section F Administrative Organization. LPA Herring has been providing Technical Assistance (TA) on the facility’s proposed staffing changes. At this time, the facility has not submitted their latest revision. 2.) On 3/24/21, the facility submitted a Plan of Correction which includes: - All new employees will receive Managing Aggressive Behaviors (MAB) training as soon as reasonably possible. - Staff that have already completed MAB training will receive refresher course every two years, unless it is deemed necessary that they receive it sooner. Over the next 6 months, all existing staff will have their first refresher training occur. - A Safety Plan will be incorporated into the EIP detailing protocol when staff is faced with any emergency situation. Plan of Action discussed during the informal meeting: 1.) The facility will submit weekly updates on the status of their MAB training (initial and refresher course). To date, 23 staffs have received the training and 8 staffs are still waiting to be trained. The Department takes into account the fact that training during the COVID-19 pandemic imposes many challenges for the training facilitator and the provider. 2.) The facility will submit the latest revision to the facility’s POO (Staffing changes) by 5/17/21. 3.) The facility recognizes that safety incidents are inevitable, even with their current emergency intervention procedures (EIP) in place. The facility is re-evaluating their EIP and looking into ways to improve their current protocols. The facility will submit an addendum to its EIP in accordance with Section 84322 Emergency Intervention Plan by 5/17/21. 4.) The emergency intervention plan is to be designed and approved, in conjunction with the licensee, by an individual with the qualifications of a behavior management consultant as defined in Section 84001(b)(1). The virtual meeting ended at 2:05 PM. A signed copy of this report was provided to the licensee.

met_with: Darla Munoz, Program Director and Everett Sutton, Group Counselor III
narrative:
On June 28, 2021 at 10:55 AM, an unannounced Annual Required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Herring and Claudia Portillo at the above named Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA met with Darla Munoz, Program Director and Everett Sutton, Group Counselor III. This TSCF is owned and operated by Kern County Department of Human Services (KCDHS) and licensed to provide temporary shelter care services up to 10 days to children (2 children maybe non-ambulatory.) There are 12 children placed at the time of inspection. Three (3) out of 12 children were placed less than 10 days ago. PHYSICAL PLANT LPA toured the entire facility with staff Sutton. Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There are no bodies of water in the facility. Disinfectants and other toxic materials are kept locked in the hallway closet. Sharps and knives are inaccessible to children. Temperatures in all rooms occupied by children are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures registered at 138 degrees (F). The fire extinguishers all throughout the facility are fully charged. LPAs were not able to test the pull down alarm due to the type of clients that were present during the facility tour. The facility has a centralized fire sprinkler system. CARE & SUPERVISION The staff to client ratio at the time of inspection was 5:12 (excludes staff working in the office). Facility exceeds the minimum Food Services requirements. Facility has contracted vendors who supply food items. LPA observed non-perishable food items for at least 30 days and perishable food items for at least one week. A review of monthly menu indicates that facility provides nutritious meals and snacks. Medications are centrally stored/locked in the medication room and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. There's an ample supply of hygiene items, clothes for all ages and linens available for children's use. (cont.)

PERSONAL RIGHTS Facility posts child's personal rights. Clients live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home. CLIENT RECORDS LPAs reviewed six (6) client records. Client records contain: placement agreement specifying that the child's placement shall not exceed ten(10) calendar days; history of previous placement/living arrangement and reason for removal from each placement/living arrangement; medical/dental consent; health assessment; weight record; signed personal rights; and inventory of clients' personal property and valuables. STAFF RECORDS LPA reviewed five(5) personnel records. Personnel records contain: current CPR/First Aid certificates and documentation of education, qualification and training received by personnel. A review of Licensing Information System on today's date indicates that facility staff or other individuals who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. All staffs are associated to the facility number. ADMINISTRATION Facility's Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan is current and available for review. Facility operates within license capacity and limitations. OVERSTAY REPORTS Facility submits to the Department initial and weekly overstay reports after child’s placement reaches the 10-day limit. INFECTION CONTROL PRACTICES Facility has COVID-19 signs at the front door and in the common areas. Facility maintains PPE and sanitation supplies. Facility conducts temperature check at entry point and mask wearing inside the facility is required/recommended for all staff and visitors. LPAs issued deficiency citations and provided Advisory Notes - Technical Assistance (LIC 9102TA) and Technical Violations (LIC 9102TV). A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with LIC 858 (Client's Records Review); LIC 859 (Review of Staff Records). Appeal Rights provided.

narrative:
During the evening shift, staff placed client in a locked bedroom for safety reasons, with one staff on duty outside, in case of emergency. However, staff were unable to remove the latch when another staff arrived to assess the client. The latch had to be cut off for staff to gain entry to the bedroom. Surveillance video show that no staff was placed on duty outside the client’s bedroom and no staff conducted a safety check on the client from 11:00 PM on 12/28/20 until 6:30 AM the following morning. The second allegation was the facility did not have sufficient staff to meet the needs of clients in care. Confidential interviews confirmed that the facility did not have the number of staff needed to properly supervise and meet clients’ needs when the allegation was reported. Clients who were usually placed in separate units due to age and behavior were placed and supervised together. Fast food was purchased to serve to clients during a meal period because there were no kitchen staff available to prepare meals. Surveillance video show that no staff was on duty outside the client’s bedroom and no staff conducted a safety check on the client from 11:00 PM on 12/28/20 until 6:30 AM the following morning. The third allegation was staff were not properly trained to care for a client. Client’s needs were described as beyond staff’s ability to care for but was not denied placement because the facility was a licensed temporary shelter and client met the requirement for placement under Welfare and Institutions Code 300. Records show that client’s needs as described, and noted in transfer of custody, met the placement criteria under the facility’s plan of operation. Furthermore, confidential interviews, supporting documents and surveillance video show that the level of care provided to the client during placement was not consistent with the practice model of what the facility described in its plan of operation. Based on information obtained during investigations conducted by the Department, the preponderance of evidence standard was met, therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to clients in care. Deficiencies are being cited under Title 22, Chapter 5 Group Home Regulations 84072(d)(14); TSCF Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 84665.5(f) and TSCF ILS 84665.3(b). This report and a Plan of Correction was discussed with the facility representative and copies of the following reports: LIC 9099, LIC 9099C, LIC 9099-D and the LIC 811 (Confidential Names dated 7/27/21) and appeal rights were provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

It was also alleged that the heat was not working in the unit/room client was placed in. LPA obtained varying accounts of what confidential interviewees could recall regarding the temperature in the unit where client was. There was no record of any work order request to address any issue with the temperature inside the facility during client’s placement. Based on the above information, the allegations are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there was no preponderance of evidence found to support it. A copy of this signed report, the LIC 811 (Confidential Names dated 7/27/21) and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative at the conclusion of the inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On July 27, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a complaint inspection at the facility to deliver the finding of the allegations. LPA met with the facility representative named above and discussed the finding. The allegations were investigated by Community Care Licensing (CCL), Investigations Branch (IB) Investigator Mariana Lomeli and the undersigned LPA. The Department received a complaint alleging multiple allegations on 12/31/2020. IB Investigator Lomeli and LPA Yamamoto investigated the allegations by reviewing records such as the facility license, floor plan, register of clients, personnel report, staff schedule, maintenance records, lead shift log, client transfer of custody, timeline/daily notes for client and incident/law enforcement contact report. Additional records were requested and reviewed such as, but not limited to, medical records, police report, photos, surveillance video and the facility plan of operation. Investigator Lomeli and LPA Yamamoto conducted independent interviews. It was alleged that staff locked client in a room. Confidential interviews reveal that a client was placed in a separate unit from other clients, inside a locked bedroom with a quick release latch. Staff determined during intake that client was a flight risk and exhibited unsafe behaviors while being supervised by two staff.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights: The licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: To not be locked in any room, building, or facility premises at any time. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Staff locked client in a bedroom during placement was corroborated by confidential interviews, surveillance video and records reviewed.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will submit a Plan of Correction by the POC due date.

deficiencies.description: Staff Ratios: If the children require special care and supervision because of age, problem behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty facility staff shall be increased. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: The facility did not have sufficient staff to meet the needs of clients in care was corroborated by confidential interviews, surveillance video and records reviewed.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will submit a Plan of Correction by the POC due date.

deficiencies.description: Additional Staff Training: All Administrators, facility managers, social work staff and direct care staff shall receive four hours of training on the specialized needs of children in transition. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: The level of care provided by staff to one client revealed that staff were not properly trained to care for a client. This was  corroborated by confidential interviews, surveillance video and records reviewed.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will submit a Plan of Correction by the POC due date.

narrative: On 7/1/21 at 3:00 PM, an unannounced Case Management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring at the above named Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA met with Darla Munoz, Program Director. The purpose of this inspection was to follow up on the following Plans of Action discussed during the Informal Meeting conducted on 5/3/21: 1. MAB (Managing Aggressive Behavior) training (initial and refresher course) - To date, 29 staffs have received MAB training. Facility will ensure personnel records contain proof of MAB training completed by staff. 2. Staffing changes - Currently, the facility utilizes Human Service Aids (HSA) to assist with supervision and provide transportation to children. Per Program Director, HSAs are left alone with the children during transportation. None of the HSAs have received MAB training. The Program Director will discuss staffing requirements with Kern County Department of Human Services (DHS) management and will update the licensing agency of their staffing plan by 7/9/21. 3. Emergency Intervention Procedures (EIP) - The facility plans to send two of their staff to get trained to become certified MAB In-service Instructor. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

On September 24, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen McGee conducted an unannounced Case Management - COVID-19 inspection at the facility. LPA met with Assistant Program Director, Tim Stevens. The purpose of the inspection was to issue a deficiency citation due to the facility's failure to comply with Reporting Requirements. On September 16, 2021, LPA Jean Herring received a report from a third party that a child recently tested positive for COVID-19 while placed at the facility. When LPA Herring contacted the facility to verify the information, LPA discovered that there was a COVID-19 outbreak at the facility that started on 8/31/21 wherein 14 clients and 5 staff members tested positive. Based on the information gathered, it was determined that the licensee did not comply with the Reporting Requirements by failing to report a COVID-19 epidemic outbreak that started on 8/31/21 affecting 14 clients and 5 staff. A deficiency citation is issued under Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06 General Licensing Requirements, Section 80061 Reporting Requirements. LPA McGee discussed the citation with the facility representative a Plan of Correction was developed. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with Appeal Rights.
