met_with: John De La Torre- Facility Youth Counselor Supervisor
narrative: During the investigation, it was reported the clients were waiting in the facility’s lobby while they were processed to go back in the facility when the fight took place between Client #1 and Client #2. According to the information obtained during the investigation, the clients were not denied of anything they asked; therefore, the children’s needs were met. No other agency investigated the allegations. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the complaint allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report left at the facility along with appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 8/06/21, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Lofton conducted a follow up inspection at A. Miriam Jamison Center and met with Title, John De La Torre, Facility Youth Counselor Supervisor with the purpose of issuing the investigative findings report for the above stated allegations. LPA Lofton interviewed the reporting party on 2/10/21, Staff #1 was interviewed on 4/1421, Staff #2 was interviewed on 12/11/20. Staff #3 was interviewed on 3/05/21, Staff #4 and Staff #5 were interviewed on 4/14/21. LPA Lofton attempted to interview Client’s #1 County Social Worker but was unsuccessful. Client#1 was interviewed on 3/05/21. LPA Lofton was unable to interview Clients #2 and #3. LPA Lofton interviewed County Social Worker for Client #2. See the Confidential Names List (LIC-811) dated 08/06/21. During the confidential interviews the allegations were denied. Interviews revealed that the facility did not deny entrance to the clients. It was reported Clients #1, #2 and #3 were returning from AWOL when the incident happened

met_with: John Dela Torre, Group Counselor Supervisor
narrative: The investigation revealed that following: The facility’s Emergency Intervention Plan (EIP) states circumstances or behaviors that may require the use Managing Aggressive Behavior (MAB) techniques include physical assault on a staff or a client, suicide attempts, physical property destruction that can lead to a serious injury and placing one’s self in danger. MAB techniques can be done by one, two or three persons and they include a list of manual restraints which are time limited. Based on surveillance videos, police report, and statements from C1 and S1, it was revealed that C2 brutally assaulted C1 on 11/26/20. Although S1 gave C2 verbal commands and pulled on his sweater with one hand, he continued punching, kicking, and dragging C1 across the room for approximately two minutes. During the assault, S1 did not attempt to use manual restraint hold nor did she seek immediate assistance even though four other staff members were on duty. S1 stated that due to C2’s size, she was unable to perform a manual restraint, but she admitted that she should have called for assistance sooner. After the assault, C1 was transported to a local hospital via ambulance. A review of C1’s Patient Discharge Instructions revealed that on 11/26/20, C1 was seen at Kern Medical Emergency Department. The attending physician noted the following on the discharge report/diagnosis: Assault; Left facial swelling; Left facial pain; Chest wall pain (see Confidential Names Form dated 3/23//21). Based on the information gathered, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was met, therefore the allegation is substantiated per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 (refer to LIC9099-D for deficiency citation.) A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, LIC 9099-D for deficiency and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On March 23, 2021 at 12:35 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted a follow-up complaint in-person inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegations above. The complaint was investigated by Community Care Licensing, Investigations Branch, State Investigator Maria Barragan. LPA Herring met with the facility representative named above and discussed the findings. During the course of the investigation, Investigator Barragan interviewed Group Counselor Supervisors on 12/11/20 and 1/14/21, Group Counselors on 1/13/21, Facility Extra Help Staff on 1/13/21, and Facility Client/s on 12/11/20. Investigator Barragan also reviewed documents on 12/4/20, 12/9/20, 12/11/20, 12/17/21, 1/6/21, 1/13/21, 1/14/21 including but not limited to facility’s complaint history, facility’s Emergency Intervention Plan, paramedics report, police report, surveillance video, Audio Recorded 911 Call, and Child Welfare Service Reports. (continued...)

deficiencies.description:
84622 PLAN OF OPERATION
(d) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in its plan of operation.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review, S1 failed to follow the facility's Emergency Intervention Procedures (EIP) to prevent altercation between clients resulting in C1 sustaining injuries. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility representative stated all staff will receive refresher training on the facility's Emergency Intervention Procedures (EIP). In addition, the licensee will submit a Safety Plan for emergency situations. Proof of correction shall include training attendance sheet, training topics and trainer's name and qualification. Proof of correction shall be submitted via email no later than 3/24/21.

narrative:
On May 10, 2022 at 10:50AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a case management inspection at the facility and met with the facility representative named above. LPA requested for and reviewed incident reports provided by the facility involving a client (C1) named in another incident being addressed by the Department. LPA cross referenced the incident reports with the saved incident reports under the regional office records. LPA did not find any regional office records of the following: An incident report dated 11/23/21 noted that one client reported witnessing inappropriate behavior of C1 towards other female clients in placement. The supervisor’s comments noted that C1’s inappropriate behavior will be addressed and C1 was to be supervised closely However, LPA reviewed four similar incidents after, dated 12/21/21, 12/25/21, 12/26/21 and 12/29/21, wherein C1 continued to engage in inappropriate behavior towards other clients. C1 touched other clients inappropriately in various parts of their bodies, gave some of them unwarranted back massages and hickeys on their necks. If the initial incident report dated 11/23/21 was received by the Department, a written plan of supervision for C1, together with a written safety plan for the other clients in placement, would have been requested by the Department from the facility. continued

Based on the above information, there is supportive evidence found during the review of the incident reports that C1 was not properly supervised, so a deficiency citation is issued for lack of supervision. In addition, there were no records found showing that the facility reported the incidents to the Department as required, so a citation under reporting requirements is also issued. This is the second reporting requirement deficiency citation issued to the facility within a 12 month period. The plans of correction were discussed with the facility representative. Copies of the licensing reports, deficiency citations and Confidential Names Form were provided at the conclusion of the case management inspection. Appeal rights forms were also provided and explained.

It was alleged that a child was raped by another minor at the facility. The child was interviewed by law enforcement and the placement agency, so Investigator Lomeli did not interview the child again, to avoid re-victimization. Confidential interviews reveal that the child was inappropriately touched in the top inner thigh area while the child and minor sat next to each other. Child pushed the minor’s hand and walked away. The incident was reported to staff who asked the child to stay away from minor. During another incident, minor attempted to touch the child’s buttocks, but child was able to push minor’s hand away. The child was unable to provide the dates of the incidents, but they occurred during child’s placement between 11/19/21 to 12/10/21. The child did not report the incidents to the placement agency worker. Child did not disclose feeling uncomfortable at placement and did not complain about anyone at the facility. One staff reported that the facility became aware of minor touching other children in care so minor was transferred to another unit with fewer children so minor can be closely supervised. A counselor closely supervised minor when minor is in proximity with other children in placement. Another staff attempted to talk to the child about the incidents, but the child was unwilling to provide any details. There was no statement obtained from the minor by the placement agency and the Department due to a pending case by another agency. Based on the above information, the allegation is closed as unsubstantiated due to the lack of preponderance of evidence. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this signed report and the Confidential Names Form (LIC 811 dated 5/10/22) were provided to the facility representative. Appeal rights explained and forms provided.
investigation_findings: 13On May 10, 2022 at 10:50AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a complaint inspection at the facility to deliver the finding of the allegation. LPA met with the facility representative named above. The allegation was investigated by Investigations Branch (IB) State Investigator Mariana Lomeli and the undersigned LPA. Investigator Lomeli conducted confidential interviews with the resource mother, adoptive parent, placement agency worker and the Detective assigned to the case. Investigator Lomeli reviewed the placement agency and law enforcement reports. LPA interviewed one staff and reviewed pertinent documents such as, but not limited to, incident reports, complaint history of the facility, intake reports, assessment of needs, daily notes and discharge reports. continued

met_with: Tim Stevens, Assistant Program Director and Silvia Rivera, Office Service Technician
narrative: On 5/25/2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted a case management inspection at the facility and met with the facility representatives named above. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident that occurred on or about 2/11/22 involving C1 and C2 (clients). On 2/15/22, the Department received an incident report stating that on 2/13/22, facility staff was made aware that C1 and C2 were claiming to have sex with each other. Per Mr. Stevens, the facility administrator interviewed the children regarding the reported incident. However, there's no documentation of those interviews found in the children's records. During today's inspection, LPA Herring interviewed staff1 and staff2. LPA also reviewed client records and obtained copies of pertinent documents. Additional time is needed in order to resolve this case. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with LIC 811 (Confidential Names list).

On 5/27/22 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted a case management inspection at the facility and met with the facility representative named above. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident that occurred on 2/11/22 involving C1 and C2 (clients). On 2/15/22, the Department received an incident report stating that on 2/13/22, facility staff was made aware by other residents that C1 and C2 were claiming to have sex with each other on the night of 2/11/22. Information obtained from incident reports, bed check charts, staff sign-in sheets, Emergency Response Referral Information and interviews, shows C1 and C2 were in a shared room for less than 5 minutes on the night of 2/11/22. Bed charts show the children were assigned to different rooms and were only allowed to sleep together in the same room that night when C1 expressed to staff he was scared to sleep in his room by himself. Follow-up information reveals staff appropriately separated the children when staff observed during a 15-minute interval bed checks that they were not following bedtime instructions (not to get into each other’s bed). The children remained separated until C2 was placed out of the facility on 2/14/22. In addition, a follow up interview with one of the children reveals they don’t know what the word sex means. Further actions taken by the facility includes completing a referral for counseling services for C1. Record review shows there were at least two reportable incidents involving C1 that were never reported to the Department. It is noted that the facility has been recently cited for failure to meet the Reporting Requirements and in the process of correcting the deficiency, therefore, an Advisory Note (Technical Violation) will be issued at this time. Late incident reporting was also addressed. There is no further follow up required regarding the incident involving C1 and C2. This licensing report was reviewed and discussed with the facility representative as well as the Advisory Notes. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative at the conclusion of the inspection along with Confidential Names list (LIC 811) and LIC 9102TV.

On August 9, 2022 at 9:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met Tim Stevens, Program Director. The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on an incident involving violation of personal rights. At 9:50am, LPA interviewed C1. At 10:20am LPA reviewed the staff and client records. On 08/04/22 and 08/08/22, LPA conducted interviews of staff. Per the incident report received by the Department, client ref #1 (C1) was agitated and had words with staff ref #1 (S1) see LIC 811 (Confidential Names List). C1 walked away and out of the unit followed by S1. S1 grabbed C1 by the shirt and then on the hair and dragged her on the floor. During a review of the incident, it was determined that S1 initiated the altercation which resulted for C1 to escalate. After the incident, S1 was terminated. Based on the information, C1's personal rights was violated. ILS 84072.11 Personal Rights: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809D, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to the Program Director.

Confidential statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegations as details obtained indicated inconsistencies which did not support the allegations such as statements denying the allegations and another statement supporting the allegations. One confidential statement obtained from a former facility client indicated that they felt they were picked on by staff when a staff called them fat, but the former client could not recall the name of the staff and stated that there were no witnesses to the incident. Facility staff denied witnessing or subjecting clients to any form of abuse or neglect. Based on the information gathered, the allegations are unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met although the allegations may have happened or are valid. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On August 24, 2022 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joshua Rarela conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegations above. LPA Rarela met and discussed the findings with the facility representative named above. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed facility clients on 4/14/22, 5/12/22, 6/15/22, 6/24/22, and facility staff on 4/14/22, 6/15/22, 6/24/22 (see Confidential Names Form dated August 23, 2022). LPA also reviewed documents including the placing agency service logs and reports, incident reports, and facility personnel records. It was alleged that facility clients are being mistreated while in care, and that staff do not provide adequate supervision to the facility clients. (CONTINUED)

narrative:
On October 3, 2022, at 10:55AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at A. Miriam Jamison Children’s Center Temporarily Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) and met with Tim Stevens, Program Director. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual Inspection at the facility. The Kern County Department of Human Services (DHS) owns and operates the TSCF. The TSFC is licensed to provide temporarily shelter care services up to 10 days to children. Currently, the TSFC shelters thirteen (13) children: 8 females and 5 males. Only 1 child is taking psychotropic medication. Physical Plant: LPA Flores conducted a tour in and outside of the facility with Tim Stevens. The areas inspected were: Unit A and Unit C. Recreation area, kitchen, cafeteria, pantry, patio and playground area, computer room, offices were children’s and staff’s files are kept and intake area. The facility is the facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair.

cont.#2 The food is safe and of the quality and the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. Each meal meets at least 1/3 of the recommended in the USDA Basic Food Group Plan-Daily Food Guide. Supplies of staples non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days are maintained in the facility. Disinfectants and other toxic materials are kept locked in the hallway closet. Sharps and knives are inaccessible to children. Temperatures in all rooms occupied by children are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures registered at 116 degrees (F). The fire extinguishers all throughout the facility are fully charged. LPA Flores was not able to test the smoke detectors due to the design of the equipment did not allow it. The facility has a centralized fire sprinkler system. The inspection will continue at a different day. A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On October 10, 2022, at 10:15AM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jean Herring and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Humberto Flores, conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at A. Miriam Jamison Children's Center Transitional Shelter Foster Care (TSFC) and met with Timothy Stevens. LPM Herring and LPA Flores stated the purpose of the inspection to the TSFC representative. During the inspection a copy of the Register of Facility Clients and Personnel Report was provided upon request. The following topics were inspected: CARE & SUPERVISION The direct care staff to client ratio at the time of inspection was 8 staff and 6 clients. A review of monthly menu indicates that facility provides nutritious meals and snacks. Medications are centrally stored/locked in the medication room and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. There's an ample supply of hygiene items, clothes for all ages and linens available for children's use.

cont.#2 PERSONAL RIGHTS Facility posts child's personal rights. Clients live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home. CLIENT RECORDS LPA Flores reviewed five (5) client records. Client records contain: placement agreement specifying that the child's placement shall not exceed ten(10) calendar days; history of previous placement/living arrangement and reason for removal from each placement/living arrangement; medical/dental consent; body sheet/health assessment; weight record; signed personal rights; and inventory of clients' personal property and valuables. The facility was found to be in compliance with children’s files. STAFF RECORDS LPA Herring reviewed five (5) personnel records. Personnel records contain current CPR/First Aid certificates and documentation of education, qualification and training received by personnel. A review of Licensing Information System (LIS) on today's date indicates that all employees have criminal record clearance.

cont.#3 During the files review LPM Herring observed that the files of 4 employees did not contain proof of initial and annual training. A citation Type B was issued. ADMINISTRATION Facility's Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan is current and available for review. Facility operates within license capacity and limitations. OVERSTAY REPORTS Facility submits to the Department initial and weekly overstay reports after child’s placement reaches the 10-day limit. A copy of this report, citation pages, LIC811, LIC858, LIC859 and appeal rights was issued. Exit interview conducted.

On December 19, 2022, at 12:45PM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at facility A. Miriam Jamison Children's Center Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) and met with Tim Stevens. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information about the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). The TSCF reported that on 09/14/2022, Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 12/19/2022) was transported to the hospital because C1 stated that she could not breathe. LPA Flores investigated the incident and interviewed Tim Stevens. A review of C1’s file was conducted, and copies were made. The information revealed that on 09/14/2022, around 1:15PM, C1 arrived at the facility after she ran away from the facility 2 days prior. C1 disclosed that she could not breathe due to using fentanyl while on run away status. Tim Stevens called 911 and emergency personnel arrived at the facility and transported C1 to a medical facility. C1 was discharged from the hospital on 09/14/2022, around 2:47PM with medical instructions and prescription medication. Currently C1 is with her biological family.

cont.#2 No further inspection is needed. No citation was issued. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

The investigation revealed that on December 14, 2022, Ref. #1 engaged in at least two incidents, one with another client at the facility around 2:10 p.m. and one with a Staff Ref. #2 at about 4:40 p.m. The investigation revealed that the second incident involving Ref. #1 and Staff Ref. #2 occurred outside the facility near the basketball court and there were no other persons present. It revealed that Staff Ref. #3 came to assist Ref. #2 with Ref. #1 after Ref. #2 initially restrained Ref. #1. The investigation revealed that Staff Ref. #2 did not call for assistance with Ref. #1, nor write a report after the incident. It revealed that Staff Ref. #2 left the facility without notifying their supervisor and went on leave of absence. Ref. #2 resigned from the facility. The investigation revealed that the facility generated Special Incident Reports, photographs of scratches and marks after both incidents and maintained surveillance video. Ref. #1 was taken to the hospital. The LPA's interview with Ref. #1 revealed that the allegation that Ref. #1 was choked was maintained and there was no mention of Ref. #1 being thrown to the ground. The LPA ended the interview with Ref. #1, because Ref. #1 did not want to cooperate with the interview. The Kern County Sheriff's Office Crime Report indicates that Ref. #1 and Staff Ref. #2 were outside the facility on the basketball court by themselves. It indicated that Ref. #1 has a history of fighting staff, other clients and required daily restraint. The report indicated that the Deputy Sheriff observed the surveillance video that was blurry. The report indicated Staff Ref. #2 appeared to restrain Ref. #1. It revealed that Staff Ref. #2 allowed Ref. #1 to get up after about four minutes and Ref. #1 walked in one direction, while Staff Ref. #2 walked in another direction. The report indicates that the Deputy Sheriff mentioned to Ref. #1 that Staff Ref. #2 did not appear to choke Ref. #2. The report indicates that the Deputy Sheriff interviewed Staff Ref. #2 and Ref. #2 denied choking Ref. #1. The report indicates that the Deputy Sheriff determined there was no violation of the Penal Code. It is determined that there is not sufficient evidence to Substantiate the allegations. There are no witnesses to incident, it is possible that the scratches and marks photographed on Ref. #1 after the second incident could be a result of the first incident with the other client, the surveillance video is blurry, Ref. #1 has a history of engaging in physical altercations with other clients and staff. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this complaint. This report was emailed to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On March 23, 2023 at 4:15 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, arrived at the facility for the purpose of delivering Investigative Findings for the complaint involving Client (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated December 15, 2022. The LPA met with Director, Tim Stevens. On December 15, 2022, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegation. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: the Director via telephone on March 15, 2023; client Ref. #1 at school March 9, 2023; and the County Social Worker (CSW) via telephone on March 22, 2022. The LPA was unable to interview Staff Ref. #2, because they no longer work at the facility, nor Staff Ref. #3, who was off work when the LPA attempted to contact them. The LPA reviewed Special Incident Reports, Needs and Services Plans and observed photographs. The LPA reviewed Kern County Sheriff's Crime Report. The investigation revealed that the facility deems Ref. #1 special needs and a danger to himself, so Ref. #1 is not allowed to run away from the facility.

narrative: On April 27th, 2023 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced inspection to open a case management at the above facility and met with the Administrator, Tim Stevens. The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department regarding a client (C1) (See LIC 811 dated 04/27/23 for confidential names) who was sexually assaulted by 3 men while on runaway status. Per the SIR reported on 04/21/23, C1 had returned to the facility after running away with another client (C2). C1 stated that C2 forced her to have sex for weed money. C1 stated that she knew the names of the two men and wanted to file a police report. C1 requested assistance and professional help from the facility to cope with the incident. LPA Ashley Ruacho was unable to conduct an interview with C1 since they are no longer at the facility. LPA will contact CSW to find out where C1 has been placed. Administrator provided a list of employees who were on site when C1 and C2 ran away. No deficiency citation was issued during today’s inspection. Further follow-up is required. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

On June 20th, 2023 at 10:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Tim Stevens. The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department. Per the SIR received on 04/21/23, Client 1 (C1) disclosed being sexually assaulted by three men while on AWOL status. C1 disclosed the name of two men and was seeking assistance from facility. The facility evaluated C1, took them to the hospital, and filed a police report. (See confidential name list LIC 811) LPA Ashley Ruacho conducted interviews with C1, CSW, and four out of five staff members. However, the staff member that the LPA was unable to interview was the individual who was providing supervision at the time C1 left the facility unauthorized. Based on interviews LPA is unable to confirm if there was any lack of supervision by the facility staff. LPA can confirm proper procedures were followed upon C1’s return. No deficiency citation was issued during today’s inspection. No further follow-up is required. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Administrator.

On July 12th, 2023, at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPA met with Tim Stevens, Program Director. The Kern County Department of Human Services (DHS) owns and operates A. Miriam Jamison Children’s Center Temporarily Shelter Care (TSCF). The TSFC is licensed to provide temporarily shelter care services up to 10 days to children. Currently, the TSFC shelters twenty children: sixteen females and four males. Physical Plant: LPA Ruacho conducted a tour in and outside of the facility with Tim Stevens. The areas inspected were Unit A and Unit C. Other areas inspected were the Recreation area, kitchen, cafeteria, pantry, patio and playground areas, garden, computer room, offices containing the children and staff files, and the intake area. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. The facility has a working telephone that is accessible to clients and staff. All passageways and grounds were free of any obstructions. The medications and cleaning solutions were locked inside the cabinets in separate storage rooms. Food is safe and of the quality and quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. There is perishable food enough for 3 days and non-perishable foods enough for client's consumption for more than a week.

Annual continuation... Disinfectants and other toxic materials are kept locked in the hallway closet. Sharps and knives are inaccessible to children. Temperatures in all rooms occupied by children are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures registered at 114 degrees (F). The fire extinguishers all throughout the facility are fully charged. LPA Ruacho was not able to test the smoke detectors due to the design of the equipment did not allow it. The facility has a centralized fire sprinkler system. For this review, three female clients and 2 male client files were selected for the sample to assess the level of care and services they receive. The inspection will continue a different day. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the Program Director.

(Continued...) Program Director stated he was unaware of any major issues reported to him by any staff concerning C1 and C2 and was unaware of any serious issues between C1 and C2. Program Director said that the children at the facility do play with each other and a staff is always present. LPA spoke with C1 on May 31, 2023 but C1 said they were tired and declined to speak. Multiple phone attempts on June 1, 2023 and June 6, 2023 were unsuccessful, as LPA could not get in contact with C1 again. LPA was unable to ascertain which staff were present during the alleged incident, or other pertinent information to investigate. It is determined that there is not sufficient evidence to prove or disprove the allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this complaint. The report was given to Timothy Stevens-Human Services Program Director . Exit interview conducted.
investigation_findings: 13On June 16, 2023 at (&&&&&) Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced visit to deliver investigative findings for a complaint involving C1 (see confidential names list, LIC 811). LPA met with Timothy Stevens-Human Services Program Director. On March 6, 2023, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program received a complaint with the above mentioned allegation. Confidential interviews were attempted with Program DIrector (HSPD) on March 9, 2023, attempted interview with C1 on May 31, 2023, June 1, 2023 and June 7 2023, and interview with reporting party on March 9, 2023. Interview with Program Director on March 9, 2023 yielded information that C1 was no longer at the facility and was unsure where C1 was currently living. (Continued...)

narrative:
On July 19th, 2023, at 10:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho, conducted an unannounced Annual Continuation Inspection at A. Miriam Jamison Children's Center Transitional Shelter Foster Care (TSFC) and met with Program Specialist Andrea Hawk. LPA used the CARE TOOL that was provide online from the California Department of Social Services (CDSS) website to complete this years annual inspection. During the inspection Client and Personnel files were provided upon request. LPA continued to inspect the following files: CLIENT RECORDS LPA Ruacho reviewed five (5) client records. Client records contained: placement agreement specifying that the child's placement shall not exceed ten(10) calendar days; history of previous placement/living arrangement and reason for removal from each placement/living arrangement; medical/dental consent; body sheet/health assessment; weight record; signed personal rights; and inventory of clients' personal property and valuables. The facility was found to be in compliance with the children files. STAFF RECORDS LPA reviewed five (5) personnel records. Personnel records contain current CPR/First Aid certificates and documentation of education, qualifications and training received by personnel. Files contained Criminal Record Statements, Mandated Reporter, Health Physical and TB test. A review of Licensing Information System (LIS) on today's date indicates that all employees have criminal record clearance. The facility was found to be in compliance with the personnel files.

PERSONAL RIGHTS Facility posts child's personal rights. Clients live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home. ADMINISTRATION Facility's Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan is current and available for review. Facility operates within license capacity and limitations. OVERSTAY REPORTS Facility submits to the Department initial and weekly overstay reports after a child’s placement reaches the 10-day limit. The facility has three county vehicles at all times to transport clients. The vehicles are registered to Kern County and have active insurance policies. Maintenance and service on the vehicles is provided and monitored by the county. LPA observed the vehicles to be safe and in good condition. An exit interview was conducted. LPA provided the Program Specialist above a signed copy this report along with the LIC 811 reports. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of this inspection.

On August 15th, 2023, at 12:15PM an unannounced Case Management was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho at the above facility. LPA met with Tim Stevens, Administrator. The purpose of this inspection was to review the facility's incident reports. During today's inspection, LPA discussed and reviewed two (2) special incident reports (SIRs) that were reported late to the department. LPA observed two of the incidents concerning C1, C2 and C3. (See LIC 811 Confidential Names List). The incidents were documented properly but not submitted within the required time frame. Licensee disclosed new procedures to LPA that will ensure on time reporting for all future SIRs. Procedures will be emailed to LPA in order to clear plan of correction. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, Section 80061 (b) Reporting Requirements. Record review reveals facility failed to notify the Department of two (2) incidents within the agency's next business day as required. A signed copy of this report was provided to the Administrator along with the LIC 811, LIC 809D, and the appeal rights were given and explained.

deficiencies.description:
80061 (b) Reporting Requirements. Upon the occurrence, of specified events, reports shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day. In addition, written reports shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days of event.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview and record review facility failed to notify
the Department of the incidents within the
agency's next business day as required which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Admisitrator will email LPA new procdures that have been put in place to ensure on time reporting. Email will also included staff training along with dates and names of attendees.

narrative: It was alleged that facility staff did not provide adequate supervision, resulting in minors engaging in inappropriate behaviors. Staff (S1, S2) denied the alleged allegation, indicating that clients are supervised adequately by staff by maintaining and adhering to the Interim Licensing Standard of staff to clients ratio of 1:4, or more depending on the needs of the facility. Staff indicated that due to the layout of the facility, anytime a client is in their room, a staff member will be posted in the hallway to ensure clients are safe and remain in their assigned rooms. Staff further stated that the alleged incident was never reported to staff nor did the client (C1) stay long enough to make it past intake, due to C1 AWOling while going through the intake process. Staff indicated that all incidents are reported promptly to the appropriate agencies. Information obtained from CSW, and SSW indicated that C1 never remained at the facility long enough to be processed and would AWOL shortly after being dropped off at the facility. Furthermore, information obtained by SSW from C1 was vague and didn’t coincide with what was originally reported by C1 providing several different versions of the incident. CSW and SSW disclosed that C1 has a history of fabricating stories to manipulate circumstances to benefit her or the situation they are in. CSW indicated that they have no concerns to the care and supervision the facility staff is providing, and that staff keeps exceptional communication with them. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with Mr. Sutton.
investigation_findings: 13On December 19, 2023, at 11:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney conducted a complaint inspection to the above Facility and met with the Facility Counselor Everett Sutton to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegation. On August 3, 2023, the California Department of Social Services Community Care Licensing Division received a complaint from the Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) with the following allegation(s): Minors in care engaged in an inappropriate interaction. The investigation of the above allegation(s) was conducted by LPA Moroney, and it consisted of but was not limited to a review of records, including the client's needs and services plans, medical records, and interviews with one staff members S1 on 9/26/23, CSW on 10/10/23, the SSW on 10/27/23. No statement was obtained from client C1 due to being AOL at the time of the attempted interview. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated December 20, 2023).

narrative: On February 12th, 2024, at 1:45 PM an unannounced Case Management was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho at the above facility. LPA met with Andrea Hawk, Program Specialist. The purpose of this inspection was to review the facility's incident reports. During today's inspection, LPA discussed and reviewed three (3) special incident reports (SIRs) that were reported late to the department. LPA observed three incidents concerning C1, C2 and C3. (See LIC 811 Confidential Names List 02/12/24). The incidents were documented properly but not submitted within the required time frame due to technical issues when Manger logged off from outlook. The manager had pressed send on the emails containing the SIRs and closed the application before they could be sent. When the Manager returned from vacation and opened Outlook, emails were being sent to the department automatically causing them to be late. Facility was given a Technical Violation (TV) of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, Section 80061 (b) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was provided to the Program Specialist.

On February 12th, 2024 at 2:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Andrea Hawk, Program Specialist (PS). The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department which stated a client (C1) was sexually assaulted by another client (C2) in the facility. (See confidential name list LIC 811 dated February 12th, 2024). During the visit LPA conducted in person interviews with PS and C1. LPA also took a tour of the facility to see the unit C1 and C2 reside in. LPA needs to conduct additional interviews and document review for this incident. No deficiency citation was issued during today’s inspection. Further follow-up is required. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Program Specialist .

On February 26th, 2024, at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility above and met with Tim Stevens, Administrator. The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department which stated a client (C1) was sexually assaulted by another client (C2) (See confidential name list LIC 811 dated 2/26/24). Per the SIR, C1 stated to a staff member that a couple months prior C2 sexually assaulted C1. No specifics were given to staff at the time. LPA Ashley Ruacho conducted interviews with Program Specialist (PS) and C1 on 2/12/24, staff (S1) and the County Social Worker (CSW) on 2/20/24. LPA was unable to interview C2 due to the client leaving the facility unauthorized and has not yet returned. Interviews and documents revealed that the incident did not take place on facility grounds but at a Mental health center prior to placement. C1 is being provided mental health services and awaiting placement elsewhere. Based on information provided in interviews LPA observed that the incident was not a result of lack of supervision. No deficiency citation was issued during today’s inspection. No further follow-up is required. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

On April 17th, 2024, at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility above and met with the Administrator, Tim Stevens. The purpose of the case management was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department which stated a client (C1) picked up a rock and threatened staff (S1) and resulted into S1 pushing the rock out of C1’s hand (See confidential name list LIC 811 dated April 17th, 2024). Per the SIR, C1 picked up a big rock the size of a small soccer ball. C1 stated to S1 they were going to smack S2 if they got close. S1 asked if C1 was going to throw the rock at them and C1 stated maybe. When C1 turned towards the street, S1 pushed the rock out of their hand. LPA Ashley Ruacho conducted interviews with S1 and S2. LPA was unable to interview CSW and C1 due to the client leaving the facility. Interviews and documents revealed that the incident did take place however during staff interviews it was disclosed that staff did implement de-escalation techniques and provided LPA which techniques were used. When C1 turned away that is when S1 pushed the rock out of their hand due to safety concerns. C1 was offered mental health services and medical although there were no injuries from the incident. Based on information provided in interviews LPA observed that the incident was not a personal rights violation. No deficiency citation was issued during today’s inspection. No further follow-up is required. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

On June 19, 2024, at 3:28 p.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) John Bonilla and Dawn Mahecha conducted a Proof of Correction (POC) inspection at the above mentioned facility. LPAs met with Tim Stevens, Program Director. On June 19, 2024, the facility was issued a deficiency for having two uncleared staff (See LIC811 Confidential Names list dated 6/19/24) on their roster. Program Director escorted both staff members off facility grounds during the course of this inspection. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report and POC Certification letter were provided to Program Director.

On June 19, 2024, at 8:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Dawn Mahecha and John Bonilla conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs met with Andrea Hawk, Program Specialist. The Kern County Department of Human Services (DHS) owns and operates A. Miriam Jamison Children’s Center Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). The TSFC is licensed to provide temporary shelter care services up to 10 days to children. Currently, the TSFC shelters five children: three females and two males. Physical Plant: LPA Mahecha and Bonilla conducted a tour in and outside of the facility with program specialist. The areas inspected were Unit A and Unit C. Other areas inspected were the recreation area, kitchen, cafeteria, pantry, patio and playground areas, garden, computer room, offices containing the children and staff files, and the intake area. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. The facility has a working telephone that is accessible to clients and staff. All passageways and grounds were free of any obstructions. The medications and cleaning solutions were locked inside the cabinets in separate storage rooms. Food is safe and of the quality and quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. LPAs obtained copies of current public health review. There is perishable food enough for 3 days and non-perishable foods enough for client's consumption for more than a week. Disinfectants and other toxic materials are kept locked in the hallway closet. Sharps and knives are inaccessible to children. Temperatures in all rooms occupied by children are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures for occupied area of unit C were un-measurable at sinks for both the girls and boys designated areas. LPAs requested a log measuring temperatures to be submitted to overseeing analyst. Continued on next page.

Water temperatures were tested in intake area and both showers, baths and sinks measured within the required 105 to 120 degree Fahrenheit. The fire extinguishers all throughout the facility are fully charged and due for scheduled maintenance July 2024. LPAs Mahecha and Bonilla were not able to test the smoke detectors due to the design of the equipment not allowing it. The facility has a centralized fire sprinkler system. LPAs obtained a copy of fire inspection and testing that was completed 5/5/2022. Program Director provided corrected deficiency letter to LPAs. For this review, LPAs reviewed three (3) female clients and two (2) male client files that were selected for the sample to assess the level of care and services they receive. CLIENT RECORDS LPAs reviewed five (5) client records. Client records contained: placement agreement specifying that the child's placement shall not exceed ten(10) calendar days; history of previous placement/living arrangement and reason for removal from each placement/living arrangement; medical/dental consent; body sheet/health assessment; weight record; signed personal rights; and inventory of clients' personal property and valuables. The facility was found to be in compliance with the children files. STAFF RECORDS LPAs reviewed five (5) personnel records. Personnel records contained documentation of education, qualifications and training received by personnel. Files also contained Criminal Record Statements, Health Physical and TB test results. 3 of 5 files (S3 & S4) (See LIC811 Confidential Names list dated 6/19/24) did not contain current CPR/first aid training. 1 of 5 files (S2) did not have a signed copy of employee rights page LIC9052 or Statement Acknowledging Requirement to Report Child Abuse LIC9108. A review of Licensing Information System (LIS) on today's date indicated that two employees (S6 & S7) did not have criminal record clearance. The TSFC was cited for two deficiencies and issued an advisory notice during this inspection. Refer to LIC809-D and LIC9102-TA. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights provided. A signed copy of this report, LIC811, LIC809-D, & LIC9102-TA were provided to Andrea Hawk. This is an amendment of a report originally delivered on June 19, 2024.

deficiencies.description:
80019 Criminal Record Clearance (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2)Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department...
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above due to the following reasons: 2 Facility Staff (S6 & S7) are not cleared and associated to the TSFC. This poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff identified were immediately removed from facility. Staff will be refingerprinted and associated to facility before return to work. Proof of clearance and association to TSFC will be emailed to LPA as soon as possible, before employee returns to facility.

deficiencies.description: 80075 Health Related Services (f)	Staff responsible for providing direct care and supervision shall receive training in first aid from persons qualified by agencies including but not limited to the American Red Cross. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above due to the following reasons: 2 Facility Staff (S3 & S4) did not have proof of current first aid/CPR training in their files. This poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will ensure staff have required first aid/CPR training. Licensee will provide proof of completed training for the two staff identified to LPA via email by POC due date.

narrative: On July 5, 2024, at 11:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced inspection at A. Miriam Jamison Children's Center, a Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) for the purpose of delivering an amended report of an annual inspection delivered on June 19, 2024. LPA met with Andrea Hawk, Program Specialist. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report and and amended LIC809 were provided to Andrea Hawk, Program Specialist. Appeal rights provided and explained.

On 12/06/2024 at 11:50 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility and met with Tim Stevens, Program Director. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a case management follow up on the incident that occurred 12/2/2024 at 1:53 pm C Unit at the facility. The Incident Report submitted to the CCL stated that during the routine room search in C1's (see the LIC811 list of confidential names) room, staff S1 (see LIC811) found a gun frame in the first top drawer of the dresser under the two items of clothing. S1 reported it to the unit lead S2 (LIC811), who reported it to the acting group counselor lead S3. After the item was found, further search of the room was conducted and no further contraband was found. Staff S3 notified Program Director Tim Stevens about the firearm and S3 was advised to contact KCSO to have them pick it up. KCSO was contacted and CHP officer arrived and confiscated the firearm frame. C1 was brought to Jamison following a police chase, where he fled the vehicle with others. CHP reported C1 was searched by at least two officers before bringing him to Jamison and found nothing. Upon release from Jamison to his family, C1 informed Lead Staff S4, that when he came in he had the item tucked into his armpit area under the jacket. CHP responded and took the item and they declined the interview or see the child at that time, pending their investigation. LPA spoke with the Program Director and it was stated by the the Program Director that the child was brought to the facility by the sheriff's after the armed robbery and the high speed car chase: the sheriff did the transfer of custody to Jamison, because C1 parents were unable to pick him up at that time. Law enforcement officers stated they did search the child and did not find any contraband. At Jamison the staff does not pat the children down, and the C1 was asked to lift his shirt at the time of admission and nothing has been found. C1 was given clothes to change and while changing C1 transferred the frame from the old clothes to the new one during the shower time.

The reason why staff did the room search of C1, because C1 could not find his retainer, and staff was looking through C1 items to find the retainer. That is when the frame was found and the lead staff and program director was notified, and the law enforcement was called to confiscate the contraband. The facility found to be in compliance and no violations have been found. No deficiencies cited at this time. The copy of this report and the LIC811 (List of Confidential names) were e-mailed to the Program Director.

met_with: Tim Stevens, Program Director Andrea Hawk, Program Specialist
narrative: On 12/6/2024 at 1:40 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted unannounced case management inspection at the above facility. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct the follow up on the incident report occurred on 11/15/2024 and involved manual one person restraint. On that day C1 (See LIC 811 List of Confidential Names) )was placed in one man standing restraint for 3 minutes, and one person restraint on his bed, which lasted for about one minute. LPA requested and was provided with the Plan of Operation Emergency Intervention Plan, Managing Aggressive Behavior (MAB) Participant's Manual and the Certificates for the Emergency Intervention (Staff is trained in Managing Aggressive Behavior and ProAct). EIP does state that the facility utilizes one person standing hold restraint and one person sitting restraint. LPA asked additional questions to the S1 and S1 stated he was called to assist with the child and at the time of restraint the lead staff S2 was present as well as the behavioral therapist, who was at the facility at that time. The S2 and the therapist followed C1 and S1 to the room when the second restraint was done. So the C1 was observed during the restraint. This is not mentioned in the SIR. The Program Director will amend it and will send a new SIR with additional information. The one person manual restraint is approved by the facility's Emergency Intervention Plan and was done in compliance with another person observing C1 during the restraint. No violations has been found, no deficiencies has been cited. The copy of this report and LIC 811 was given to the Program Director.

met_with: Tim Stevens, Program Director Lito Murillo, Director of Human Services Kern County, Maria Bermudez,Assistant Director Child Welfare Services Bureau, Andrea Hawk, Program Specialit
narrative:
On 04/02/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Tira Logan-Shanks conducted a virtual meeting via Teams with the facility’s Program Director Tim Stevens, Maria Bermudez, Assistant Director, Director of Human Services of the Kern County Lito Murillo, and Andrea Hawk, Program Specialist. The reason for the meeting was to follow up on the Security Restraint Protocols that facility had in place. On 03/11/2025 the Department received a Special Incident Report (SIR), which stated that one of the clients was restraint by security due to the client posing danger to the themselves, other clients in care and the staff. After reviewing the SIR, LPA also reviewed the Emergency Intervention Plan for the facility and have not observed the protocols for the facility to utilize security personnel to conduct restraints as a part of the facility EIP. Following the review, LPA requested information from the Program Director on the security restraint protocols and the documentation or record of the procedure approval by the licensing. Program Director sent the security restraint protocols that facility had in place to the LPA. The facility had no record of the protocols being approved by the Licensing. LPA also reviewed Field Automated System and the facility folder and have not located any approval information for the protocols. The Licensing had a concern that utilizing security to conduct restraints on the clients does not meet the emergency intervention training for staff required by the licensing, nor they have a criminal record clearance from the Department. Therefore, they do not meet the qualifications of staff to provide care and supervision, which include de-escalation and restraints. The SIRs state security was contacted, and a restraint was used, there is no identifying information for security staff involved. if there was an incident that rose to the level of action needed by Department, CCLD would be concerned since the security staff does not meet all of the above mentioned criteria.

During the meeting, LPM inquired about the role of the security in the facility. Mr. Morillo stated that security is provided on all locations that county oversee to ensure of staff and clients safety due to clients of the facility having complex behavioral, emotional and psychological issues. They oversee the grounds and the perimeter of the facility as well as assist when people enter the facility utilizing safety protocols. They also assist with the contraband searches on the premises as needed. Assistant Director also added that security staff, which is provided by the third party Trans West Security, mostly utilized for the assistance with the security purposes if clients become escalated and the restraint procedures were not intended to be a regular practice. The procedures were intended to be a last resort to prevent serious injury for the staff and clients. Since Licensing contacted the facility about the security restraint protocols, all the operations and restraints by security were suspended by the facility and the facility has been in discussion on the adjustment of the protocols. Today the facility also having a higher level management meeting on further planning and implementing of the protocols to meet licensing requirements and ensure of the safety of staff and clients. Facility also conducting an internal review to follow up on the incident and discuss with the staff involved and staff present at the time incident occurred. LPM also mentioned if the facility would like to utilize security staff to assist wit the restraints protocols, the security personnel will have to meet the CCLD requirements for emergency intervention protocols (fingerprinting and training). The only personnel who would be exempt from the CCLD requirements would be a sworn peace officers. Facility also inquired about the use of metal detectors and if any other counties were using the metal detectors and LPM stated that that is not approved by CCLD at this time due to the procedure being a personal rights violation and would be considered as an unreasonable search. LPA will follow up with the facility once facility completes their review and assessment of current policies and procedures. No citations were issued at this time. The copy of this report was provided via e-mail to all the parties who took a part in this meeting. The signature for the facility will be provided on the hard copy to the LPA.

On 06/20/25 at 8:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility and met with Tim Sevens, Program Director. The purpose of the inspection is to follow up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on 06/09/25. The incident indicated that staff S1 blocked the entrance that C1 was trying to exit (refer to Confidential Names List LIC811 dated 06/20/25). It was also later reported in the addendum that C1 attempted to run out of the area. She has previously disclosed that she wanted to leave the facility. Due to concerns about her age, behaviors and the possibility of outrunning staff, she was prevented from exiting the unit during quiet time while upset about the movie selection. C1 eventually ran outside, and, in response to physical aggression of C1 towards the staff she was placed in a one-person standing restraint. LPA Maico reviewed the SIR and the facility Runaway section of Plan of Operation. The Plan of Operation indicates that : “If the RAW child is under 12 years old and/or on Safety Level or is otherwise incapable of being in the community without supervision (i.e., "critical"), the Lead or Acting Lead Group Counselor will call and submit a MPR to the KCSO immediately. A designated staff shall follow the child. If the child is located, staff will encourage the child to return to the facility with staff. If the child continues to refuse to return to the facility, staff will call back to the facility and advise the Lead or Acting Lead Group Counselor of their location. The Lead or Acting Lead Group Counselor will then notify KCSO, provide location of the child and KCSO will assist in returning the child to the facility.” It is also in the description of personal right that the child has a right no “To not be locked in a room, building, or facility premises, unless placed in a community treatment facility.” Per Program Director there were 3 (three) other exits the client could have exited if wanted to.

The facility is being issued Technical Violation for the section 84072 (d)(23) To not be locked in any room, building, or facility premises at any time, unless the child is placed in a community treatment facility. The copy of this report, Lic 811 and LIC 9102TV and Appeal Rights were issued to the facility representative.

met_with: Andrea Hawk, Human Resources Program Specialist Hashim Boss, Youth Care Supervisor
narrative:
On July 16, 2025, at 10:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Olena Maico and Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility for the purpose of initiating an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs met with Hashim Boss, Youth care Supervisor and Andrea Hawk, Human Resources Program Specialist. The Kern County Department of Human Services (DHS) owns and operates A. Miriam Jamison Children’s Center Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). The TSFC is licensed to provide temporary shelter care services for up to 10 days to children. Currently, the TSFC shelters 15 children: 9 females and 6 males. LPA requested LIC 500 Staff Roster, Roster of Clients, Emergency Disaster plan. Physical Plant: LPAs Maico and Ruacho conducted a tour in and outside of the facility with Andrea Hawk, Human Resources Program Specialist. The areas inspected were Unit A and Unit C. Other areas inspected were the recreation area, kitchen, cafeteria, pantry, closet, patio and playground areas, garden, computer room, offices containing the children and staff files, and the intake area. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. The facility has a working telephone that is accessible to clients and staff. All passageways and grounds were free of any obstructions. The medications and cleaning solutions were locked inside the cabinets in separate storage rooms. Food is safe and of the quality and quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. LPAs observed report of current public health review. There is perishable food enough for 2 days and non-perishable foods enough for client's consumption for more than a week.

Disinfectants and other toxic materials are kept locked in the hallway closet. Sharps and knives are inaccessible to children. Temperatures in all rooms occupied by children are maintained at 73 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures for occupied area is 107 degrees F. The fire extinguishers throughout the facility are fully charged and inspected June 2025. LPAs were not able to test the smoke detectors due to the design of the equipment not allowing it. Facility posts children's personal rights, facility’s license, licensing contact information. Clients live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home. Facility's Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan available to the LPAs and was reviewed back. Facility representative updated the plan with additional information. Facility operates within license capacity and limitations. Currently the facility in the process of hiring new Program Administrator, and the facility has an interim Administrator. Facility submits to the Department initial and weekly overstay reports after a child’s placement reaches the 10-day limit. Facility also submits quarterly reports required by the regulations. The facility has county vehicles at all times to transport clients. The vehicles are registered to Kern County and have active insurance policies. Maintenance and service on the vehicles is provided and monitored by the county. LPAs observed the vehicles to be safe and in good condition. The direct care staff to client ratio at the time of inspection was 11 staff and 15 clients. A review of the monthly menu indicates that facility provides nutritious meals and snacks. For this review, LPAs reviewed 5 client files that were selected for the sample to assess the level of care and services they receive.

CLIENT RECORDS LPAs reviewed five (5) client records. Client records contained: placement agreement specifying that the child's placement shall not exceed ten(10) calendar days; history of previous placement/living arrangement and reason for removal from each placement/living arrangement; medical/dental consent; body sheet/health assessment; weight record; signed personal rights; and inventory of clients' personal property and valuables. The facility was found to be in compliance with the children files. STAFF RECORDS LPAs reviewed five (5) personnel records. Personnel records contained documentation of education, qualifications and training received by personnel. Files also contained Criminal Record Statements, Health Physical and TB test results, contain current CPR/first aid training., employee rights page LIC9052 or Statement Acknowledging Requirement to Report Child Abuse LIC9108. LPA did not observe education record for S5, CPR records for S1, S2, S5. LPA did not observe health screening for S1, S2, S4 and S5. The TSFC was cited for three deficiencies and issued an advisory notice during this inspection. Refer to LIC809-D and LIC9102-TA. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights provided.

This report is continued from the attached LIC9099. The LPA made multiple attempts to interview the FY and was unsuccessful. The LPA reviewed Serious Incident Reports and found several altercations involving the FY, some where the FY was the aggressor. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated.

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that C2 was being bullied by other clients in the facility, however, C2 is placed in the under-five cottage. Additional information indicated that no one witnessed C2 being bullied by older clients. Confidential interviews revealed inconsistency as to whether C1’s ear lobe was injured as there was no marks or abrasion on C1’s ear lobe. Confidential interviews revealed that C2 was not allowing staff to do C2’s hair. Additional information revealed that staff would try to do C2’s hair after C2 bathed. Confidential interviews revealed that staff denies clients and biological parents phone calls. Additional information revealed that staff do not deny clients to make calls or receive calls from the biological parents. Confidential interviews revealed that staff attempt to call the clients when the clients have a phone call, however, clients may decline the call due to activities. Confidential interviews revealed inconsistency as to whether C3 was threatened to sleep outside if C3 did not follow staff directions after a behavior outburst. Based on confidential interviews and file review, the allegations that staff failed to protect C2 from being bullied by other children, C1 sustained unexplained injury to C1’s ear, C2 grooming needs are not being met, staff denied client’s request to make phone calls, and staff threatened C3 in care may have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to PSPM Durning for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

deficiencies.description:
84665.5(b)(1)(B) STAFF RATIOS During the hours of 7am to 10pm: When there are two to four children present at the facility, there shall be at least two awake and on duty direct care staff present at the facility.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on, interviews and record reviews: Multiple staff deficiencies identified during the hours of 7am to 10pm within the 7/7/2019 – 7/9/2019 and 7/12/2020 – 8/8/2020 timeframe.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will transition 14 on call staff to permanent staff and will hire 15 additional on call staff, 5 residential supervisors, and 1 duty officer to prevent further staffing deficiencies. The licensee will provide the LPA with verification of hire and proof that staffing ratios for all shifts were met from 11/8/2020 - 11/21/2020.

narrative: confidential information, C1 was attempting to use drugs while sitting on a picnic table and became physically aggressive towards S1 when approached by staff in an effort to retrieve the drugs from C1. According to confidential interviews, restraint was necessary due to C1’s aggressive behavior and threat to staff’s physical safety. Confidential information received stated that restraint was done according to protocol and that no new injuries were observed on C1 as a result of the restraint. While other confidential information obtained by Licensing office stated that allegation had occurred, and that C1 was unnecessarily restrained in an aggressive manner by S1 and S2 when C1 had not yet posed any physical threat to staff or others. Confidential information received also stated that C1 had re-injured some pre-existing scarring as a result of restraint. LPA Mena also spoke to County Social Worker who stated that they had no concerns regarding this incident nor C1’s level of care while placed at this facility. Based on interviews and record reviews, the allegation that facility staff mishandled client in care, more specifically that Staff # 1 (S1) and Staff # 2 (S2) inappropriately restrained Child #1 (C1), may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed for signatures. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

Personal Rights: (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child.. is accorded the personal rights as specified in Welfare and Institutions code Section 16001.9 as applicable. 

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential witness statements and record review the facility did not ensure  C1 was able to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable… treated with respect which posed a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Admisitrator stated that during the monthly training bitting protocals and what to look for will be reviewed with all staff members.  ADM will provide LPA with copy of training log by POC date of 5/15/2021.

narrative: A second allegation was also received on December 10, 2020 alleging staff (unknown) threatened minor (C1). Specifically, it was reported that unknown staff threaten C1 by saying “if you tell anyone, I will call someone to kill you.” Confidential interviews provided vague descriptive details of the staff member who allegedly threatened C1. Confidential interviews provided a possible timeline of when alleged incident occurred which revealed no staff member matching the vague description. Record review was unable to confirm or dispute the incident occurred leading to the alleged threats. CCL received an additional allegation that staff (unknown) interfered with minor’s phone calls. Specifically, it was reported telephone calls between C1 and C1’s Biological Mother (BM) always got cut short by the staff. Confidential interviews reported staff would end the supervised telephone calls between C1 and BM when BM would ask for details on how C1 was doing. Confidential interviews could not provide information as to when or which staff were supervising the telephone calls. Record review could not confirm or dispute that calls were cut short. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations of staff sexually abused minor (Child #1 (C1), staff threatened minor (C1), and staff interfered with minor’s (C1) phone calls, may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided along with appeal rights to A. B. Jessie Polinsky Children’s Center Program Manager Elizabeth Rosas.

narrative: On 12/15/2020, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations that S1 inappropriately restrained C1 and C1 sustained injuries while in care. Confidential interviews revealed that there are inconsistencies to whether S1 sat on C1 or fell on C1 while trying to intervene between C1 and C2 altercation. Additional information received revealed that no staff witnessed S1 sitting on C1. Confidential interviews indicated that staff had witnessed S1 tripped on C1 and fell on C1 while trying to intervene. Additional information revealed that there was not a witness to S1 restraining C1. Additional information revealed that there were no injuries noted and C1 refused medical attention. Based on confidential interviews and file review, the allegations that S1 inappropriately restrained C1 and C1 sustained injuries while in care may have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and an electronic copy of this report was emailed to PSPM Rosas for review and signature. The original signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

narrative: On 02/02/2021, the Department received allegations that staff used inappropriate form of discipline on C1 and staff do not allow C1 to speak with their biological parent. It was alleged that staff would discipline C1 by leaving C1 outside in the cold. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 is disciplined by removing privileges such as use of the game room, and early bedtime. Confidential interviews did not reveal C1 being left outside in the cold was a form of discipline used by staff. There are no witness to C1 being left outside in the cold. Confidential interviews revealed that there are phone hours for outgoing and incoming phone calls. Additional information revealed that phone calls are only denied when court ordered. There are no witness to C1 being denied to speak with C1’s biological parent. Based on confidential interviews and file review, the allegations that that staff uses inappropriate form of discipline on C1 and staff do not allow C1 to speak with their biological parent may have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, appeal rights and LIC 811 was given to PSPM Rogers.
