narrative:
On August 3, 2021 at 11:15 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez, Danielle Garcia and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced inspection. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia and LPM Valenzuela met with Protective Service Program Manager (PSPM) Elizabeth Rosas. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct an annual required for the Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). The TSCF has a capacity of 204 clients, mixed gender, ages 0-17 years of age. This program provides emergency shelter care for San Diego County. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, LPM Valenzuela and PSPM Rosas inspected the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility has administrative offices, reception, intake, medical, seven cottages, gymnasium, and cafeteria. The facility is set up as follows: The administrative building has staff offices, intake office, reception area, visitation area and medical clinic. The clients’ files are kept behind the reception area. The medication is kept in the medical clinic in lock cabinets. Fire alarms are wired, smoke detectors throughout the cottages and administrative building. The facility’s last fire drill was on 07/13/2021. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, and LPM Valenzuela inspected cottage B with PSPM Rosas. The water temperature measured at 111 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Meza -Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the cottage to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. See page 2.

LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, and LPM Valenzuela inspected cottage C with PSPM Rosas. The water temperature was measured at 116 degrees F. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. The cottage had a kitchen where snacks are stored. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the cottage to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, and LPM Valenzuela inspected cottage D with PSPM Rosas. The water temperature was measured at 116 degrees F. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. The cottage had a kitchen where snacks are stored. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the cottage to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, and LPM Valenzuela inspected cottage E with PSPM Rosas. The water temperature was measured at 118 degrees F. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. The cottage had a kitchen where snacks are stored. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, and LPM Valenzuela inspected cottage F with PSPM Rosas. The water temperature was measured at 105 degrees F. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. The cottage had a kitchen where snacks are stored. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, and LPM Valenzuela inspected cottage G with PSPM Rosas. The water temperature was measured at 113 degrees F. LPA Meza- Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. The cottage had a kitchen where snacks are stored. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, and LPM Valenzuela inspected cottage H with PSPM Rosas. The water temperature was measured at 109 degrees F. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. The cottage had a kitchen where snacks are stored. Each cottage has a communal area, kitchen, laundry room, staff office, bathrooms and bedrooms. The clients’ personal rights are posted in each cottage. See page 3

The gymnasium has a recreation room and an art room. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed in the pool area, a wrought iron fence at least six feet high that surrounds the entire pool area with a lock on the gate that is inaccessible to clients, per PSPM Rosas all cottage supervisors have keys to access pool. Cafeteria prepares all meals and menu posted. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed sufficient perishable and non-perishable food. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed all areas inspected in the cafeteria to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. Deputy Director (DD) Norma Rincon provide LPA Meza-Gonzalez with a project management report for the facility for a renovation of the entire facility as it was delayed due to COVID-19 pandemic. Based on observations made during the inspection, the facility meets California Code of Regulations, Title 22. The annual inspection is being extended due to insufficient time to complete staff and clients’ files reviews. An exit interview conducted, and a copy of this report along with will be provided to PSPM Rosas.

narrative:
On May 24, 2021, an office conference was held virtually with A.B. Polinsky Children’s Center Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) via MS Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In attendance were: Regional Manager (RM) Lacresha Cook, Licensing Program Managers (LPMs) Stephanie Hudak and Ann Valenzuela, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez; TSCF Representatives, Deputy Director (DD) Norma Rincon, Protective Service Program Managers (PSPM) Elizabeth Rosas, Alicia Rogers, Lerone Jenkins, and System of Care Manager (SCM) Marjana Jackson. The following issues were discussed:  Complaints  Reporting Requirements  Emergency Intervention Plan  Overstays During the meeting, LPM Hudak discussed increase of complaints at TSCF in the last three years. In 2019 there were 23 complaints, in 2020 there were 26 complaints and as of May 24, 2021 there are 20 complaints. The majority of the complaints have to do with supervision and personal rights such as unexplained injuries on foster youth, inappropriate interaction with foster youth, handling foster youth in rough manner, and lack of intervening between foster youth. DD Rincon was given the opportunity to speak regarding the increase of complaints. DD Rincon stated that they have noticed the increase of complaints as well. She stated over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic things have changed. DD Rincon stated that service providers had stopped coming for foster youth with high behavior needs, new staff, and the census was in the 90s. She said that they have started to look to bring in services that will help address all the issues for the increase of complaints. DD stated they are in the process of procuring a contract that will assist Nurture Heart Program with behavior modification for foster youth with high behavior issues. DD Rincon stated that the plan for staffing is for staff to take refresher courses and immediately train new staff on the interventions. She said that they are working on partnering with community services, enlisting help to locate advocates to help support their CSEC population, establishing a mentor program, and offer enrichment for therapy program through San Diego Probation Department. See page 2

LPM Hudak discussed reporting requirements in terms of receiving Special Incident Reports (SIRs) untimely. She said the Department is receiving the 24-hour notification however the Department is receiving the full detailed SIRs between three weeks to four weeks late. LPM Hudak explained that it is important to receive the SIR timely as the Regional Office also has time frames to report to CCL Program Office of arrests, injuries, etc. DD Rincon stated that they sat down as a team to discuss the SIRs, to hold staff and managers accountable, to allow staff to step away after the incident has been dealt with to write up the SIR and for the TSCF CCL liaison to follow up within 24 to 48 hours to ensure the SIR is submitted timely. She stated that they discuss with new staff the importance of SIRs, weekly SIRs, documentation training, and 1:1 SIR coaching. DD Rincon stated they have a couple of social workers that have re-assigned to help process SIRs. LPM Hudak discussed emergency intervention plan. LPM Hudak asked if the facility reviews restraint SIRs and PSPM Jenkins said yes. PSPM Jenkins stated they debrief with staff on what went well, what worked and what did not work. He said they look at training for refresher courses. DD Rincon stated that they have Proact training every month for new staff and refresher for ongoing staff every year. She said new staff attend Proact immediately upon hire. DD Rincon said that the contracted support staff attends Proact training. LPM Hudak discussed overstay reports. LPM Hudak stated she reviewed the last quarterly report and there were 29 children with over 10 day overstays. DD Rincon discussed strategies for the 10 days overstays. She said they are utilizing ILT processes in which Child Welfare Director, Judge, Deputy Director, Education, Probation, and the Regional Center come together to discuss barriers to placement. DD Rincon said that they discuss how to reduce the length of stay and how-to bring change of placement. When asked about placing out of county, DD Rincon stated that reason foster youth are not placed out of county is due to court order, legal reasons, visitations, and lack of placement. LPM Hudak informed DD Rincon that there are newly licensed out of county placement that boarder San Diego and Riverside in Murrieta and Temecula. LPM Hudak asked if they utilized Resource Foster Agencies that take Intellectual delayed foster youth and DD said yes. LPM Hudak asked if they are utilizing Polinsky’s Nest homes and they said due to the COVID-19 pandemic they placed themselves on a voluntary hold, and subsequently there is a reduction of NEST beds available. LPM Hudak requested that in the 10 day overstay reports to include details and dates of the delay in placement process. DD Rincon stated the facility has weekly managers meetings to discuss all the concerns LPM Hudak had discussed in the meeting. In lieu of the issues presented during this meeting, the TSCF is being required to submit a Corrective Action Plan (CAP) detailing the following: 1) How the facility is working on reducing complaints, 2) ensuring Title 22 reporting requirements are met; 3) staffing training plan to include, supervision, and emergency interventions; and 4) providing more details on the overstay reports on the progress of placement. The CAP will be due 30 days from the date of this report. All recommendations/suggestions and requirements given during the meeting by both CCL and TSCF were acknowledged. It was also suggested that Polinsky incorporate these types of changes in their Plan of Operation/Program Statement and submit the changes to the Department for review. See page 3.

In closing, all parties were satisfied with all information that was discussed during the meeting. CCL will follow-up with the TSCF in 30 days. A copy of this report reviewed and emailed to with PSPM Rosas. Original signature will be placed in file.

outdoor area, as children hid from staff. The STRTP is being issued a citation for violations of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Section 87078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. deficiencies.description:
Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision 
The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs 
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Confidential interviews and information obtained by LPAs Mena and Meza corroborated allegation that C1, C2 and C3 had engaged in inappropriate sexualized behaviors, including kissing, touching and oral sex on the night of February 09, 2021.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Protective Services Program Manager states that since the date of this incident new lighting has been installed in the outdoor area and staff also now have flashlights, and that ongoing training regarding supervision is provided to all new and current staff.

narrative: On 07/29/2021, Community Care Licensing received allegations that minors are using drugs while in care, staff are mishandling minors while in care and staff allow inappropriate sexual interactions while in care. Confidential interviews revealed that clients did use marijuana while in care and staff try to retrieve the contraband from the clients, but staff cannot physically take it from the clients. Other confidential interviews gave conflicting statements where the clients smoke the marijuana some individuals stated outside of the cottage and some individuals said that they smoke inside of the cottage. Due to not all clients being interviewed it is unknown of all circumstances involving the clients smoking marijuana. Confidential interviews revealed that no one has witnessed staff mishandle minors, however they have witnessed staff putting clients in restraints. Staff are trained in PRO-ACT and trained to restrain minors as last resort to prevent harm to themselves or others in care. Other confidential interviews revealed that staff may not be conducting restraints correctly. Confidential interviews revealed that no one has witnessed clients have inappropriate sexual interactions but have heard rumors of sexual activity or kissing. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute that staff is mishandling minors while in care and that staff allow inappropriate sexual interactions while in care. Based on interviews conducted and evidence gathered during the investigation, the allegations that staff is mishandling minors while in care and staff allow inappropriate sexual interactions while in care may have occurred, however is not supported, or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were reviewed and explained to Administrator Elizabeth Rosas.

narrative: On 2/23/2022 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility. LPA Meza-Gonzalez entered the facility through a Pavilion and met with Duty Office (DO) Stephanie Bailey at 9:15 AM. At 9:00 AM, LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed C1 waiting outside the main door of the facility with no staff around. Another staff arrived as LPA Meza-Gonzalez was engaged in a conversation with C1. LPA Meza-Gonzalez contacted Program Protective Program Manager (PSPM) Alicia Rogers regarding C1. PSPM Rogers stated she will contact the duty officer to inquired. LPA Meza-Gonzalez asked DO Bailey why can’t C1 come inside the facility and was told that C1 has a placement. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 had arrived shortly before 9am and the clerical contacted staff. Additional information revealed that C1 was getting aggressive and kicking the door while waiting for the duty officer to arrive. The SG directed visitors to another door while SG waiting for staff to arrive. Additional information revealed that at no time did staff prevented C1 from entering the facility. The facility is issued a technical violation, LIC 9102, for the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Continuing Requirements ) 84072 (d) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and LIC 811 was given to Protective Service Program Manager Elizabeth Rosas.

narrative:
On February 8, 2022, the California Department of Social Services’ (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) conducted a virtual meeting with the County of San Diego Health and Human Services Agency regarding its temporary shelter care facility, A.B Jessie Polinsky Children's Center (Polinsky). The meeting was facilitated by CCLD Deputy Director Kevin Gaines via the Microsoft TEAMs platform, to discuss the licensing violations contained in the letter that CCLD issued to the County dated January 21, 2022. Participants in the meeting included: CCLD representatives: Deputy Director Kevin Gaines, Program Administrator Jean Chen, Assistant Program Administrator Kimberly Taylor, Riverside Regional Manager LaCresha Cook, Staff Services Manager II Marisa Sanchez CDSS’ Children and Family Services Division (CFSD) representative: Deputy Director Angie Schwartz, System of Care Branch Chief Sara Rogers Child Welfare Services County of San Diego Health and Human Services Agency representatives: Director Kimberly Giardina, Assistant Director Alfredo Guardado, Deputy Director Norma Rincon, Policy Analyst Vilma Martinez-Vallecula, Policy Manager Antonia Torres The purpose of the meeting was to discuss Polinksy’s noncompliance with the temporary shelter care facility requirements provided in Health and Safety Code section 1530.8 and the Temporary Shelter Care Facility Interim Licensing Standards. Discussion included San Diego’s plan to correct the violations and CFSD technical assistance opportunities.

CDSS will further consider San Diego’s plan of correction and will schedule another meeting with the County to discuss any proposed modifications to the plan or further technical assistance that can be provided by CDSS. A copy of this report was electronically sent to Norma Rincon. The signed copy will be retained in CCLD’s Polinsky facility file.

On 10/21/2021 the Department received allegations that S2 kicked C1 in the head, S1 and S2 inappropriately restrained C1, C1 sustained injuries while in care, and staff did not intervene during an altercation. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was not kicked in the head by staff and thereby C1 did not sustain head injuries while in care. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements that S1 kicked C1 in the stomach and S1 did not kick C1; however there was no witness to the incident. Confidential interviews revealed inconsistency to whether C1 sustain injuries while in care as C1 did not report any injuries of the day of the incident. Additional interviews indicated that S2 redirected C1 to go into C1’s room and C1 had refused directives from staff. In addition, the interviews indicated that S1 and S2 did not enter C1’s room and there were no witnesses that saw S1 and S2 entering C1’s room where the inappropriately restraint of C1 was alleged. Furthermore, the confidential interviews could not determine if the alleged restraint took place on the floor or the bed in C1’s room. Additional interviews revealed that S3 had intervened when C1 was trying to kick S2 when C1 refused to return to C1’s room. . Based on confidential interviews the allegations S1 and S2 inappropriately handled a minor while in care, S1 and S2 engaged into physical altercations with the minors while in care may or may not have occurred, however the allegation is not supported or proven by the evidence gathered. Therefore, the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, and appeal rights were provided to PSPM Elizabeth Rosas.

narrative:
On April 28, 2022, at 10:00 AM, an office conference was held virtually with A.B. Polinsky Children’s Center Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) via Microsoft Teams. In attendance were: Regional Manager (RM) Lacresha Cook, Licensing Program Managers (LPM) Ann Valenzuela, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez; TSCF Representatives, Assistant Director Child Welfare (ADCWS) Alfredo Guardado, Deputy Director (DD) Norma Rincon, Protective Service Program Managers (PSPM) Elizabeth Rosas, Alicia Rogers, Lerone Jenkins, System of Care Manager (SCM) Marjana Jackson and System of Care Policy Analyst Gina Jones. The following issues were discussed: · Number of complaints since the last informal conference on May 24, 2021 · Staff Supervision · Youth sustaining injuries while in care · Absent without approved leave (AWOLs) · Minors smoking on grounds · Allegations of staff inappropriately handling youth · Allegations of staff not intervening during altercations · Law Enforcement Special Incident Reports During the meeting, LPM Valenzuela discussed the increase of complaints at TSCF in the last year. The last informal conference was on May 24, 2021, there were 41 complaints with multiple allegations. The department has received 23 complaints regarding staff causing harm or verbally to minors in care, 18 complaints about lack of supervision, 7 complaints of minors sustaining unexplained injuries/bruises while in care, and three complaints dealing with access to drugs and alcohol. DD Rincon was given the opportunity to speak regarding the increase in complaints. DD Rincon stated that they have noticed the increase in complaints as well. She stated a lot of the complaints are related to the increase of high-needs youth that entered TSCF and due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the County has had a lack of community resources that include foster caregivers, changes in the juvenile justice system which led to youth at TSCF’s staying a longer period of time. DD Rincon stated that pre-pandemic the TSCF used to have one to three high needs youths however during the last year in months, December to March, the facility had a lot of high needs youth more than the TSCF has seen before due to the COVID-19 pandemic. She stated that she has noticed the pandemic is on the downward trend and they noticed that a lot of the high needs youths that are making a lot of the allegations are being placed in appropriate settings. DD Rincon stated that a lot of the same youth were also AWOLing from the facility and since those youth were no longer in placement; the AWOLs have decreased. She said that currently, the TSCF has five youth that has been identified as high needs. DD Rincon stated that they are working on finding placements for the five youths. See LIC809c page 2

DD Rincon stated the challenges the TSCF had because of the pandemic from December 3, 2021, through the beginning of April 2022 was that they were in outbreak status which resulted in 120 positives in the TSCF which included both youth and staff being sick. During that time, they were unable to place a lot of the youths. DD Rincon reported that some of the things they started to work on are doing some additional staff training, they have implemented some Lived experience coaching and services through South Bay Community Services Center which is an achievement center that provides support services and social support to the youths. DD Rincon stated they have partnered with San Diego Probation to access services in which the youth will receive therapeutic services, coaching and mentoring from people with Lived experience, and outings that are all trauma-informed. TSCF supervisors and managers are being provided with additional training using appropriate engagement models and have partnered with Just In Time which is a community-based organization. Just In Time has provided some training on youth engagement. All the managers, supervisors, and staff have participated in the training. DD Rincon stated that PSPM Jenkins is in charge of the Nurtured Heart Program and has also incorporated monthly Nurtured Heart training for all the staff. He has focused the training within the cottages because traditionally the staff is assigned to the same cottage who work with high-needs youth. For the younger youth, they have the developmental screening program through Rady’s hospital that has returned to campus since the pandemic; and provides specialized training to staff for those youth with developmental delays. DD Rincon stated they have completed refresher training regarding the SIRs. They have implemented learning circles in which they pick certain topics to educate the supervisors so they can be better equipped to support the staff on the floor. TSCF utilizes ProACT and has done some advanced training with all the duty officers on campus so the duty officers can be better equipped to support the staff on campus. DD Rincon reported they are focusing on the de-escalation techniques of the Enhanced ProACT Model so they can help support the high-needs youth. She stated they are looking into other models that are being utilized from other programs to see what type of de-escalation techniques they use to see if it’s anything they want to incorporate into the TSCF program. DD Rincon stated they have been doing the ProACT model and the Nurtured Heart Program and have found them to be effective, however, they are looking into exploring other models to assist in supporting the staff. They have engaged in assistance with a Safety Consultant referred by another county that utilizes another model called the CARE model. Which is a model that creates a team of responders when a crisis starts to happen and responds to the situation as it is happening. DD Rincon stated they have also put out a proposal to enhance the TSCF mental health services. She stated they are changing the model to have rehabilitation staff that is specially trained in crisis intervention that will be assigned to the cottages in addition to mental health one on one and group settings to serve the needs of the youth. Psycho-educational groups would be provided for substance abuse, vaping, and CSEC youth as well as AWOLing youth once the program is in effect. See LIC809c Page 3

DD Rincon stated that another challenge was during the last 6 months, November 2021 through March 2022, the facility had to bring in additional temporary staffing to maintain the staff-to-client ratios. She stated the staff was not their permanent staff as they had to rely on temporary staff such as Protective Service Workers. She stated that permanent staff has been returning to work and being trained, and as a result AWOLs have reduced over the last month, SIRs have been on a downward trend, placements of high needs youth are happening, and using the State Technical Assistance calls have also helped the program. RM Cook reviewed the AB388 unit’s incident reports and concerns. Angela King is the Licensing Program Manager for the Law Enforcement (LE) incident reports. LPM King sent information regarding LE incident reports. RM Cook stated that there has been a total of 329 LE incident reports this year, from January 1, 2022, through April 25, 2022. 304 incident reports were AWOLs, 11 incident reports were assaults and/or physical aggressions, 9 incident reports were harm to self and/or psychological and 5 incident reports were behavior and/or property damage. She stated the TSCF uses its own reports however some questions are not being answered when completing the incident reports such as: Was the escort or restraint documented in the youth’s restraint log? Was the restraint incident debriefed? The reports do not mention the type of debriefing or describe the type of the debriefs after the incident. Were de-escalation techniques utilized before contacting law enforcement? RM Cook also advised of incomplete incident reports where the “prepared by” and “approved by” sections were not always filled out and youth race and ethnicity are not always consistently documented in the SIR. DD Rincon addressed the concerns regarding the incident reports. She stated that PSPM Rosas oversees the incident reports and recently started reviewing all the incident reports so it is not just the supervisors and line staff therefore PSPM will be paying attention to those details as well as identifying some of the training needs for the staff on campus. LPA Meza-Gonzalez mentioned the AWOLs occurring at the back fence and youth bringing in contraband on campuses such as vape pens and alcohol through the back fence and hiding it in the bushes on campus and/or the youth hiding the contraband on their person. DD Rincon stated the Safety Consultant provided ideas to help minimize contraband from coming on campus by adding additional security, adding additional security cameras around the perimeter of the campus as well as the cameras being monitored 24 hours in real-time by a posted person. The San Diego Sheriff Department had done an assessment of the facility. DD Rincon stated the facility is in the process of installing some anti-climbing fences. On February 14, 2022, the facility began renovations in which the campus will be renovated and installing the security features such as the cameras. DD Rincon stated they are trying to be trauma-informed in the security measures. They have a proposal in procurement with new policies and procedures that are being reviewed by San Diego County leadership. Perimeter checks are being completed by Duty officers and bushes are being removed and replaced with grass. See LIC 809 C page 4

LPM Valenzuela will follow up and send information regarding the cameras. RM Cook stated when facility policies are changed and/or initiated the facility Program Statement needs to be updated and in compliance with regulations. Due to technical difficulties at the end of the meeting, the virtual meeting dropped via Microsoft Teams connection. DD Rincon contacted LPA Meza-Gonzalez to complete the meeting via the telephone with LPM Valenzuela. DD Rincon stated that the facility is also working with the youth’s attorney to provide additional support. An email was forwarded to DD Rincon and PSPM Rosas from LPM Valenzuela with an attachment entitled Family Finding Resource from the System of Care Branch Manager (SCM) Marjana Jackson. The facility has agreed to the following: 1) An updated Program Statement that incorporates the new training and models the facility will utilize for de-escalation techniques will be submitted to CCL by the end of July 2022. 2) Ensuring Title 22 reporting requirements are met including Law Enforcement Contact Review Unit recommendations for SIRs. 3) PSPM Rosas will send information regarding the installation and use of cameras to LPA Meza-Gonzalez by May 15, 2022. A copy of this report was reviewed and emailed to PSPM Rosas. The original signature will be placed in the file.

On July 21, 2021, the Department received allegations that the staff does not ensure the clients are properly fed while in care, the facility is operating out of ratio, staff did not safeguard a C1's personal belongings, and staff does not provide an appropriate sleeping arrangement for a minor while in care. Confidential interviews revealed that on a couple of occasions the food was undercooked however it was brought to the attention of the cafeteria staff, and the food was replaced. On August 3, 2021, LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed in the cafeteria seven days of non-perishable food and two days of perishable food. Confidential information revealed inconsistencies in the staff ratio to clients. It’s alleged that there is insufficient staffing in the cottages when staff is assigned one-to-one supervision however the duty officer and supervisors are counted as part of the ratio to clients. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 did have a Nintendo Switch as part of C1’s inventory however C1 chose not to keep it in the safe for safeguarding, and the Nintendo Switch was stolen. C1 signed an electronic device agreement in which it states that the clients are responsible for their devices if lost or stolen if they choose not to store them in the safe. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was assigned to a cottage that was not the gender C1 identified. Additional interviews revealed that C1 identified with both genders. Additional interviews revealed inconsistencies to whether C1 asked to move to the gender cottage with which C1 identified. Based on confidential interviews the allegations staff does not ensure the clients are properly fed while in care, the facility is operating out of ratio, staff did not safeguard a C1's personal belongings, and staff does not provide an appropriate sleeping arrangement for a minor while in care may or may not have occurred, however, the allegation is not supported or proven by the evidence gathered. Therefore, the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to PSPM Rogers due to technical difficulties with the printer.

investigation_findings: 13On March 5, 2021, at 9:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced tele-inspection, via Microsoft Teams, of the facility due to COVID 19. LPA met with Pablo Cerda, Administrator, to deliver and discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. On November 3, 2020, LPA initiated the complaint investigation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed three of five clients (C1, C2, C3), please refer to confidential names list (LIC 811) dated March 5, 2021, one of one staff, and Special Incident Reports (SIRs). On October 29, 2020, the Department received an allegation that C1 was harassed by other youths in the facility; youths intimidate C1, youths make sexual comments to C1 and youths steal C1’s money. Confidential interviews and documents reviewed indicated that C1 began AWOLing 14 days after placement with other youth in the facility and continued to get into mischief with them throughout C1’s placement. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was not bullied, but the youths were older than C1 and it took some time for C1 to befriend the older youths. CONTINUED ON PAGE 2.

narrative: facility staff. According to confidential interviews, first incident occurred after Staff # 6 (S6) received a text message during the night shift from S1 asking for S6’s assistance in getting up from C1’s bed, this after C1 had apparently fallen asleep on top of S1’s arm. According to confidential interviews, second occasion was said to have occurred on the date that C1 was to leave the facility. According to confidential information, incident occurred in the early morning when Staff # 3 (S3) discovered S1 laying in C1’s bed and holding C1 in a “spooning” position. According to confidential interviews, during both incidents, both C1 and S1 were observed to have been fully clothed. LPA Mena spoke to C1’s County Social Worker who expressed concerns that S1 could have possibly been in the process of “grooming” C1. Based on interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that facility staff member had inappropriate interactions with youth in care, more specifically that Staff # 1 (S1) was observed to have been laying on the same bed with Child # 1 (C1) on at least two occasions is substantiated. The facility is issued a citation for S1’s inappropriate interactions with C1, posing an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to the child placed in care. These actions are in violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80072 (a)(1) See attached LIC 9099D for cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were emailed for signatures. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

On 08/19/2021 at 09:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs)Gloria Meza and LPA Danielle Garcia conducted an unannounced inspection at the Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). The purpose of this inspection is to conduct an annual inspection. LPA Meza and LPA Garcia met with Program Administrator (PA) Pablo Cerda and Social Worker Supervisor II I(SWS) Alma Garcia. The TSCF has a capacity of 30 clients, mixed gender, ages 0-17 years of age. This program provides emergency shelter for the Imperial County. There currently are ten children in care. LPA Meza, LA Garcia, SWS Garcia and PA Cerda inspected the interior and exterior of the facility at 10:30 AM. The facility is a one-story building. LPA Meza and LPA Garcia observed the following: There are five staff offices, a medical office, storage closets for cleaning supplies and personal protective equipment (PPE)s. The client records are kept in a lock cabinet in the lock control center. LPA Meza reviewed ten client files. LPA Meza observed the client files to complete and in order. LPA Garcia interviewed five clients (see Confidential Name List, LIC 811: dated 08/19/2021). The Medication Administration Records (MARs) are kept in the medical office. LPA Meza reviewed MARs. LPA Meza observed the facility using the correct MARs, LIC 622A and LIC 622B, and Centrally stored and destruction record, LIC622 are complete and in order. Staff files are kept in the administrator office in a lock cabinet. LPA Meza reviewed nine staff files. LPA Meza observed the staff files to complete and in order. The medication is locked in a cabinet in the locked medical office. There is a communal area is a sitting area. LPA Meza and LPA Garcia observed two age appropriate play areas. There are four closets and the honor room, in the communal area. Closet #1 is points room/prize room. Closet #2 has arts and crafts. Closet #3 has hygiene products and age appropriate shoes. Closet #4 has school supplies, prizes, extra toys for the children and the honor room. The honor room has a TV, video games and couch. See page 2.

The boys’ dorm, ages 6-17 years old, has five rooms with two twin beds in each room and one room with a single twin bed. Each room has plenty of closet and storage space. The hot water in the boys’ bathroom measured at 109 degrees Fahrenheit in which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regulation 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Each bed had proper bedding and linen. In the boys’ hallway there is a locked janitor’s room, staff office/supplies room, a room for age appropriate clothing and a file/storage room. The girls’ dorm, ages 6-17 years old, has six rooms with two twin beds in each room and one room with a single twin bed. The hot water in the girls’ bathroom measured at 105 degrees Fahrenheit which is within CCL Regulations of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit . Each bed had proper bedding and linen. In the girls’ hallway there is a storage closet, electrical room, and a room for appropriate clothing. The facility has a library with age appropriate books. The facility has a room used for visitation, staff training, arts/crafts and COVID-19 isolation. The room has a storage closet two beds, a crib, and a bathroom. LPA Meza observed two nurseries for children ages 0-5. In nursery #1 there is five cribs and one toddler beds and one changing table. The facility is currently not using nursery #2. The hot water in the nurseries measured at 105 degrees Fahrenheit in which is within CCL Regulations of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The nurseries are stocked with age appropriate diapers and hygiene products. The room next to the nursery #1 has stores clothing, hygiene products and diapers. The laundry room stores additional car seats for children ages 0-8 years old and additional clothing for the nursery. The laundry room has two washers and two dryers. The kitchen has seven days of non-perishable and three days of perishable food. Menus and daily activities are posted. The smoke detectors are hardwired throughout the facility. The facility last fire drill was held on 08/19/21 at 10:40 AM. The carbon monoxide was checked and operable. The facility appeared clean, sanitary and in good repair. The entire facility has central heating and air-conditioning. The clients’ personal rights and the Office of the ombudsman information is posted by entrance to the cafeteria. The facility’s physical plant meets the minimum requirements of Title 22 regulations. This annual inspection will be extended to conduct staff interviews. An exit interview conducted; a copy of this report was given to PA Cerda.

On August 26, 2021 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection. LPA Meza-Gonzalez with Program Administrator (PA) Pablo Cerda. The purpose of this inspection is to complete the annual inspection from 08/19/2021 for the Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). TSCF has a capacity of 30 clients, mixed gender, ages 0-17 years of age. This program provides emergency shelter care for Imperial County. LPA Meza-Gonzalez interviewed four staff. Based on observations made during the inspection, the facility meets California Code of Regulations, Title 22. An exit interview conducted, and a copy of this report along with will be provided to PA Cerda.

on 1/27/2022 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Program Administrator (PA) Pablo Cerda and Program Manager (PM) Evelyn Sanchez. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a case management to issue an amended report dated 12/10/2021 An exit interview was conducted and this report was given to PA Cerda.

On 07/12/2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff did not follow emergency intervention plan resulting in Client #2 (C2) and Client #3 (C3) physically assaulting (C1). Confidential interviews revealed that C2 and C3 got into a physical altercation with C1 due to C1 leaving client #4 (C4) behind during an AWOL. Additional information revealed that staff failed to use emergency intervention to separate C2 and C3 from physically assaulting C1; staff did not conduct a manual restraint when C2 was demonstrating a level of danger. Based on confidential interviews and documentation reviewed the allegations that C2 and C3 physically attacked C1 while in care is substantiated. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to clients placed in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with Title 22 regulations. Division 6, Chapter 1: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision section code 80078 (a). See page LIC809d for the cited deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights discussed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, LIC811 and appeal rights were given to the PA Cerda. ***This is an amended report***

On 07/21/2021 at 3:15 PM, LPA Carol Anderson conducted a safety inspection; and there were no safety issues observed. During the investigation, Investigator Bellucco interviewed PA, Deputy Director, SWS, Staff #1 (S1), Staff #2 (S2), Staff #3 (S3), Staff #4 (S4) and Client #1 (C1) (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 12/10/2021). Investigator Bellucco reviewed special incident reports, police report, pictures, medical reports, facility roster, staff roster, house rules, Law Enforcement contacts, daily roster, communication log, and case files. See LIC9099C for continuation

deficiencies.description:
80078(a)  - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision -The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential witness statements that staff did not follow emergency intervention plan resulting in C2 and C3 physically assualting C1 resulting in injuires.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will retrain staff involved on emergency intervention by 02/01/2022. ***This is an amended report ****

narrative: On January 20, 2022, the Department received a complaint report, with the allegation that staff did not provide a safe environment leading to Client #1 (C1) sustaining injury. Confidential interviews revealed S7 was transporting bikes out of the facility due to C1 using the bikes to be absent from care. Additional interviews revealed that C1 was upset that the bikes were being removed therefore C1 jumped on the truck while it was moving. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements that S7 ran over C1’s foot while C1 jumped on the moving truck that S7 was driving. Based on record reviews and confidential interviews, that S7 did not provide a safe environment leading to C1 sustaining injury is unsubstantiated. The details gathered for the incidents did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegations that S7 ran over C1’s foot. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted an exit interview and provided a copy of this report, appeal rights and LIC811 was given to SWS Garcia

narrative: On February 4, 2022, the Department received a complaint report, with the allegations that staff did not follow the emergency intervention plan resulting in youths engaging in a physical altercation, staff not properly supervising youths in care and the facility does not meet the C1’s hygiene needs. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements regarding staff not following the emergency intervention plan when clients have physical altercations. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements revealed that staff would let clients fight and not separate them. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements as to whether the staff is supervising the clients. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting statements that staff has not assisted C1 with C1’s hair and has prompted C1 to bathe. On the other hand, interviews revealed staff has assisted with C1’s hair and has directed C1 to bathe. Based on record reviews and confidential interviews, that staff did not follow the emergency intervention plan resulting in youths engaging in a physical altercation, staff not properly supervising youths in care and the facility does not meet the C1’s hygiene needs is unsubstantiated. The details gathered for the incidents did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegations that staff did not follow the emergency intervention plan resulting in youths engaging in a physical altercation, staff not properly supervising youths in care and the facility does not meet the C1’s hygiene needs. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted an exit interview and provided a copy of this report, appeal rights and LIC811 was given to SWS Garcia.

Confidential interviews revealed that does re-direct youth from engaging in inappropriate touching in the facility. Confidential interviews revealed inconsistency that staff did not prevent youths from physical altercations. Confidential interviews revealed that staff has had training in emergency intervention and has utilized the training when attempting to prevent youth from engaging in physical altercations. Confidential interviews revealed that staff has conducted on the outside and inside of the facility however youths hide the drugs on their person. narrative: On May 13, 2022, the Department received a complaint alleging that staff did not provide adequate supervision to minors while in care. Confidential interviews revealed inconsistency regarding staff providing adequate supervision which resulted in C1 having sexual relations with C2 while in care. It was alleged that C1 helped sneak C2 into the facility to have sexual relations in C1’s room. Confidential interviews disclosed that staff were always supervising the clients in care, therefore, C2 could not have been able to sneak into the facility without being noticed. Based on record reviews and confidential interviews, the staff did not provide adequate supervision to C1 while in care is unsubstantiated. The details gathered for the incidents did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegation. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted an exit interview and provided a copy of this report along with appeal rights to PA Sanchez.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Latricia Rogers & Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection April 6,2023 @ 11:10am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 22 Direct Care Staff and 3 discharged youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 22 Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 0 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated April 6, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the Child and Adolescent Needs and Strengths (CANS), the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Rogers observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Evelyn Sanchez- Program Manager and Renee Robles- Deputy Director

On August 31, 2023 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced inspection at Betty Jo McNeece Receiving Home. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct an annual inspection. LPA Jauregui met with Evelyn Sanchez, Administrator. The facility has a capacity of 30 clients, mixed gender, ages 0-17 years of age. This program provides emergency shelter for the Imperial County. There is currently one children in care. LPA Jauregui inspected the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility is a one-story building. LPA Jauregui observed the following: There are five staff offices, a medical office, storage closets for cleaning supplies and personal protective equipment (PPE)s. The client records are kept in a lock cabinet in locked Administrator office. LPA Jauregui reviewed one client file. LPA Jauregui observed the client file to complete and in order. The Medication Administration Records (MARs) are kept in the medical office. The medication is locked in a cabinet in the locked medical office. LPA Jauregui reviewed MARs. Staff files are kept in the administrator office in a lock cabinet. LPA Jauregui reviewed five staff files. The staff files have the acknowledgement of child abuse reporting requirements and criminal record clearances. LPA observed the following items posted by entrance of cafeteria: Clients’ personal rights and Office of the ombudsman information. LPA observed Activity Schedule and Meal Menu in the entrance hallway of the facility. Facility Sketch with Evacuation plan was posted in each section of the facility. Emergency Disaster Plan dated 3/28/23 was reviewed. The Recreational Area consists of a communal area with couches, TV, communal table with chairs, three closets, restroom, Honor Room, and a toddler play area. Closet #1 is the Point Store with age appropriate prizes. Closet #2 is the Hygiene Closet which was observed with shoes, socks and personal hygiene products. Closet #3 has school supplies, prizes, and extra toys for the children CONTINUED....

The boys’ dorm, ages 6-17 years old, has five rooms with two twin beds in each room and one room with a single twin bed. Each room has plenty of closet and storage space. The hot water in the boys’ bathroom measured at 105.2 degrees Fahrenheit in which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regulation 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Each bed had proper bedding and linen. In the boys’ hallway there is a locked janitor’s room, staff office/supplies room, a room for age appropriate clothing and a file/storage room. The girls’ dorm, ages 6-17 years old, has six rooms with two twin beds in each room and one room with a single twin bed. The hot water in the girls’ bathroom measured at 105 degrees Fahrenheit which is within CCL Regulations of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit . Each bed had proper bedding and linen. In the girls’ hallway there is a storage closet, electrical room, and a room for appropriate clothing. The facility has a library with age appropriate books. The facility has a room used for independent study, staff training, and arts/crafts. LPA Jauregui observed nursery for children ages 0-5. LPA observed 2 cribs and 4 toddler beds. All beds can be convertible crib/toddler bed. A hallway behind the nursery has a closet stocked with age appropriate diapers and hygiene products. The laundry room stores additional car seats for children ages 0-8 years old and additional clothing for the nursery. The laundry room has two washers and two dryers. LPA Jauregui observed all chemicals to be in locked cabinets. The kitchen has seven days of non-perishable and three days of perishable food. The smoke detectors are hardwired throughout the facility. Fire Extinguishers are located in each section of the facility and last inspected on 3/29/23. The facility appeared clean, sanitary and in good repair. The entire facility has central heating and air-conditioning. The facility’s physical plant meets the minimum requirements of Title 22 regulations. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Evelyn Sanchez, Administrator.

On May 8, 2023, the California Department of Social Service (CDSS) hosted a virtual meeting with the Imperial County regarding its temporary shelter care facility, Betty Jo McNeese Receiving Home (Betty Jo). The meeting was facilitated by CCLD Deputy Director Kevin Gaines via the Microsoft TEAMs platform to discuss the licensing violations contained in the letter that CCLD issued to the County dated 08/12/2022. Participants in the meeting included: CCL representatives, Program Administrator (PA) Jean Chen, Assistant Program Administrators (APAs) Kimberly Taylor and Angela Carmack, Riverside Licensing Program Managers Natasha Dunlap and Ann Valenzuela, Staff Services Manager II Marisa Sanchez CDSS’ Children and Family Services Division (CFSD) representatives: System of Care Branch Chief Sara Rogers, System of Care Health Program Specialist II (HPS) Dianna Wagner County of Imperial Child Welfare Services representatives: Deputy Director (DD) Paula Llanas, Assistant Director (AD) Iris Montes, Imperial County Department of Social Services - Children and Family Services Division Renee Robles and Tracy Shiro Consultant/Contractor (CC) for Betty Jo. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss Betty Jo’s noncompliance with the temporary shelter care facility requirements provided in Health and Safety Code Section 1530.8 and the Temporary Shelter Care Facility Interim Licensing Standards. Discussion included Imperial’s plan to correct the violations and CFSD technical assistance opportunities. *** CONTINUED ON PAGE 2***

CDSS requested a written plan of correction within 30 days, no later than June 7,2023. CDSS will further consider Imperial’s plan of correction and will schedule another meeting with the County to discuss any proposed modifications to the plan or further technical assistance that can be provided by CDSS. A copy of this report was electronically sent to Renee Robles. The signed copy will be retained in CCLD’s Betty Jo facility file.

On November 20, 2023, Imperial County submitted a revised Plan of Correction that has been accepted and no additional Plan of Correction is being requested at this time. In comparing shelter data reported by Imperial County, the year 2022 to the year 2023, there has been a decrease trend for the length of stay, total number of 10 day overstay and the total number of 30 day overstays of children in care. In an effort to continue to provide collaboration and technical assistance, System of Care and Community Care Licensing (CCL) will meet with Imperial County every quarter. A copy of this report was sent to Renee Robles. The signed copy will be retained in CCL’s Betty Jo facility file.

LPA Jauregui conducted a safety inspection of the facility with Diana Villarreal, Social Worker Supervisor I and no deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this signed report was provided to Diana Villarreal, Social Worker Supervisor I.

On 06/30/2021, starting at approximately 9 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted an on-site inspection of this facility. LPA was met by Administrators Georgeta Muresan and Elisianna Rios. The purpose of this inspection was to confirm that the Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) has been vacated of clients. LPA was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the program's physical plant--no indications of ongoing placements were observed. This TSCF side of the Children's Receiving Home of Sacramento (CRH) is closing--Community Care Licensing (CCL) was formally notified of this closure via a letter dated 06/28/2021 citing the reason for the closure as the "termination of the Emergency Shelter Care Contract by Sacramento County effective June 30, 2021." The posted licenses were surrendered to this LPA. A closure plan was also obtained by this LPA. No citations were issued as a result of this inspection. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill, Levi Huser, AGPA, and Alicia Bernstein, Manager, System of Care Branch, Provider Policy Implementation Unit met with Georgeta Mureson, Administrator, and Glynis Butler-Stone, CEO, to discuss the review of the application for Temporary Shelter Care Facility.. LPA Hill provided the agency with a copy of the review tool that gave the facility a list of the items to review and agreed that the revisions will be provided by August 27, 2024. In the interim that the agency is working on their revisions, Systems of Care Branch will provide their written review. LPA Hill also noted that the Pre-Licensing Inspection and Component III could be conducted once all parties agree. Exit interview conducted and documentation was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced prelicensing inspection on 9/13/24 and met with Glynis Butler-Stone, Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Georgeta Muresan, Administrator, and Samantha Escamilla, Administrator designee. LPA Hill toured the facility inside and out. LPA Hill observed that one of the buildings being used for the operation of the Temporary Shelter Care Facility intake. This building will not house clients but will be used strictly for visitations, intake and other administrative functions. LPA Hill toured the facility's two dorms, Oaks and Willows, and observed that each of the dorms are set up to house five clients in single occupancy rooms but there is adequate space in each of the bedrooms to place sibling sets should that be a need. Total capacity of the facility shall not exceed ten. LPA Hill observed that fire extinguishers were last inspected on July 11, 2024. Carbon monoxide detectors were present in all of the dorms, including intake, also called the Acorns building and were functioning. The agency has a sprinkler system so there are no smoke detectors to be checked. Each dorm had two toilets and two showers for the clients to be served. LPA Hill observed that the dorms were stocked with appropriate beds and bedding including mattress covers, fitted sheets, top sheets, and blankets. LPA Hill also observed that there are dressers and closet space in the bedrooms. LPA Hill observed closets stocked with additional mattress covers, sheets, blankets, and towels. LPA Hill also observed a hygiene closet in each dorm with hygiene items accessible to clients in care. In each dorm LPA Hill also observed staff offices that will remain locked and inaccessible to clients in care. Each of the staff offices has filing cabinets that lock and first aid kits that have all of the required items. LPA Hill did advise that the dorms have their own thermometers as these are usually in the clinic. LPA Hill observed a staff restroom equipped with a toilet, sink, paper towels, and soap. LPA Hill also observed that the fire extinguisher is on the wall in the staff restroom.

LPA Hill reviewed that the program statement addresses that medications are to be kept in the clinic and clients in need of medication administration will go to the clinic at designated times for their medications. LPA Hill observed that each of the dorms had postings of Personal Rights, Complaint Posters with Community Care Licensing Division's complaint hotline, and Grievance Policy and forms are accessible at all times for clients in care. LPA Hill observed that the Oaks dorm water temperature measured 119 degrees Fahrenheit and the Willows dorm water temperature measured 117 degrees Fahrenheit. The toilets were functioning as were the showers in each of the dorms. There is a door to the bathroom but it is not a locking door. The toilets have individual stalls and doors. The showers have shower curtains. There is a dining area for the youth in care where there are eight chairs and the facility will stagger dining times to accommodate youth in care should the dorm be at capacity. There is a kitchenette that is to have a refrigerator, microwave, and sink for the clients in care. There will also be a television mounted on the wall in the dining area. This room will also serve as the activity area should there be a need for additional space outside of the dorm areas. LPA Hill observed that the agency is ready for licensure but did inform the agency that a final review of the licensing application is required prior to issuing the license. LPA Hill advised that the agency will receive a letter of approval of the application, Program Statement and Plan of Operation. End of documentation.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara made an unannounced case management inspection on 12/19/24 at 10:30 AM and met with Georgeta Muresan, Administrator, to discuss an incident report. LPA Hill met with Ms. Muresan to discuss an incident regarding a youth, C1 (see LIC811 dated 12/19/24), indicating that facility staff neglected to pick C1 up from school due to a scheduling conflict. LPA Hill discussed with Ms. Muresan that youth transportation is required and since this incident, the facility staff have been counseled by the administrator to ensure that transportation is reviewed for discrepancy or assessment of additional transporters by Supervisors on Duty at the beginning of the day. If additional transporters are needed to provide the required transportation, the agency will assign additional staff to transport or pick up children as needed. Ms. Muresan states the agency works diligently with supervisors and staff to ensure client needs are communicated clearly to responsible staff within the agency. LPA Hill provided the agency with a Technical Violation for transportation. In addition to discussing the incident report, LPA Hill discussed overstay reports with the agency and when they need to be submitted to the Department in addition to ensuring that the daily rosters are kept and available to the Department upon request. LPA Hill requested that the agency provide the overstay report for the two clients in care who have been in care beyond the required 10 days. End of documentation.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced post licensing inspection on 2/21/25 at 11:45 am and met with Georgeta Muresan, Administrator, who assisted in the inspection. LPA Hill toured the physical plant of the facility, inside and outside, and observed that the facility was clean and sanitary. LPA Hill observe that there were two youth present in the facility during the inspection. Youth in care have their own bedrooms and there is a restroom in the building with dual showers and dual toilets and three sinks for youth to use. Youth had all the required storage and equipment in their rooms and all required postings were observed in the dorm. LPA Hill observed that the facility does have a dining area in the facility and food is taken to the dorms for the youth during meal times. LPA Hill reviewed one client file during the inspection on this date and did interview one youth about their stay in the facility. LPA Hill interviewed one staff during the inspection. During the review of C1's (see LIC811 dated 2/21/25) file and observed that youth was admitted on 11/16/24. LPA Hill discussed with the agency's active efforts for placement of C1 since C1 has been in the facility three months. LPA Hill observed the file contains weekly Individual Service Plans since C1's admission LPA Hill discussed C1's medications and did observe that the facility is administering psychotropic medications to C1 but does not have the necessary JV220 series documentation for the administration of these medications. C1 originally was a private placement but there was no active effort in obtaining written authorization for the administration of medications. LPA Hill observed the agency did place a call to check on the status of the JV220 as that process has been initiated by the agency. LPA Hill provided a Technical Violation as the facility is required to work with the County on obtaining the required documentation for the administration of medications as soon as a child is admitted if this applies. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Muresan and documentation provided, including the LIC9102TV.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 2/21/25 at 11:45 am and met with Georgeta Muresan, Administrator, who assisted in the inspection. LPA Hill discussed multiple incident reports with Ms. Muresan as follows: 2/16/25 incident involving C1 (see LIC811 dated 2/21/25) detailing that S1 allowed C1 to go through their phone and showed C1 photos in their phone and taking photos or videos of C1 on their phone. LPA Hill interviewed C1 and S1 during the inspection. S1 denies taking photos or videos of C1 and denies allowing C1 to see photos on their phone. LPA Hill reminded staff about confidentiality of youth in care. There is no additional investigation needed at this time. 2/18/25 incident indicating that C2 was being medically neglected in the facility. During discussion about this incident, it was revealed that C2 never informed the facility that they were having active medical issues nor was the agency aware that C2 had a medical issue that needed attention until 2/18/25 when the social worker informed the agency of the need. C2 did see a medical professional on 2/20/25 and services were initiated to obtain the necessary medical attention needed. LPA Hill reminded the staff about discussing all medical need and histories with youth in care so as to be able to manage the needs of youth placed at the facility. No additional investigation is needed at this time. 2/19/25 incident indicating that C1 made a spontaneous utterance in the dorm about S1 and S2 hitting C1 as C1 walked past them in the dorm. During an interview with C1, they indicated that they were just playing and denies staff hit them. Cameras were reviewed by the administrator which failed to show C1 being hit. In addition, LPA Hill interviewed S1 and S2 who denied ever hitting C1. There is no additional investigation needed at this time. End of documentation and exit interview conducted with Ms. Muresan.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted a case management inspection at the facility on 5/1/25 and met with Georgeta Muresan, Administrator, and Aleksei De Santiago, Administrator in Training. LPA Hill conducted the inspection to discuss an incident report dated 4/17/25 which details that C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/1/25) was shocked when trying to use an outlet in their room to plug in or unplug a charging base for the cell phone. LPA Hill toured C1's bedroom and observed several bases plugged into the outlets and several items seemed to be charging and the outlets seemed to be working. LPA Hill observed that the outlets did not appear to be loose or indented or otherwise have any issues. LPA Hill questioned about C1 going to the doctor and LPA was informed that C1 was offered medical services but denied them stating they were okay. The agency did have their Facility Maintenance Manager come to the dorm and check the outlets and it was reported there were no issues. The agency reported that the base C1 was using was replaced with a new one to ensure there were no future issues. LPA Hill conducted and exit interview and documentation was provided.

Camera footage review of the incident indicates that S2 moved from the common area to the staff office and C1 also moved themselves and their chair closer to the staff door. S1 responded at the staff office door and appeared to ask that C1 move the chair back and themselves back to the table where C1 was seated prior. S1 then attempted to close the staff door but C1, being seated outside the staff door, extended their leg, preventing the door from closing. S1 then raised their own foot in an effort to move C1's leg and when that did not work, S1 moved C1's leg with their hand and closed the staff door. During the camera footage review, it was acknowledged by the administrator and administrator in training, that there did not appear to be any reason for S1 to have placed hands on C1 as it did not appear that C1 was exhibiting any behaviors that warranted S1 to make physical contact with C1. As a result of the investigation conducted including camera footage review and interviews conducted, the allegation that staff handled minor in a rough manner is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. Facility was cited for violation of the Interim Licensing Standards section WIC 16001.9(a) Personal Rights as youth have a right to be free of any actions of a punitive nature while in care. C1 was not exhibiting any behavior that posed a danger to themselves or others when S1 placed their foot and/or hand on C1 which is punitive. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Muresan and Mr. DeSantiago and documentation, along with appeal rights, were provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted a complaint inspection on 7/3/25 at 10:15 AM and met with Georgeta Muresan & Aleksei DeSantiago to deliver findings on the complaint allegations as stated. deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. Youth have a right to be free of any actions of a punitive nature. This was not met as evidenced by Based on investigation including review of camera footage and interviews conducted, staff redirected youth's foot out of the way, making physical contact when not necessary, to allow the staff office door to close which is a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The agency conducted a Supervision Note with staff regarding this interaction on 6/24/25 which includes additional training. Proof of additional information regarding the emergency intervention training shall be provided to LPA by end of business 7/10/25.

narrative: Youth are able to have these plates of food any time between those hours but at 10:00 PM, they only offer youth snack items or fruit if they express that they are hungry. This policy has been vetted in the facility's program statement and approved by the Department. During the alleged incident, youth was offered the snack and fruit but refused. Youth was offered food and refused and as a result, the allegation that youth was denied access to food is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The allegation that staff mishandled a minor's personal belongings is related to C1's planarians which are free-living flatworms that, depending on the specific species, can be hazardous to humans. C1 was in possession of a small tank containing these planarians when they arrived at the facility but claimed they were not dangerous. C1 was told they could not bring them into the dorm and they needed to be stored outdoors. C1 explained that the planarians would die if they got too warm, even if still in water. Agency policy is to not allow pets or other critters into the dorm as they could be harmful to youth in care. C1 brought the small tank into their room and was keeping the small tank in their personal belongings without staff knowledge. Agency staff stated that upon finding out the tank was in client's bedroom, did not force C1 to then put it back outside and did attempt to educate themselves on the planarians. As a result of the investigation, the allegation that staff mishandled C1's personal belongings is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted and document was provided to the facility, along with appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced complaint inspection on DATE at TIME and met with Aleksei DeSantiago, Administrator in Training, and Georgeta Muresan, Administrator, to deliver findings for the allegations stated. LPA Hill informed agency staff that the investigation included an initial inspection conducted on 6/24/25 where documentation was obtained regarding clients in care, staff roster and client roster and a subsequent inspection was conducted on 7/7/25 where staff and clients were interviewed. The allegation that staff denied a minor from accessing food is related to youth asking for a full meal plate of food after bedtime. Confidential interviews were conducted with youth and staff and revealed that it is agency policy to only give youth fruit or snack items past their bedtime. Staff indicate that meals are sent to the dorms by the kitchen staff and typically they get two to four additional plates of food, depending on the number of youth in care, for when youth get hungry between dinner time and bedtime.

narrative: privacy when they observed youth was talking on the phone. Youth did not take the call into their room for privacy and instead continued their call in the main room of the dorm where all individuals present could hear. C1 made no effort to be discrete during their phone call. The allegation related to staff behavior poses as a risk to a minor is related to S1 and C1 having a conversation during which C1 made comments to S1 about their lack of qualifications and experience. S1 disengaged in the initial conversation. When C1 went to their room, S1 went into the room to check in with C1. The conversation between C1 and S1 escalated again and S1 perceived that C1 was coming after S1 in an aggressive manner. When S1 exited the room, they closed the door behind them, placing their body against the door, preventing C1 from exiting their room. S2 stepped in at that time to de-escalate the situation, requesting S1 to leave the dorm. Confidential interviews conducted failed to indicate S1's behavior posed a risk to C1 during this exchange. As a result of the interviews conducted, documents obtained, and incident reports reviewed, the allegations that staff did not afford C1 privacy and that S1's behavior posed a risk to C1 are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 7/24/25 at 9:10 AM and met with Georgeta Muresan, Administrator, and Kayla Miller, Program Manager, to discuss an incident. LPA Hill conducted the inspection to discuss an incident report dated 6/9/25 regarding a verbal confrontation between C1 and S1 (see LIC811 dated 7/24/25). During the course of a complaint investigation related to this confrontation, it came to the attention of LPA Hill that the exchange lead to S1 exiting C1's room in a hurry and closing the door behind them due to S1's perception that C1 was displaying aggressive behavior(s). S1 then placed their body against the door, preventing C1 from exiting their room. S2 stepped in upon seeing S1 holding the door closed and asked that S1 leave the dorm in an effort to de-escalate the situation. As a result of this investigation, the facility was cited for violation of Group Home Regulations Section 84072(d)(23) Personal Rights as youth have the right to not be locked in any room at any time. S1 did lock C1 in their room, while brief, it is not allowed and is a Personal Rights violation. Exit interview was conducted and documents, along with appeal rights were provided to the facility at the conclusion of the inspection.

During a review of the incidents involving youth in care, there were several incidents requiring staff verbal and/or physical interventions to keep youth separated or to redirect youth. Confidential interviews with staff and clients in care indicated that each of the youth play a part in harassing, bullying, and using racial and offensive slurs at one another since being in the facility. During one particular incident on 6/26/25, C1 did kick C2 out of frustration which lead to C2 being escalated and another youth getting involved and throwing items at C1. Confidential interviews with staff and clients indicated that all three youth have been known to behave in ways that escalate the other in care which leads to the youth yelling and screaming at one another, slinging racial slurs at one another, attempts to hit or kick one another, and even engage by throwing items at one another. Staff indicated that their intervention protocol is to get in between youth to prevent physical contact, redirecting youth outside of the dorm until things calm down, removing youth from the immediate area but that physical intervention is a last resort and used only in times when imminent danger exists. Staff interviewed indicated they have been trained in de-escalation techniques and they do utilize all avenues available to keep youth from harming others or saying awful things to one another. Staff indicated that they can typically de-escalate the youth by getting them outside of the facility to play basketball, go for a walk, or employing soothing techniques designated by their therapist. As a result of the investigation conducted including interviews with staff and clients and review of incident reports, the allegations that staff did not prevent minor from hitting another minor in care and that staff did not prevent minors from harassing another minor in care are UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted and document was provided to the facility, along with appeal rights.

The allegations that staff did not prevent minor from hitting another minor in care and that staff did not prevent minors from harrassing another minor in care is related to several incidents involving physical interactions, verbal and offensive slurs between C1, C2, and C3 (see LIC811 dated 7/17/25).
