facility_name: COUNTY OF SACRAMENTO DCFAS ELDER CREEK HOUSE
narrative: The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff did not provide adequate supervision to ensure safety of youth.” All interviewed youth admitted to being exposed to vaping and/or marijuana use in the facility. There was also substantial corroboration through obtained statements that youth were exposed to, or possibly even recruited for, CSEC (Commercially Sexually Exploited Children) activities. Staff interviewed stated they communicate with youth about safety and making healthy choices and provide harm reduction strategies when youth are determined to participate in unsafe activities. Upon observation of drug use, staff attempt to confiscate contraband and discourage the use. There was not enough evidence to clearly and directly attribute these instances to a lack of supervision on the part of facility staff. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon arrived at shelter to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 04/30/2025. During the investigation, 13 confidential interviews with youth and 8 interviews with staff were conducted between 02/06/2025 and 04/17/2025. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative:
On May 20, 2022, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray and Licensing Program Analyst Kuliema Calloway arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a PreLicensing Inspection at the Temporary Shelter Care Facility. LPA’s met with the Administrator Shona Rucker who granted access to the facility and a tour of the facility. The entire physical plant was inspected. The facility is to provide Temporary Shelter Care Services up to 10 Days to six (6) males ages 14-17 years. Ambulatory only. Currently there are no clients residing in the facility. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. There are no weapons or guns on the premises. TSCF Overview: The facility is a single-story home located in a residential neighborhood and it is set up as follows: 4 bedrooms, 2.5 bathrooms, a living room, a dining room, kitchen, managers office/therapy office and a laundry area. There is a detached garage utilized as a game room equipped with a ping pong table, foosball, basketball game, a large table, and a 55inch television mounted on the wall. The Licensee will ensure that the children are always monitored by staff when utilizing the equipment. There is one (1) facility vehicle parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. Outdoor Area: The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPAs observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves for gas and water. LPA observed all windows, screens, and cordless blinds from the inside and outside of the facility were observed to be in good condition. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan and personal rights are all posted on the wall at the entrance. Posting is also in the common area accessible to clients (i.e Personal Rights and Grievance forms, suggestion box, emergency disaster and evacuation plan). LIC809-C Page 1 of 3

The Living Room is fully furnished two (2) sofas, one (1) ceiling fan and a 55-inch television. Dining room/Kitchen: Observed to be clean and organized; The Kitchen stove is gas operated with 6 burners; separate oven and a double refrigerator. There is also an additional freezer locate located in in the game room will be utilized to food and storing medication. The dining room has s ceiling fan and area eight (8) chairs. LPA observed coverage trash cans in the kitchen, bathrooms, and staff office. The linen closet is in the hallway adjacent to the manager’s office. LPA observed three (3) Fire Extinguisher. The hot water heater located outside on the side of the house secured inside a medal cover. The cleaning supplies solutions, disinfectants, sharp knives are inaccessible stored in locked cabinet in the manager’s office. LPA observed a hard wired enter connected combined Smoke detector and Carbon Monoxide; tested to be operable. Bedrooms: There are four (4) bedrooms each bedroom twin size beds six with a mattress, clean linen, adequate closet, and drawer space. Bedroom # 1, 2 and 3 will be occupied by two (2) clients, the bedroom is equipped two (2) twin sized beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets, and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows, cordless blinds observed to be in good condition. Bedroom #4 is being utilized as the staffing office and it is equipped with a desk, a chair, and a cabinet. There are 2.5 bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean. LPA observed S1 test the water temperature, bathroom sinks and ensured that all toilets flushed. The water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Bathroom #1 one (1) tub shower and a toilet Bathroom #2 located in the near adjacent to the kitchen (shower sink and a toilet) Bathroom #3 is located outside near the conference room equipped with a sink and a toilet. There is a conference with 2 offices utilized for Department of children and Family Services and the administrator’s office. Children will enter through the driveway for intake office. The First Aid kit is in the manager office. It has the required items inside (age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. The facility has a working telephone and clients can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. Report continued on LIC809-C Page 2 of 3

Upon approval from authorized representatives the staff will accompany clients to local recreational facilities outside extracurricular activities and social events. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. LPA observed that facility ensures that CDC Guidelines are implemented in effort to prevent other from contracting the COVID-19 virus (i.e wash hands with alcohol based hand sanitizer, display colorful preventative hygiene posters, temperature checks, maintain social distancing (six feet of space), disinfect commonly used areas and items (remote controls, mouse’s, playing, cards cell phones, practice “cough etiquette”. The facility keeps an inventory of the PPE supplies and to report when they are depleted. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. The Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. LPA confirmed that Mentor/Counselors are referred from “Forever Friends” that will cleared from authorized representative (i.e Probation). The staff client ratio is 2 to 1 during peak hours. LPA confirmed that all staff have required criminal record clearance are on file which meet qualification. Staff files and records will be reviewed later. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA’s concluded the Pre-License Inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility with the Chief Program officer on 05/20/2022

On August 24, 2022, at 2:40 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Shona Rucker, who granted access to the facility and together a tour of the entire facility was conducted both inside and out. The facility is to provide Temporary Shelter Care Services for up to 10 days to six (6) male clients ages 14-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census at the time of the inspection was three (3) clients. The facility is a single-story 4 bedroom, 2 ½ bathroom home located in a residential neighborhood. The home includes a living room, a dining room, kitchen, managers office/therapy office, a laundry area, a detached garage, conference room, and backyard. The facility is set up as follows: Living room: is furnished with two (2) sofas and a television. Dining room: is furnished with a table and 8 chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with gas operated 6 burner stove, all operable at the time of this visit; double door refrigerator, microwave, and a lid covered trash can. Laundry area: is equipped with washer and dryer. Detached Garage: has been converted into a game room and is equipped with a ping pong table, basketball game, foosball, a game table, a mounted TV, video game console, and a freezer for extra food storage and medication storage. Conference room: this area has 2 rooms; one is used by the Facility Administrator and the second room is used by Department of children and Family Services Co-locator personnel. Backyard: sitting area. Bedroom #1: is furnished with two twin beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, and pillows. This room is occupied by 2 clients, and has closet space, a working light, and a window. Bedroom #2: is furnished with two twin beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, and pillows. This room is occupied by 2 clients, and has closet space, a working light, and a window. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Bedroom #3: is furnished with two twin beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, and pillows. This room is occupied by 2 clients, and has closet space, a working light, and a window. Bedroom #4: is used as the staffing office and it is equipped with a desk, chair, computer, and cabinet. Bathrooms: All bathrooms were checked and found to be in good repair and working order. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). The First Aid kit is in the staffing office and was observed to be fully equipped. The facility has a working telephone and clients can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The first aid kit is located in the staffing office and was found to be complete. The home has 3 regulation fire extinguishers. There is a working telephone readily accessible to clients. Medications not requiring refrigeration and Sharp knives are kept locked in staffing office in a locked box and made inaccessible to clients in care. Temperatures in client’s room are maintained between 68-85 degrees (F). Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There was no swimming pool or bodies of water located at the facility. The facility ensures CDC Guidelines are implemented in effort to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The facility keeps inventory of PPE supplies and replenishes supplies as needed. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The Program has a total of seventeen staff. LPA received copy of the LIC 500. LPA will return on a later date to review staff records. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst Raymond Canal conducted a case management inspection on 2/28/24 at 10:30 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 21 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 21 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 2/28/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meeting related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the Child Family Team Plan and Safety Plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Canal observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Area Manager Raven Morrow.

narrative:
On March 22, 2023, at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an announced visit at the above location, for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection for the pending licensure of Dimondale Adolescent #11 Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA met with Chief Program Officer, Theresa Foster and Facility Administrator, Shona Rucker who granted access to the facility, and provided a tour of the entire interior and exterior physical plant. This facility will be licensed to provide Temporary Shelter Care Services for up to ten (10) days for six (6) male children ages 14-17 years old, ambulatory only. Currently the census is zero (0) and there are no children residing in the facility. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. There are no weapons or guns on the premises. The facility is set up as follows: This is a two-story home located in a residential neighborhood. There are three (3) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, living room, dining room, kitchen, den/TV room, laundry area, office, an attached garage, and a backyard. LPA observed the following during the inspection: Living room: equipped with two sofas, a lamp, gas fireplace with a screen, and shelves that have board games and books. Dining Room: equipped with a wood dining table with ten (10) chairs. Kitchen: equipped with a four (4) burner gas stove, double door oven, double door refrigerator/freezer, dishwasher, microwave, a trash can with a fitted lid, and plenty of cabinet space. LPA observed the facility to have dishes, eating and cooking utensils, an adequate supply of food at the time of this inspection and the weekly sample menu was posted on the refrigerator door. Den/TV room: equipped with two sofas, a wall mounted TV, and a desk. There is also a door in this room leading to the attached garage. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 3)

Laundry area: is located in the garage and includes a washer and dryer. Office: is located on the second floor and is equipped with 3 desks, chairs, a computer, a printer, a small refrigerator for staff use, a locked filing cabinet which contains medication, knives and sharps, and files. The room also contains a bathroom and a small closet, which will be used for storage. An office door with a lock is pending to be installed. Attached Garage: was observed to be used for storage. The garage contains the laundry area and an extra refrigerator for food surplus. Backyard: contained a shed, which will be used as the therapist office. The shed was unfurnished at the time of this inspection. 3 Bedrooms: All three bedrooms are located on the second floor of the facility. LPA observed each room to have two (2) twin beds, new mattresses, clean linens, blankets, pillows, two (2) dressers, closet space, and sufficient lighting. · Bedroom # 1– located to the right of the stairs and has a window facing the backyard. There are no bars on this window. · Bedroom # 2 – located straight in front of the stairs and has a window facing the backyard. There are no bars on this window. · Bedroom # 3 – located to the left of the stairs, along the hallway, and has a window facing the front yard. This window is equipped with quick-release security bars, that was tested and found to be fully functional 3 Bathrooms: The three bathrooms were all checked and found to be clean, safe, and in working order. · Bathroom # 1– located on the first floor of the facility to the right of the entry way. It is equipped with a toilet, sink, and contains a small closet. · Bathroom # 2 – located in between Bedroom#3 and the Office. It is equipped with a toilet, sink, and shower. · Bathroom # 3 – located inside the Office. It is equipped with a toilet, sink, and a bathtub with a shower. LPA observed the home to have three (3) fire extinguishers. Smoke and Carbon Monoxide combination detectors were tested and found and to be in working order. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 2 of 3)

LPA observed the facility to have a complete First Aid Kit. All posting requirements were met and publicly posted for all clients and authorized representatives to see. The Emergency Disaster Plan, Grievance Procedures were also posted. Outdoor Area: The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. LPA observed the Administrator display where the utility shut-off valves for gas and water were located. LPA observed the downstair windows to have security bars, without quick release latches. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, The following was discussed with the facility Administrator: Children will be supervised & protected at all times. Licensee will provide and ensure three nutritious meals, snacks, and special diets. Children will be accorded personal rights. Children will be supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children will be able to contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman in confidence without threats or punishments for making complaints. Children will be accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children will not be restricted in telephone use except by court order. Licensee will ensure to have written authorization to obtain medical and dental care. Licensee will ensure to have personal rights forms in children’s files as well as the Needs and Services plan. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Staff working in the facility will have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances, and Child Abuse Index Checks. Facility will operate within license conditions & limitations including capacity limit. Facility meets posting requirements, including COVID-19 best practices signage and emergency telephone numbers are in prominent locations. The following is needed for license approval: Office door with a lock has to be fully installed. Fire inspection approval. Therapy room needs to be equipped. LPA will conduct a follow up visit once all requirements have been met. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Facility Administrator.

On November 8, 2023 at 12;12 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an unannounced visit to Dimondale Adolescent #11, for the purpose of conducting a Case Management for Special Incident Report #10-2023-34-CM-07. The incident occurred 10/30/2023 and the incident report was received by the Department on 10/31/2023. LPA met Facility Manager, LaVette McCrary and discussed the incident. During this visit, LPA conducted confidential interviews. Additional interviews will be conducted on a later date. LPA requested a copy of the following documents: LIC 500 and Staff #1’s training records and contact information. Additionally, LPA was informed Staff #1 had been suspended pending an investigation and Client #1 was discharged from the facility on 11/07/2023. Based on interviews and information gathered, this case management needs further investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Facility Manager.

On November 30, 2023, at 1:24 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a follow-up Case Management for Special Incident Report #10-2023-34-CM-07. During this visit, LPA reviewed staff records and conducted a confidential interview. Additional interviews will be conducted on a later date. Additionally, LPA was informed the internal investigation was concluded and Staff #1 did returned to work. Staff #1 was not available to be interviewed during the visit. Based on interviews and information gathered, this case management needs further investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

Based on review of documentary evidence, confidential interviews and contacts with former resident, Los Angeles County Children and Family Services and other related parties there is a lack of evidence to prove reported allegations. Information received from statements and record review revealed inconsistencies due to recantation and or resistance to provide a statement during the investigation process. Therefore, the allegation is determined Unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies per California Code of Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) cited at this time. A copy of this report was emailed to Administrator for signature.
investigation_findings: 13On February 23, 2024, at 4:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. LPA Martin met with Facility Staff and further met with Facility Administrator Janina Holt, via telephone to discuss the investigative outcome. On October 9, 2023, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received allegations of sexual abuse and exploitation towards Youth #1 (Y1) by a staff person at Dimondale Adolescent #11 as the youth was reportedly drugged, assaulted, and offered drugs by said staff member while residing at the facility. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigator Juan Lozano for assignment. On October 13, 2023, LPA Martin met with Facility Administrator, requested records and informed of the investigation. Records reviewed indicates Youth #1 resided at Dimondale Adolescent #11 in August 2023. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative:
On June 14, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) K. Ellis arrived at the above location, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA’s met with Administrator, Janina Holt granted access to the facility, and provided a tour of the entire interior and exterior physical plant. The facility is licensed to provide Temporary Shelter Care Services for up to ten (10) days for six (6) male children ages 14-17 years old, ambulatory only. Currently the census is two (2). There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. There are no weapons or guns on the premises. This is a two-story home located in a residential neighborhood. There are three (3) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, living room, dining room, kitchen, den/TV room, laundry area, office, an attached garage, and a backyard. The facility is set up as follows: Living room: equipped with two sofas, has recessed lighting, non operational gas fireplace equipped with a security screen, board games and books. Dining Room: equipped with a wood dining table with ten (10) chairs. Kitchen: equipped with gas operated four (4) burner, stand-alone double door oven, refrigerator/freezer, dishwasher, microwave, a lid covered trash can, dishes, eating and cooking utensils. Facility had adequate supply of food at the time of this inspection. LPA’s observed the weekly sample menu posted on the refrigerator. Den/TV room: equipped with two sofas, a wall mounted TV, and a desk. The room has 2 exit doors, one leads to the garage and the other to the backyard. Laundry area: is located in the garage and includes one (1) washer and one (1) dryer. Office: is located on the second floor and is equipped with desks, chairs, a computer, a printer, a small refrigerator for staff use, a locked filing cabinet. The room has a locked closet which contains medication, knives, and sharps. The room also contains a bathroom for staff use. Attached Garage: is used for storage and as the laundry area. There is also an extra refrigerator for food surplus. Backyard: contains a shed, which is used by Department of Children and Family Services Co-locator personnel. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 3)

3 bedrooms for client use: All bedrooms are located on the second floor. Each bedroom can accommodate 2 clients. Bedrooms were observed to have two (2) twin beds, clean linens, blankets, pillows, ample closet space, sufficient lighting, and windows. There are no bars on the upstairs windows. 3 Bathrooms: Bathroom # 1– located on the first floor of the facility to the right of the entry way. Bathroom # 2 – located in between Bedroom#3 and the Office. It is equipped with a toilet, sink, and shower. Bathroom # 3 – located inside the Office. It is equipped with a toilet, sink, and a bathtub with a shower. All bathrooms were all checked and found to be clean, safe, and in working order. The hot water was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). Outdoor Area: The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. LPA’s observed the downstair windows to have security bars, without quick release latches. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. LPA’s observed the home to have three (3) fully charged fire extinguishers. Smoke and Carbon Monoxide combination detectors were tested and found and to be in working order. LPA’s observed the facility to have a complete First Aid Kit. All posting requirements were met and publicly posted for all clients and authorized representatives to see. The Emergency Disaster Plan, Grievance Procedures were also posted. There is a working telephone readily accessible to clients. Medications not requiring refrigeration and sharp knives are kept locked in staffing office in a locked box and made inaccessible to clients in care. The home has central air and heat and the temperature maintained between 68-85 degrees (F); at the time of the inspection the temperature was 69 degree (F). Overall LPA’s observed the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA’s discussed the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 2 of 3).

LPA’s reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements were met and publicly posted for all clients and authorized representatives to see. Vehicle: Staff utilize six (6) passenger 2018 Ford Transit Connect to transport clients. LPA’s observed the facility vehicle to have working seat belts, horn, and lights. Vehicle has current registration through August 2024 and insurance with Nonprofits United which expires on July 1, 2024. LPA’s received copy of the LIC 500 and LIC 9020. LPA’s reviewed the following records during the inspection: Client Records: The program currently has a total of two (2) clients. LPA reviewed each client record and found each records to meet required regulations. Staff Records: The program currently has a total fifteen (15) staff. LPA reviewed a total of five (5) staff records and confirmed files contained staff qualifications, current CPR/First Aid cards, health screening, and TB test results. LPA obtained the LIC 500 to verify Staff to Client ratio. LPA reviewed the Facility Profile and Personnel Report and confirmed that personnel have required criminal record clearance: DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse; which meet qualification. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator. (Page 3 of 3).

On August 30, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) C. White and J. Armstrong made an unannounced visit to Dimondale Adolescent #11, for the purpose of conducting a Case Management on Special Incident Report #1096931 which involved a medication error. The incident occurred 08/20/2024 and the incident report was received by the Department on 08/21/2024. LPA met with Program Director/Administrator, Shona Rucker and discussed the incident. During this visit, LPA conducted a confidential interview. Additional interviews will be conducted on a later date. LPA requested a copy of the following documents: LIC 500 and Staff #1’s training record. Additionally, LPA was informed Client #1 is no longer placed at the facility. Client was discharged on 08/22/2024. Based on interviews and information gathered, this case management needs further investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Facility Manager. Program Director/Administrator.

On April 14, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Andrea Aceves and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at the above location, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Administrator, Janina Holt, who granted access to the facility and provided a tour of the entire interior and exterior physical plant. The facility is licensed to provide Temporary Shelter Care Services for up to ten (10) days for six (6) male children ages 14-17 years old, ambulatory only. Currently the census is (0). There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. There are no weapons or guns on the premises. This is a two-story home located in a residential neighborhood. There are three (3) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, living room, dining room, kitchen, TV room, laundry area, staff office, an attached garage, and a backyard a separate office for the co-located CSW personnel. The facility is set up as follows: Living room: equipped with two sofas, has recessed lighting, non-operational gas fireplace equipped with a security screen, board games and books.

Dining Room: equipped with a wood dining table with ten (10) chairs. Kitchen: equipped with gas operated four (4) burner, stand-alone double door oven which is currently not working, refrigerator/freezer, dishwasher which is not utilized per staff, microwave, a lid covered trash can, dishes, eating and cooking utensils. Facility has adequate supply of food at the time of this inspection. LPA and LPM observed the weekly sample menu posted on the refrigerator. TV room: equipped with two sofas, a wall mounted TV, and a staff desk. The room has 2 exit doors, one leads to the garage and the other to the backyard. Staff Office: is located on the second floor and is equipped with desks, chairs, a computer, a printer, a small refrigerator for staff use, a locked filing cabinet. The room has a locked closet which contains medication, knives, sharps and hygiene products. First Aid kit is kept in a locked cabinet. The room also contains a bathroom for staff use. A landline phone is available for client use. When staff office is locked, clients may use facility cell phone that staff carry with them. Attached Garage: is used for storage and as the laundry area. LPA observed one (1) washer and one (1) dryer. There is also an extra refrigerator for food surplus. Backyard: contains a shed, which is used by Department of Children and Family Services Co-locator social worker/personnel. 3 bedrooms for client use: All bedrooms are located on the second floor. Each bedroom can accommodate 2 clients. Bedrooms were observed to have two (2) twin beds, clean linens, blankets, pillows, ample closet space, sufficient lighting, and windows. There are no bars on the upstairs windows. LPA observed no window screen and dresser drawer was off its track and needs repairing in bedroom #2. Bathroom # 1– located on the first floor of the facility to the right of the entry way. Cleaning solutions were in a locked closet. Bathroom is clean and in good repair. Bathroom # 2 – located in between Bedroom#3 and the Office. It is equipped with a toilet, sink, and shower. Bathroom is clean and in good repair. Bathroom # 3 – located inside the Staff Office. It is equipped with a toilet, sink, and a bathtub with a shower. Bathroom is clean and in good repair. The hot water in bathroom #1 and #2 was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F).

Outdoor Area: The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and cleared of debris and hazards materials. The right front gate entrance is designated for DCFS personnel and handling client intake. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. LPA observed the home to have two (2) fully charged fire extinguishers. Smoke and Carbon Monoxide combination detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The following posting requirements were observed and posted in public area: The Emergency Disaster Plan, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, the facility license, the food menu, the daily activity schedule. There is a working telephone readily accessible to clients. The home has central air and heat and the temperature maintained between 68-85 degrees (F); at the time of the inspection the temperature was 69 degree (F). LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Vehicle: Staff utilize six (6) passenger 2020 Ford Transit to transport clients. LPA observed the facility vehicle to have working seat belts, horn, and lights. Vehicle has current registration through August 16, 2025 and insurance with Nonprofits United which expires on July 1, 2025. LPA received copy of the Staff and Client Roster. LPA verified that all staff on the personnel roster have a criminal record clearance. The following deficiency is being cited for violating California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 80076 (a)(21)-Food Service. (See page LIC 809d) Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
Equipment necessary for the storage, preparation and service of food shall be provided, and shall be well-maintained.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above due to the oven not being operable which poses a health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA and LPM advised staff to service the oven and to submit verification to licensing once oven is operable.

narrative:
On 06/19/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Andrea Aceves and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), arrived at the above location, for the purpose of conducting the Case Management - Annual Continuation. LPA and LPM met with the Direct Care Worker, Cranisha Clark and inquired about the current census. A copy of the Staff and Client Rosters were requested and received. LPA and LPM requested to interview all available clients and staff. Management Staff, Emily Nsubuga arrived at the facility and provided staff and client files. Client Records: The program currently has one (1) client. LPA reviewed two (2) client records that are kept electronically and found each record to meet required regulations. Client #1 was not interviewed due to his trigger of being asked questions. Staff Records: The program currently has a total seventeen (17) staff on the roster. LPA reviewed a total of three (3) staff records. LPA obtained the LIC 500 to verify Staff to Client ratio. Two staff were interviewed and LPA reviewed staff online training log via RELIAS. See LIC809C

According to regulations, The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when children are present. LPA informed staff to identify facility managers on the personnel report (LIC 500). In addition, there is a Delta T staff on premises that provides 1:1 supervision to client. LPA and LPM advised staff that any staff working with children must obtain criminal record clearance with CCL. There is currently a pending waiver request to set up a central administrative facility for criminal record associations. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

On January 15, 2021 at 2:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Emelyn Sanchez P. made an announced visit to Emergency Care Firmona for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing inspection visit. LPA Sanchez P. met with Diana Flaggs, ASM III, Contracts Administration Division and Compliance Section for Dept. of Children and Family Services(DCFS). Also present at the time of the inspection was Sabina Sayre, LCSW, Assistant Regional Administrator, DCFS Airbnb Program; Dr. Aline Smith and Mr. Robert Smith. LPA Sanchez P. toured the interior of the facility. The facility is requesting children ages 0 to 17 and Non-minor dependents, ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The census today is zero (0). LPA Sanchez P. observed the follow during the inspection: This is a one story house with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, living room, family room, staff office, dining area, kitchen/laundry area, and outdoor space. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition there is one sofa, a desk with a operating computer and a locked file cabinet. Family Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition there is one love seat and one sofa, a desk with a operating computer, center table, a covered fire place, and an operating sliding door that exits out into the left side of the home. Staff Office: Located to the right of the family room. There is a desk with a operating computer, fax machine, and closet space. All medication will be kept double locked in the staff office inside a locked box. Dining Area: One table with six (6) chairs. Kitchen/Laundry Area: There is a stove/oven with four (4) burners, all working at this time. There is a microwave and two refrigerators/freezers. The food service in the home will be adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. There is a fire extinguisher located to the right once entering the kitchen. Trash can has a tight lid on. All cleaning supplies are kept locked in cabinets above the washer and dryer. The knives are kept locked in the kitchen cabinet and will be made accessible only to employees. Bedroom #1: Is vacant. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #2: Is vacant. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. Report Cont. on LIC 809-C.

There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #3: Is vacant. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms. One (1) bathroom is located inside the staff office and the other bathroom is located next to Bedroom #3. The bathroom located inside the staff office will only be used by the facility staff. All bathrooms were checked and were in operating conditions. The faucets that are used by the children were tested and delivered hot water at a safe temperature range. There are security bars on the windows in Bedroom #1 and #3. The emergency release handle is in working conditions. Outdoor Space: LPA Sanchez P. observed the entrance area and backyard to be free of debris and hazardous materials. Garage: The detached garage will be kept locked and will only be used for storage space. LPA Sanchez P. also observed a freezer that will be used to store extra food. The home was inspected and the following was observed: The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Medicines, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions will be made inaccessible to children in care. No more than two (2) children will share a bedroom. Children have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows which are all in good repair. Outdoor activity space is free of obstructions. There are no weapons in the facility. Sharp knives are stored in a locked cabinet and inaccessible to children. Adequate supervision will be provided for children in care. Staff will ensure three nutritious meals and snacks. Food supply will be ample in the home. Children will be accorded personal rights. All Licensing posting requirements were met. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable and meet statutory requirements. The home will operate within capacity and limitations of license. LPA Sanchez P. observed age appropriate First Aid supplies. However, LPA Sanchez P. encouraged Licensee to obtain a regular thermometer to have instead of the disposable thermometers located inside the first aid kit. LPA Sanchez P. observed COVID-19 signs to be printed however, the COVID-19 signs need to be posted as required. The facility fire clearance is currently pending. Exit Interview conducted with Diana Flaggs.

On January 12, 2021 at 3:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an announced Tele-Inspection via facetime to Emergency Care Wilbur for the purpose of a Pre-Licensing inspection. This facility is licensed to Penny Lane Satellite #5 and will be utilized for Emergency Transition Care Facility. LPA met with Staff #1, who toured via facetime the interior and exterior of the facility. There are no clients residing in the facility at the time of the inspection. There are three bedrooms and an office. Each bedroom has two twin beds inside. Facility has 2 bathrooms. The facility is a single family dwelling located in a residential neighborhood. LPA Hernandez observed the follow during the inspection: Bedroom #1: There are two (2) twin size bed, and adequate closet space and lighting. Bedroom #2: There are two (2) twin size beds, and adequate closet space and lighting. Bedroom #3: Master bedroom There are two (2) twin size beds, and adequate walking closet space and lighting. Bathroom is attached There were two charged fire extinguishers, one in the dining area and one in the staff office. Office staff is designated for staff only. There was ample seating in the living/dining room area. Hallways free from hazards. Windows in bedrooms open freely. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. There are no bodies of water. Smoke detector and carbon monoxide was operable at the time of the inspection. LPA informed Staff #1 that Hot water temperature in the facility should be maintained between 105 and 120 degrees and Staff #1 will measure temperature at a later date. Medications cabinet with locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. LPA observed in that in the two facility bathrooms there was no trash cans with lid. Staff #1 stated that he will go today to get them and pictures will be send. The following should be in place before children are placed in the facility: LPA Observed that there was no food in the facility refrigerator, due to that there are no clients residing in the Facility. Staff #1 stated that they will go buy food when clients arrived at the facility. LPA heard during the inspection the smoke detector beeping. Staff #1 is going to put a request to change the battery. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility, in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.

On October 26, 2020 at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks made an announced tele-visit to Emergency Care Hollywood-3 for the purpose of a Pre-Licensing inspection. LPA met with Sabrina Sayre, Assistant Regional Administrator from LA County Dept. of Children and Family Services (DCFS) Airbnb Section. LPA toured the interior of the facility. The facility is requesting children ages 3 to 17, ambulatory only. LPA Banks observed the follow during the inspection: This apartment unit is one-story located in a residential area with 2 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. There is also a dining room which seat four (4), living room with balcony, kitchen, and a washer and dryer. Bedroom #1: There is one (1) king size bed, adequate closet space and lighting. Bedroom #2: There are two (2) queen size beds, and adequate closet space and lighting. There is an attached bathroom. This room is designated for two (2) children. There was ample seating in the living/dining room area. Hallways free from hazards. Windows in bedrooms open freely. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. There are no bodies of water. Temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Smoke detector and carbon monoxide was inoperable at the time of visit. LPA advised Ms. Sayre to have issue corrected as soon as possible. Hot water temperature should be maintained between 105 and 120 degrees (F) and Ms. Sayre will measure temperature at a later date. Children in care shall be supervised and protected at all times. Facility shall have non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Facility shall provide nutritious snacks between meals. Medications shall be locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. LPA advised the following: Make sharp knives and cleaning solutions inaccessible by storing in the locked closet. Medications, detergents and other items can be safeguarded in the locked closet as well. Signs need to be posted as required. The following should be in place before children are placed in the facility: Facility shall have basic hygiene products such as toothpaste, toothbrushes, combs, brushes, soap, deodorant, lotion. Facility shall have Linen: Blankets, sheets, towels, pillows. First aid kit shall be available. Refrigerated medication must be stored in a locked container. There is a Fire Extinguisher placed in the home. Fire clearance pending.

On January 12, 2021 at 12:10pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an announced tele-Inspection via facetime to Emergency Care Wilbur for the purpose of a Pre-Licensing inspection. This facility is licensed to Penny Lane Satellite #7 and will utilized for Emergency Transition Care Facility. LPA met with Staff #1, who toured via facetime the interior and exterior of the facility. There are no clients residing in the facility at the time of the inspection. There are three bedrooms and an office. Each bedroom has two twin beds inside. Facility has 2 bathrooms. The facility is a single family dwelling located in a residential neighborhood. LPA Hernandez observed the follow during the inspection: Bedroom #1: There are two (2) twin size bed, and adequate closet space and lighting. Bedroom #2: There are two (2) twin size beds, and adequate closet space and lighting. Bedroom #3: There are two (2) twin size beds, and adequate closet space and lighting There were two charged fire extinguishers, one in the dining area and one in the staff office. There is attached bathroom located in the office staff is designated for staff only. There was ample seating in the living/dining room area. Hallways free from hazards. Windows in bedrooms open freely. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. There are no bodies of water. Smoke detector and carbon monoxide was operable at the time of the inspection. LPA informed Staff #1 that Hot water temperature in the facility should be maintained between 105 and 120 degrees and Staff #1 will measure temperature at a later date. During the inspection LPA observed the padlocked cabinet that will be used for the clients' medication, and accessible only to the employees responsible for the stored medications. LPA recommended the following: Step pedal trash can with lid in both bathrooms and kitchen. The barbecue that was in the backyard must be kept in the garage. A separate locked box for the knives only. The following should be in place before children are placed in the facility: LPA observed that there was no food in the facility's refrigerator and this is because there are no clients residing in the facility. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility, in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: Staff denied withholding food from C1. C1 would not answers question related to specific details of allegation. C1 did state that S1 was mean to her all the time and was abusive. When asked were there any witnesses C1 never responded. Additional it was reported that S2 also was abusive towards her but when ask about alleged abuse she denied it stating “No, he just talked”. C1 was unresponsive to questions related to specifics of the allegations throughout the interview. Based on the investigation LPA was unable to confirm or deny the allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred due to conflicting information and C1 refusal to answer question during the interview. The Department has decided that the allegation is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies cited. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Claudia Rice Division Director for signature due to COVID-19 Public Health Crisis.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/02/20 3:40 PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Sharonda Grimitt contacted Five Acres via telephone for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and to deliver the findings. LPA Grimitt spoke with Claudia Rice, Division Manager and together discussed the investigation details. Based on the interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegation of Staff hit minor while in care. Staff inappropriately pushed minor while in care. Staff allows minors to cause harm to other minors while in care. Staff withheld food from minor while in care. Staff inappropriately threw water at minor while in care cannot be substantiated. Staff interviewed denied all allegation to be true. It was reported that C1 was push by staff and was pushed in the pool. It was revealed the pool was closed while C1 was at the facility. It was also reported that C1 was being beat up by boys at the facility. Staff interviewed revealed that C1 never interacted with the boys on campus and was placed in a girl’s cottage. Continued On LIC 812-C

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: On September 27, 2021 at 10:36AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Meghan McGee and Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit for the purpose of conducting a case management for an incident that occurred. LPA discussed with Jalisa McFee SIR # 768689 which was reported by a staff member at the facility involving a client bringing a BB gun on campus. LPA interviewed Jalisa McFee regarding this incident. Based on information gathered there was insufficient information to support the above allegation at this time. Additional Interviews will be conducted at a later date. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was emailed for a signature.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative:
On December 3, 2021 at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison arrived at the above facility for the purpose of a Case Management – Licensee Initiated visit. LPA met with Claudia Rice (Administrator), Jennifer Woolery (Program Manager), and Ulysses Silva (Safety Supervisor) who granted access and provided LPA with a tour of the facility. The provider is requesting to increase their capacity from 10 to 20 at the Temporary Shelter Care program. Five Acres will provide care and supervision for a capacity of 20 male and female children, ages 6-14 years of age, ambulatory only. There are seven (7) clients currently residing in the program. The facility has two cottages on campus designated to accept 20 clients. All bedrooms contain 1 twin bed and personal storage space. All bedrooms have beds with clean linens. There are 2 bathrooms equipped with a sink, toilet, and shower. Hot water was measured within a safe temperature in the bathrooms. The living & dining room is equipped with a television and furniture in good repair. The living/dining room is equipped with a table with 10 chairs. Facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. There were books, board games, and DVDs for clients. The kitchen was observed to be clean and is equipped with refrigerator and a four-burner stove. The kitchen trash can is covered with a lid. Meals are transported to the cottage from the main kitchen on campus. Knives, disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are made inaccessible to clients. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks. Continued on LIC 809-C

Medications are locked/accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. Laundry area has a stackable washer and dryer. LPA observed additional linens, towels, and hygiene products. LPA observed a staff office located in the cottage. Clients are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and are operable. Fire extinguisher was fully charged. First aid kit complete. Outdoor activity space consists of a swimming pool and play area. Passageways, stairways, and open porches are unobstructed. The following documents were posted: emergency disaster plan, personal rights, and grievance procedure. Exit interview completed and a copy of this report will be emailed to staff.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative:
On March 1, 2022 at 11:33am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison arrived at the above facility for the purpose of a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Claudia Rice, Division Director who granted access and provided LPA with a tour of the facility. Five Acres is licensed to provide care and supervision for a capacity of twenty (20) male and female children, ages 6-14 years of age, ambulatory only. There are four (4) clients currently residing in the program. The facility has two (2) cottages on campus designated to accept twenty (20) male and female clients. All bedrooms contain one (1) twin bed and personal storage space. All bedrooms have beds with clean linens. There are two (2) bathrooms equipped with a sink, toilet, and shower. Hot water was measured within a safe temperature in the bathrooms. The living & dining room is equipped with a television and furniture in good repair. The living/dining room is equipped with a table with ten (10) chairs. Facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. There were books, board games, and DVDs for clients. The kitchen was observed to be clean and is equipped with refrigerator and a four-burner stove. The kitchen trash can is covered with a lid. Meals are transported to the cottage from the main kitchen on campus. Knives, disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are made inaccessible to clients. Facility has non-perishable foods necessary for one (1) week. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks. Medications are locked/accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. Laundry area has a stackable washer and dryer. Cleaning, laundry, disinfectants are kept in a locked cabinet accessible by staff. LPA observed additional linens, towels, and hygiene products kept in locked cabinets accessible by staff. The following documents were posted: Emergency disaster plan, personal rights, and grievance procedure. All posting requirements are met. Adequate supervision is provided for children in care. Continued on LIC 809-C

Children are afforded personal rights. Children in care are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children in care are able to contact the licensing agency or Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. LPA observed a staff office located in the cottage. Clients are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and are operable. Fire extinguisher was fully charged. First aid kit complete. Outdoor activity space consists of a swimming pool and play area. Passageways, stairways, and open porches are unobstructed. LPA informed Division Director of licensing fees that were due on 2/28/2022 of $706.00. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.
investigation_findings: 13On April 7, 2022 at 2:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres (TSCF) and spoke with Claudia Rice, Division Director. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, a total of three (3) clients, (3) staff, and two (2) witnesses were interviewed. Confidential interviews and documentary evidence revealed Client #1 had limited access to use the phone and electronic devices due to their abuse of the phone policy at Five Acres (TSCF). Confidential interviews did not reveal that staff improperly restrained youth and placed youth in a locked room. Confidential interviews did not reveal that youth was not allowed to attend school. Confidential interviews did not reveal staff yelled at youth. Additional confidential interviews revealed there are no locks on the bathroom doors but handles for the safety of the residents in care to prevent them from locking themselves inside and imposing self-harm but that residents are afforded privacy when in the restroom.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: On May 6, 2022 at 03:55 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted an unannounced Case Management-Deficiencies inspection. LPA met with Facility Representative, Oscar Menendez, Crisis Intervention Specialist to discuss details. During investigation in connection with complaint control # 34-CR-20211025134156, records reviewed, and statements obtained revealed Staff Member #1 (S1) [see LIC811, dated May 6, 2022] was scheduled and worked during regular scheduled shift on October 23, 2021 and performed chest compression on a youth while having an expired CPR/First Aid Certification. This poses potential Health and Safety risk that, without correction, could become an immediate risk to the health, safety or personal rights of clients that could impact the care of clients and/or protection required to meet clients’ needs. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, Section 80075 Health Related Services. Exit interview was conducted with Facility Representative. Appeal Rights issued, and a copy of this report was provided and emailed to Facility Administrator. (Continued on LIC809D)

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: Witness statements obtained corroborate Client #1 (C1) did not show or exhibit any unusual or concerning behaviors prior to the incident (see LIC811, dated May 6, 2022). C1 was not assigned one on one level of supervision and was not on any special restrictions. Witness statements further indicate staffs last checked on C1 minutes prior to finding minor hanging on the back of minor’s bedroom door. Immediately upon discovery, two staff members cut C1 down from the door and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) on C1 until paramedics arrived. On November 17, 2021 while in the hospital, C1 was pronounced deceased due to complications from apparent mode of death by suicide. There were no suspicions of abuse or neglect in relation to C1’s death. The Department has investigated the complaint and found that the allegation is Unsubstantiated at this time; although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove neglect/lack of supervision contributed to the alleged. There were no deficiencies cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On May 6, 2022 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst Regina Martin conducted a subsequent complaint inspection to conclude and deliver findings concerning the allegation as mentioned above. LPA Martin met with Oscar Menendez, Crisis Intervention Specialist and advised the Complaint Investigation investigated by Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD); Investigator Peter Zertuche has been completed. Investigation details are discussed. On October 25, 2021, CCLD received a complaint referral alleging possible neglect/lack of supervision as Youth was presented to the Hospital Emergency Room, via ambulance. Youth resident attempted suicide by hanging self while at the facility. Youth was non-responsive, pulseless and not breathing when the paramedics arrived. The investigation including confidential interviews with associated parties and review of client file, related incident report, client medical records and related reports from the Department of Children and Family Services and the County of Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department Incident and supplemental Reports revealed a lack of evidence to support alleged neglect/lack of supervision (Continued on page LIC9099-C).

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: On June 14, 2022 at 1:26pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres TSCF for the purpose of a Case Management Incident regarding Special Incident Report #816758 (SIR), Fire. During this visit, LPA Edison conducted confidential interviews. Division Director granted LPA access to Willow Cottage, where fire took place, and together a tour was conducted. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: Upon LPA observation, food was inspected and observed to be of good quality with current expiration dates. Confidential staff and client interviews revealed that meals and food prepared for clients are at a proper temperature to ensure safety when consumed. Consistent statements from staff and clients revealed that additional food options are available to those clients who may not like what food is being served or for those clients who are still hungry after their meal. Based on the interviews conducted, documentary evidence, and LPA observation, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegation. LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegation occurred, therefore the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations.
investigation_findings: 13On July 28, 2022 at 9:32am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres TSCF and spoke with Julian White, Crisis Intervention Specialist (CIS) to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: Confidential interviews with Witness #2, #3, #4, and #5 revealed efforts were made by DCFS and Region Worker staff to make arrangements to transport C1 to their school of origin in Los Angeles County (Culver City), however, there were barriers with LAUSD and Pasadena USD that prevented C1 from being able to attend school. C1 was placed at the TSCF for twenty-one (21) days without attending school. Documentary evidence in the Five Acres TSCF Program statement reveal that “DCFS and/or TSCF program staff will transport children to their school of origin, unless the child is considered a flight risk and/or at risk of abduction”. LPA obtained a copy of the Program Statement for Five Acres TSCF. The documentary evidence is not consistent with statements made during confidential interviews. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence of the Five Acres TSCF Program Statement, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Appeal rights were discussed with the Division Director. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.
investigation_findings: 13On June 21, 2022 at 9:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres (TSCF) and spoke with Claudia Rice, Division Director. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, a total of three (3) clients, three (3) staff, and five (5) witnesses were interviewed. Confidential interviews with staff and witness statements revealed that transportation of Client #1 (C1) to their school of origin is solely the responsibility of the Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS). Confidential interviews with witnesses reveal that once a child is placed at Five Acres TSCF, DCFS Co-Locater staff contacts the DCFS Region Worker staff to inform them of the child’s need for transportation to school and the arrangements are made to transport the child to school or their school or origin by the Region Worker staff. facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: On March 28, 2023 at 11:26am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres TSCF and spoke with Jalisa McFee, Crisis Intervention Specialist (CIS). The purpose of this visit is a follow-up for a Case Management conducted on January 26, 2023 for SIR #841120. LPA was informed that Claudia Rice, Division Director is not in the office today. During the investigation, three (3) staff and one (1) client were interviewed. LPA Edison determined Client #1 (C1) was able to gain access to Staff #1 (S1) badge and use the badge to access the main building of the facility. Additional information received from Division Director states that badge procedures are discussed during onboarding training with staff which includes the purpose of the badge and what staff should do if the badge is lost. Division Director stated that badge procedures are discussed by the supervisor as a verbal conversation with staff to address keeping the badge on their person. It is unclear why S1 removed the badge and set it down making it accessible to C1. CIS was advised by LPA that they will discuss conducting additional staff training on supervision and badge security and providing LPA with documentation once the staff training has been completed with Division Director. CIS stated will inform Division Director regarding LPA advisory on how to prevent this incident from occurring again. LPA Edison issued a technical assistance advisory to facility to conduct additional staff training regarding badge policy and security. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative:
On March 12, 2024 at 10:19am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Deborah Lee arrived at the above facility for the purpose of an Annual Random Inspection. LPA met with Claudia Rice, Division Director who granted access and provided LPA with a tour of the facility. Five Acres is licensed to provide care and supervision for a capacity of twenty (20) male and female children, ages 6-14 years of age, ambulatory only. There are four (4) clients currently residing in the program. The facility has two (2) cottages on campus designated to accept twenty (20)--10 male and 10 female clients. All bedrooms contain one (1) twin bed and personal storage space. All bedrooms have beds with clean linens. There are two (2) bathrooms equipped with a sink, toilet, and shower. Hot water was measured within a safe temperature in the bathrooms. The living & dining room is equipped with a television and furniture in good repair. The living/dining room is equipped with a table with ten (10) chairs. Facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. There were books, board games, and DVDs for clients. The kitchen was observed to be clean and is equipped with refrigerator and a four-burner stove. The kitchen trash can is covered with a lid. Meals are transported to the cottage from the main kitchen on campus. Knives, disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are made inaccessible to clients. Facility has a supply of non-perishable foods necessary for one (1) week. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks. Medications are locked/accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. Laundry area has a stackable washer and dryer. Cleaning, laundry, disinfectants are kept in a locked cabinet accessible by staff. LPA observed additional linens, towels, and hygiene products kept in locked cabinets accessible by staff. The following documents were posted: Emergency disaster plan, personal rights, and grievance procedure. All posting requirements are met. Adequate supervision is provided for children in care. Children are afforded personal rights. Children in care are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children in care are able to contact the licensing agency or Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. Continued on 809C

LPA observed a staff office located in the cottage. Clients are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and are operable. Fire extinguisher was fully charged. First aid kit complete. Outdoor activity space consists of a swimming pool and play area. Passageways, stairways, and open porches are unobstructed. LPA reviewed (3) staff files. Per review of files, ( 3 )out of ( 3 ) files met current licensing requirements. LPA reviewed (2 ) client files. Per review of files, ( 2 ) out of ( 2 ) files met current licensing requirements. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Program Approval, valid through June 6, 2024. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA (Council of Accreditation). The Accreditation is valid through December 31, 2027. There were no deficiencies no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.

narrative: Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegation. LPA Edison was unable to determine if the above said allegation occurred, therefore the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended, and the finding can be changed. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Division Director.
investigation_findings: 13On April 9, 2024, at 10:33am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Five Acres TSCF and spoke with Shontel Davis, Crisis Intervention Specialist. LPA was informed Division Director is out of the office. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings regarding the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, confidential interviews and documentary evidence were reviewed. Statements indicate that minor attempted to swing at staff with a pen. Statements indicate that due to minor’s assaultive history with staff and safety concerns for minor and others, staff restrained minor. Confidential interviews and documentary evidence did not corroborate staff pulled minor’s hair and scratched minor while minor was being restrained. Statements indicate that minor has very long hair which extends down minor’s back. Statements indicate that on the day of the incident, minor’s hair was not tied in a ponytail, therefore, child’s hair may have gotten tangled during the restraint due to the length of minor’s hair, attempting to hit staff, and thrashing around during the restraint. LPA obtained Special Incident Report (SIR), staff ProAct training certificates, and nurse assessment for minor from the day of the incident.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: On July 3, 2024, at 10 AM, Kenrick Ellis, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) and JoAunne Griffin, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management – Incident investigation. LPA met with Claudia Rice, Administrator. A health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. The department received a Self- Reported Incident Report dated June 29, 2024. The Incident Report disclosed that Staff 1 (S1) yelled and made inappropriate comments to Child 1 (C1). Report also indicated that S2 grabbed C1 by his neck and slammed C1 to the ground the night before. There were no reports of C1 having any injuries, marks, or bruising. During the investigation, LPA interviewed S3,S4,S5,S6,S7, S8 and C2. LPA also requested and reviewed Personnel Report (LIC500), client roster, Incident Report, internal investigation, and shift notes. Based on the information obtained during this visit, additional information is needed. There were no deficiencies cited at time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Claudia Rice, Administrator.

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: On August 15, 2024, 10:30 AM, Kenrick Ellis, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of concluding a Case Management – Incident investigation. LPA met with Claudia Rice, Administrator. A health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. The department received a Self- Reported Incident Report dated June 29, 2024. The Incident Report disclosed that Staff 1 (S1) yelled and made inappropriate comments to Child 1 (C1). Report also indicated that S2 grabbed C1 by his neck and slammed C1 to the ground the night before. There were no reports of C1 having any injuries, marks, or bruising. During the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with eight staff and one client. LPA also reviewed video evidence, Personnel Report (LIC500), client roster, Incident Report, internal investigation, and shift notes. Video evidence revealed S1 in C1's personal space as she was clearing the campus. S1 was also seen taking a bike from C1 and throwing it away from C1 with two hands. Statements indicated S1 was repeating the same inappropriate language that C1 was using towards S1 during the incident. Documentary evidence indicated that S1 received a write up for using inappropriate language when communicating with C1. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80072 (a)(1). S1 repeated inappropriate language and posturing when interacting with C1.

deficiencies.description:
(a)	Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following:

(1)	To be accorded dignity in his/her personal relationships with staff and other persons. This regulation was not met as evidenced by the following:
Video footage, confidential interviews and documentary evidence indicating that S1 repeated inappropriate language and postering when interacting with C1. This poses a health and sately risk for children in care
