POC was discussed. Personal Rights training will be conducted with staff. Training agenda and sign-in sheet will be provided to LPA Kenrick Ellis via 
email ( Kenrick.Ellis@dss.ca.gov)

facility_name: FIVE ACRES-BOYS' AND GIRLS' AID SOCIETY OF LA TSCF
narrative: Confidential interviews were consistent that the staff utilized crisis communication protocol and provided redirection in attempt to prevent Child 1 (C1) from assaulting staff. There was no documentary evidence to support that youth are being verbally and emotionally abused, bullied, and provoked by staff. Documentary evidence indicated Special Incident reports were written that C1 met the criteria to be escorted out of the cottage for the safety of other children and staff. Records indicated C1 was restrained on several different occasions due to assaultive behavior towards staff. C1 was assessed and evaluated by the Psychiatric Mobile Response Team (PMRT), hospitalized placed on a on 72-hour hold. Due to lack of evidence obtained during the investigation, LPA determines that the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Facility Administrator/Claudia Rice
investigation_findings: 13On May 15, 2025 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation. Prior to entering the facility LPA Gray conducted a health and safety risk assessment. During the investigation, LPA Gray interviewed all available relevant parties and gathered pertinent information in reference to the allegations. The Licensee denied the allegations. Based on confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence, there is no evidence or witnesses to support that the staff used excessive force to restrain youth; Youth are being verbally and emotionally abused by staff; Youth are being bullied and provoked by staff and the staff are untrained. Records indicated that staff received multiple trainings on how to de-escalate a child in crisis. All staff are trained to implement Professional Assault Crisis Training (Pro-ACT) during a crisis by means of verbally redirection to de-escalate the child.

narrative:
On January 24, 2025 at approximately 9:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zaria Turner and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez conducted an in-person Component II Meeting in the office for the purposes of reviewing the LIC9106, A Documents, and Program Statement. Present during the meeting were LPA Zaria Turner, LPM Rosa Rodriguez, Executive Director, Erin Brown, Clinical Supervisor, Jessica Wharton, Program Manager Administrator, Antoinette Carter, Youth Counselor, Rebecca Solono, Training Coordinator, Grace Cole. Below is a summary of the topics that were discussed and the answers that were provided by the applicant: LIC9106 - LPA, LPM, and attendees present reviewed the LIC9106. LPA and LPM informed the attendees of adjustments and additional information that needs to be included. Information such as: population clarification, ratio, social work services being provided, and missing pages 13-19 from LIC9106 form. A Documents - LPA, LPM, and attendees present reviewed the A Documents. LPA and LPM informed the applicants of adjustments and additional information that needs to be included. Information such as: missing forms(LIC215, LIC308, LIC309, LIC402, LIC404, LIC420, LIC501, LIC503, and LIC9054), signatures, days, and hours on duty need to be added to the LIC500, ages and facility type on the LIC200, lease agreement, source of water, and update operating costs on the LIC401 and LIC403, and number of non-ambulatory clients in care. Program Statement Sections to be Revised/Updated - LPA, LPM and the attendees present reviewed the program statement. Sections reviewed and corrections needed included: (report continued on LIC 812C)

SECTION 3 · Specify the Age Range · Explain why you are not taking this specific youth. · Elaborate on how CCL/FHS will expedite the placement. SECTION 3B · Verify that the home is empty. (Can't co-mingle populations) · Getting insight and approval from youth in care for separate bedrooms · Elaborate on how you would handle splitting the sibling set if over capacity. · Advisory: Staff be removed if causing issues/other staff step in to de-escalate SECTION 4 · Example of the Daily Log should be placed here. SECTION 8 · Elaborate staff training for that specific population (infant/toddler) · Are you equipped to care for infant/toddler? (Furniture, bottles, etc.) · Examples of barriers preventing youth from attending school regularly. · Elaborate on behaviors and high-level needs? Include information from LIC 9106 · Based on the regulations, modify age range if needed SECTION 11 · Elaborate appointment only. What happens if the parent does not make appointment and shows up? SECTION 12 · What takes place when clients do not want to do chores? Do staff assist? · What happens if clients do not turn over personal devices? · What happens if client does not want to change? · What does gang related clothing entail? · Specify what kind of holes in clothing. · Goes against regulations. (Should not encourage smoking) · Preventing AWOL · What is the schedule for clients under 6? (report continued on LIC 812C)

SECTION 13 · What are the logical consequences? · What are the unacceptable behaviors? · What is the punishment orientation? SECTION 14 · Age range needs to be updated. · Specify who you will be sending it to the whereabouts and conditions to. SECTION 15 · Missing Runaway Plan · What takes place when clients do not want to do chores? Do staff assist? · What happens if clients do not turn over personal devices? · What happens if client does not want to change? · What does gang related clothing entail? · Specify what kind of holes in clothing. · Goes against regulations. (Should not encourage smoking) · Preventing AWOL · What is the schedule for clients under 6? SECTION 16 · What if the complaint involves the staff member? SECTION 17 · 80026(d)(e) · What happens when there is a death of child? Where do the funds go? SECTION 19 · 84076(b)(c) · What if the client does not like the food? (Dietary Restrictions) · Menus due weekly instead of monthly (report continued on LIC 812C)

SECTION 20 · What is the stored location? Clothing/Items need to be stored on site. · Clarification (Obtain/Purchase) · What will happen to belongings if not obtained by client or representative? · Intake agreement/clients will be inventoried. SECTION 21 · Reminder: submit an LIC500 (Every time there is a schedule change/personnel change). · Clarification on numbers (FTE) SECTION 26 · Lease will expire on 3/31/25. Going to extend for another year until 3/31/26. SECTION 27 · Missing Control of Property. SECTION 28 · Missing window exits. 4. Serving Clients Under Six Requirements - LPA and LPM advised applicants present on what items and training need to be included in the Program Statement for the home if caring for the age range 0-6. Items advised needed included: · Elaborate staff training for that specific population (infant/toddler) · Formula (options for the different needs or allergies)/ Rice Cereal/ Baby Food · Bottles (different sizes)/ Bottle Wand or Bottle Cleaner · Different nipples for the bottles · Diapers (All sizes and recommend different brand in case of allergies) · Changing Table & Changing Pads · Wipes · Bibs and Burp Rags · Cribs (Interchangeable is recommended so it can change as needed for the size/age) · Pack and Play · Crib Mattress (report continued on LIC 812C)

·Linens and Blankets (3 pair minimum, for changes) · Clothes (All size ranges and seasonally appropriate) · Age-appropriate toys · Towels/Washcloths · Potty Chair · Pacifier with guard shields · Highchair with broad base legs, straps, and a washable seat) · Car Seats and Baby Gates · Clothes in range from infants to teens for different seasons. · Infant Bathtubs · Some Diaper Changing supplies (Aquaphor, A & D ointment, and lotion) · Some bathing supplies (Baby Shampoo) · Elaborate staff training for that specific population (infant/toddler) LPA Turner and LPM Rodriguez offered up the opportunity for discussion and questions. Executive Director, Erin Brown advised that they would be sending completed and updated copies of the missing LIC forms to LPA and LPM. LPA, LPM, and applicants present coordinated a Pre-Licensing date. Due to Sacramento County placement at the facility the Pre-Licensing has been scheduled to be determined March 5, 2025. LPA and LPM will be enrolling attendees in the online Component III meeting; date to be determined, no schedule is showing in SharePoint at this time. LPA and LPM thanked the attendees for their time and concluded the Component II Meeting.

On March 5, 2025 at approximately 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Zaria Turner and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez, made an announced visit with the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection to the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA and LPM met with Executive Director, Erin Brown, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. LPA and LPM conducted a walk though of the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility was clean, safe and kept free of obstruction. LPA and LPM observed the posting of License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 ½ bathrooms, activity room, kitchen, living room/dining room, storage/pantry room, staff office, intake room, and garage. Each client room is equipped with 2 twin size beds, bedding, 2 bedside tables, and closet space for clothing and personal belongings. The 2 bathrooms at the facility are equipped with working toilets, shower/tub, and running water. The ½ staff bathroom is equipped with a water heater, storage for cleaning supplies, a working toilet, and running water. Upon entry, there is a desk and monitor, a double sided fireplace, a sofa, side table, a table with 2 chairs, a TV, and a TV stand. The living/dining room is equipped with 3 sofas, 2 side tables, a TV, a TV stand, and a dining table with 4 chairs. The staff office is equipped with a desk, monitors, a staff and client filing cabinet, and locker. The intake room is equipped with 2 fridges used for medications. lockers, and filing cabinets. The storage/pantry room is equipped with cabinets used to store nonperishable foods, a fridge to store perishable foods, and racks to store extra linens. The garage is converted into a storage room equipped with extra toiletries, bedding and linens, mattresses, cleaning supplies, dining utensils, car seats, and toys/games. There are 4 hall closets. There are 3 hall closets used for extra toiletries, linens, and supplies. There is one hall closet equipped with the HVAC (Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning Unit). There is a washer and dryer located in the kitchen and cabinets above and below where extra linen, toiletries, and cleaning supplies are kept and locked away. Continue summary of inspection on 809-C

Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible to clients in care and locked, under the kitchen sink, in the ½ staff bathroom, and above the laundry units. The refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees F. There is nonperishable food for one week and fresh perishable food for three days minimum. There are containers to place leftover food. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. Hot Water between 105–120 degrees F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. The toilets, bathtubs, and shower fixtures are in good repair. Soap and paper towels are available to clients in care. The facility is free of vermin. The backyard contains a concrete area with 2 chairs, 2 tables, a bench, and 12 chairs. There is a basketball hoop and horizontal bars. There is a detached cottage located in the back of the property. The cottage is equipped with 4 chairs. The cottage is large enough to be converted into an extra room for the population under 6 or an isolation room(not for behaviors). There is a tool shed that is currently not in use. There is no pool on the premises. The following adjustments need to be made: Smoke detector in cottage. Air conditioning unit in cottage. An exit interview was conducted with Executive Director, Erin Brown, and a copy of this report was discussed and provided during today's inspection.

On May 8, 2025 at approximately 12:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zaria Turner, made an unannounced visit to the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) for the purpose of conducting a Case Management to follow up on an incident report received by the department on April 24, 2025, regarding lack of details on the incident report. LPA Turner met with Facility Administrator, Erin Brown. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiencies: The incident report received by the department on April 24, 2025 lacks a detailed narrative, describing the incident and the events leading up to the incident. The facility is submitting the incorrect Incident Report Forms. The facility is ineligibly handwriting the Incident Reports Forms. (See LIC 9102 TV) On May 6, 2025 LPA Turner submitted a referral to the Technical Support Program (TSP) to ensure the facility receives additional training on incident reporting procedures. TSP will contact the licensee to coordinate and schedule training to aid the facility in resolving the deficiencies. This case management will remain open until a follow up inspection is conducted to ensure the facility is in full compliance. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Erin Brown, Facility Administrator.

On June 18, 2025, 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Zaria Turner, made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a post licensing inspection. LPA met with Erin Brown, Facility Administrator, and walk through of the interior and exterior of the facility was conducted. LPA conducted a walk though of the interior and exterior of the facility. LPA observed the posting of License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 ½ bathrooms, activity room, kitchen, living room/dining room, storage/pantry room, staff office, intake room, and garage. Each client room is equipped with 2 twin size beds, bedding, 2 bedside tables, and closet space for clothing and personal belongings. The 2 bathrooms at the facility are equipped with working toilets, shower/tub, and running water. The ½ staff bathroom is equipped with a water heater, storage for cleaning supplies, a working toilet, and running water. Upon entry, there is a desk and monitor, a double sided fireplace, a sofa, side table, a table with 5 chairs, a TV, and a TV stand. The living/dining room is equipped with 3 sofas, 2 side tables, a TV, a TV stand, and a hammock. The staff office is equipped with a desk, monitors, a staff and client filing cabinet, and locker. The intake room is equipped with 2 fridges used for medications. lockers, and filing cabinets. The storage/pantry room is equipped with cabinets used to store nonperishable foods, a fridge to store perishable foods, and racks to store extra linens. The garage is converted into a storage room equipped with extra toiletries, bedding and linens, mattresses, cleaning supplies, dining utensils, car seats, and toys/games. There are 4 hall closets. There are 3 hall closets used for extra toiletries, linens, and supplies. There is one hall closet equipped with the HVAC (Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning Unit). Continue summary of inspection on 809-C

There is a washer and dryer located in the kitchen and cabinets above and below where extra linen, toiletries, and cleaning supplies are kept and locked away. Medication is centrally stored, locked, and inaccessible to clients in care. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible to clients in care and locked, under the kitchen sink, in the ½ staff bathroom, and above the laundry units. The refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees F. There is nonperishable food for one week and fresh perishable food for three days minimum. There are containers to place leftover food. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. Temperature in facility is between 68 degrees F and a maximum of 85 degrees F. Hot Water between 105–120 degrees F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. The toilets, bathtubs, and shower fixtures are in good repair. Soap and paper towels are available to clients in care. There is a working telephone accessible to clients. The facility is free of vermin. The backyard contains a concrete area with 2 chairs, 2 tables, a bench, and 12 chairs. There is a basketball hoop and horizontal bars. There is a detached cottage located in the back of the property. The cottage is equipped with a table, 11 chairs, and a bookshelf. There is a tool shed that is currently not in use. There is no pool on the premises. Based on a review of the facility’s Guardian Roster the staff working during today’s inspection are fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. A Technical Violation (TV) was assessed during today's inspection. (See LIC 9102 TVs) Licensee has been notified by the county that the lease agreement has not gone out for signature and they are working to get it out this week and will provide and update to LPA Turner via email by June 24, 2025. An exit interview was conducted with Facility Administrator, Erin Brown, and a copy of this report was discussed and provided during today's inspection.

On August 1, 2025 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at Foster Hope Sacramento Welcome Home. LPA was greeted by Reyes Bonilla, Facility Administrator who granted LPA access. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiencies. The front door of the home is bent creating a gap large enough for bugs and pest to enter. 2 windows are broken exposing glass. They are boarded from inside of the facility but the outside is exposed. A drawer is missing in the kitchen. The Client bathroom in the hallway has a shower which is stuck and cannot be changed into a bath. The Client bathroom in the hallway has a sink which is not draining properly. There are large amount of ants in both client bathrooms. A strong odor of Marijuana throughout the entire facility. LPA observed the facility to place tape over the exterior windows which were exposing glass. LPA also requested copies of work orders for the above deficiencies be sent to LPA Zaria Turner via email at zaria.turner@dss.ca.gov by close of business on August 1, 2025. LPA Turner will also conduct the remainder of this case management. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Reyes Bonilla, Facility Administrator.

On August 22, 2025 at approximately 1:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zaria Turner conducted an Informal Meeting with the above facility for the purposes of initiating a conversation about expectations and current observations regarding Physical Plant. Present during the meeting was (LPAs) Zaria Turner, Sarina Buchannan, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Connie Goldie, and Facility Administrator (FA) Erin Brown. Below is a summary of the topics discussed and the responses provided by the licensee. Expectations: LPAs and LPM discussed the importance of clear and open communication, honesty in all matters, reporting requirements, and the appeal process, and asking as many questions as needed. Current Observations: LPA Buchannan discussed the following observations from their inspection on August 1, 2025 regarding the Physical Plant. Additionally, section 84087(c) The licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility. Collaborative Discussion: LPA Turner discussed immediate response to safety risks, including email dates; clear expectations for youth regarding smoking in the facility and on the grounds; the cleaning crew’s routine for the facility; pest control measures; and overall facility maintenance. Agreement and Responses provided by the licensee: The FA shared communication about the focus of hiring. A contract has been put in place for pest control and a contractor's list has been created to assist in maintaining the Physical Plant.

On August 6, 2025 at 2:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zaria Turner, made an unannounced visit to the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) for the purpose of conducting a Case Management to follow up and assess a deficiency that was observed on August 1, 2025 by LPA Sarina Buchannan, regarding two broken windows exposing glass. LPA Turner met with Program Manager, Reyes Bonilla. Facility Administrator, Erin Brown, approved Program Manager, Reyes Bonilla, to sign off on any documentation left at the facility today. LPA Buchannan observed the facility place tape over the exterior windows which were exposing glass. LPA also requested copies of work orders for the above deficiencies be sent to LPA Zaria Turner via email at zaria.turner@dss.ca.gov by close of business on August 1, 2025. LPA Turner conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiencies: Two broken windows exposing glass. The windows are boarded from the inside and outside of the facility. The deficiencies were assessed during today's inspection. (See LIC 809-D) Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Reyes Bonilla, Program Manager.

facility_name: HATHAWAY SYCAMORES CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report will be emailed to the facility on a later date. There are no deficiencies cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/02/2021 at 8:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong conducted a follow-up complaint inspection and met with Program Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct confidential interviews and deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During investigation of the allegation minors are smoking marijuana at the facility, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed the Child and Family Team (CFT) Meeting Minutes, Incident Reports, Staff Training Calendar, Emergency Intervention Plan and Emergency Response Services. Confidential interviews and documentary evidence indicated that minors obtain marijuana from the community or while AWOL and return with marijuana substance or under the influence of marijuana. Evidence also indicated that when minors are observed to be under the influence, staff provides crisis communication, redirect minors to surrender the substance, asks to conduct contraband searches and substance use barriers are discussed during CFT meetings. Evidence further indicates staff receives Emergency Intervention trainings as required.

narrative: On 10/05/2020 beginning at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Dara Campos and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raulito Alarcon conducted a Case Management tele-inspection via Microsoft Teams to the facility. LPM and LPA spoke with the facility Director, Stephanie McCoy, and explained that the purpose of today’s meeting was to discuss the topic of the facility’s locked gates. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an incident report on 06/29/20 regarding an incident where a youth had attempted to leave from the facility. The youth was told it was against facility policy to unlock the gate. On 07/03/20 LPA Alarcon conducted a case management regarding the locked gate. LPA was told by the Director the front gate is now locked, and the back gate was unlocked. During an unannounced in-person inspection of the facility on 08/02/2020, LPAs Raulito Alarcon and Tana Kinder observed that the back gate feeds into an enclosed property of a San Joaquin County school. This property is secured with a lock which does not belong to Mary Graham. LPAs also conducted confidential interviews with staff and consistent statements were made, acknowledging that the school property was enclosed and locked. The facility is being cited for violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80072(a)(7) Personal Rights: To be free from corporal or unusual punishment; infliction of pain; humiliation; intimidation; ridicule; coercion; threat;… Not to be locked in any room, building, or facility premises by day or night. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on LPAs’ observations and interviews conducted with five staff, LPAs were told about the property gates being locked. This poses a potential Personal Rights, Health and Safety risk to clients. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was given to the facility’s Director, Stephanie McCoy.

narrative: On 01/29/2021 the Department had received an incident report dated 01/26/2021 which stated there was a medication error. The incident report stated the nurse was distributing medication to two residents within the same dorm. The nurse had placed the medications into a medication cup and transported the medications to the dorm. Upon distributing the medications it was found a medication was given to the wrong child. LPA contacted the Director to determine the process of dispensing medications. The Director stated there is a medication cart in the nurse's station. The medication cart has a medication drawer that has each child's medication. On top of the cart is a binder with a Medication Administration Record (MAR) which indicates medications for a child and instructions. The Director stated the child is typically brought to the nurse's station and waits at the door. The nurse will dispense medication according to the MAR into the dispensing cup and provide water to the child as well. Due to COVID-19 procedures and limiting the commingling of children, the nurse was dispensing the medications to each dorm. The medication cups were not labeled. LPA discussed a plan with the Director to prevent future medication errors. The Director stated the nurse will identify the child's medication cup by writing the child's name on the medication cup. The cups will be labeled with the child's name to ensure medications are provided to the correct child upon providing medication. Exit interview conducted, Copy of report given.

narrative: On 3/11/22 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) met with staff Kim Robinson Shelter Supervisor II (SSII) for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection regarding Incident Reports. LPA discussed the facility appears to contact Law Enforcement (LE) within a few minutes after a client is reported missing or staff have lost sight of the client. SSII stated the facility is in the process of re-examining their LE contact procedures and the facility calls LE immediately under certain circumstances based upon the clients needs. LPA discussed the facility's incident reports regarding the clients use of illegal substances. LPA stated the incident reports should specify if staff are asking the clients to conduct a self search for contraband or illegal substances as specified in the facility's Runaway Plan in their Program Statement. LPA discussed the facility's policy on searching a client's room after they have been observed using illegal substances or having contraband. SSII stated this was discussed on 3/9/22 with the Leadership Team. It was clarified that a room search is acceptable and expected to be conducted by staff under these circumstances. SSII stated the facility will include any client self searches or room searches in their incident reports.

On 3/17/22 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Kim Robinson Shelter Supervisor II for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection. LPA reviewed the facility's Plan of Operation (POO) for House Rules. The POO states "A room inspection may be initiated if a Supervisor determines a risk exists due to suspicion of the presence of contraband, stolen items, or items to be used to injure a resident's self or others." The facility failed to abide by this House Rule for an incident on 1/15/22 and 3/14/22 when staff suspected clients were using illegal substances. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80022(k) Plan of Operation. Per LPA's review of incidents reports submitted in March 2022 the facility failed to submit several incident reports after the agency's next working day and a written report within seven days following the occurrence of such event. The facility submitted several Incident Reports for October and November 2021, January and February 2022 in March 2022. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Kim Robinson Shelter Supervisor II.

On 9/1/22 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Stephanie McCoy Executive Director (ED) for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Inspection. LPA discussed several incident reports are not being submitted according to regulation time frames. Such as: On 8/25/22 LPA received one 7-day incident report dated 8/21/22 but a 24-hour/next business day report was not submitted. On 8/31/22 LPA received one 7-day incident report dated 8/17/22 that should have been submitted by 8/29/22. On 8/31/22 LPA received four 7-day incident reports dated 8/18/22 (2), 8/12/22, and 8/20/22 that should have been submitted by 8/29/22, 8/23/22 and 8/30/22 respectively. LPA discussed the facility is not following their Plan of Operation (POO) for House Rules regarding room inspections. The facility failed to conduct room searches for incidents on: 8/20/22 when four clients refused to hand over suspected contraband for approximately two hours. 8/24/22 when seven clients refused to hand over suspected contraband for approximately 6.5 hours 8/29/22 when staff suspected one client was using illegal substance while holding another client's child. LPA & ED reviewed the facility's Runaway Management Policy regarding when to contact Law Enforcement when supervision of a client is lost. ED stated this policy has been updated and will send the update to LPA. LPA discussed the incident reports need to be more specific on how client supervision was lost. LPA discussed incident reports need to specify how staff were supervising the clients. Incident on 8/17/11 regarding eight clients fighting and on 8/23/22 between one client and their significant other with the client's child present failed to specify how the staff were supervising the clients. LPA discussed an incident report dated 8/11/22 when a client was restrained for trying to leave the facility by climbing over the fence. LPA stated this restraint was not warranted due to the client's safety was not at risk. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Stephanie McCoy Executive Director .

The allegation is whether minor’s clothing needs were met while in care or not. A client stated during interview, he did not have enough underwear or pants. Records review of Inventory of clothing at intake, Itemization of resident’s personal items and clothing and shopping lists indicates that client arrived with just one set of clothing at intake. Client received 2 pairs of shoes, 3 pairs of socks, 4 pairs of pants, 1 pair of shorts, 8 t-shirts, and 2 sets of pajamas, but, only 2 pairs of underwear. 2 pairs of underwear doesn’t meet the standard of appropriate. Based on LPA’s observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Hillary Hall and Misty Valencia arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Jason Eala, Shelter Supervisor II, for a case management inspection. LPAs interviewed six staff and one client, and reviewed records. Based on interviews and records provided by the facility, 31 out of 46 staff were out of compliance with CPR/1st Aid requirements, as their certification had expired. An additional 4 staff were not listed as having completed any CPR/1st Aid. Facility is issued a citation per Interim Licensing Standards, version 4, STRTP, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, 87065.1(b)(8)(A): Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements: Completion of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and first aid training shall be demonstrated by current and valid CPR and first aid cards issued by the American Red Cross, the American Heart Association, a training program approved by the State Emergency Medical Services Authority pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1797.191, or from an accredited college or university. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809D Report was provided to the Shelter Supervisor and an exit interview was conducted. Appeal Rights Provided.

narrative: On 11/3/22 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman met with Stephanie McCoy, Director and Kim Robinson Assistant Director for the purpose of a Case Management Inspection regarding an incident that occurred on 10/23/2022 where two clients engaged in a sexual inappropriate behavior. LPA discussed the incident and interviewed Stephanie McCoy Director, reviewed two client’s files and collected copies of each client's checkoff list, admission report, pre-placement questionnaire, personal rights, house rules, resident grievance procedure, discharge/removal procedure, cell/phone electronic policy, behavior & risk assessment, and court report documents from these files. LPA collected a copy of one client's Individual Plan. No client interviews conducted due to neither client was on-site during the inspection.

compliance, expired or missing, for MABpro (Management of Assaultive Behavior) training. When questioned about emergency intervention training, the Director states that they are in transition to Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (TCI) and is aware that they are currently not in compliance and have been out of compliance for some time. As a result of the information obtained, documentation reviewed, confidential interviews conducted with staff and clients, staff are out of compliance with the emergency intervention training plan is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. Facility cited for Type A violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 84365.5(b): Staffing Requirements. The facility personnel who will use emergency interventions, must be trained in the appropriate emergency intervention techniques approved to be used by the licensee. Evidence shows that the facility is out of compliance with their emergency intervention training in 53 out of 58 records reviewed on 10/14/22. Staff records showed that the MABpro certificates were either missing or expired. When LPA Hillary Hall contacted the Management of Assaultive Behavior training agency, she was informed that the training was still being conducted in person during the COVID epidemic. In addition, records reviewed that of 39 staff who completed de-escalation training, 38 staff completed the training in December 2018 or January 2019 and one completed the training in December 2020 and seven staff haven’t completed the training at all. This poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care at the facility. Exit interview conducted with Ms. McCoy and documentation provided, including appeal rights.

narrative:
there are clients in the care of the shelter that need additional supervision or have behaviors that warrant additional supervision than the other clients and the shelter does not staff to that need. All staff interviewed indicated that C31 (see LIC811 dated 11/3/22) has behaviors that always warrant heightened supervision and possibly one staff assigned to C31, but the facility does not staff to this need. In addition, interviews with staff and clients indicate that staff to client ratios are typically five or six clients to one staff during the day which is out of compliance with the required four clients to one staff. Regarding the allegation that facility staff did not provide supervision to clients involved in the distribution, possession and/or use of marijuana, this allegation is related to the facility not intervening to remove marijuana or other contraband clients are found to be in possession of while at the facility. Ten of twelve clients interviewed confirmed that the staff at the facility would not intervene to stop the clients from smoking marijuana or vapes while in the facility. Clients also stated that staff “don’t try” to confiscate drugs or other contraband and that if they are found to be in possession of contraband, the staff write it up, but nothing is done after that. Clients also confirmed that staff in the AFS (Absent from Shelter) cottage, did little to nothing to confiscate contraband or tell clients to not smoke in their rooms in the cottage. One staff interviewed indicated that the clients have a right to smoke, despite being under the legal age limit. Twelve of twelve staff reported that there is very little that they can do to remove contraband because “they have rights” and have been told that they can’t touch clients to remove contraband or other unauthorized items. Additionally, the Director reported a lack of drug use training for staff and staff confirmed inadequate training to identify substance use and detection, as addressed in the 9/14/22 complaint findings issued on the same date as the findings for this complaint investigation. Regarding the allegation that facility staff did not provide supervision to clients involved in sexual touching and/or assaulting other clients, this allegation is related to the facility not intervening or being present to stop unwanted or inappropriate touching between clients. Eight of twelve clients interviewed confirmed that they engaged in sexual contact while at the facility and that it was not always consensual. Interviews confirmed that staff either didn’t check on them or staff could do little to nothing to stop the interactions. Confidential interviews with clients revealed that staff were either not present or failed to provide adequate care to keep clients safe. One staff interview indicated clients have a right to have sex in the cottage and that staff intervention would only be necessary if a sexual assault were occurring, with the assumption that “the client would ask for help during the assault.” One client interviewed stated that they were touched inappropriately

by another client at the facility when they were supposed to be in their beds and going to sleep but that staff never came to their room to check on them, thus not preventing the inappropriate touching. Regarding the allegation that facility staff did not provide supervision to clients threatening other clients with violence, this allegation is related to fighting in the cottage, threats of violence from clients to other clients, and clients being physically aggressive towards and hitting clients and staff. Nine of twelve confidential interviews with clients demonstrated that staff did not do what they could to stop fights from turning physical and once they got physical, they did little to stop this too. One client’s interview detailed an assault on another client that the client intervened to stop because no staff was present to intervene or prevent the assault. Confidential interviews with clients alerted to staff blaming client(s) by “instigating” incident(s) meaning that a client’s behavior leads to or causes assaults. One client reported having to fight three clients with staff present and staff did nothing to intervene. Records reviewed showed that 53 out of 58 staff either did not have MABPro Emergency Intervention training or the certifications were expired. Staff interviewed reported that because the facility does not have enough staff to keep eyes on clients, staff are not appropriately trained in emergency interventions and/or staff are not sufficient in numbers to physically intervene, staff can only verbally redirect clients to comply and hope that clients listen. (The facility not being compliant with this training plan is addressed in the 10/14/22 complaint findings issued on the same date as the findings for this complaint investigation.) As a result of the information obtained, documentation reviewed, confidential interviews conducted with staff and clients, the allegations that the facility maintains an insufficient quantity of staff to meet the needs of the clients in care, facility staff did not provide supervision to clients involved in the distribution, possession and/or use of marijuana, facility staff did not provide supervision to clients involved in sexual touching and/or assaulting other clients, and facility staff did not provide supervision to clients threatening other clients with violence are SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. Facility cited for Type A violation of Transitional Shelter Care Facilities, Interim Licensing Standards, Regulation 84665.5(f): Staff Ratios. Records review, confidential interviews with staff and clients indicate that the facility is not providing the care and supervision needed to keep clients safe, in that the facility is required to evaluate clients and if they require special care and supervision due to age, problem behaviors

or other factors, they are to increase the number of on-duty staff. All staff interviewed conformed that the facility is staffed to ratio. The facility is not evaluating the staffing need based on observed unsafe behaviors including but not limited to inappropriate interactions between clients, clients physical and sexually assaulting other clients, clients physically assaulting staff, age of the clients in care, or other observed problem behaviors including possession of drugs, alcohol, and other contraband which poses and immediate risk to the safety of the clients in care. Facility cited for Type A violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80078(a): Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Confidential interviews with staff and clients indicate that the facility is not providing the care and supervision as necessary to meet the clients’ needs including having sufficient staff persons on duty to physically intervene in physical altercations or other aggressive behaviors, shadow clients during walkabouts as identified in clients’ individualized plans, or when engaging in appropriate or inappropriate activities in the cottages which poses an immediate risk to the clients in the care of the facility. Facility cited for a Type A violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 84072(d): Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable, including the right to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. Investigation shows that clients were not provided with this right as evidenced by the failure to appropriately staff and provide supervision to prevent or safeguard clients from threats of violence, sexual activity or assaults, and/or the continued possession and use of marijuana in the facility, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to the rights of clients to live in a safe and healthy environment as required by this regulation. Exit interview conducted with Ms. McCoy and documents, including appeal rights, were provided via email.

“girl…if I wasn’t working here I would beat you up” or “[if you mess with my car], I’ll lose my job…” where clients perceived an implicit threat of harm. During a client interview, it was reported that staff made a comment that a client may have instigated a fight, insinuating that the client deserved to be attacked by other clients. While these comments were not direct threats, interviews largely supported a lack of trauma-informed care as some staff were reported as being rude and making disparaging remarks to and about clients in care. As a result of interviews conducted with staff and clients the allegation that facility staff threaten and intimidate clients in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Ms. McCoy and documentation provided to the facility.

narrative:
appropriately to stop altercations or other acts of aggression and/or violence. Confidential interviews with staff and clients indicate that the facility does not have sufficiently trained staff to adequately prevent or physically intervene when these physical altercations happen. Evidence showed that of the 58 staff records reviewed, 53 records indicate that staff members are out of compliance, expired or missing, for MABpro (Management of Assaultive Behavior) training. When questioned about emergency intervention training, the Director states that they are in transition to Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (TCI) and is aware that they are currently not in compliance. Nine of twelve confidential interviews with clients demonstrated that staff did not do what they could to stop fights from turning physical or did little to nothing to stop this too. One client’s interview detailed an assault on another client that the client intervened to stop because no staff was present to intervene or prevent the assault. Confidential interviews with clients alerted to staff blaming client(s) by “instigating” incident(s) meaning that a client’s behavior leads to or causes assaults. One client reported having to fight three clients with staff present and staff did nothing to intervene. (The facility not being compliant with this training plan is addressed in the 10/14/22 complaint findings issued on the same date as the findings for this complaint investigation.) Regarding the allegation that minor’s behavior poses a risk to other minors, this allegation is related to the facility not intervening to keep other clients safe when behavioral or aggressive incidents happen at the facility. Investigation shows that there are clients in the care of the shelter that need additional supervision or have behaviors that, when escalated, can pose a danger to other clients in the facility, as shown by the facility’s lack of compliance addressed in the 7/18/22 and 9/2/22 complaint findings issued on the same date as the findings for this complaint investigation. All staff interviewed indicated that C31 (see LIC811 dated 11/3/22) has aggressive and violent behaviors that warrant heightened supervision and possibly one staff assigned, but the facility does not staff to this need. Confidential interviews revealed that staff do not physically intervene when altercations happen between clients at the facility due to lack of training. Several client plans revealed the facility failed to identify appropriate intervention plans based on documented child welfare, mental health, and behavioral history of the client to ensure the safety of the subject client and/or other clients in the facility. In regards to placement decisions, staff reported limitations regarding a lack of space or having insufficient information in deciding where to safely place a client at intake. Staff and clients reported placing “behaviorally challenged” clients in a separate cottage (also referred to as the “bad kids cottage” or “AWOL cottage”) with no additional staffing or supervision measures despite knowledge of the client(s) history of drug use, physical altercations and prior incidents of running away from the facility.

Regarding the allegation that the facility is out ratio, this allegation is related to the facility staffing the facility to the ratio of the clients that the shelter has in their care rather than to the need of the clients in the shelter. Investigation shows staff are frequently out of ratio of four clients to one staff in the cottages and particularly when clients walk out of the cottage, requiring a staff follow. While the regulations allow that additional staff be on call and capable of arriving at the facility (cottage) within 30 minutes, confidential interviews demonstrated that the staff are frequently out of ratio beyond this allowed 30 minutes. Investigation shows that staff to client ratios are typically five or six clients to one staff which is out of compliance with the required four clients to one staff during the day. Multiple confidential client interviews demonstrated that clients in the “bad kid cottage” (also referred to as the “AWOL cottage”) were frequently out of ratio as there were frequently more than eight clients but only two staff in the cottage. Regarding the allegation that facility staff are not providing adequate supervision to minors, this allegation is related to the staff not being able to provide the approved interventions for clients in care due to a lack of staffing. Clients identify coping skills in their Individual Plans written and approved by the facility which may include “walkabouts”. Interviews demonstrated that this means that when a client gets frustrated or anxious, they can walk about the campus to release feelings of frustration and/or anxiety. However, staff indicate that when a client asks for this, more times than not they have to tell the client to wait for additional staff if additional staff are available to come. In addition, confidential interviews revealed that when staff call for additional staff to perform these functions or to take over for cottage ratio, they are met with staff telling them to “make do.” Multiple staff interviews indicate that the facility does not staff to the need of the clients in care rather ratio of the clients in care. Confidential interviews with staff and clients also demonstrated that clients are often caught in explosive or violent incidents at the facility due to not having enough staff to keep clients not involved safe while also intervening to stop behaviors including inappropriate interactions, aggression, and fighting amongst clients. Records reviewed demonstrates that 53 out of 58 staff either did not have MABPro (Management of Assaultive Behavior) training or the certifications were expired. Staff interviewed reported that the facility does not have enough staff to keep eyes on clients, staff are not appropriately trained in emergency interventions and/or staff are not sufficient in numbers to physically intervene and can only verbally redirect clients to comply and hope that they do. Additionally, the Director stated that she does not go out on the floor often to see what is happening. Regarding the allegation that facility staff do not meet the minimum qualifications required, this allegation is

related to facility staff not having the appropriate training to meet the needs of clients that are accepted at the facility. All staff interviewed indicated that clients accepted to the facility include developmentally delayed clients, clients with mental health issues, behavioral health issues, violent tendencies, and aggression, to name a few. Several staff reported having inadequate training in order to meet the needs of the clients. One staff indicated the facility does not have adequately trained staff to meet the mental health needs of the clients. Additionally, multiple staff reported not receiving training on trauma-informed care. The Director states that the facility needs training on drug use and dual diagnosed children, and reported Regional Center staff has never come to provide training on dealing with clients with developmental disabilities or autism. Records reviewed indicate that 53 of 58 staff do not have current training in emergency interventions. Confidential interviews also demonstrate that clients are admitted frequently with substance use issues. While staff have received training on Narcan administration for clients, there has been no training provided on substance use and detection. As a result of the information obtained, documentation reviewed, confidential interviews conducted with staff and clients, the allegations that minors are being aggressive to another minor while in care, minor’s behavior poses a risk to other minors, facility is out ratio, staff are not providing adequate supervision to minors, and staff do not meet the minimum qualifications required are SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. Facility cited for Type A violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 84072(d): Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable, including the right to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. Investigation shows that the facility is not staffing the facility to the need of the clients in care to prevent assaults, altercations, or aggression towards other clients or when it is identified that the needs of clients are such that additional staff are warranted which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to the rights of clients to live in a safe and healthy environment as required by this regulation. Facility cited for Type A violation of Transitional Shelter Care Facilities, Interim Licensing Standards, Regulation 84665.5(b): Staff Ratios. Records review, confidential interviews with staff and clients indicate that the facility is not providing the care and supervision required including meeting the minimum staff ratios

of one awake and on duty direct care staff present at the facility for ever four children present at the facility which poses an immediate risk to the safety of the clients in care at the facility. Facility cited for Type A violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80078(a): Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Confidential interviews with staff and clients indicate that the facility is not providing the adequate supervision to clients in care including having sufficient staff persons on duty to provide supervision as needed. Confidential interviews with clients and staff reveal that staff do not have “enough eyes” to maintain supervision, cannot implement clients’ coping skills including walkabouts, engage in age and developmentally appropriate activities with the varying ages and developmental needs of the clients in the cottages, or physically intervene in physical or aggressive behaviors, or other behaviors or inappropriate interactions observed due to lack of adequate staffing and staff training which poses an immediate risk to the clients in the care of the facility. Facility cited for Type A violation of Transitional Shelter Care Facilities, Interim Licensing Standards, Regulation 84665.3(b): Additional Staff Training. Records reviewed and interviews conducted indicate that staff have not received specialized training on the specialized needs of children in transition including clients accepted with developmental delays, mental health issues, behavioral health issues, violent tendencies, and aggression or substance use and detection, to name a few. Director states that training is needed in regards to drug use and dual diagnosis clients, and reported nobody from the Regional Center has ever come to provide training on dealing with clients with developmental disabilities or autism, which poses an immediate risk to the safety of the clients in care at the facility. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided along with appeal rights to Ms. McCoy.

staff are notified and told to clean their cottages and additional staff go out to the cottages to ensure that they are meeting ratio. Confidential interviews of staff indicated that certain staff who are “less vocal,” tend to be selected to speak with Licensing. During an inspection to the facility on 10/14/22, Licensing received push back from facility supervisors when requesting staff contact information. As a result of confidential interviews conducted with staff and clients, the allegation that staff interfere with licensing inspections is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Ms. McCoy and documentation provided to the facility.

This was not met as evidenced by Records review, confidential interviews with staff and clients indicate that the facility is not providing the care and supervision required including meeting the minimum staff ratios of one awake and on duty direct care staff present at the facility for ever four children present at the facility which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.

LPA Hill also provided Director McCoy with a copy of a request for Non-Compliance Conference letter while at the facility on 11/3/22. LPA informed Ms. McCoy that she has until 11/6/22 to provide dates and times to Licensing for Non-Compliance Conference for the week of 11/7/22.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This was not met as evidenced by Confidential interviews with staff and clients indicate that the facility is not providing the adequate supervision to clients in care including having sufficient staff persons on duty to provide supervision as needed. Confidential interviews with clients and staff reveal that staff do not have “enough eyes” to maintain supervision, cannot implement clients’ coping skills including walkabouts, engage in age and developmentally appropriate activities with the varying ages and developmental needs of the clients in the cottages, or physically intervene in physical or aggressive behaviors, or other behaviors or inappropriate interactions observed due to lack of adequate staffing and staff training which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to the clients in care.

deficiencies.description: Additional Staff Training. All administrators, facility managers, social work staff, and direct care staff shall receive four hours of training on the specialized needs of children in transition. This was not met as evidenced by Records reviewed and interviews conducted indicate that staff have not received specialized training on the specialized needs of children in transition including clients accepted with developmental delays, mental health issues, behavioral health issues, violent tendencies, and aggression or substance use and detection, to name a few. Director states that training is needed in regards to drug use and dual diagnosis clients, and reported nobody from the Regional Center has ever come to provide training on dealing with clients with developmental disabilities or autism, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.

met_with: Kim Robinson, Assistant Director & Stephanie McCoy, Director
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 1/20/23 at 11:15 AM and met with Kim Robinson, Assistant Director and Stephanie McCoy, Director to discuss findings of a case management investigation conducted by the Investigations Branch. LPA Hill informed Ms. Robinson and Ms. McCoy that on 10/24/22, an initial incident report was received stating that C1 and C2 (see LIC811 dated 1/20/23) had engaged in inappropriate sexual activity while at the facility. This incident was referred to Community Care Licensing Division's Investigations Branch for investigation and Investigator Melissa Weaver was assigned to investigate this incident. Confidential interviews conducted by Investigator Weaver confirmed that staff discovered C1 and C2 engaged in inappropriate sexual activity at the facility. Investigation revealed that S1 was informed by another youth in care about plans for C1 to go into C2's room and that S1 did enter C2's room and found the youth engaged in sexual acts. In addition, S2 reported to S1 that S2 observed C1 and C2 to be "too close to one another" during a movie at the facility prior to this incident. S1 was alleged to have had a conversation with C2 prior to the incident about C1 being "a child" but S1 failed to increase supervision and bed checks knowing the propensity of the youth in care. Additional staff interviews revealed that staff feel that they are not properly supervising youth at all times and that there are not enough staff during the graveyard shift. Additional interview with Ms. McCoy acknowledges that the facility is understaffed. Based on Investigator Weaver's observations, interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80078(a): Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The facility failed to provide the proper supervision necessary to meet the needs of the youth in care. Findings were discussed with the facility and documents, citations and appeal rights were provided.

met_with: Kim Robinson, Assistant Director & Stephanie McCoy, Director
narrative: Investigation concluded that C1 did report the incident to a staff at the facility. When interviewed by Investigator Weaver, C1 did remain consistent with their original report to facility staff and with their prior disclosure to LPA Tamara Hill. C2 denied knowing C1 but during an interview, C2 made statements that lead investigator to believe that C2 was not being honest. When facility staff were interviewed, they reported seeing C1 and C2 interacting on the evening of the alleged incident and admitted that it could have been possible for C2 to have entered C1’s room undetected due to there not being enough staff to supervise children on the graveyard shift. As a result of the information obtained and interviews conducted the allegation that a lack of care and supervision resulted in an inappropriate interaction between children is SUBSTANTIATED. The facility was cited for Type A violation of Title 22 Division 6 Regulations, 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs. The facility did not provide the supervision necessary to prevent an inappropriate interaction between C1 and C2. Exit interview conducted with Ms. McCoy and Ms. Robinson and documents were provided.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s needs. This was not met as evidenced by: Investigation revealed that the facility did not provide the supervision necessary to prevent an inappropriate interaction between C1 and C2 as staff admitted that the inappropriate interaction could have happened due to there not being enough staff in the overnight hours which is an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility is currently under a plan of correction that includes additional supervision and increased ratios of 1:2 during the day and 2 staff to seven children on the overnight shift per the agreement made with Community Care Licensing. Facility shall ensure that the required ratios are maintained and when additional supervision is necessary, youth will be designated "point person" which would require additional supervision and monitoring.

Written understanding of this requirement and any changes to the POC indicated shall be submitted to Licensing by close of business 1/23/23 by Director McCoy.

met_with: Matt Jaeger, Shomari Bond and Michelle Jenks
narrative: On 11/2/2021 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an announced inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to pre-licensing the facility as an emergency temporary shelter care facility (E-TSCF). LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Program Director (PD) Matt Jaeger and Assistant Program Director (APD) Shomari Bond. LPA Meza-Gonzalez inspected the facility along with PD Jaeger and APD Bond. The facility is set up as follows: Bedroom #1 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedroom #2 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedroom #3 has two twin beds with bedding, two chests and a bathroom. Bedroom #4 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedroom #5 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedroom #6 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate space for client’s belongings. There is a ½ bathroom next bedroom #1 and four full bathrooms next to bedrooms #2, 4, 5 and 6. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. There is an emergency door between bedroom #3 and 4. There are two closets for linen, one next to bedroom #1 and next to the staff office. The facility has a dayroom with a couch and a TV. There is also a TV in the main living areas with couches. The medication closet is locked and located next to the dayroom. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The food is prepared by the cafeteria on campus. The facility has seven days of perishable and two days of non-perishable food. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There are no bodies of water. Based on LPA Meza-Gonzalez’s observation of the facility, the clean, sanitary and in good repair. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided to the group home APD Bond.

On 2/28/2022 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to post-licensing the facility as an emergency temporary shelter care facility (E-TSCF). LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Assistant Program Director (APD) Shomari Bond. LPA Meza-Gonzalez inspected the facility along with APD Bond. The unit has five bedrooms, four ½ bathrooms, dayroom room, staff office, and communal area. The facility is set up as follows: Bedroom #1 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedroom #2 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedroom #3 has two twin beds with bedding, two chests and a bathroom. Bedroom #4 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedroom #5 has two twin beds with bedding and two chests. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate space for client’s belongings. There is a ½ bathroom next bedroom #1 and four full bathrooms next to bedrooms #2, 4, 5 and 6. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. There is an emergency door between bedroom #3 and 4. The closet next to the bedroom #1 has extra linen and board games. The closet next to the staff office is and has lockers for client to storage their belongs for safe keeping. The facility has a dayroom with a couch and a TV. There is also a TV in the main living areas with couches. The medication closet is locked and located next to the dayroom. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The food is prepared by the cafeteria on campus. The menu was posted. The facility has seven days of perishable and two days of non-perishable food. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. See LIC809C page 2

The water temperature measured at 112 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. The exterior of the facility has a basketball court and exercise equipment. There are no bodies of water. The following required posted items were observed and accessible to children: Ombudsman and Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation Policies, Neighbor complaint Policy, house rules and current menu. Based on LPA Meza-Gonzalez’s observation of the facility, the clean, sanitary and in good repair. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided to the group home APD Bond.

narrative: On April 15, 2022, the Department received a complaint report, with the allegations that staff caused injury to C1, staff physically assaulted C1 and staff made inappropriate comments to C1. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was involved in a restraint due to C1’s safety however there is inconsistency if C1 received bruises on C1’s foreman due to the restraint. Confidential information revealed inconsistency that a staff kicked C1 in the back which resulted in bruising on C1’s back. Confidential interviews revealed that there were no witnesses that heard staff making an inappropriate comment to C1 however there was inconsistency on who made the comment to C1. Based on record reviews and confidential interviews, staff caused injury to C1, staff physically assaulted C1 and staff made inappropriate comments to C1 are unsubstantiated. The details gathered for the incidents did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegations. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted an exit interview and provided a copy of this report along with appeal rights to APD Bond.

narrative: A review of the checklist submitted revealed that the facility was noting that they were calling the parents when the child was running away. LPA reviewed the phone records and noted that C1 had runaway on several occasions and the parents were called on most occasions except two. LPA found that phone record for 11/16/2020 and 11/19/2020 do not show a call was made to either phone numbers listed for the parents. Note that the Run/Return checklist did indicate a call was made to the parents for the same dates. Based on the information obtained there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility failed to contact the responsible parties when C1 ran away from the facility. therefore, the above allegation is unsubsantiated, meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence. narrative: The evidence as follows; On June 16, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed S2. During this interview, S2 told this LPA that sometime in December, S2 had seen one of the residents, name unknown, and (C1) hanging over the banister. S2 stated, “oh my god, are you retarded”. S2 stated to LPA Raissi that “it slipped out”. S2 denied that any inappropriate things were said to C1 and that C1 and S2 would joke around. On June 16, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed C1. During this interview, C1 told this LPA that S2 did say inappropriate comments but it was resolved in the meeting with the cottage supervisor (S3) and S2. Based on staff interviews conducted by LPA Ann Valenzuela and S2 on December 12, 2019, and LPA Raissi interviews with S2 on June 16, 2020, and S3 on June 16, 2020; C1 has a history of joking around and at times can be sensitive over comments made. Based on interviews with S2, S3, and CSW; C1 has a history of exaggerating claims. Based on interviews with two staff members (S1, S3) and one resident C2 (C2 interviewed on June 18, 2020), S2 has not made inappropriate comments. Interviews with S2 and C1 show that an inappropriate comment was made “retarded”; Therefore, the allegation is Substantiated. Based on interviews with S2, S3, and C1, the differences between S2 and C1 were resolved in a meeting and the outcome was not to joke with C1. Based on LPA Raissi interviews with S2, the intent was not to be insensitive to C1’s feelings. Interviews conducted by LPA Raissi revealed that the meeting initiated by the staff members resolved the differences between C1 and S2; Therefore, the licensee will NOT be cited. Based on LPA Raissi observations and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility will NOT be cited. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Linda Bourne for review and signature.

narrative:
information provided, stating the Junior’s cottage had ants during the time C1 and C2 were placed in there. All witnesses corroborate ants would be in C2’s bedroom and some witnesses also state ants were in the bathroom/shower of the cottage. SSSS states the facility has a pest control that serviced the facility in October, LPA was provided with invoice. However, all witnesses corroborated that C2 was moved rooms due to the continued ant problem in the cottage, specifically in C2's room. While CSW did not ever see the ants or hear about the ants directly from C1 and C2, CSW confirms she received notification from the facility that C2 was complaining of continued ant issue and was being moved to another room because of the ants. SSSS confirms ants were a problem at the end of 2020, however, states the ants were primarily in the yard/playground area a few steps away from the cottages, not in the cottage where C1 and C2 were placed. Still, the majority of witnesses confirm the presence of ants within the cottage even after pest control treatment. Based on confidential interviews, information gathered, and documents reviewed, the allegation that staff failed to keep the facility free from ants is SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met for the allegation. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. The facility is being cited under Title 22, Division 6, chapter 1 of the California Code of Regulations section 80087 (a) (1): Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were emailed to Ms. Linda Bourne for signature. Original signed report will be placed in facility file.

use the bathroom or ask for anything after lights go out in the cottage for bedtime. Additionally, it was reported that staff do not provide a variety of food and no alternative foods are offered to C2, so C2 goes hungry and has lost weight. Finally, it was reported that C1 and C2 are not allowed to have their own personal items brought by bio-mom to facility. While some witnesses state all of these allegations occurred as detailed, few details were provided. All other witness statements do not corroborate this information. Staff and CSW confirm that C1 and C2 never reported not being able to get water or use the restroom after lights out. Staff corroborate this does not occur, as children can always use the restroom or get water if needed. Both staff and CSW corroborate food is plentiful at the facility and that it was an adjustment for C1 and C2 as they are not used to eating healthier type foods. All witnesses corroborate that staff offer alternative meals and/or modify meals for C1 and C2. There is no documented evidence of weight loss for C2. All interviews corroborate that the facility required approval of items brought to the facility due to the risk of COVID-19. CSW and staff all confirm that C1 and C2 were able to receive personal items brought to them as long as they were approved by facility staff. Lastly, it was alleged that staff failed to seek timely medical attention for C1. Per SSSS, C1’s ankle injury was assessed immediately. Other witnesses corroborate this information. While the facility nurse assessed injury as an ankle sprain, C1’s bio-mom was not satisfied with the assessment made at the facility and called law enforcement to have C1 taken to emergency room to be assessed and treated. Witnesses corroborate that all necessary first aid steps and medical assessment steps were taken at the facility. Facility took immediate action and followed standard protocol. While a witness maintains these allegations occurred, they were unavailable for additional details. Based on interviews conducted and information obtained, the allegations that staff do not meet C1 and C2’s needs and staff failed to seek timely medical attention for C1, may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. The allegations are, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were emailed to Ms. Linda Bourne for signature. Signed report will be placed in facility file.
