On August 31, 2021 at 10:39AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Adrian Mendez and LPA Jesus Cervantes arrived unannounced and conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility Is a Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPAs were met at the facility by Senior Social Services Supervisor Linda Bourne. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There are six cottages: The Preschool Cottage houses both female and male children ages zero to five years, Junior Cottage houses both female and male children ages six to ten years, Intermediate Girls Cottage houses females ages eleven through fourteen years , Intermediate Boys Cottage houses males ages ten through thirteen, Adolescent Girls Cottage houses females fourteen years of ages eleven to fourteen years old, Adolescent Boys Cottage houses males fifteen years of age up to seventeen years old. All cottages occupied within approved capacity for each cottage. LPA toured the facility's dining hall; menu and food supply and facility is providing nutritious balance meals and snacks are provided at the cottages. Medical Unit is providing medical services and dispensing medication to clients as required. Medications were locked and properly stored. All sharp objects and utensils were locked and inaccessible to the clients in care. Cleaning products were observed to be locked and inaccessible to clients in each cottage. Hygiene items are being provided for each client and are stored in each client's personal locker when age appropriate. The facility has two pools on site, and they were both observed to meet the fencing requirements per Title 22 Regulations. The playgrounds areas were observed to have adequate cushioning material and the fall zones were maintained. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Disaster Plan, and current menu. Cont. on 809-C

A sample of 10 client files were reviewed during the inspection. No deficiencies were noted. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained off-site in the facility corporate office. LPA began review of 10 staff files. Due to time restraints, LPA will return at a later date to complete client and staff file reviews. During the inspection, three children and six staff were interviewed. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to Senior Social Services Supervisor Linda Bourne.

Confidential interviews and record review revealed that on 3/19/2021, C1 kicked and threw an object at a staff member that resulted in an injury to that staff. As a result, C1 was given a disciplinary consequence of being placed on Intensive Teaching Level (ITL). Confidential interviews revealed ITL is a restrictive program that takes away client privileges such as participating in certain activities and the usual length of ITL is 3 days or 6 shifts (2 shifts per day). Confidential interviews revealed C1 was placed on ITL several times while placed at OCFC due to C1’s aggressive and assaultive behavior. Confidential interviews revealed that ITL is a known disciplinary consequence for assaultive behavior and that during the 3 days of ITL clients must have good behavior for each day (or shift) to count, otherwise, ITL is extended for the period of time behavior is poor or can even start over. All interviews revealed there was no unfair discipline or treatment of C1 and some interviews further revealed C1 was also given opportunities to work off of ITL. Confidential interviews also revealed C1 would often say C1 was being targeted by staff if C1 received disciplinary consequences. CSW revealed C1 has a hard time understanding consequences and taking accountability for C1’s actions. Furthermore, CSW had no concerns about staff inappropriately disciplining C1 and CSW had observed staff to be very patient with C1. Based on confidential interviews of what occurred, the allegation that facility staff inappropriately disciplined C1, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and given to Kristi Fiskum.

met_with: Kristi Fiskum, An Tran, Christine Snapper, Debra Baetz
narrative:
On May 11, 2022, the California Department of Social Services’ (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) conducted a virtual meeting with the County of Orange Children and Family Services regarding its temporary shelter care facility, Orangewood Children and Family Center (Orangewood). The meeting was facilitated by CCLD Deputy Director Kevin Gaines via the Microsoft TEAMs platform, to discuss the licensing violations contained in the letter that CCLD issued to the County dated April 8, 2022. Participants in the meeting included: CCLD representatives: Deputy Director Kevin Gaines, Program Administrator (PA) Jean Chen, Assistant Program Administrators Kimberly Taylor, and Angela Carmack, Riverside Regional Manager LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Manager Ann Valenzuela, Licensing Program Analyst Adrian Mendez, Staff Services Manager II Marisa Sanchez CDSS’ Children and Family Services Division (CFSD) representative: Deputy Director Angie Schwartz, System of Care Branch Chief Sara Rogers, System of Care Health Program Specialist II (HPS) Dianna Wagner. Child Welfare Services County of Orange Children and Family Services representatives: Social Services Agency Director Debra Baetz, Chief Deputy Director An Tran, Director Christine Snapper, and Deputy Division Director Kristi Fiskum. Cont. on 809-C

The purpose of the meeting was to discuss Orangewood’s noncompliance with the temporary shelter care facility requirements provided in Health and Safety Code section 1530.8 and the Temporary Shelter Care Facility Interim Licensing Standards. Discussion included County of Orange’s plan to correct the violations and CFSD technical assistance opportunities. Deputy Director Gaines stated the purpose of the meeting and provided an explanation of the topics to be discussed. Program Administrator (PA) Jean Chen stated the meeting would cover System of Care’s case review information and Community Care Licensing’s required plan of correction for the shelter from the County of Orange. HPS Wagner offered information regarding the case reviews. Division Director Christine Snapper requested more specific information of the case reviews in order to identify solutions to the barriers. HPS Wagner will share this information subsequent to the meeting. The following written plan of correction is due to CDSS within 30 days, that includes: • A separate and distinctive plan of correction to address the children under six with overstays versus older children • A discharge plan for each child over 30 days currently placed at Orangewood • The County’s plan to eliminate overstays • Submit updates to the Plan of Operation/Program Statement for any modifications or revisions to policies and procedures The plan of correction shall be submitted to Regional Manager LaCresha Cook. A copy of this report was emailed to County of Orange Children and Family Services Deputy Division Director Kristi Fiskum for signature.

met_with: Linda Bourne, Senior Social Services Supervisor
narrative: It was reported that C1 had a scheduled medical appointment and was told the medical appointment would be rescheduled so C1 could attend the Disneyland trip. Conflicting interviews revealed C1 asked for the appointment to be rescheduled so they could attend the trip. Other interviews indicated that C1 wanted to attend the original appointment. Records reviewed showed that the appointment was rescheduled for two days later than the original appointment date. It was reported that when C1 returned to the facility from Disneyland they had dirty water on them, wanted to take a shower, and were told they needed to wait until the morning. Confidential interviews revealed clients were offered the option to take showers in the evening or morning. Conflicting interviews revealed clients were not allowed to take showers when they returned and were told they could use wipes to clean off. It was reported that clients brought drugs into the facility. Confidential interviews revealed clients smoked or used vaping devices in their bedrooms and bathrooms. Confidential interviews indicated that staff do not allow clients to bring in drugs, however, staff are not allowed to pat down clients as it would be a violation of their personal rights. Conflicting interviews revealed that some clients bring in vape pens and other interviews indicated that clients did not bring in vape pens. Based on confidential interviews, and records reviewed, the allegations that the facility did not ensure C1 attended a scheduled medical appointment, the facility did not allow C1 to take a shower on a timely basis, and facility staff did not prevent a minor from bringing drugs into the facility, which may or may not have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were reviewed with Linda Bourne, Senior Social Services Supervisor. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report, appeal rights, and LIC 811 will be emailed to the Administrator. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: staff check clients upon their return by using a metal detection wand, asking them to turn out their pockets, and backpacks. Per confidential interviews, when staff suspects clients are using drugs or has observed drug paraphernalia at the facility, staff talk to the clients to educate them and try to convince them to turn in the drugs. For the allegation of clients bringing weapons into the facility, confidential interviews revealed clients hide weapons outside of the facility to later retrieve. Conflicting interviews revealed staff use a metal detecting wand on the clients when they return from running away. Confidential interviews reported campus support staff do a perimeter check of the facility at least two times a day and if they find any weapons or drugs, they are confiscated. Lastly, for the allegation that the Facility is operating with insufficient staffing to meet the needs of children in care, confidential interviews revealed there have been a few times where there have not been enough staff in the cottage due to staff calling out or going to a meeting and calls are made to Campus Support or other cottages to see if they have additional staff to help in the cottage. Confidential interviews could not recall the dates or times there were not enough staff in the cottage. Confidential interviews and records reviewed did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegations that staff do not prevent children from using illegal drugs in the facility, staff do not prevent minors from bringing weapons into the facility, and the Facility is operating with insufficient staffing to meet the needs of children in care. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with Jose Mendez, Senior Social Services Supervisor. deficiencies.description:
80061(b) Reporting Requirements    
Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event....  This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  Based on observations and record review, incident reports have been submitted up to 36 days after the said incident occurred, which poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, Cottage Supervisors will send the SIR's directly to CCL.   All Incident Reports past 7 days will be submitted to CCL by June 14, 2023, by 5:00 pm. immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

On August 30, 2023 at 9:33 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz, LPA Jacquelyn Garcia and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela arrived unannounced and conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility Is a Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPAs Garcia and Valenzuela were met at the facility by Ben Turriietta and given a tour. . A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There are six cottages: The Preschool Cottage houses both female and male children ages zero to five years, Junior Cottage houses both female and male children ages six to ten years, Intermediate Girls Cottage houses females ages eleven through fourteen years , Intermediate Boys Cottage houses males ages eleven through fourteen, Adolescent Girls Cottage houses females fifteen years of ages to seventeen years old, Adolescent Boys Cottage houses males fifteen years of age up to seventeen years old. All cottages occupied within approved capacity for each cottage. Cleaning products were observed to be locked and inaccessible to clients in each cottage. Hygiene items are being provided for each client and are stored in each client's personal locker when age appropriate. LPAs did not tour the facility's dining hall or kitchen due to construction remodeling. Each cottage had menus and food supply. The facility is providing nutritious balanced meals and snacks are provided at the cottages. Medical Unit is providing medical services and dispensing medication to clients as required. Medications were locked and properly stored. All sharp objects and utensils were locked and inaccessible to the clients in care. Cont. on 809-C

The facility has two pools on site, and they were both observed to meet the fencing requirements per Title 22 Regulations. The playgrounds areas were observed to have adequate cushioning material and the fall zones were maintained. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Disaster Plan, and current menus. A sample of 5 client files were reviewed during the inspection. No deficiencies were noted. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained off-site in the facility corporate office therefore LPA's will need to return to complete file reviews. During the inspection, interviews were conducted of children. Due to time restraints, LPA will return at a later date to complete client and staff file reviews. . Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report and 811 form with list of confidential names was reviewed and given to Senior Social Services Supervisor Linda Bourne.

On the date listed above at 1:45 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley met with Marina Nunzez, Social Services Supervisor, to review a concern that incident reports are not reported within the seven-day time period. Per Title 22 all incidents are required to be reported within a seven-day time frame or less. LPA received an incident report for C1 dated 08/07/2023 and was sent to CCL on 09/13/2023. LPA Linley stressed the importance of reporting incidents in a timely manner. This process is necessary to ensure the welfare and well-being of all residents who are in care. The agency is in violation of regulation 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Please refer to LIC 809-D for detailed deficiency information. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were reviewed. Due to printer malfunctions, a copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to Linda Bourne. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements:
Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report.... shall be submitted  to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event....
This requirement was not met as evidenced by:   Based on observations and record review, the incident report for C1 was submitted 37 days after the said incident occurred, which poses an potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Ms. Nunez, a meeting will be scheduled with Social Service Supervisors and discuss that SIR's will be reviewed and submitted within 7 days or less.  A meeting agenda with signatures will be sent to LPA Linley by 09/29/2023 by 5:00 pm.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights:
84072(d)(10) To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by:  S1 struggling with C1 when they tried to remove the mattress from the bedroom until C1 let go of the S1 removed a piece of paper from the window and tossed it toward C1.
Based on confidential interviews and record review, staff did not treat C1 with dignity and respect, which posed a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Linda Bourne, S1 will met with their Supervisor and review training on Personal Rights and sign off acknowledging the training.  Linda will email LPA by end of day on 10/17/2023 with verification of training.

narrative:
On October 26 2020 at 12:00PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray made an announced Tele-Inspection via ZOOM at the (TSCF) TEMPORARY SHELTER CARE FACILITY, located on the grounds of the PACIFIC LODGE Campus (4900 SERRANIA AVE. WOODLAND HILLS CA 91364). The purpose of the Tele-Inspection was due to a SIT ALERT (1 Staff tested Positive for COVID-19).LPA and the participants objective were to ensure the Health of Safety of the Children in placement will be exhibited by ensuring that CDC Guidelines are implemented; in effort to prevent others from contracting the virus. Present in the inspection conducted via FaceTime and Zoom and are three (3) staff; including this LPA-Gray. Staff #1 (S1)-Facility Clinician Administrator and Staff #2 (S2) Health Facilities Evaluator Nurse. LPA-Gray ensured that all participants were linked and present. LPA-Gray reintroduced herself and cross introduced the participants (S1, S2). LPA-Gray asked a series of questions and observed the following preventive measures regarding COVID-19 during the video tour: LPA asked “If one or more of the youth Test positive, will the facility be able to isolate the youth from others? S1 confirmed that neither she, additional or youth have tested positive and discussed the facility quarantine isolation plan. S1 provided a virtual inspection of the TSCF facility including nine bedrooms (9). LPA observed six (6) feet of spacing between the beds and space in the common area. LPA-Gray asked were the youth and staff’s temperature checked daily and logged as well. S2 inquired about the number staff that has been tested who are assigned to the facility and came in close contact with the staff that tested positive. S1 did not disclose the names of staff that came in contact with the staff that tested positive; Due to the HIPAA Privacy Rule, Staff to protect individuals' medical records and other personal health information cannot be disclosure. S1 stated that she, other staff and youth temperatures are tested 1x a day, logged and the Health Department is notified. S2 recommended that temperature be tested twice a day; "When the staff arrive and when the depart for the day". S2 also ensure that disinfectant/cleaning agents were alcohol based recommended by the CDC.

LPA and S2 observed limited COVID-19 postings particularly in the hallways and on the door of the children's bedroom door. S2 and LPA recommended that additional colorful visual aids consolidating COVID-19 CHHS Positing; hygiene hand washing signs be posted in the hallway and on the door of the bedrooms. S2 suggest that the signs be laminated to prevent from fading and or ripping from moisture; particularly the signs that are posted in the bathroom and kitchen. LPA-asked has a plan been developed in the event when a youth returns from AWOL for short-period and extended period. S1 discussed the emergency plan in event that a child or staff displays asymptomatic. S1 stated that youth’s temperature are taken; they are instructed to shower and quarantined depending on how long they have been gone on AWOL. LPA-asked have all staff, residents, families and officials been informed and understand that they must always maintain social distancing (six feet of space). S1 stated that essential visitors are limited (i.e Social Workers, Probation Officers) and have been notified of the that a staff tested Positive for COVID-19. The cottage kitchen is not being utilized to cook food and all meals are delivered to each cottage from the facility Dining Hall; snacks are also distributed from the Dining Hall to the staff office 3 times a day to the residents. Youth eat in the common area at six feet distance. LPA recommended that resident youth and staff are directed to wash hands upon return to the facility. S1 ensured that the youth rooms are cleaned, commonly used areas and items (laptops, key boards, computer mouse, remote controls, cell phones, playing cards, are disinfected throughout the day and evening. S1 also ensured that social distancing, correctly wash their hands and displayed by practicing “cough etiquette”. LPA observed uncovered trash cans and loose paper towel on top bathroom counters and sinks. LPA advised S1 to place lids on all trash cans. S2 recommended that S1 have paper towel dispensers mounted on the wall. S1 agreed to send a pictures of the paper towel dispenser installed. LPA asked did the facility have enough PPE supplies and informed S1 that the department has ample PPE upon request with the options to pick up from CRP in EL Segundo or the and Wood Hills office. S1 displayed the PPE supplies in the cottage and stated that additional PPE's are stored in another building on the campus grounds. LPA recommended that the facility staff S1 review the CDC Resource Packaged items that was emailed in reference to reporting requirements for confirmed COVID-19 cases (County Public Health Department, Primary Physician, Responsible party/family, CCL Regional Office). S1 agreed to make the contact LPA when the changes have been made via email or telephone. LPA-Gray concluded the Tele-Inspection Positive and ask the S1 if any questions or needed further technical assistance. A copy of the report will be emailed to S1 Administrator of the TSCF for signature.

LPA reviewed the Unusual Incident Reports to confirm that the staff’s effort to provide a safe and healthful environment for residents, that indeed did follow restraint procedure evident by observation, monitoring, engaging, using crisis communication techniques to de-escalate and successfully used Pro-Act Protocol techniques were implemented based on the facilities Emergency Response plan. The staff implemented techniques to separate the fight, putting themselves in harm’s way by positioning themselves in between clients. Statements and documents obtained revealed that the all Walkie-Talkie’s were available, operable in addition to the cottage phone that is connected to office and the OD. LPA confirmed the staff to client ratio met regulations. LPA reviewed the facilities 25 Page: Emergency, Intervention Plan, Protocol and Procedures. In addition to the statements LPA gathered the facilities supportive documents: Optimist TSCF Staff Involved in the Incident (Optimist TSCF SIR written 5-3-2021 (I-track 754020); copy of PRO ACT Training and an Excerpt from an administrative staff regarding the radio checks to confirm that the Walkie Talkies were operable. LPA assessed that all statements were congruent with the method of interventions implemented to ensure that the facility provided proper supervision to support and met the needs of children in placement. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has determined that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision; Personal Right and Physical plant violations are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There are no deficiencies noted or cited per California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3. An exit interview was conducted in person and the report was provided to the Bekins Cottage Supervisor on 07/02/2021.

narrative:
On May 5, 2022, at 8:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), JoAunne Griffin conducted a Case Management Licensee Initiated inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to identify Neimeyer Cottage and Bekins Cottage, as the Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA met with Maria Bhattachan, Chief Administrative Officer (S1) who granted access to the facility. The entire physical plant was inspected. The facility is to provide Temporary Shelter Care Services up to 10 Days to sixteen (16) female clients ages 12-17 years and non-minor dependents. Each cottage will have a capacity of 8 clients. There is a pool on the premises that meets regulations. LPA observed pool surrounded by 5-foot self-latching gate that meets regulations; all staff have keys, are trained in water safety, have certificates, and monitor the clients while swimming. There is a dining hall, school and a chapel located on the campus that is not being utilized. Neimeyer Cottage: There are no clients currently residing in cottage. The bedrooms are prepared to be occupied by one (1) client. There is one (1) twin size bed, comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. There are two (2) separate walk-in closets and one (1) desk mounted to the wall. There is adequate lighting and the windows are observed to be in good condition. Room #3 is utilized as storage room equipped with extra clothing, linen, and hygiene items. LPA observed ample stored hygiene supplies and feminine products stored in a locked closet. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working order. Continued on LIC 809-C

Bekins Cottage: There are five clients currently residing in the cottage. The bedrooms are prepared to be occupied by one (1) client. There is one (1) twin size bed, comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. There are two (2) separate walk-in closets and one (1) desk mounted to the wall. There is adequate lighting, and the windows are observed to be in good condition LPA observed ample stored hygiene supplies and feminine products stored in a locked closet. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working order. In both cottages LPA observed, Ombudsperson for the Youth, Grievances, and a suggestion box. All required postings were posted on the wall in the dining area. Children are not restricted to make phone calls based on the approved phone calls list. There is a private room available for the clients to make phones calls and the Phone Call Log is kept in the staff office. The Needs and Services plans will be kept in the therapist office. The common area is equipped with adequate furniture; three (3) sofas, a bookshelf; furniture (i.e table, television). The kitchen is not being utilized to cook food. There is a non-operable gas stove (shut off) with the burners and all nobs removed. The refrigerator is used to store extra snacks and non-perishable foods. There is a dining table with eight (8) chairs. The food menu is posted on the refrigerator. The food is provided by an outside vender Every-Table that brings prepped meals with an expiration date. Clients will have access to snack including fresh fruit inside the cottage. The smoke detectors are operated on a connected system and carbon monoxide detectors are operational in both cottages. LPA observed four (4) fully charged fire extinguishers located in the kitchen and hallways. Fire extinguishers expire May 2022. The First Aid kits are in accordance with all required items and are located in the staff offices. LPA observed that trash cans are covered with a lid in the kitchen, bathrooms, and bedroom. There is a gym, activity room, art room, basketball court, baseball diamond, music studio and recreational activities available. LPA Gray concluded the inspection, and a copy of this report was left at the facility with the S1.

Based on interviews and analyzing all evidence, the department has found this complaint to be Unsubstantiated, meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to FA at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On October 26, 2022, at 10:15 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kuliema Calloway, made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of concluding complaint findings. LPA met with Theresa Nunez, Facility Administrator at Pacific Lodge Campus who granted access. LPA arrived and observed the front gate on Serrania Ave. is missing and under construction. LPA took photos. Based on the interviews with three of the Clients (C1, C2, and C3) and three of the Staff (PS, S2, and S3) the investigation revealed some of the clients are using drugs however, the investigation did not reveal enough evidence to corroborate the allegations of whether staff are not preventing minors from using drugs while in care. Also, the investigation revealed the staff has received training and is aware of the client’s needs therefore, there is not enough evidence to conclude staff are not competent to provide the services necessary to meet minors needs while in care.

narrative: Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has determined that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision is Unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and the report was provided to the Program Director on 12/21/2022.
investigation_findings: 13On December 21, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation and to deliver the findings. During the investigation, LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information in reference to the allegations. The Licensee denied the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, LPA assessed that all statements were congruent with methods of crisis communication to were implemented to redirect and encourage clients to make better choices for the health and safety. In review of documentary evidence there is no evidence or witnesses to support that the clients in care were not properly supervised and that the facility staff did not prevent a minor from AWOLing. Documentary evidence show that proper protocol that include evidence of iTrack Special Incident Report-(SIR) was written and submitted within the proper time frame and authorized representatives were notified.

investigation_findings: 13On December 21, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation and to deliver the findings. During the investigation, LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information in reference to the allegation. The Licensee denied the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, LPA assessed that all statements were congruent with methods of crisis communication were implemented to protect the minor from being assault by another minor in the facility. In review of documentary evidence, client was provided medical attention and there was no evidence of injuries sustained. There is no evidence or witnesses to support that the client in was not properly supervised and that proper reporting protocol was utilized to prevent the client in care from going AWOL. An iTrack Special Incident Report-(SIR) was written and submitted within the proper time frame and authorized representatives were notified.

narrative:
On August 16, 2023, at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray to conducted a Annual/Random inspection. LPA inspected the Neimeyer Cottage and Bekins Cottage identified as the Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). A health and risk assessment was conducted prior to entering the facility cottages. LPA met with the Assistant Supervisor (S2) who granted access to the facility who provided a tour of of the entire physical plant to be inspected. LPA also met with S1 who provided additional information regarding the building and grounds. The facility is to provide Temporary Shelter Care Services up to 10 Days to sixteen (16) female clients ages 12-17 years and non-minor dependents. Each cottage has a capacity of 8 clients. The facility will ensure to provide a document for clients that over-stay. There is a pool on the premises that meets regulations. LPA observed pool surrounded by 5-foot self-latching gate that meets regulations; all staff have keys, are trained in water safety, have certificates, and monitor the clients while swimming. There is a dining hall, school and a chapel located on the campus that is not being utilized. Outdoor Area: The space is free of hazardous materials and debris. LPAs observed all windows and screens to be in good condition. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. Neimeyer Cottage: There is one (1) client currently residing in cottage. There are 7 bedrooms that are prepared to be occupied by one (1) client. There is one (1) twin size bed, comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. There are two (2) separate walk-in closets and one (1) desk mounted to the wall. There is adequate lighting and the windows are observed to be in good condition. Room #3 is utilized as storage room equipped with extra clothing, linen, and hygiene items. LPA observed ample stored hygiene supplies and feminine products stored in a locked closet. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working order. LIC 809 1 of 2

Bekins Cottage: There are two (2) clients currently residing in the cottage. There are six (6) bedrooms prepared to be occupied by one (1) client. There is one (1) twin size bed, comfortable mattresses, clean linen, blankets, and pillows. There are two (2) separate walk-in closets and one (1) desk mounted to the wall. There is adequate lighting, and the windows are observed to be in good condition LPA observed ample stored hygiene supplies and feminine products stored in a locked closet. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working order. In both cottages LPA observed, Ombudsperson for the Youth, Grievances, and a suggestion box. All required postings were posted on the wall in the dining area. Children are not restricted to make phone calls based on the approved phone calls list. There is a private room available for the clients to make phones calls and the Phone Call Log is kept in the staff office. The Same Day Assessments and the Safety Plans are kept in the therapist office located in the Bekins Cottage. The common areas are equipped with adequate furniture; three (3) sofas, a bookshelf; table and television. The kitchens are not being utilized to cook food. There is a non-operable gas stove (shut off) with the burners and all nobs removed. The food is provided by an outside vender Every-Table that brings prepped meals with an expiration date. LPA observed ample perishable, non perishable food and extra snacks store in both refrigerators. There is a dining table that seats eight (8) chairs, the chairs provided according to the Census and other chairs are temporarily stored in another room for the safety of client and staff. The food menu is posted on the refrigerator. Clients have access to snack including fresh fruit inside the cottage. The smoke detectors are operated on a connected system and carbon monoxide detectors are operational in both cottages. LPA observed a total of six (6) fully charged Fire extinguishers expired July 2024 located in the staff office for the safety of the clients and staff during a crisis. The First Aid kits are in accordance with all required items and are located in the staff offices. LPA observed that trash cans are covered with a lid in the kitchen, bathrooms, and bedrooms. There is a gym, activity room, art room, basketball court, baseball diamond, music studio and recreational activities available. LPA Gray concluded the Annual/Random inspection and a copy of this report was left at the facility Program Director LIC 809 2 of 2

This report is Amended from 08/23/2023 to update the language to the LIC809-D On August 29, 2023, at 11:35AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Other inspection. LPA met with Theresa Nunez Program Director A health and risk assessment were conducted. The purpose of the inspection was to assess Civil Penalties for Staff #1 not being associated to the above facility while providing care and supervision to children in care. Staff was observed to be working in the facility without a criminal record clearance and/or clearance transfer. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 86019(e)(1) Criminal Record Clearance. Staff was observed to be working in the facility without a criminal record clearance and/or clearance transfer. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 809D, LIC 421BG and Appeal Rights were provided to the Program Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
(a) (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing, or volunteering in a licensed facility: (1) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff #1 was observed to be working in the facility without a criminal record clearance and/or clearance transfer.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Deficiency was discussed with Administrator and with the Facility Supervisor. The Facility will submit written plan of correction regarding policy and procedure to ensure all staff will have a criminal record clearance before beginning work, no later than September 6, 2023. Staff #1 was immediately removed from the scheduled until fingerprint clearance has been completed.

deficiencies.description: Notwithstanding Section 80054(a), an immediate penalty of $100 per cited violation per day for a maximum of five (5) days shall be assessed if any individual required to be fingerprinted under Health and Safety Code Section 1522(b) has not obtained a California clearance or a criminal record exemption, requested a transfer of a criminal record clearance or requested and be approved for a transfer of an exemption as specified in Section 80019(e) prior to working, residing or volunteering in the facility.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Bill will be mailed. 
LIC 421BG provided on 08/29/2023

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara, and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection on 11/7/23 at 10:15 AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 22 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 22 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811,11/7/23). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the same day assessment, CFT Matrix, and safety plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Theresa Nunez.

On March 12, 2024, LPA Regina Martin conducted the initial complaint inspection and met with Facility Director to inform receipt of the allegation and subsequent investigation. Evidence obtained from confidential interviews of three residents and one staff member, as well as review of facility file and related records, revealed one youth being sexual assaulted occurring while outside the facility during an attempt to recruit them into prostitution. Confidential statements revealed staff are trained on being observant of signs of sex trafficking and prostitution recruitment. Staff take an active trauma informed role in minimizing the impact on youth in care. Confidential interviews further revealed that facility staff made numerous attempts to prevent youth from interacting with sex trafficking youth and staff make continued attempts to discourage youth leaving the facility without permission. The investigation found a lack of evidence to support the allegation of facility staff’s lack of supervision leading to sexual exploitation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. A finding that the allegation is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On June 20, 2024, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin arrived at PACIFIC LODGE CAMPUS-TEMPORARY SHELTER CARE FACILITY and met with Facility Director, Theresa Nunez to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. On March 5, 2024, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging lack of supervision as a youth was reportedly sexually exploiting another youth in care. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigations Branch, Investigator Edward Hector. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative:
On 2/18/2025 at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez made an announced visit with the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing/relocation inspection to the above facility. LPA and LPM met with Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant LPA and LPM entered from the front door into the Living Room that has 2 couches, 1 side table, 1 coffee table and a closet nook with shelving and hanger space. There is a dining room with a table and 2 chairs next to the kitchen area. The kitchen has a working stove top, microwave, dish washer, toaster and sharps are kept locked under the sink. There is no refrigerator at the time of this inspection. There are 3 bedrooms all of them equipped with 2 full beds, a closet and the three screens on the bedroom windows needs to be replaced. Room 1 is an office area with 4 desks, a closet that houses a secure cabinet that will hold the client’s medications, files with a window that will be secured to prevent break ins and a bathroom with a working sink, shower, and toilet. Room 2 is the living room/common area with 1 couch, 1 chair and a bookshelf with arts and crafts supplies, all furniture is in good repair. There is one full bathroom leading to the client bedrooms with a working toilet and running warm water with a temperature of 120 degrees. LPA suggests lowering the water temperature to maintain client’s safety. LPA also suggests adding to the fence line on the left side of the home when approaching the front door due to easy access to parked campers on the side of the home. Continue to LIC 809-C

The backyard is gated, with ample space for the clients to move about. The facility has a 2019 Kia to be used to transport clients the facility plans on acquiring a second facility vehicle. Once the new vehicle has been attained the information will be provided to the LPA. There is a garage with bins that have spare clothes, toys, arts and crafts materials, cleaning supplies, a washer and dryer unit and the First Aid kit. LPA observed a camera in the front of the house but there were no cameras observed inside the facility. LPA provided a copy of the PIN for the licensee to reference. The following required documents need to be posted, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Let-Us-Know flyer and Complaint contact numbers and license once granted. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children in care and kept in the locked garage. Once a refrigerator is installed the temperature need to be at or below 45 degrees F. With nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods three days minimum. There are plates, cups and cooking supplies ready for clients. A working telephone will need to be made available at the facility. Smoke detectors are in working order. The Carbon monoxide detector will need to be installed. Hot Water between 105–120-degree F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order but will need to be mounted for the fire inspection. Toilets, wash basins and shower fixtures in good repair, no leaks and there is hot water accessible. Soap and Paper towels are available to clients. Bedroom-required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. The facility is free of vermin. For the fire clearance to be granted the Fire Department requests the facility to make the following adjustments: · Garage door shall be 20 minute fire rated, self-closing, self-latching, and provided with smoke/fire gaskets. Door and frame shall bear the 20 fire rated label. · Fire extinguisher is not mounted. Mount extinguisher, it shall be mounted between 3-5’ from floor level, but no lower than 4”. Mount extinguisher in a centralized area where is easily visible, accessible and not prone to being blocked. · Provide smoke alarms in dining room and family room. Smoke alarms shall be interconnected and hardwired to the homes electrical wiring. · Provide carbon monoxide detector. Continue to LIC 809-C

· Provide room numbers, two bedrooms, being used by Residents. Room numbers shall match facility floor sketch. · Bedroom screens need to be replaced. · Refrigerator needs to be installed. · The office closet window needs to be secured and inaccessible to clients. · Night stands with drawers need to be added to client bedrooms. · Water temperature needs to be lowered. · Perishable food should be available for 3 days and Nonperishable for 7 days. · Sealed containers for leftover food need to be made available. · 6 chairs will need to be made available at the dining room table. · Garage shelving should be organized and made inaccessible to clients. A follow up inspection will be conducted once the facility passes their fire inspection. Per licensee they will not be open for business until late March or early April. CCL will be notified when the facility is ready for operation. No CareTool was available for this type of inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

On 3/25/2025 at 9:04 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez made an announced visit with the purpose of conducting a follow up pre-licensing/relocation inspection to the above facility. LPA and LPM met with Administrator, Ian Longue and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. Physical Plant LPA and LPM entered from the front door into the Living Room that has 2 couches, 1 side table, 1 coffee table and a closet nook with shelving and hanger space. There is a dining room with a table and 4 chairs and a bench next to the kitchen area. The kitchen has a working stove top, microwave, dish washer, toaster, refrigerator and sharps are kept locked under the sink. There are 3 bedrooms all of them equipped with 2 twin beds, a closet and foldable shelving units. Room 1 is an office area with 4 desks, a closet that houses a secure cabinet that will hold the client’s medications and files with a window that has been secured to prevent break ins and a bathroom with a working sink, shower, and toilet. Room 2 is the living room/common area with 1 couch, 1 chair and a bookshelf with arts and crafts supplies, all furniture is in good repair. There is one full bathroom leading to the client bedrooms with a working toilet and running warm water with a temperature of 113 degrees. Continue to LIC 809-C

The backyard is gated, with ample space for the clients to move about and a gardening service that comes by for maintenance every 2 weeks. The facility has a 2019 Kia to be used to transport clients the facility plans on acquiring a second facility vehicle. Once the new vehicle has been attained the information will be provided to the LPA. There is a garage with bins that have spare clothes, toys, arts and crafts materials, cleaning supplies, a washer and dryer unit and the First Aid kit. The following required documents will be posted by the licensee in the common area, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, See Something Say Something Flyer, Complaint contact numbers and license once granted. Licensee will submit a picture to LPA to prove that the required documents are posted in the common area. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children in care and kept in the locked garage. Refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees F. With nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods three days minimum. There are plates, cups and cooking supplies ready for clients. A working telephone is available at the facility. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are in working order. Hot Water between 105–120-degree F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. Toilets, wash basins and shower fixtures in good repair, no leaks and there is hot water accessible. Soap and Paper towels are available to clients. Bedroom-required linen and furnishings are fully stocked. The facility is free of vermin. The fire clearance for the facility was granted on 3/18/2025. Deficiencies that were observed during the initial pre licensing inspection on 2/18/2025 have been fixed. · Room numbers were added to clients bedrooms. · Bedroom screens have been installed. · Refrigerator has been installed. · The office closet window has been secured with brackets and has been made inaccessible. · Foldable drawers are accessible to the clients. · Water temperature was lowered to 113 degrees Continue to LIC 809-C

·Perishable food are available for 3 days and Nonperishable for 7 days. · Sealed containers for leftover food is available. · 4 chairs and a bench are available for client use at the dining table. · Garage shelving is organized and made inaccessible to clients. In addition, the licensee shall have an area for clients and their representative to file grievances when needed. Licensee will show proof to the LPA of a grievance box/designated area. Per licensee they will begin accepting clients towards the second week of April. CCL will be notified when the facility is ready for operation. No CareTool was available for this type of inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Ian Longue and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

On May 23, 2025 at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived unannounced at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection to follow up regarding an incident report. LPA met with Hans Owhowho, Lead Staff, who assisted LPA Buchannan with the inspection. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility. On March 22, 2025 CCL received an incident report dated May 15, 2025 in which a client had gotten into an altercation with another peer. LPA requested the following documentation: Client Roster, Staff Roster, Staff Schedule, Staff Contact information, and Needs and Services Plans. LPA conducted 3 staff interviews during today's visit. This case management will remain open. Further investigation is needed. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Ian Longue, Facility Administrator and Alyssum Maguire, Executive Director via email. LPA was unable to provide a physical copy of report due to technical issues with their printer.

On May 23, 2025 at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Facility and was greeted by Han Owhowho, Lead Staff, who granted LPA access. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiencies. 4 window screens were missing from 3 client bedrooms and 1 client bathroom. 1 client bedroom was missing their curtain rod. LPA observed the staff pick up all the missing window screens and the curtain rod was in the clients bedroom. Staff also stated that they called the facilities maintenance worker to fix the screens and curtain rod prior to LPAs arrival and that they would be fixed the same day. LPA observed the call log as evidence that the work order was placed. This case management will remain open, until facility provides proof of completed repairs. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Ian Longue, Facility Administrator and Alyssum Maguire, Executive Director via email. LPA was unable to provide a physical copy of report due to technical issues with their printer.

On June 5, 2025, at approximately 11:40 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Orlando Areizaga made an announced visit with the purpose of conducting a closure inspection to the above facility on behalf of LPA Sarina Buchannan. LPA met with Administrator, Ian Longue and conducted a walk through of the interior and exterior of the facility. LPA observed the following: · 1 living room, 1 kitchen, 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 1 office, garage, and outdoor area. · The home was furnished, per Administrator that is how the facility came. · Closets were empty · An assortment of donated clothing in the garage · There were no signs of clients living at the facility · Two copies of the license were retrieved. During the inspection LPA observed a stack of folders on the desk, which were client’s folders collected by the Administrator who indicated that the folders must have been left behind. This facility will be closed effective June 5, 2025. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Ian Longue and a copy of this report will be sent to Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire via email.

On June 26, 2025 at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at Progress Ranch Welcome Center II (Kenneth) to close this case management that was initially open at Progress Ranch Welcome Center (Mariposa) on May 23, 2025. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the Progress Ranch Welcome Center II (Kenneth). On May 22, 2025 CCL received an incident report dated May 15, 2025 in which a client had gotten into an altercation with another peer. LPA requested the following documentation: Client Roster, Staff Roster, Staff Schedule, and Staff Contact information. Based on interviews conducted and documentation obtained it was confirmed that the clients in care had gotten into an altercation, but staff did follow the appropriate procedure to ensure the health and safety of the clients. Staff attempted to deescalate clients on multiple occasions throughout the incident using both proximity support as well as verbal techniques. Staff also used the approved emergency intervention plan by following the clients and communicating among each other to determine the best way to respond. In addition, staff followed protocol on reporting requirements. LPA was unable to interview both clients in question regarding the incident. This case management that was initially opened on 5/23/25 is now closed. No further investigation is needed. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Meghan Reedy, Clinical Supervisor.

On June 26, 2025 at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at Progress Ranch Welcome Center II (Kenneth) to close this case management that was initially open at Progress Ranch Welcome Center (Mariposa) on May 23, 2025. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the Progress Ranch Welcome Center II (Kenneth). On May 23, 2025 LPA observed the following deficiencies at Progress Ranch Welcome Center (Mariposa): · 4 window screens were missing from 3 client bedrooms and 1 client bathroom. · 1 client bedroom was missing their curtain rod On June 5, 2025 LPA Orlando Areizaga made an announced visit to Progress Ranch Welcome Center (Mariposa) for the purpose of conducting a closure inspection and observed no clients to be present and the facility to be in good repair. This facility was also closed on June 5, 2025 therefore this case management was closed without confirming a plan of correction. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Meghan Reedy at Progress Ranch Welcome Center II (Kenneth).

met_with: Alyssum Maguire, Matt Lemcke, Kourtney Hamilton
narrative: On 01/29/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted this Prelicensing Inspection and was met by Progress Ranch Executive Director Alyssum Maguire, Director of Operations Matt Lemcke, and pending Administrator Kourtney Hamilton. A tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant was given and the following was observed: There are three bedrooms designated for clients, each of which are equipped with the appropriate furnishings: the beds had sufficient linens, coverings, and were all found to be in good working condition. There was also enough dresser space for clients' personal clothing/belongings. The kitchen refrigerator contained enough perishable food for at least three days at capacity; there was also enough dried goods for at least seven days at capacity. There is also a full freezer in the garage for overstock food items. Two faucets (at the two downstairs vanity sinks) delivered hot water above 120 degrees Fahrenheit (123 and 128 degrees, respectively). The area out of which medications are to be administered/stored is yet to be determined. There were two areas of the exterior fencing that needed repair. There are no bodies of water on grounds. There were no potentially hazardous items or areas on the premises that were left accessible. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Maguire.

On 02/16/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a follow-up walk-through inspection to confirm the corrections have been completed on physical plant items that were pointed out during the first pre-licensing visit on 01/29/2024. Bathroom fixtures (sink faucet, showers) provided hot water whose temperature readings were within normal regulatory requirements. The fence's minor fixes were observed to be completed. There was a securable cabinet designated for medications to be centrally stored. An upstairs window was also observed to be equipped with a securing device to help prevent unsafe egress. The facility had on hand sufficient perishable food for two days and dried goods for seven days for a capacity of six children; the children's bedrooms were found to have all the required linens, furnishings, and storage for clients personal belongings. No potentially hazardous areas or items were left accessible. Per Ms. Maguire only a handful more staff need to complete Ukeru training by the end of Sunday. The license for this TSCF will tentatively be issued on 02/19/2024. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Maguire

On 02/16/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a case management inspection to follow up on an incident that occurred on 02/11/2024. LPA met with Executive Director Alyssum Maguire who was informed that the incident was concerning an escalated youth, County of Sacramento direct-care staff, and also involved responding law enforcement. No youth or direct-care staff were on site at the time of this inspection; LPA requested for Ms. Maguire to help identify the youth and staff involved--further investigation is required as of this time. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Maguire.

On 09/11/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) and met with Ian Longue, Co-Administrator. A tour of the interior and exterior areas of the program's physical plant was facilitated as well as interviews with youth and Progress Ranch staff. No Building & Grounds violations were observed; a review of clients' records was initiated. More time is needed to complete the inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On October 3, 2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a case management. LPA met with Radiance Clinton, Administrator in Training (AT) and was granted entry into the home. LPA and AT discussed that the facility wishes to take youths under six (6) years old. LPA explained the regulations and asked that AT and the Facility Administrator should meet with their team and discuss what decision they wish to take with this new information. LPA recommended having the following items if they do go the under six route: Formula (options for the different needs or allergies)/ Rice Cereal/ Baby Food Bottles (different sizes)/ Bottle Wand or Bottle Cleaner Different nipples for the bottles Diapers (All sizes and recommend different brand in case of allergies) Changing Table & Changing Pads Wipes Bibs and Burp Rags Cribs (Interchangeable is recommended so it can change as needed for the size/age) Pack n Play Crib Mattress Linens and Blankets (3 pair minimum, for changes) Clothes (All size ranges and seasonally appropriate) Age Appropriate toys Towels/Washcloths Potty Chair Pacifier with guard shields High Chair with broad base legs, straps, and a washable seat) Car Seats and Baby Gates (Cont. on LIC 809C)

During LPA's walk through of the facility LPA observed in the garage storage area the following items: Clothes in range from infants to teens for different seasons. Infant Bath Tubs Some Diaper Changing supplies (Aquaphor, A & D ointment, and lotion) Some bathing supplies (Baby Shampoo) Crib in the box Baby Gates LPA provided their business card so that AT can let LPA know if they are going to pursue the change in license. No deficiencies were cited at this time.

No other youth reported that Shelter staff, either in general or particularly the two mental health workers, were bullying clients—contrary to part of a youth’s statement about staff. There was only one other youth who was a supposed witness to the incident but this youth provided inconsistent details about the alleged rough handling of the purported victim—that youth also stated that they only got glimpses of the incident that took place in a client’s bedroom and that they were only walking by the opened door of the room. There was enough corroboration between obtained statements and an incident report to support the staff’s claim that while some physical restraint was applied on the youth in question, this was done within the context of that youth attempting to harm themselves with a piece or pieces of broken glass. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 09/23/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) to close the complaint investigation. LPA met with Ian Longue, Co-Administrator, to whom the following findings were delivered: LPA investigated an allegation that Staff handled minor in a rough manner. LPA opened the investigation on 05/15/2024, during which time a walkthrough of the Shelter’s building & grounds was done—inside and out. Throughout the course of the investigation four youth, four direct-care staff, and one case-carrying county social worker were interviewed. Records reviewed as part of the investigation were a youth’s intake documents as well as staff training records, and submitted unusual or special incident reports from the facility. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: There was no consensus as to the identity of an individual seen in a video recording to be holding a youth by the wrist and dragging the youth out of the bedroom. The video cannot be placed in a moment in time as no timestamp information was retrieved from the video file. The youth being dragged could not recall who the other individuals in the video were, nor could the youth remember what was happening in the video. This youth did state that, though it happened a lot, whenever they were placed in a manual restraint, they “probably deserved it.” It was clear to this LPA that the individuals in the video were laughing, indicative of it being more of a playful situation rather than something egregious, punitive, or abusive in any way. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 09/23/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) to close the complaint investigation. LPA met with Ian Longue, Co-Administrator, to whom the following findings were delivered: LPA investigated allegations that a 1) Minor was not accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff, and that 2) Facility staff handled minor in an inappropriate manner. LPA opened the investigation on 04/26/2024, during which time a walkthrough of the Shelter’s building & grounds was done. Two youths in care were interviewed on this day. Several more youths were interviewed throughout the course of the investigation as well as multiple staffers. Records reviewed were intake packets and individualized program plans; additionally, incident reports were re-examined. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative:
On 11/21/2024 at approximately 9:00am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz conducted an Informal Meeting with the above facility for the purposes of initiating a conversation about the new changes happening at the facility. Present during the meeting was LPA Tatyana Shulz and Sarina Buchannan, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez, Regional Manager (RM) Margo Castaneda, Clinical Supervisor Sydney Harkruiz and Executive Director Alyssum Maguire. Below is a summary of the topics that were discussed and the answers that were provided by the licensee: Follow up on the three staff members that were terminated. The three staff members were terminated as of 11/8/2024. Around that same time it was brought to the facilities attention that the previous assigned Administrator has family ties to one of the terminated staff members and has since resigned from their position as of 11/15/2024. An HR representative was also found to be related to several of the staff allowing for the hire of family members without the Executive Directors knowledge. Which caused the checks and balances of the hiring and internal complaint process to be ineffective. That HR representative has since been terminated from their position. Appointment of a new Administrator. LPA Shulz requested the facility provide the documentation needed in order to assign the prospective Administrator Ian Longue to the role. The facility has implemented four full-time lead staff. Three being a Lead I and one being a Lead II, with plans of making one Lead I a Lead II. With the Lead II position being able to provide audits for the Administrator and vice versa. Qualifications and duties that the role requires will be discussed in detail with Ian Longue, Alyssum Maguire and Sydney Harkruiz on 12/5/2024. Quarter Reports. LPA Shulz reiterated the dates that the Quarter Reports need to be submitted to Licensing and the critical details that need to be mentioned in those reports. Facility staff acknowledged the requirements and stated they would put those deadlines on their calendars for a swifter turn around time of said reports. LPA will send those due dates to the facility. Continue to LIC 809-C

Staff hiring. When the three terminated staff were let go from their positions other staff members that were not directly involved in the incident have since decided to part ways with the facility. There is currently a new cohort of 6 staff members graduating on 11/22/2024 that are waiting for a certified trainer in CPI and Ukeru to conduct those training's before being allowed on the floor. Ian Longue is one of the staff members that is taking the training in order to become a CPI and Ukeru instructor. Facility population change (Children under 6). Progress Ranch is currently in the process of opening up another facility. In the new Plan of Operation for that home the population that they plan on serving will include children under 6. In order to keep siblings/families together, the facility plans on clearing the house any time a sibling set or parent and child dynamic is brought into the home. The current facility address for Progress Ranch will be relocating shortly due to the home owner selling the property. LPA will follow up on the relocation plans. The relocation has to be a new facility address. How will the facility operate moving forward? Moving forward the facility will begin to construct checks and balances in the scheduling by placing Lead II staff to cover front end and back end shifts allowing for a shift cross over which will keep all staff accountable. The Lead II will be available Sunday- Wednesday and Wednesday- Saturday for 7 day coverage instead of the previous 5 day coverage. They plan on implementing weekly training's every Wednesday. Yesterday on 11/20/2024, the facility had their first weekly training on boundaries, family relationships, and use of personal phones. If the staff cannot attend the training's for any reason that week, they will be recorded and staff will be made to watch them as early as possible. Upper management also plans on making more unannounced visits to the home which will allow for more face time with all staff. Lastly, staff plan on holding each other accountable for their actions and there will no longer be just one staff monitoring a client alone.

On November 25, 2024 at approximately 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced Case Management inspection at the above facility and met with, Kailah Bickle, who assisted LPA with the inspection. On November 21, 2024 CCL received 2 incident reports stating that there had been a medication error for 2 clients in care resulting in both clients missing their prescribed night time dose on November 18, 2024. LPA requested the following documentation: client roster, staff roster, staff training's, and staff schedule with contact information from the date of the incident. LPA toured the inside and outside of the facility. LPA conducted 2 interviews at the facility. This case management will remain open. Further investigation is need. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Kailah Bickle, Case Manager.

On November 25, 2024 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Care Shelter. LPA was greeted by Kailah Bickle, Case Manager, who granted LPA entry. LPA conducted a tour of the Temporary Care Facility where LPA Buchannan observed the following deficiencies: Mold and mildew in the caulking of the downstairs client bathroom. The Temporary Care Shelter has been cited a Technical Violation..This case management will remain open, until a follow up inspection is conducted to ensure the facility is in full compliance. (see LIC 9102TV) Exit interview conducted and A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Kailah Bickle, Case Manager.

On 12/5/2024 at approximately 10:00am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz conducted an Informal Meeting with the above facility for the purposes of discussing administration duties, responsibilities and reporting requirements. Present during the meeting was LPA Tatyana Shulz and Sarina Buchannan, Clinical Supervisor Sydney Harkruiz, Prospective Administrator Ian Longue and Executive Director Alyssum Maguire. Below is a summary of the topics that were discussed and the answers that were provided by the licensee: New Staff and Training. Due to staff dismissal and turn over the facility has begun the process of training other supervisory staff in CPI and Ukeru. The facility has been given two weeks upon the trained supervisors return to complete recertification of all staff in Ukeru. Currently, the facility is conducting interviews for the Lead staff position which will work either the 6am-4pm, 2pm-midnight, or 11pm-9am shift ensuring that a facility manager will be on site during all hours. Administrator Qualifications and Duties. LPA Shulz discussed the Administrator qualifications and duties. Reviewing the specific job duties that are required for the position and the documentation still needed in order to appoint Ian Longue as the new administrator of this facility. LPA discussed creating a system that will allow CCL access to requested documentation if the Administrator can not be on site to provide them. It was agreed that the facility will create a separate shared folder for CCL that will house, training documents, work orders, plans of correction and incident reports which Lead staff will have access to. If CCL staff needs access to confidential personnel files, they will be able to contact HR, once a new HR representative has been appointed or Alyssum. Continue report on LIC 809-C

Quarter Reports. LPA Shulz reiterated the dates that the Quarter Reports need to be submitted to Licensing and requested a new Quarter 3 report be drafted and submitted due to incorrect quarter information being placed on the report. Facility staff acknowledged the requirements and the need for an updated report. Staff placed those deadlines on their calendars for all upcoming report requests. Note: Quarterly Reports are due to CCL on the following dates March 31, June 30, September 30 and December 31. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the licensee for signature.

On December 10, 2024 at 12:54 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Care Shelter for the purpose of conducting a follow up case management inspection. LPA was greeted by Danaye Hall, House Lead 2, who granted LPA entry. LPA conducted a tour of the Temporary Care Facility where LPA Buchannan observed the following deficiencies: Mold and mildew in the caulking of the downstairs client bathroom. LPA Buchannan received pictures from the facility on 12/3/24 showing that the caulking in the bathroom had been repaired and all mold and mildew had been removed. On 12/10/24 LPA Buchannan observed the caulking to be replaced and mold and mildew was no longer present. This case management that was initially open on November 25, 2024 is now closed. The facility is in full compliance. Exit interview conducted and A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Danaye Hall, House Lead 2.

No other interviewed youth corroborated the purported improper or unjustified search of a particular minor’s personal belongings, nor did any interviewee (children and staff alike) report that they had ever seen a client’s personal items left strewn about after a direct-care staffer’s apparent search of the inside of that youth’s bag. Statements gathered from interviews with staff were individually conducted in separate places and times—with consistent descriptions of the facility’s protocol concerning searches of clients’ personal property and rooms: that there is no blanket search policy and that they are only done when there is, or has been, reasonable suspicion that a minor has, in their possession, prohibited and/or illicit substances and paraphernalia or any other manner of potentially hazardous items. In regard to accusations of staff speaking to minors inappropriately, and staff not treating youth with dignity and respect, no additional clarifying details were provided by youth as to what was said by whom, when and where these instances took place, and/or how staff went about in doing these things—no other witnesses were named and youth did not provide more specific times in which these violations allegedly happened. Overall, there were inconsistent statements obtained throughout the investigation process; therefore, the above allegations cannot be substantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, and of the Appeal Rights, is being provided to the facility.
