narrative: On December 26, 2024 at approximately 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced follow up Case Management inspection to the above facility and met with Danaye Hall, House Lead 2, who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA Buchannan opened a case Management on November 25, 2024 regarding 2 incident reports received on November 21, 2024. The reports stated that there had been a medication error for 2 clients in care resulting in both clients missing their prescribed night time dose on November 18, 2024. The purpose of today's visit was to follow up with subsequent interviews. During todays visit LPA attempted 1 client interview but was informed that the client left the facility without permission on December 20, 2024 and has not returned since. LPA Buchannan was informed that client was exited from the program and will no longer remain at the facility. LPA also attempted 1 staff interview but also informed that both staff involved in the medication error no longer work at the facility. This case management will remain open. Further investigation is needed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Danaye Hall, House Lead 2.

On December 26, 2024 at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Care Shelter for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection. LPA was greeted by Danaye Hall, House Lead 2, who granted LPA entry. LPA conducted a tour of the Temporary Care Facility where LPA Buchannan observed the following deficiencies: The 2 clients bedrooms are missing the bedroom door LPA was informed that the bedroom door has been missing since at least December 16, 2024 and has yet to be replaced. LPA was unable to confirm if work orders had been placed due to staff not having access to the documents. This case management will remain open, until a follow up inspection is conducted to ensure the doors were replaced. (See LIC 9102TV) Exit interview conducted and A copy of this report were provided to Danaye Hall, House Lead 2.

On January 9, 2025 at approximately 1:29pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz arrived unannounced at the above Temporary Care Shelter for the purpose following up on a Case Management investigation. LPA Shulz met with Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire who granted LPA access to the facility. LPA Buchannan opened a case Management on November 25, 2024 regarding 2 incident reports received on November 21, 2024. The reports stated that there had been a medication error for 2 clients in care resulting in both clients having missed their prescribed nighttime dose on November 18, 2024. During the investigation LPA requested and obtained copies of Medication Logs from the facility for 3 clients in care. LPA observed that one client in care had missed their prescribed psychotropic medication 6 times in the month of November 2024 and 4 days of the missed medication had no staff initials, and no recorded reasons for why the client missed the medication. LPA observed this same client to have missed their prescribed non psychotropic medication 9 times in November 2024 with 3 missed doses initialed by staff with a reason. LPA was also informed during confidential interviews that staff administering the medication were not properly trained to be dispensing the medication and were also not informed that the clients were taking medications. LPA was unable to obtain proof from the facility that the staff have had proper training to dispense medication. Based on interviews conducted and evidence obtained the facility is being cited (See LIC 809D). Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire.

On January 9, 2025 at approximately 1:15pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz arrived at the above Temporary Care Shelter for the purpose of conducting a follow up case management inspection. LPA Shulz met with Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire who granted LPA access to the facility. On December 26, 2024 LPA Sarina Buchannan conducted a tour of the Temporary Care Facility where LPA Buchannan observed the following deficiencies: · The 2 client’s bedrooms are missing the bedroom door LPA Buchannan was informed that the bedroom door has been missing since at least December 16, 2024 and has yet to be replaced. LPA was unable to confirm if work orders had been placed due to staff not having access to the documents. During today’s inspection LPA Shulz observed the missing bedroom doors have been replaced and are in good repair. This Case Management that was initially opened on December 26, 2024 has now be closed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report will be provided to Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire.

On January 9, 2024 at approximately 1:15pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz arrived unannounced at the above Temporary Care Shelter for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection regarding reporting requirement errors. LPA was greeted by Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire who granted LPA access. Based on Incident Reports received during the months of November and December 2024. LPA Shulz received 37 Incident Reports from the facility, 23 of which did not have a 24 hour report submitted to CCL. The facility has since agreed to conduct further incident report training in order to make staff aware of the reporting requirement and has agreed to participate in the Technical Support Program (TSP) as well. This case management will remain open, until proof of correction has been submitted to the LPA to ensure the facility is in full compliance. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire. The facility has been cited for Reporting Requirements 84061 (i)(1) (See 809-D for plan of corrections).

On January 29, 2025 at approximately 12:24pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz arrived unannounced at the above Temporary Care Shelter for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection regarding reporting requirement errors. LPA was greeted by Marisa Johnson, Lead II who granted LPA access. Based on Incident Reports received during the month of January 2025. LPA Shulz received 57 Incident Reports from the facility, 37 of which mentioned Law Enforcement being contacted with no subsequent LIC 624-LE form or alternative documentation containing all the information required in LIC 624-LE report submitted to CCL. The facility has since agreed to conduct further incident report training in order to make staff aware of the reporting requirement and has agreed to participate in the Technical Support Program (TSP) as well. This case management will remain open, until proof of correction has been submitted to the LPA to ensure the facility is in full compliance. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire and Administrator, Ian Longue. The facility has been cited for Reporting Requirements 84661 (e) (See 809-D for plan of corrections).

on the said client. As for the allegation that a minor was locked out of the facility, staff interviews were consistent in describing a particular incident in which a youth was being prompted to re-enter the facility safely: that said youth was attempting to climb in through a bedroom window—this was discouraged by staff due to the risk of the client cutting or scratching themselves. In addition, there was an unknown adult individual who accompanied the youth back to the facility and with whom the facility was unfamiliar. According to statements from multiple staff, the facility was merely gate-keeping to ensure that an unknown stranger would not come into the facility—which was deemed an apparent risk if they had let the youth back in at that moment. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, and of the Appeal Rights, is being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 01/16/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) to close the investigation and deliver its findings. LPA met with Executive Director Alyssum Maguire and the following report was discussed: LPA opened the complaint on 10/09/2024 at the facility, during which time a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the Shelter’s physical plant was conducted; LPA also interviewed staff on this day. Additional interviews were conducted with clients, County personnel, and more staff. Submitted incident reports, County referral documentation, and client records were reviewed as part of the investigation. No other interviewed clients were able to corroborate that a manual restraint was ever applied to a particular youth by facility staff, let alone that the said client sustained an injury as a result of a hold (or of an attempted restraint)—reportedly, none of the other clients would have witnessed the purported hold as described by the youth in question, and none of the interviewed staffers reported ever having to apply a manual restraint (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: facility staff were being disruptive to a youth during a virtual care team meeting. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, and of the Appeal Rights, is being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 01./16/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) to close the investigation and deliver its findings. LPA met with Executive Director Alyssum Maguire and the following report was discussed: LPA opened the complaint on 09/11/2024 at the facility, during which time a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the Shelter’s physical plant was conducted. LPA also interviewed staff and clients; records reviewed as part of the investigation included a hospital visit summary, an admission agreement, and authorization forms. Additional interviews were conducted with former staff-people, youth’ authorized representatives, County personnel, and Wraparound service providers. Statements gathered by this LPA from interviews with clients and staff were inconsistent on how much privacy was being afforded to youth placements. No other youth reported witnessing any particular client not being allowed to make confidential phone calls; however, there was one service provider who corroborated that (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: taken as yelling to minors, for example—there was no consensus on what specific inappropriate comments were made about, or directed to, a youth. Similarly, statements from interviewees were not consistent about whether facility staff yells at minors (for no good reason) or if particular staff-people were only trying to be firm in prompting or redirecting non-compliant clients. As for the facility taking a youth to emergency or urgent care, though the client’s legal guardian ultimately did not agree that it was necessary, signed Consent to Treat or Medical Authorization forms were obtained by the facility; as such, it was within Progress Ranch’s scope of authority to have the minor at least be evaluated—however, the facility could have better communicated and/or collaborated with that minor’s guardian. Regarding the transportation of a minor to extra curricular activities, there was enough indication that this had been done by the facility to a reasonable extent up until a point wherein the facility decided to not continue supporting the youth’s attendance to after-school activities due to that client not being honest about what they actually wanted to do when they got to school. According to corroborating staff statements, the school and the facility were in agreement on discontinuing transportation for the youth to extra-curricular activities due to the safety risk involved (the youth would have effectively been unaccounted for because they were not doing what they stated they would or they would not be where they initially claimed they would be). Finally, not enough corroborating youth spoke to not being allowed to use a phone in the facility—a number of staff and children did speak to a “lights out” house rule in which phone use is restricted after a certain time at night to allow for quiet time and sleep throughout the facility. Overall, there were inconsistent statements throughout the investigation process and there were not enough witnesses to corroborate the allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, and of the Appeal Rights, is being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 01/16/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) to close the investigation and deliver its findings. LPA met with Alyssum Maguire, Executive Director, and the following report was discussed: LPA opened the complaint on 09/11/2024 at the facility, during which time a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the Shelter’s physical plant was conducted. LPA also interviewed staff and clients; records reviewed as part of the investigation included a hospital visit summary, an admission agreement, and authorization forms. Additional interviews were conducted with former staff-people, youth’ authorized representatives, County personnel, and Wraparound service providers. On the allegation that Staff are not providing a comfortable environment for minor, though a number of the interviewed youth and some facility staff corroborated that, at times, certain other staff’s general approach on interacting with clients could have been inappropriate—either a reprimand was expressed harshly or staff are (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative:
On 11/25/24 LPA requested staff training hours and was only provided CPI, Ukeru, and First Aid. In addition, LPA Buchannan requested staff training logs on 12/3/24 and the facility was not able to produce training documentation requested. 6 out of 11 staff and client confidential interviews confirmed that staff had no trauma informed training which resulted in inappropriate interactions between clients and staff at the facility. It was also confirmed by the Facility Administrator that staff were interacting inappropriately with youth which resulted in the Facility terminating staff between 11/8/24 and 2/13/25. Based on LPAs interviews which were conducted and record review, The Preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

Statements obtained during confidential interviews were inconsistent and could not establish whether the facility was or was not in ratio. 6 out of 11 confidential interviews stated that the facility does not operate out of ratio. LPA was informed that there was a large number of staff terminated which affected scheduling and resulted in the facility occasionally operating at the minimum ratio requirements. LPA could not establish if the facility operated below required ratio during this time. Additionally, LPA also observed the facility to be in ratio during their inspection on 11/25/24 and during all subsequent inspections. 8 out of 11 confidential interviews also stated that they felt staffing was adequate to ensure clients needs were met. Statements obtained during interviews stated that even when staffing was low the facility was able to adjust to meet clients need by having staff on call or having an administrator arrive at the facility to cover a shift. Also, 3 out of 4 clients stated they felt there was an adequate number of staff to meet their needs. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On February 10, 2025 at 3:35 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) ) Sarina Buchannan made an unannounced visit to deliver findings to Progress Ranch Welcome Center 2 and met with Ian Longue, Facility Administrator. LPA was unable to visit Progress Ranch Welcome Center due to the facility moving locations. Prior to the meeting LPA Sarina Buchannan conducted the 10-day inspection of the facility on 11/25/2024. LPA Buchannan requested the following documents: Staff Roster, Client Roster, Staff Schedule, Staff Training Hours, Medication Administration Records, and Staff contact information. LPA Buchannan attempted 1 confidential interview and conducted 11 interviews between 11/21/2024-2/4/2025. Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegation is substantiated. (report continued on LIC 809C)

deficiencies.description:
80065 (f) (3) All personnel shall be given on-the-job training or shall have related experience which provides knowledge of and skill in the following areas... client care and supervision, including communication. 

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: LPA requested staff training on 12/3/24 and the facility was not able to produce documentation. 6 out of 11 staff and client confidential interviews confirmed that staff had no trauma informed training resulting in inappropriate interactions between clients and staff at the facility.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A written plan of staff training should be submitted to LPA Buchannan by 3/3/25 indicating how the facility will comply moving forward. Training plan and logs should be also submitted to LPA Buchannan once training has been completed.

narrative: On 2/18/2025 at 9:50 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez made an announced visit with the purpose of conducting a closure inspection to the above facility. LPA and LPM met with Administrator, Ian Longue and Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. LPA and LPM observed the following: · No furniture in the home. · Beds were removed. · Closets were empty. · There were no signs of clients living at the facility. · All furniture was moved to the new location. · License was retrieved. This facility will be closed on their anniversary date of 2/20/2025. An exit interview was conducted with Executive Director, Alyssum Maguire and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations above have been substantiated. LPA received video footage dated 11/08/2024 of staff members speaking inappropriately while on shift as well as, throwing objects at clients in care. 8 out of 14 confidential interviews also state that they have witnessed staff belittle, yell, and intimidate clients in care. LPA received the separation paperwork dated 11/08/2024 for the staff involved in these incidents. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Title 22 Standards are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations above cannot be substantiated due to conflicting statements. 12 out of 14 confidential interviews state that they have not seen staff smoking marijuana on facility grounds. 10 out of 14 confidential interviews also stated that they have not witnessed staff allowing clients to smoke marijuana inside the facility but rather they have a strict policy of confiscating all paraphernalia brought into the facility. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. deficiencies.description:
84072 (d)(19) Personal Rights
To be free of physical… emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment… humiliation, intimidation, ridicule… threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature... This requirement is not met as evidenced by:

Based on interviews conducted and video footage received on 11/08/2024, confirming that the incidents took place the licensee did not ensure the safety of clients in care which poses a potential Health and Safety risk.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The staff in question were terminated from employment on 11/08/2024. Moving forward CCL recommends more Personal Rights and Trauma Informed trainings.

narrative: Based on evidence gathered and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation, the allegation above cannot be substantiated. Statements obtained during confidential interviews were inconsistent and could not establish that the facility staff physically abused clients in care. 17 out of 21 confidential interviews stated that they have never witnessed staff physically abuse any clients in care. LPA was informed that an incident took place on December 14, 2024, in which all clients placed in the facility stated that they witnessed the staff hit a client. LPA was unable to obtain any statements from Staff or County Social Workers to corroborate the allegation. In addition, any staff aware of the allegation had been told by other staff or clients and did not witness the event them self. Also, the client who was allegedly hit informed their County Social Worker that the facility had conducted a restraint during this incident and the client did not like it but did not mention they were hit. Lastly, the County Social Worker stated it was difficult to get the client to leave the facility as they wanted to stay. LPA Buchannan was also informed of two additional incidents in which clients may have been physically abused at the facility. One incident took place on November 10, 2024, but LPA was unable to obtain any witnesses to corroborate the allegation. LPA was also unable to confirm with the client due to them refusing an interview. In addition, Facility Administrator and Executive Director stated that the client had hit their hand on a printer while engaging in destructive behaviors. Lastly, the County Social Worker confirmed the client was taken to the hospital following this event and there was no report of injury consistent with being physically abused. Another incident took place on December 4, 2024, in which a client had allegedly been choked by staff. LPA was able to confirm with staff who witnessed the incident stated that the staff conducting the restraints arm slipped due to the client moving a lot, this resulted in one arm being around the client’s neck momentarily. Also, the incident was said to have been reported by the client and staff who witnessed it at a Child Family Team meeting, but the County Social Worker stated that it was never reported or addressed. Lastly, the witness stated they did not attend any CFT meeting regarding the incident, it was not reported, and the restraint was necessary to keep clients safe. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to Administrator, Ian Longue.

deficiencies.description:
84675(c) Health Related Services: Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication...

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Interviews conducted and documents obtained confirmed facility did not ensure the safety of clients in care by not providing them their psychotropic medication as prescribed by a physician from 12/27/2024, to 1/01/2025 which poses an immediate health and safety risk to persons in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will provide a written statement on how they plan to make sure an incident like this does not occur again and immediately administer medication as prescribed. Licensee will also provide any logs of any previous medication trainings conducted and sent to LPA via email by 4/14/2025.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill called the office meeting for Progress Ranch Welcome Center II to conduct a Component II Face-to-Face meeting between Community Care Licensing (Department) and the applicant to discuss the application and necessary corrections for the progression of the application. In attendance for this office conference are Jodean Hall, Licensing Program Manager, Alicia Berstein, Staff Services Manager I, Chadwyck Moore, System of Care Analyst, Ali Neira, Program Planner CPS, Alyssum Maguire, Executive Director, Kourtney Hamilton, Regional Residential Manager, Lisa Henry, Executive Assistant, Sydney Harkruiz, LCSW Clinical Supervisor, Sarah Mascardo, Mental Health Rehabilitation Specialist. LPA Hill addressed the following as part of the review of the application: LPA Hill started the conversation discussing with the facility about the accepting of children under the age of six into this six bed facility. LPA Hill advised the agency that per 84268.1 Intake Procedures for the Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Subchapter 2. Care for Children Under the Age of Six Years, the following is stated: "A group home that cares for children under the age of six years shall not accept older children in the same family-like setting, unless the needs and services plan of a younger sibling recommends the presence of that older sibling." The facility shall work on updating and providing additional information for this population. LPA Hill also addressed the mention of the facility accepting minor parents into this facility. The Department is concerned that the program statement does not provide enough information about how the agency will provide appropriate supervision of the minor parent and their child and what services they would provide to the minor parent while at the facility. Training for the minor parent on bathing, dressing, diapering, feeding, care and supervision, etc.

LPA Hill also addressed the agency's plan to accept youth that may have involvement with probation with the under six population, parenting minor population and/or youth that may have been initially removed from parent or guardian. The program statement and plan of operation needs to include how the facility plans to keep youth separated and safe while at the facility given the mixing of these populations. The program statement is not clear on how the facility will monitor these populations, if approved to have both at the same time, to ensure safety of all youth in care. LPA Hill also addressed the Neighborhood Complaint Policy to ensure that it articulates a name of an individual and phone number to be reached outside of the facility. Discussed were the following: * Staying consistent with the age of the population of the youth to be served. * Assessments and Safety Planning * Mental Health Program Approval and direct services being provided to youth in care. * House Rules and how the facility will ensure that the facility * Room disgnation for under six and crib locations. Facility corrections are to be received by the LPA Hill by December 5, 2024. LPA Hill shall also schedule the agency for the Component III. PreLicensing visit shall be scheduled for December 5, 2024 in person. End of document.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced prelicensing inspection on 1/15/25 at 10:00 am and met with Alyssum Maguire, Executive Director. LPA Hill toured the facility inside and out and observed the following: Three dual occupancy bedrooms with appropriate bedding, supplies and storage. Three restrooms are available to youth, one does not have shower but the other two do and are available for youth to use. LPA Hill observed that the water temperature in the restrooms measured between 105 degrees Fahrenheit and 110 degrees Fahrenheit. The kitchen is fully stocked with supplies for youth in care. LPA observed the oven, stove top, fridge and freezer were working during the inspection. There are some nonperishable foods available during inspection but no nonperishable supplies were present or necessary. LPA Hill observed that there are supplies for children under six, including cribs, play pens, car seats, clothing for all ages, high chairs, diapers, and other supplies as necessary in the garage. LPA Hill observed that the smoke detectors were all functioning and there is a carbon monoxide detector that is functioning in the hallway. LPA observed a fire extinguisher is also present, last serviced 1/13/25. LPA Hill observed that the yard of the facility is accessible and safe for youth in care. LPA Hill observed that there are fruit bearing trees in the back yard and that the yard was safe for use. LPA did advise that the agency paint the top of the stump in the yard to ensure that no youth fall or trip while in that area. LPA Hill observed that the locked cabinet for cleaning supplies is in the laundry area and that there is adequate storage for washing supplies. LPA Hill observed the common area of the living room had activity supplies for youth and the living room has several activities, including television, playing video games, and other activities as necessary. LPA Hill observed the facility is ready for licensure but advised the program statement is still under review. Until the Program Statement is complete and approved, the facility cannot be issued a license. Exit interview was conducted and document was provided.

On April 11, 2025 at 9:45 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility and was greeted by Patrick Kent, Administrator (training), who granted LPA access. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiency. A large crack on the clients bedroom window exposing sharp glass edges. LPA observed the staff place tape over the crack ensuring glass is no longer exposed to clients. The facility provided proof that a work order was submitted on 4/11/2025 and the window is expected to be repaired by 4/18/2025. Facility will send proof of completed repairs to LPA once completed. This case management will remain open, until facility provides proof of completed repairs. (See LIC 9102TV) Exit interview conducted and A copy of this report were provided to Patrick Kent, Administrator (training).

On April 17, 2025 at 2:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility and was greeted by Ian Longue, Facility Administrator, who granted LPA access. On April 17, 2025 LPA Buchannan arrived at the facility to conduct a follow up inspection to ensure the above deficiencies were corrected. LPA observed the following: A large crack on the clients bedroom window exposing sharp glass edges had been repaired and was no longer exposed to clients. The outlets in the clients bedrooms was not working and a large extension cord was being run from the clients bathroom in order to provide an outlet. LPA Buchannan observed the facility remove the cord and install lighting which is battery operated until the outlets are repaired.The facility placed work orders on 4/16/2025 and are repairs expected to be completed tomorrow 4/17/2025. LPA will follow up with an inspection at a later date to confirm repair. Exit interview conducted and A copy of this report was provided to Ian Longue, Facility Administrator.

On May 5, 2025 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility and was greeted by Ian Longue, Facility Administrator, who granted LPA access. On May 15, 2025 at 3:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility and was greeted by Imani Richardson, Lead Staff, who granted LPA access. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiency. A clients bedroom door was broken creating a large whole in the door. The whole had been covered with cardboard and taped on the door to ensure privacy. LPA observed the facility had temporarily repaired the door and placed work orders on May 10, 2025. Facility informed LPA that in order to replace the doors it will take a significant amount of time because they are custom. Facility will inform LPA once repairs are completed. This case management will remain open until facility provides proof of completed repairs. Exit interview conducted and A copy of this report was provided to Imani Richardson, Lead Staff.

Based on evidence gathered and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation, the allegations above cannot be substantiated. Statements obtained during confidential interviews were inconsistent and could not clearly establish whether the facility staff did or did not prevent bullying among clients in care. 7 out of 10 confidential interviews stated that staff did prevent clients from being bullied. LPA was informed that one client was involved in multiple verbal altercations, however, this client was also frequently instigating conflict with peers. LPA was unable to determine that any one client was being targeted more than others. Also, interviews stated that staff did attempt to prevent bullying by giving the client their own personal room, maintaining physical distance between clients during high-risk situations, and to use verbal de-escalation techniques. 7 out of 10 confidential interviews also stated that staff did not handle clients in a rough manner. Witness statements obtained during interviews indicated that during an altercation between two clients, a staff member struck a client with their elbow while attempting to manage the situation. Statements also described the incident as accidental with no evidence suggestions intentional harm. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

narrative:
On May 23, 2025 at approximately 2:15 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchnanan conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Imani Richardson, Lead Staff, and walk through of the interior and exterior of the facility was conducted. There are currently 4 residents residing in the facility. During this inspection the physical plant was as follows: Required postings present License, Personal Rights, Complaint Hotline, and Facility Grievance process. Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible. Menu present and posted, nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods three days minimum. Dining area fully furnished to accommodate clients in placement. Bedrooms have required linens, and furniture is adequate and in good repair. Bathroom toilets, wash basin, and shower fixtures are in good repair, no leaks, and water temperature is between 105–120-degree Fahrenheit. Soap and paper towels are provided and available to clients. Washer and dryer available and in good repair. The staff office is maintained locked. Medication was centrally stored, locked, and inaccessible. Temperature of the facility was between 68 degrees F and a maximum of 85 degrees F. Fire Extinguisher up to date and inspected on 01/13/25. Facility is free of vermin and pests. Garage is maintained locked or secured. There is a working telephone accessible to clients. Carbon monoxide detectors and smoke detectors are fully functional. The First Aid Kit is fully stocked. There is a 2018 Kia Sorento that is properly maintained, lights, tires, seat belts, and registration/insurance up to date. Based on a review of the facility’s Guardian Roster the staff working during today’s inspection are fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. (report continued on LIC 809C)

The facility did not have the mass casualty and disaster plan posted but LPA observed a copy of the plan, therefore the facility is being cited a technical violation. (See LIC 9102TV) Exit interview was conducted with Imani Richardson, Lead Staff, a copy of this report was discussed and provided to the licensee.

Seven out of the eight interviews conducted confirmed the allegations staff engaged in a physical and verbal altercation with minor and staff did not allow minor to leave bedroom did not occur. During the investigation LPA Turner was informed during the day of the incident the client in care was repeatedly turning the stove on and off while staff were in the kitchen baking cookies. Staff appropriately intervened by advising the minor not to touch the oven to prevent potential burns or other injuries. At no point did staff use physical force or act inappropriately in response to the clients behavior. Staff stated that the client was attempting to provoke a confrontation with staff members and was verbally trying to escalate the incident. Staff advised that the client exit the kitchen. The client informed LPA Turner that they chose to go to their room and that staff did not force them to go or to stay in their room. During the interviews conducted LPA Turner was notified by other clients in care that they have had no physical or verbal altercations with the staff and that the staff remain professional. Staff and clients stated that this client tends to make false allegations often and attempts to engage in physical and verbal altercations with staff and clients in care. Lastly, the client recanted their statement that staff members kept them in their room. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

narrative: Six out of seven interviews conducted confirmed the allegation staff do not prevent minor(s) from harming other minor while in care was false. During the investigation LPA Turner was informed that staff members took immediate steps to de escalate the situation between all the clients in care. The client in care was being argumentative and confrontational towards staff members causing the other clients in care to engage in a verbal dispute. Staff are aware of the tension between the clients in care and tried to prevent them from engaging in verbal and physical altercations. Staff members positioned themselves between the clients. Staff members sustained some injuries while trying to block and restrain clients in care. Lastly, during interviews LPA Turner was notified that the clients in care struggle to get along with each other and that staff take preventative measures to separate them during outings and provide them their own space so that they stay away from engaging in any altercations with each other. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

LPA met with Ian Longue, Facility Administrator, who assisted LPA Buchannan with the inspection. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility. On May 31, 2025 Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an incident report with the same date in which a client was unable to be driven to the hospital due to staffing ratios. LPA requested the following documentation: Client Roster, Staff Schedule, Staff Contact information, and after visit summary for date of incident. LPA conducted 4 staff interviews during today's visit. This case management will remain open. Further investigation is needed. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided the the licensee.

On June 9, 2025 at 11:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility and was greeted by Ian Longue, Facility Administrator, who granted LPA access. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiencies. A clients bedroom door was broken creating a large whole in the door. The hole had been covered with cardboard and taped on the door to ensure privacy. The staff door was broken creating a large hole. The hole was covered with cardboard and taped on the door to ensure privacy. Two large holes in the walls of the client bedroom. LPA confirmed that work orders had been placed but due to custom doors they are taking an extended period of time. Facility will inform LPA once doors have arrived. Facility stated holes in the wall will be fixed by 6/16/25 and if they are not able to be fixed they will request an extension. Exit interview conducted and A copy of this report was provided to Ian Longue, Facility Administrator.

On June 26, 2025 at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived unannounced at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection to follow up regarding an incident report. LPA met with Meghan Reedy, Clinical Supervisor, who assisted LPA Buchannan with the inspection. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility. On May 31, 2025 Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an incident report with the same date in which a client was unable to be driven to the hospital due to staffing ratios. LPA requested the following documentation: Client Roster, Staff Schedule, Staff Contact information, and after visit summary for date of incident but was unable to obtain it due to it not being provided to the facility. Based on interviews conducted and documentation obtained it was confirmed that the client in care was unable to be taken to the hospital due to staffing being at minimum ratio, however, the facility was not out of ratio. LPA was informed that there were 3 staff working on the day of the incident which was also confirmed by the staff schedule. During the time the incident took place, one staff had left to go to the office leaving the facility with 2 staff for the 4 clients present. While this was still in ratio, Case Managers had informed staff the day before that the client who was requesting medical care needed to have 2 staff present while being transported to preserve the safety of clients and staff. To transport the client requesting medical care, it would have meant the facility would be out of ratio. To ensure the client was given medical attention staff called an ambulance and it was confirmed that the client was taken to the hospital and received medical attention, this was an isolated incident. This case management that was initially opened on June 9, 2025 is now closed. No further investigation is needed. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was provided.

On July 8, 2025, at approximately 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan made an announced visit with the purpose of conducting a closure inspection to the above facility. LPA met with facility Administrator, Ian Longue and conducted a walk through of the interior and exterior of the facility. LPA observed the following: · 1 living room, 1 kitchen, 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 1 office, garage, and outdoor area. · The home was partially furnished, per Administrator the facility is being left this way in preparation for another facility to relocate to the home. · Closets were empty · There were no signs of clients living at the facility · The license was retrieved. This facility will be closed effective July 8, 2025. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Ian Longue and a copy of this report was emailed to licensee.

On July 8, 2025 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility and was greeted by Ian Longue, Facility Administrator, who granted LPA access. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility On June 9, 2025 LPA observed the following deficiencies: A clients bedroom door was broken creating a large whole in the door. The hole had been covered with cardboard and taped on the door to ensure privacy. The staff door was broken creating a large hole. The hole was covered with cardboard and taped on the door to ensure privacy. Two large holes in the walls of the client bedroom. During today's inspection LPA Buchannan conducted a closure inspection and observed no clients to be present and the facility to be in good repair. This facility is now closed and therefore this case management was closed without confirming a plan of correction. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was emailed to Ian Longue, Facility Administrator.

Documentation obtained shows that on 01/17/2025 Community Care Licensing (CCL) was informed that there were 8 staff members who were not background cleared who were providing care and supervision to clients in care, also the facility confirmed on 01/17/2025 that they would follow up to obtain clearances. However, on 03/06/2025 Community Care Licensing (CCL) reached out to the facility to inform them that a Guardian review found that there were staff who were still not cleared and associated to the facility but were providing care and supervision to clients in care. It was confirmed by CCL staff that there were 16 staff who did not have eligible clearances, and the provider was aware that 5 of those staff did not have clearances from the previous communication with CCL on 01/17/2025. LPA confirmed from a Guardian review that Staff 1 (S1) was on the schedule starting 01/13/2025 until 02/19/2025 but did not have an eligible clearance until 03/24/2025. Although LPA was informed that S1 was removed from the schedule and not allowed to work the floor on 02/19/2025, LPA Tatyana Shulz encountered S1 at the facility during their visit on 02/28/2025 despite not being on the schedule for that day. Therefore, it was confirmed S1 was providing care and supervision without a background clearance. In addition, Staff 2 (S2) was not background cleared until 04/03/2025 and the staff schedule shows that S2 started working with clients weekly starting from 02/19/2025 until 04/19/2025. Also, LPA Tatyana Shulz interviewed S2 on 02/28/2025 while at their visit prior to them having an eligible clearance. Staff 3 (S3) did not have an eligible background clearance until 03/26/2025 but the schedule shows S3 started working on 01/27/2025 through 04/19/2025. Staff 4, (S4) was not cleared until 03/26/2025 and was on the schedule from 01/13/2025 through 04/14/2025. Lastly, Staff 5 (S5) was put on the schedule on 01/30/2025 through 04/12/2025 and as of 06/26/2025, S5 does not have an eligible clearance. Based on LPAs interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED, and a Civil Penalty has been assessed for $ 500 per staff which is a total of $ 2,500. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report, civil penalty, and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee during today’s inspection.

LPA conducted a walkthrough of the interior and exterior of the facility and no deficiencies were noted. Prior to the meeting LPA Sarina Buchannan conducted the 10-day inspection of the TSCF on 04/17/2025. LPA Buchannan requested the following documents: Client Roster (LIC 9020), Staff Roster (LIC 500), Staff schedule for the January 2025 to April 2025, Staff contact information, and most recent board meeting minutes. LPA Buchannan conducted 13 confidential interviews and attempted 1 interview between 04/15/2024-06/24/2025. Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegation is substantiated. (report continued on LIC 9099C)

deficiencies.description:
80019 (e)(2)(3) individuals subject to criminal record review... shall prior to working... Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption... or Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance...

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: 5 staff members supervising clients in care while not having eligible fingerprint clearances between January and April 2025.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The 5 staff members shall be fingerprint cleared as soon as possible, or the facility should provide documentation to the department indicating that the 5 staff members are no longer working for the facility.

deficiencies.description:
84092 (b) Unless otherwised ordered... all penalties are due and payable upon receipt of notice of payment and shall be paid only by money order or cashier’s check made payable to the Department.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: A total of $ 2,500 dollars has been assessed to the facility for 5 staff who were not fingerprinted.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: An invoice will be sent via mail to the provider indicating where the payment shall be sent.

narrative: Statements obtained during confidential interviews were inconsistent and could not clearly establish whether the facility staff did or did not use inappropriate language in front of clients. 6 out of 9 confidential interviews stated that staff do not use inappropriate language in front of clients in care. LPA was unable to determine that staff were purposefully using inappropriate language while clients were present. It was discovered that on very few occasions some staff and clients had overheard staff using profanity, but it had not been done purposefully and the staff apologized to the clients for the language. 8 out of 9 confidential interviews also stated that staff do not speak in an inappropriate manner to clients in care. Although staff had been heard by multiple people to have used profanity while clients where present LPA was unable to prove that it was directed at clients. Lastly, the staff in question does not have any disciplinary record during the length of their employment. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the Meghan Reedy, Clinical Supervisor.

narrative: Statements obtained during confidential interviews were inconsistent and could not establish if staff engaged in a physical altercation with clients in care. 7 out of 9 confidential interviews stated that staff did not engage in physical altercation with clients in care. LPA was able to confirm that an incident took place in which a client and two staff members engaged in a confrontation, but LPA could not confirm that the incident became physical. LPA also confirmed that 3 out of 4 clients placed have never witnessed or been involved in any physical altercations with staff during their time in the placement. One of the staff members who witnessed the incident stated that one staff had placed their hand over the client’s hand to prevent the client from shutting the other staff member inside the closet. LPA was unable to obtain any witnesses that could confirm that the incident escalated to a physical altercation. Also, the staff in question does not have any disciplinary record during the length of their employment. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the Meghan Reedy, Clinical Supervisor.

narrative: Based on evidence gathered and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation, the allegations above cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements during the interview process and could not establish that staff do not provide a safe environment for minors in care. 6 out of 8 confidential interviews also stated that staff do provide a safe environment. In addition, it was confirmed by the client that they felt safe during their time in placement. 6 out of 8 confidential interviews stated that staff at the facility do report incidents to the appropriate parties in a timely manner. LPA confirmed that an incident took place in which a client wrote a letter which contained reportable information. However, LPA was unable to establish that the staff who obtained the letter had knowledge of its contents prior to giving it to the facility administrator. Also, LPA was able to confirm the letter was given to the County Social Worker, but it could not be determined whether there was a significant delay from when staff obtained the letter to when it was reported. Lastly, the client stated it was known information and had already been reported to appropriate parties in the past. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

narrative: Based on evidence gathered and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation, the above allegation cannot be substantiated. narrative: Although one client detailed the improper behavior referenced in this complaint report, no other interviewed youth corroborated instances of facility staff “yelling” at any of the youth clients or, for that matter, that there had ever been other forms of verbal communication by staff that could be taken as disrespectful. Interviewed youth did not report any incidents where staff talked about clients in a disparaging way. No Interim Licensing Standards or Title 22 Regulations were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, along with the Appeal Rights, is being provided to the facility.
