narrative: On 07/29/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a Prelicensing Inspection at this location as a result of a change of location. LPA met with Administrator Cathi Johnson. LPA was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. The facility has three shared client bedrooms with each room having two beds and containing the required furnishings observed to be in good repair--additional drawer space for clients' personal belongings will be moved with the clients from the Sacramento Welcome Home - Hilltop House after licensure of this location. There is one shared full bathroom in the hallway off of which all of the client bedrooms are situated. There is an additional en suite full bathroom in one of the client bedrooms. All the bathrooms were in good repair, with toilets that flushed and fixtures that provided hot water that was within the required temperature range. Refrigerator and freezer units were all observed to be in good working condition. There is also sufficient storage space for dried good or non-perishable items. Also observed within two secured staff offices were lockable cabinets for confidential files and medications. There are securable cabinets in a designated staff bathroom where potentially hazardous cleaning agents and chemicals are to be stored appropriately--away from areas where food preparation is done. The thermostat read a temperature that was within the required range. The backyard was found to not have any potentially hazardous areas or items; the pathways are unobstructed. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Johnson..

On 09/10/2024, at 11:00 AM, Regional Manager, Margo Castaneda, Licensing Program Managers, (LPMs) Jodean Hall, Hillary Hall, and Rosa Rodriguez and Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Connie Goldie, Tina Thorn and Chad Cabigon conducted an in-person Office Meeting. Present from Sacramento County's Chicago House, Pasadena and Hilltop/Madison Temporary Shelter Care Facility Homes is Cathy Johnson, Division Manger, Alondra Neira, Program Planner, CPS, Veronica Carrillo, Program Manager, CPSU, Tashna Ward, Program Manager Alicia Wasklewicz, CPS Planner. Present from Systems of Care is Ashley Bray, Staff Services Manager II and Kayla Haith, Health Program Specialist II. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss CCL's concern regarding issues around the non-compliance in the facilities and to collaborate and problem solve together for the success of the programs. The primary areas of concern discussed, and outcomes provided include the following: ·Administrator/ Designation of Authority o It was discussed that a qualified administrator shall be on the premises for the number of hours necessary to manage and administer the facility in compliance with applicable laws and regulations. There needs to be someone readily available for the responsibilities and over site of all three facilities. There also needs to be staff designated to act on the administrator's behalf in the overall management of the facility when the administrator is not at the facility. These designees also need to be able to provide plan of corrections on site during an inspection. o CCL requested a written plan by 9/25/2024. Continued on LIC809C

· Reporting Requirements o CCL is receiving 24-hour notifications as required but, the full reports continue to be received past the regulatory requirement of seven days following the incident. o County staff communicated that they have streamlined the approval process to become compliant with full report. o CCL requested a written plan by 9/25/2024. · Training opportunities o CCL identified training concerns in the following areas: emergency intervention procedures, personal rights, medication, and job descriptions. o CCL offered training support by CCL staff and the Ombudsperson office. · Services Provided o Child specific services, Intake Assessment, CFT's and community resources are some of the services being provided. o Further collaboration will be ongoing. · Additional items discussed: o CCL suggested that a copy of Title 22 regulations, the Program Statement and a copy of the policies and procedures be located at the facility and available to staff. o The County shared that they are in the process of creating an employee handbook. o Administrator shared that two additional supervisors are being added which will provide supervision in the homes for all shifts. Written plans shall be submitted by email to all CCL attendees. A copy of this report was emailed to Cathy Johnson, Division Manager for signature.

met_with: Aquibi Davis, Sacramento Welcome Home Supervisor
narrative:
On 09.26.24 at 04:40 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn conducted a Post-Licensing Inspectio,n. LPA Thorn met with Aquibi Davis,SWH Supervisor who assisted with this inspection. Upon arrival 4 staff 4 clients, and a secutity guard were present. LPA toured the facility on previous visits on 09.11.24 and 09.13.24 as well as on 09.26.24. See 809 from 09.13.24 for full description of premises.. LPA conducted two staff interviews on 09.13.24 and 2 client interviews on 09.26.24. LPA requested staff records on 09.11.24 and there was no manager or supervisor present to provide records for LPA to review. The records were sent via email on 09.12.24. LPA returned on 09.13.24 and a supervisor joined after being called by a staff member. LPA was unable to complete inspection on 09.13.24 so a subsequent visit was scheduled. On 09.26.24 LPA observed the facility to be clean and the outdoor area was freshly mowed and free of debris. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were functional. A first-aid kit was available and contained required items. Children’s records were observed to be incomplete. Placement agreements were unavailable in children’s files. Only one of five clients had a file that included a signed personal rights form on this date and on the two previous visits a supervisor was not present to meet LPA until a staff member called for one. The facility did not have a list of persons allowed to visit clients nor were there consent forms in any of the clients' files

with consent forms to authorize medical and dental treatment. LPA observed there to be 0 of five clients' files that included copies of removal and/or discharge policies and there were no copies posted in the facility. On 09.26.24 LPA cited facility for 4 Title 22 deficiencies referenced in the following D pages and issued 1 technical violation. An exit interview was conducted with Aquibi Davis, SWH Supervisor. A hard copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to facility.

deficiencies.description: Children's Records (b)(13)(17) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained.....(13)consent forms completed by clients authorized representative.....(17) the signed acknowledgment of receipt of personal rights. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview and record review the licensee did not comply with this regulation as 0 of 4 files reviewed included consent forms and 1 of 4 clients' included signed personal rights agreement., which poses a health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC already developed as a result of another SWH location.

deficiencies.description: Intake Records 84668.1(3)-(5) (3)The licensee shall acquire necessary information...to conduct individualized assessment(4)whether the client may present a threat to self.....(5)Provide each client with a health,mental health....which poses a health and safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. Based on observations and record review 0 of 4 client files had placement agreements, assessments or any other comparable documentation, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC already developed as a result of another SWH location.

deficiencies.description: Personnel Requirements 84065 (d) the licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when clients are present. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interviews facility did not have a supervisor on site to meet when LPA was present, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC already developed as a result of another SWH location

deficiencies.description: Removal/Discharge 84668.4(b)(1)-(3) The licensees shall maintain policies governing a client's removal(1) A client and client representative shall receive a copy(2)..shall be maintained in clients record (3)shall post these written requirements. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observations and record review 0 of 5 files include copies of removal and/or discharge policies and removal/discharge policies were not posted in facility., which poses a potential health and safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC already developed as a result of another SWH location

met_with: Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewics, and Tashna Ward
narrative:
On 10/08/2024 Community Care Licensing (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly Sacramento Welcome Home (SWH) TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. In attendance were Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewics, and Tashna Ward from the County and, from CCL, Rosa Rodriguez, Jodean Hall, Hillary Hall, Connie Goldie, and Chad Cabigon. After introductions, the following was covered: CCL acknowledged and thanked the County for the submission of its Written Plan, received by CCL on 09/25/2024, in response to the items covered during the first collaborative meeting held on 09/10/2024. The County has since assigned two new program supervisors to the SWH locations and is looking to fill a third supervisor position pending the Sacramento County Board of Supervisors’ approval which is expected to pass on 11/05/2024, bringing the total number of program supervisors to five (currently, there are four). Regarding the plan to re-designate an administrator, it was noted that Alicia Wasklewics is set to go through the administrator training/certification at the end of this month (October, 2024). CCL clarified that the required facility manager designation is specific to each shift per House/location when children are present. Being that there are only four supervisors covering all the Houses, there are times when no supervisor is available at a given location. The County stated that they have implemented an assigned Worker of the Day or “WOD” to cover those locations and/or times when a program supervisor is not available. CCL requested that on the schedules (on the LIC 500 or Personnel Report) it is specified who the WODs and supervisors are and that those designated are spelled out as ‘facility managers’, that all other CCL-required positions are spelled out (including, for example, Administrator) under the "Job Title," and that an updated form be submitted for each location by October 31, 2024. The County stated that some of the limitation(s) in properly reflecting these positions may be due to the need to have it cleared by the staff's union beforehand and that, relatedly, the same constraint(s) may be affecting the finalizing of job duty statements for care staff to acknowledge. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 2) Also discussed were the missing full or seven-day reports which are the follow-up reports to the County’s 24-hour notifications. Per the County, management is paying close attention to the October reports to ensure compliance: the 24-hour reports are being done in a timely manner but the intermediate step involving a supervisor de-brief is where the reports are getting held up. The County are actively working on a pilot program set to start at the end of November or the beginning of December, 2024, which is meant to help track reports through a more automated system. It is CCL’s expectation that the outstanding full or seven-day reports for previously-submitted 24-hour notifications (for September, 2024) will also be submitted to CCL by October 31, 2024—the number of missing full or seven-day reports are as follows: Pasadena House – 11; Madison - 27, and Chicago – 10 (for a total of 48). It is also CCL’s expectation that an immediate correction plan be put in place to be in compliance with Title 22 Regulations. Regarding training requirements—specifically, Section 84065(i)(1)(D) which discusses the need for an assessment of the efficacy of training—CCL noted, based on interviews, that direct-care staff may not have a sufficient understanding of the training topics covered despite having received the training. CCL advised that post-testing or return demonstrations to assess for competency may be developed by the County, themselves, so long as those assessments are documented in each staffer’s file. The County stated that management will check-in with the supervisors about this protocol and also added that the supervisors do meet with their staff every month, are probably doing at least some type of performance evaluations, and that they may just need to do better at documenting. CCL is requesting an implementation plan to be compliant with Title 22 Regulations, and that this plan should be submitted by October 31, 2024. Additional training support: CCL advised that the Ombudsperson’s Office only provides training on the Foster Youth Bill of Rights but not on anything more specific like medications, for example. CCL provided the Ombudsperson's Office portal and link to sign up for Bill of Rights training. The County asked if CCL, apart from the Ombudsperson’s Office, provides more topic-specific training—CCL advised that it does and that this training will be scheduled for the County by the end of November or the beginning of December, 2024. On the SWH Program Statement being made accessible to staff: the County stated that they are still working on the employee handbook—along with this process the care staff have been given electronic access to the Title 22/Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Regulations digitally and parts of the Program Statement on which staff get trained. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 3) Regarding the POC for the Personal Rights citation on the Chicago House on inventory check/searches. The POC was submitted to CCL on 10/03/2024, this procedure is still under review by CCL. Regarding the POC for the Personal Rights citation on the Madison House, the County will check on the progress of training for staff which is expected to be completed by 10/11/2024. Regarding the POC for the overcapacity citation on the Pasadena House, this POC was submitted to CCL on 10/02/2024 and is still under review. A copy of this report is being emailed to the County for signature.

met_with: LaShon Tate, Engagement Social Worker Supervisor
narrative: On 09/13/24 at 9:33 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tina Thorn conducted a Post-Licensing inspection. LPA Thorn met with LaShon Tate, Engagement Social Worker Supervisor, who assisted with this inspection. Upon arrival, 4 staff, 2 youth and a security guard are present in the facility. LPA toured the facility with LaShon Tate. Upon entering the home there is a receptionist area with a security officer present. LPA observed a dining room table with six chairs to the right of the family room area which provides adequate seating for children. A current menu was posted on a bulletin board in the dining area. The kitchen was observed to have a sink with no dirty dishes and appliances that are in good working order. Perishable and non-perishable foods available exceeded the minimum requirements. LPA requested Supervisor to open a locked door that is attached to the main living room. This was a small, secured room that had locked medication and sharps. LPA observed plates, cups and cutlery adequate for the capacity of the home. The garage of the home is where the facility stores extra hygiene products, youth belongings, and household items like games and activities. There is a locked storage room attached to the dining room that has extra bedding, food, and small appliances. A small office is located in a locked room attached to family room. The family room has a table with 4 chairs, a couch and television. There are 3 bathrooms, one for staff, one for clients and one that is attached to a bedroom that is locked and not used. The family room space has clear pathways and comfortable seating for the youth in the home. The three bathrooms observed have soap, paper towels and hygiene products available. LPA observed the outside area to be free of debris. There is an unattached room outside of the house that is locked. It is being used for youth to meet with their service providers. The hallway closet was observed to have linens. Two bedrooms were observed to have beds and storage space as required. A third dual bedroom was observed to not have any youth and currently isn't being used. LPA conducted two staff interviews. LPA will return to complete Post Licensing Inspection on a subsequent visit. An exit interview was conducted with LaShon Tate, Engagement Social Worker Supervisor. A copy of this report was provided.

On 02/11/2025, at 10:00 AM, the CA Department of Social Services’ (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. The attendees were: from County, Cathi Johnson, Sac County Administrator, Alondra Neira,Program Planner, and Alicia Wasklewicz,Sac County Administrator, from CCL, Margo Castaneda, Regional Director, Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, Hillary Hall, Licensing Program Managers and Tina Thorn, Chad Cabigon, and Connie Goldie, Licensing Program Analysts and from CDSS’ System of Care Branch (SOC), Levi Huser, Ashley Bray, and Alicia Bernstein. The following items were discussed— What’s working well: Ms. Johnson stated that the County is continuing to focus on training of staff in various areas and two houses have placement. Duty statements will be reviewed with staff, signed, and placed in their files. CCL stated facility staff are pleasant, workers of the day are helpful during inspections and youth are observed to be engaged. CCL requested copy of duty statements by 02/21/2025. Administrator Update: Alicia Wasklewicz, administrator applicant provided Group Home Certificate to CCL on 02/11/2025. CCL clarified expectations that Administrator will provide oversight as needed. Program Statement Update: CCL received Program Statement updates as requested on 01/31/2025. CCL is in the process of reviewing received documentation. CCL’s review of revisions will be completed by 02/21/2025. Continued on LIC809C.

page 2 Pasadena House License Status: The County stated the Pasadena House license will be maintained until further notice. County will communicate when this transition occurs. Trauma Informed Care (TIC): CCL requested a list of which staff are not currently trained in TIC. County stated they will provide a copy of the training log highlighting staff who still need to complete this training. CCL requests this be submitted by 02/14/2025. CCL asked if security guards will receive restraint training. The County stated security guards will not be restraint trained and will not put hands on youth. Reporting Requirement Update: CCL discussed the continued issue of late and/or missing reports for all TSCF facilities. The County stated that their records are not consistent with CCL reported numbers and requested that CCL attach which reports are missing going forward. Increase of Unauthorized Absences: CCL discussed observation of increased unauthorized absences and asked how staff attempt to prevent youth from leaving. County shared that staff follow youth to the property perimeter line when leaving due to safety concerns. It was also stated staff ratios can determine if a youth is followed. CCL advised the county to include reason for not going further than property line on incident reports. Levi Huser from Systems of Care Branch offered an opportunity for collaboration to discuss ideas on reducing law enforcement contacts. LIC809 Office Meeting Review: Licensing Program Analyst and Licensing Program Manager will have a Teams Meeting with the County to review the LIC809 report for the monthly collaboration meeting each month in order for any revisions to be made immediately as necessary. The reports will then be emailed to obtain a signature. Ashley Bray from Systems of Care offered to assist with creating individual safety plans with a harm reduction approach in order to be proactive. Ms. Bray suggested County staff and licensing staff participate in the meeting. The office meeting concluded at 10:40 AM.

On 01/14/2025 the CA Department of Social Services’ (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. The attendees were: from County, Cathi Johnson, Alondra Neira, Tashna Ward, Alicia Wasklewicz, and Veronica Carrillo, from CCL, Margo Castaneda, Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, Hillary Hall, Connie Goldie, Tina Thorn, Chad Cabigon, and from CDSS’ System of Care Branch (SOC), Kelley Hartman, Levi Huser, and Alicia Bernstein. Topics discussed at the meeting were: What’s working well: The County expressed having two TSCF’s is much more manageable. They have also had a lower census on average as of late between the Welcome Home locations which has been helped by the recent capacity expansion through outside partners. Temporary move from Chicago House to Pasadena House: Due to an infestation of carpet beetles the facility is being fumigated. Designated Administrator: CCL noted that Alicia Wasklewicz passed the Administrator Exam; County was informed that Regional Manager (RM) Castaneda requested the expedited processing of Ms. Wasklewicz’s administrator certification. CCL reiterated expectations for a facility administrator: to be on facility premises for the number of hours necessary to manage and administer the facility in compliance with applicable laws and regulations, and to be readily available for the responsibilities and oversight of the facilities. CCL also reiterated the need for staff to be designated to act on the administrator’s behalf with the overall management of facilities in the administrator’s absence. CCL emphasized that these designees also need to be able to provide Plans of Correction for citations issued during inspections—County confirmed that these facility manager designees have been given this authority. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 2) Plan for Pasadena House license: The County will continue to keep the license until further notice. Training Requirements: Follow-Up: County will be sending the template for staff training. Security Guards – Fingerprint Clearance Needed: CCL advised that all security guards positioned in the home need to be fingerprinted and obtain criminal record clearances through Guardian due to the frequency, consistency, and recurring nature of their presence. The due date for the completion of fingerprinting is 01/31/2025. Reporting Requirement Update – Incident Reporting CCL discussed the continued issue of late and/or missing reports and acknowledged it is vastly improving. County stated that they are continuing to address this and with Ms. Wasklewicz as administrator, her presence in the Houses more frequently should help address the reporting. The County also expects to start testing the SMILE system this week with the goal of launching in the end of February. Inventory Check/Searches: CCL followed up on the submission of the County’s Prudent Parenting activation form related to searches for CCL to review. The County will be submitting the form. CCL/SOC pointed out that Prudent Parenting is usually in reference to decisions that a substitute caregiver makes to afford youth something that resembles a more “normal” way of life such as allowing youth to participate in certain activities without prior approval from their authorized representative. SOC discussed that the Prudent Parent Standard is a general framework through which providers can respond as necessary to help support youth, but it might not always be appropriate, and its use should depend on the population and/or individual youth in question. Facility Overview: Both LPAs stated seeing an increase in engagement between youth and staff participating in various house activities. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 3) Additional feedback: SOC reminded County of standing offer to provide consultation and guidance and encouraged County to reach out, as necessary. Training materials have been sent to County from SOC that may be helpful and could be integrated in the Shelter’s program. County to submit Program Statement updates by 01/31/2025, to include clarification on the mandated initial vs. annual training, as well as policies and expectations related to contracted security personnel who work onsite at the SWH locations. Closing discussion on restraints: The County stated that all staff will start Phase 2 of the TCI training in February, 2025, and that they anticipate completion in March, 2025. CCL advised that a manual restraint should only be executed by a trained staff and should only be resorted to in a health and safety consideration for a child or staff, that it is more about good training that truly helps staff be proactive with early interventions, how to identify early on what the specific youth’ triggers are, and how staff can equip themselves with enough techniques to de-escalate a situation. Additionally, it should also be helpful for the County to be familiar with the temperament and tendencies of their direct-care personnel so as to better inform management on staffing decisions and training considerations. A copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

met_with: Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewicz, Veronica Carrillo, Kelley Hartman, and Alicia Bernstein
narrative:
On 12/10/2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly Sacramento Welcome Home (SWH) TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. In attendance from the County were: Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewicz,, and Veronica Carrillo. Attending from CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager (RM), Rosa Rodriguez, Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Jodean Hall, LPM, Hillary Hall, LPM, Connie Goldie, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Tina Thorn (LPA), and Chad Cabigon, LPA. Also present was Kelley Hartman and Alicia Bernstein from Systems of Care (SOC.) After introductions, the following was discussed: The County and CCL acknowledged what has been going well for them and for each facility. The County noted that operating two rather than three homes has been going well. CCL shared that all three locations were reported to have had great communication and LPAs have observed staff engaging with the youth. Alicia Wasklewics passed the Administrator Certification test and completed her background clearance. An expedited request will be sent by RM once paperwork is submitted. County plans to hire one more staff to meet the goal of having six supervisors. The LIC 500 will reflect a Worker of the Day (WOD), who meets Facility Manager qualifications. WOD will be present when a supervisor is not. There will be a WOD at each house during each shift. The County agreed to send a list of qualified facility managers for each facility as well as the staff schedules. The LIC 500 is to be sent to CCL by 12/11/24.

CCL shared the staff training records submitted do not match the Program Statement and clarity is needed on the initial training versus annual training. The County said they would revise their program statement training requirements. CCL addressed a recent Incident Report (IR) involving a manual restraint. The County stated that while all staff are in the process of restrain training, restraints will always be a last resort. The County used the information provided by CCL regarding medication training and Personal Rights to create a self-paced training for the staff. The County has implemented information from the medication training and incorporated the new MARS form. The County is developing a staff training template and will send updated staff training records by 12/11/24. CCL requested information on the security guards at the facilities and the lack of security personnel mentioned in their Program Statement. CCL requested the security complete training on mandated reporting and Trauma Informed Care. CCL requested updates to the Program Statement on how the security is Trauma Informed and their level of engagement with staff and clients. Due date for Program Statement Update: January 11, 2025 CCL shared incident reporting by the County has improved in timeliness. The County is developing a system to track Incident Reports. Until development is complete, the County supervisor has created a schedule to review IRs. Monitoring Youth personal property and conducting searches was discussed. The County agreed to update the program statement to reflect and describe the Youth personal property log. The County will send CCL the Prudent Parent Activation form and Youth Care and Goal Plan. Inventories, not searches, are currently being conducted. The County explained that the inventory checks are a case-by-case. CCL recommended that the Youth Care and Goal Plan have an area in which client’s history of substance use should be included to better predict the use of Prudent Parent Activation. The County provided updates on their Home-Based Shelter Program, which is near capacity. Next Meeting schedule for January 14, 2025.

met_with: Rashenda Williams, Engagement Social Worker, Worker of the Day
narrative: One youth was listed on the placement roster as having been at the Sacramento Welcome Home- Madison facility for about one month, with extended absences during that time. When the youth exited placement at Madison, personal items were reported as missing. The youth had been placed at a different facility for several months prior to Madison and some of their personal property had been documented as left behind at this location. The youth did not provide details regarding personal property missing from Madison. The county social worker and CASA Worker believed all the youth’s personal property from Madison had been retrieved and that photos were taken of those items. However, there were no records to match the items reported missing, and whether they were not safeguarded by Madison, or if these were the items missing from the prior placement. Case notes for Y1 indicate that during the 4 days that Y1 was enrolled in school, rides were offered. Y1 attended school on 3 of 4 days. On one day youth missed a ride with the Family Service Worker who arrived earlier to take youth to school. By the time youth got up there was no transportation available. When Y1 got up later in the morning Y1 would yell at staff about staff not waking Y1 up, however case notes indicate that staff attempted to wake youth on all 4 days. Case notes also indicate that a Family Service Worker was assigned to take Y1 to school on each day of enrollment. Based on LPA’s interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation are UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility on 03.07.25 for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Rashenda Williams, Engagement Social Worker. LPA Thorn, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall, and LPA Misty Valencia conducted the complaint investigation. LPM Hall opened the investigation with the facility on 12.20.24 and met with Brittany Taylor, Engagement Social Worker and Danielle Chan, Supervisor and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPM interviewed reporting party and 2 staff. LPA Valencia interviewed 1 county social worker, and LPA Thorn interviewed 1 youth, 4 staff, a CASA Worker, and a Facilities Administrator Officer. LPA reviewed records from the facility including social worker case notes, prior complaint history, Serious Incident Reports, Facility Program Statement, and Facility youth inventory log.

narrative:
Present: CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager Licensing Program Managers: Hillary Hall, Jodean Hall, and Rosa Rodriguez Licensing Program Analysts: Chad Cabigon, Tina Thorn, and Connie Goldie Sacramento Welcome Home County Partners: Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Tashna Ward, Alicia Wasklewicz Systems of Care: Alicia Bernstein, Ashley Bray and Levi Huster On 03.11.25, the following was discussed during the CCL collaboration meeting with Sacramento County regarding the Temporary Shelter Care Facility. Both the county and CCL reported on what’s going well: Alicia Wasklewicz collaborated with Systems of Care representative and obtained resources and expressed gratitude for the connection. LPAs for each facility reiterated that the staff have been engaged with clients and responsive to LPAs. LPA Goldie reported on progress with Program Statement Review. LPA stated that she was able to access forms easily. LPA also stated that most of the revisions were a matter of gaining clarification, requesting transcripts, and having County provide more explanation regarding how the processes will be implemented. LPA Goldie gave a briefing on revision requests, namely the under 6 and discipline policies and of requesting transcripts for staff to ensure requirements are met. The County expressed that obtaining transcripts is proving to be a longer process depending on the time frame in which the staff took the required courses. The incident report submission process was discussed, with the county’s new system, SMILE being implemented 03.17.25. C. Johnson explained that the county’s new system should reduce the reporting time frame by providing email alerts to submit required reports and will provide more reminders to support staff. Continued 809C

The county was informed that, going forward, they will be cited if incident reports are turned in late. CCL shared information about our Technical Support Program that will provide support and training for the facility. T. Ward reported 12 staff are fully trained in Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (TCI). There are still staff needing to be trained. It was reported that enough staff are trained to ensure there are 2 people per shift available to do restraints if necessary. The expectation is that all staff are trained by April 1, 2025. County reported that on March 22, 2025, Foster Hope is set to take over operations at the current Madison House. Youth will move to Pasadena and Chicago House to allow Foster Hope to get situated. The County expressed a desire to keep Pasadena House as a home to relocate youth if Chicago House needs to be evacuated for emergency reason or if something needs to be fixed at Chicago House. It was also expressed that Chicago House may be used to conduct staff training and/or for youth visitation when needed and if not occupied by youth. SOC asked if County wanted their harm reduction policies/forms reviewed. A. Bernstein provided email address to the County. Regional Manager M. Castaneda concluded the meeting after offering time for more questions or comments.

It was alleged that reporting requirements are not being met in relation to restraints not being documented and submitted to the department. Staff interviewed stated that they understand the procedure and that it is a mandatory part of their job to report any restraints that occur during the staff member’s shift. Six out of Seven Interviews reported that all incidents of restraints had been documented and submitted timely to the department. LPA reviewed records and not all staff have completed the incident reporting training. Based on LPA’s interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegations may have happened, or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violations did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility on 04.01.25 for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Tamika Hardy, Child Development Supervisor. LPA Thorn conducted the complaint investigation. LPA opened the investigation with the facility on 01.14.25 and met with Kaeley Vang, Facility Manager and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed 2 youth, one County Social Worker, and four Staff. LPA reviewed records from the facility including Placement Roster, Training logs, County Social worker case notes, Serious Incident Reports, and prior complaint history. It was alleged that restraints were being used. Six out of seven confidential interviews reported that no restraints have been used. One confidential interview indicated there were physical interventions being used with the youth. Inconsistent statements were provided regarding whether these physical interventions rose to the level of restraint. Continued 9099C

met_with: Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor by phone and Mike Gilbert, Engagement Social Worker
narrative: Staff interviewed stated they communicate with youth about safety and making healthy choices and provide harm reduction strategies when youth are determined to participate in unsafe activities. Upon observation of drug use, staff attempt to confiscate contraband. There was not enough evidence to clearly and directly attribute these instances to a lack of supervision on the part of facility staff. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn and Connie Goldie arrived at shelter to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 04.25.2025 at 3:33 PM. LPA Thorn spoke with Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor and Mike Gilbert Engagement Social Worker to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegation stated above. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted by LPA Tina Thorn on 02/05/2025. At the shelter, LPA Thorn obtained the following documentation: PMIs (Placement Matching Information), Youth Intake Screening Tools, Health & Education Passports, Daily Progress Logs, and a youth’s Care & Goal Plan as well as a Safety Plan. During the investigation, eighteen confidential interviews were conducted between 02/05/2025 and 04/23/2025. The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff did not provide adequate supervision to ensure safety of youth.” All interviewed youth admitted to being exposed to vaping and/or marijuana use in the facility. There was also substantial corroboration through obtained statements that youth were exposed to, or possibly even recruited for, CSEC (Commercially Sexually Exploited Children) activities. Continued 9099C

narrative:
On 07/15/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a Prelicensing Inspection of this property. Present were County of Sacramento DCFAS (Department of Child, Family, and Adult Services) Division Manager Cathi Johnson and Administrative Services Officer Diana Rethford. LPA was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility grounds; the findings of the inspection are as follows: The property has two common living areas adjacent to each other with ample couch seating. The house has three bedrooms for clients, each was furnished with two beds & mattresses, beddings & linens, and personal storage space in the form of stowable under-bed rolling bins all found to be in good condition. Each bedroom also had a working light fixture and a smoke detector that appeared to be in working order. There is one shared bathroom for clients’ use—there is one toilet in good repair, a vanity and a bathtub shower whose fixtures provided hot water. There is a dining table in an area next to the kitchen; a working refrigerator maintained a temperature of 38 degrees F with a freezer that maintained a temperature of 0 degrees F. There is an extra freezer in the garage whose temperature was also kept at 0 degrees F. Per Ms. Johnson, an additional refrigerator will be obtained to ensure accommodation of the required perishables at capacity. There is a dedicated staff office that was securable, within which were lockable file cabinets for confidential files and storage for centrally-stored medications that can also be secured. The property has a working landline located within the staff office. The dwelling has centralized air and a thermostat located in the bedroom hallway that displayed a room temperature of 77 degrees F. The washer and dryer were located in the garage, and within which chemicals and other potentially dangerous liquids will be stored. The backyard outdoor space included a covered patio with seating and a bench or picnic table found to be in good condition. There was a pile of loose branches on the far end of the lawn that is to be cleared, otherwise, there were no potentially hazardous items or areas observed. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

The following was communicated to Ms. Johnson and Ms. Rethford: all waste bins shall have covers; an inordinate amount of house flies observed during the inspection is to be addressed; required beddings and linens are to be in place; the weekly menu, foster youth rights (to be provided by Licensing), the Disaster or Mass Casualty Plan, and complaint procedures are to be posted conspicuously at the appropriate areas; the hot water out of the bathtub fixture was 130 degrees F—this needs to be adjusted and maintained between 105 – 120 degrees F. A subsequent onsite inspection is necessary to re-evaluate this property’s readiness to serve clients. County of Sacramento is to inform LPA once the property is ready for the follow-up inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Johnson.

met_with: Cathi Johnson, Alicia Wasklewicz, Diana Rethford
narrative: On 08/08/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a follow-up onsite walkthrough of this property to complete the Prelicensing Inspection. LPA met with County of Sacramento DCFAS (Department of Child, Family, and Adult Services) Division Manager Cathi Johnson, Program Manager Alicia Wasklewicz , and Administrative Services Officer Diana Rethford. The hot water temperature out of the bathtub shower fixture was 105 degrees F; no house flies were observed, all waste bins had covers in place; required beddings and linens for all the beds in clients' rooms were in place and each bedroom had the required storage space for personal belongings; the backyard did not have any potentially hazardous areas or items; the Disaster/Mass Casualty Plan and a weekly food menu were posted; the facility has perishable food sufficient for at least three days. The provisional Temporary Shelter Care License will be issued effective 08/11/2025. The County plans on housing clients at this location starting that date. A copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

facility_name: COUNTY OF SACRAMENTO DCFAS SUNSET HOUSE
met_with: Cathi Johnson, County of Sacramento Division Manager; Alondra Neira, Program Planner
narrative: On 06/14/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon was given a tour of the prospective Temporary Shelter Care Facility grounds; the following were observed: -# of bedrooms: 3 for clients, 1 room to be utilized as staff office -# of bathrooms: 3.5 -bodies of water: none -furnishings: full -notable health & safety concerns: none

On 04/08/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a Prelicensing Inspection at this location as part of the licensure process for a Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA met with County of Sacramento Division Manager Cathi Johnson. LPA was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. The facility has three client bedrooms with each room having two beds; the bedrooms contained the required bedding and furniture which were observed to be in good repair; sufficient storage/drawer space for clients' personal belongings was also observed. There is one common or shared full bathroom in the hallway that leads to the bedrooms. There was a carbon monoxide detector observed in the hallways. There is an additional ensuite full bathroom in one of the client bedrooms. All the bathrooms were generally in good repair, with toilets that flushed and fixtures that provided hot water. The temperature in spaces/rooms that clients occupy was within the required range. There are multiple refrigerators and/or freezer units all observed to be in good working condition and provided temperatures within the required range for perishable items. There is also sufficient storage space for dried goods or non-perishable items. The facility currently has a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable food items for at least three days and one week, respectively. Also observed within a secured staff office off the hallways were lockable cabinets for confidential files and medications. Most of the potentially hazardous cleaning agents and chemicals were stored appropriately in a secured cabinet. The backyard was found to not have any potentially hazardous areas or items; the pathways are unobstructed. The following items will need to be addressed for the issuance of the provisional license: two of the three bedrooms did not have smoke detectors; there was an exposed light socket in the ensuite bathroom of one of the bedrooms; cleaning agents/chemicals were found readily accessible under the kitchen sink; there was no posted weekly food menu; the hallway bathroom sink's water temperature was 134 degrees F; there needs to be a separate log for each psychotropic medication being administered; the facility also needs to post the Foster Youth Bill of Rights in a conspicuous location.. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Johnson.

On 04/26/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this pending TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) in response to reported operational concerns. LPA met with Engagement Social Worker Michael Gilbert who facilitated a tour of the physical plant; Mr. Gilbert also facilitated LPA interviews with two clients--Mr. Gilbert, himself, was interviewed by LPA regarding designated rooms/spaces being, or may be, utilized by youth for meetings (CFTs, etc.) or other other purposes that could require privacy. LPA inspected the House's stock of food items. Further inspection may be required; a copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

On 04/17/2024 CDSS (California Department of Social Services) and the County of Sacramento DCFAS (Department of Child, Family and Adult Services) held a virtual meeting on the Microsoft Teams platform. The attendees were, from the County, Melissa Lloyd and Cathi Johnson, and from DSS, Margo Castaneda, Ashley Bray, Alicia Bernstein, Rosa Rodriguez, Kayla Haith, Chadwyck Moore, and Chad Cabigon. The following items were discussed: -County to continue sending daily reports to CFSD (Children and Family Services Division) listing children staying at this location and their demographic information. -special incident reporting: County to submit reports for previously unreported unusual incidents at this, and any other, location since the start of residential operations; C. Johnson has commenced sending incident reports to C. Cabigon as of 04/05/2024. -LIC 200 (Application for a Community Care Facility): County to clarify/revise as needed item # 11 on form to reflect Program Statement narrative language addressing the age range of children to be accepted by the facility. -C. Johnson discussed possibility that County may need to update Plan of Operation/Program Statement to include provisions for the care of children under six years of age should outside TSCF providers not meet programmatic regulatory requirements allowing the admission of this age group. -continuing collaboration between County and CDSS via quality improvement evaluations, technical assistance calls, and ETCFT (Expedited Transition Child and Family Team) meetings discussed by A. Bray; feedback provided by C. Johnson on these processes. -updates on capacity building efforts are being given by County during recurring calls between CDSS and County of Sacramento.

On 05/24/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a second prelicensing inspection of this facility and was met by Division Manager Cathi Johnson and Admin. Services Officer Hazel Magett. A tour of the facility was conducted with focus on items/areas that needed to be addressed during the last prelicensing inspection, namely: 1) the clients, for their bedrooms, have been offered roll-out bins for clothing and personal belongings that can be stowed under the beds, 2) warning signs have been prominently displayed by fixtures that delivered water above the temperature limit set by Regulations (one in the hallway bathroom by the client bedrooms and one in the restroom by the entrance to the garage), 3) the curtain rods in all of the client bedrooms were observed to be secured, 4) one smoke detector in a client bedroom was missing--a youth who occupied that bedroom stated that they (the client) had taken it out the night before, and 5) the light fixture in the master bedroom en-suite bathroom has been fixed. No other deficiencies were observed during this inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

facility_name: COUNTY OF SACRAMENTO DCFAS SUNSET HOUSE
narrative: Based on observations and interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation that Unlicensed care is being provided is Substantiated. An exit interview was conducted, the Appeal Rights were discussed, and a copy of this report is being provided to Program Manager Carrillo.
investigation_findings: 13On 05/03/2024 at 3:45 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon met with Veronica Carrillo, Program Manager at the Branch Center Rd. County of Sacramento offices, the purpose of which was to deliver the findings of this complaint investigation. On 04/04/2024 the Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) of the California Department of Social Services (CDSS) received a complaint alleging unlicensed care was being provided in a house located at the address indicated on the top portion of this report. On 04/08/2024 LPA Chad Cabigon conducted an onsite inspection at the aforementioned location and met with County of Sacramento Division Manager Cathi Johnson. LPA was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the physical plant; LPA observed that there was one youth on premises—an interview was conducted with said youth. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

met_with: Tamika Hardy Child Development Specialist Tashna Ward Program Manager
narrative: On 07/31/2024 at 1:55 PM License Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted a Post-Licensing inspection. LPA Goldie met with Tamika Hardy, Child Development Supervisor who assisted with this inspection. Upon arrival, three staff, four youth and a security guard are present in the facility. LPA toured the facility with Ms. Hardy. Upon entering the home there is a receptionist area with a security officer present . LPA observed a dining room table with six chairs to the right of the family room area which provides adequate seating for children. A personal rights poster was located in the family room. The kitchen was observed to have a sink with no dishes,appliances in good working order and a menu posted. Perishable and non-perishable foods available exceeded the minimum requirements. LPA requested Ms. Hardy to open cabinet under sink and observed bleach to be accessible in an unsecured location. LPA observed plates, cups and cutlery adequate for the capacity of the home. The garage of the home is where the facility stores extra hygiene products, youth belongings in cabinets along wall and additional food. An additional refrigerator and freezer are located in the garage. The bulletin board had license, a grievance QR code and an emergency procedure plan posted. A small office is set up in this area but, files are not located here. The living room space has clear pathways and comfortable seating for the youth in the home. The four bathrooms observed have soap, paper towels and hygiene products available. The water temperature was measured at 123 degrees which is above the allowed temperature per regulation. A secured office was observed to have medication, sharps and youth files. LPA observed the outside area to be free of debris. Hallway closet was observed to have linens. Two dual bedrooms were observed to have beds and storage space required. A third dual bedroom was observed to not have any youth and currently isn't being used. LPA Goldie conducted two client interviews and three staff interviews. LPA cited facility for 2 Title 22 deficiencies. LPA will return to complete Post Licensing Inspection on a subsequent visit. An exit interview was conducted with Tamika Hardy. A copy of this report was provided.

deficiencies.description:
80087 Buildings and Grounds
(a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interview, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above when bleach was in an accessible cupboard, which poses/posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff immediately removed bleach to a secure location.Supervisor will create a sign to post on cabinet under kitchen sink to remind staff to secure chemical and submit a photo to licensing via email to Connie.Goldie@dss.ca.gov

narrative: On 08/07/2024, at 09:55 AM, Regional Manager, (RM) Margo Cataneda, Licensing Program Manager , Jodean Hall and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie met with Engagement Social Worker-acting supervisor Esteban Baul to continue an unannounced Post Licensing Inspection. Mr. Baul stated that four staff and three clients are currently in the facility. A security guard was also present. A walk through of the facility and grounds was completed. Four outside cameras were observed pointing away from home. LPA requested Esteban Baul to obtain staff files in order to conduct file review of staff files for S1, S2, S3, S4 and S5 as they are not located on site. LPM spoke with Veronica Curillo, Program Manager to request staff files and they were unable to provide. Background clearances of staff present were verified. LPA Goldie conducted a medication review. Medication Administration Records (MAR's) were observed, policies and procedures were discussed, and medication counts were conducted. LPM Hall conducted three staff interviews, S4, S5, S6, and 1 client interview C3. RM conducted a record review of three children's files. Reporting Requirement documents observed included the Daily Log and Missing Person Reports. A follow up visit is needed to complete this Post licensing Inspection. RM, LPM and LPA conducted exit interview with Esteban Baul at 1:10 PM. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

met_with: Miguel Rubio Child Development Specialist Elizabeth Jones, Engagement Social WOrker Kellie Jackson Engagement Social Worker
narrative:
On 08/16/2024, at 12:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted a visit to the facility for the purpose of a Case Management visit relating to the Post Licensing inspections completed on 07/31/2024 and 08/07/2024. LPA met with staff listed above who assisted with this inspection. LPA Goldie discussed issues observed during Post licensing inspections completed on dates listed above, LPA Goldie observed the following during the physical plant inspection: Upon arrival on 07/31/2024, LPA observed three staff playing cards at the kitchen table. Three clients in care were in their bedrooms. Additionally, on 08/07/2024, LPA observed a client sleeping on the couch in the living room area. Outside, assorted garbage including a water bottle, perfume bottle, paper plates and food wrappers on lawn adjacent to bedroom was observed. Staff stated clients just toss garbage out of their bedroom windows. LPA discussed that it needs to be picked up. A gate door, observed to be broken, was leaning up against the chain link fence on the back right corner of the property. In the kitchen, a cabinet door was missing. Staff stated work orders have been placed for these items to be repaired. Bedroom number 3 was barricaded with a bed pushed up to the door on both dates listed above. On 07/31/2024, Staff, S3 stated that they were unaware if staff or youth placed the bed to block the doorway. LPA stated that the bed needed to be moved as the bedroom needs to be accessible. On 08/07/2024, staff (S7) entered the window of bedroom number 3 and moved furniture to make bedroom accessible as required as it was again found to be barricaded. The mattresses in bedrooms one, two and three were observed to have worn bedsprings and unclean mattresses. Linens as required were not observed on any of the beds either. There was no activity calendar available for the summer and a client (C5) stated during interview that there were no activities available in the home. The First Aid kit was observed to be missing the first aid manual, scissors, antiseptic solution and adhesive tape. LPA requested staff records on both dates and staff were unable to provide files. Continued on LIC809C

Children’s records were observed to be incomplete. Placement agreements were unavailable in children’s files. Assessments were unsigned. Personal rights forms were unsigned by C2 and C4, consent forms for medical were missing for C2, C3 and C5. All clients did not have cash resource logs. No Medication Administration Records (MARS) were present for August 2024. The acting supervisor was unaware of medication policy and procedures according to regulation and stated training had not been provided. Medication count verifications are not being completed. There was no way for LPA to determine if medication is being dispensed as prescribed due to no documentation available (MARS and PMARS) Clients did have personal property inventories but not cash resource records. The facility does not adhere to reporting requirements per regulation. Thirty plus 7 day written reports have been submitted late and the Department is not consistently receiving 10-day weekly reports as required. Staff S4, S5 stated that all clients who return from unauthorized absences are refused entry until they are searched for contraband. If youth refuse to be searched, staff will call law enforcement. This is considered to be an unreasonable search as it is not being assessed on an individualized basis. One Technical Advisory is being given today. This is not a deficiency. Sixteen Title 22 California Code of Regulation and two Interim Licensing Standards citations are being issued today. (See LIC809D forms) An exit interview was conducted with Program Planner, Ali Neira via telephone who assisted with the plan of correction piece for deficiencies. A copy of this report along with appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility. * Liz Jones signed on behalf of La Shon Tate as directed.

narrative:
On 09/10/2024, at 11:00 AM, Regional Manager, Margo Castaneda, Licensing Program Managers, (LPMs) Jodean Hall, Hillary Hall, and Rosa Rodriguez and Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Connie Goldie, Tina Thorn and Chad Cabigon conducted an in-person Office Meeting. Present from Sacramento County's Chicago House, Pasadena and Hilltop/Madison Temporary Shelter Care Facility Homes is Cathy Johnson, Division Manger, Alondra Neira, Program Planner, CPS, Veronica Carrillo, Program Manager, CPSU, Tashna Ward, Program Manager Alicia Wasklewicz, CPS Planner. Present from Systems of Care is Ashley Bray, Staff Services Manager II and Kayla Haith, Health Program Specialist II. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss CCL's concern regarding issues around the non-compliance in the facilities and to collaborate and problem solve together for the success of the programs. The primary areas of concern discussed, and outcomes provided include the following: ·Administrator/ Designation of Authority o It was discussed that a qualified administrator shall be on the premises for the number of hours necessary to manage and administer the facility in compliance with applicable laws and regulations. There needs to be someone readily available for the responsibilities and over site of all three facilities. There also needs to be staff designated to act on the administrator's behalf in the overall management of the facility when the administrator is not at the facility. These designees also need to be able to provide plan of corrections on site during an inspection. o CCL requested a written plan by 9/25/2024. Continued on LIC809C

· Reporting Requirements o CCL is receiving 24-hour notifications as required but, the full reports continue to be received past the regulatory requirement of seven days following the incident. o County staff communicated that they have streamlined the approval process to become compliant with full report. o CCL requested a written plan by 9/25/2024. · Training opportunities o CCL identified training concerns in the following areas: emergency intervention procedures, personal rights, medication, and job descriptions. o CCL offered training support by CCL staff and the Ombudsperson office. · Services Provided o Child specific services, Intake Assessment, CFT's and community resources are some of the services being provided. o Further collaboration will be ongoing. · Additional items discussed: o CCL suggested that a copy of Title 22 regulations, the Program Statement and a copy of the policies and procedures be located at the facility and available to staff. o The County shared that they are in the process of creating an employee handbook. o Administrator shared that two additional supervisors are being added which will provide supervision in the homes for all shifts. Written plans shall be submitted by email to all CCL attendees. A copy of this report was emailed to Cathy Johnson, Division Manager for signature.

met_with: Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewics, and Tashna Ward
narrative:
On 10/08/2024 Community Care Licensing (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly Sacramento Welcome Home (SWH) TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. In attendance were Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewics, and Tashna Ward from the County and, from CCL, Rosa Rodriguez, Jodean Hall, Hillary Hall, Connie Goldie, and Chad Cabigon. After introductions, the following was covered: CCL acknowledged and thanked the County for the submission of its Written Plan, received by CCL on 09/25/2024, in response to the items covered during the first collaborative meeting held on 09/10/2024. The County has since assigned two new program supervisors to the SWH locations and is looking to fill a third supervisor position pending the Sacramento County Board of Supervisors’ approval which is expected to pass on 11/05/2024, bringing the total number of program supervisors to five (currently, there are four). Regarding the plan to re-designate an administrator, it was noted that Alicia Wasklewics is set to go through the administrator training/certification at the end of this month (October, 2024). CCL clarified that the required facility manager designation is specific to each shift per House/location when children are present. Being that there are only four supervisors covering all the Houses, there are times when no supervisor is available at a given location. The County stated that they have implemented an assigned Worker of the Day or “WOD” to cover those locations and/or times when a program supervisor is not available. CCL requested that on the schedules (on the LIC 500 or Personnel Report) it is specified who the WODs and supervisors are and that those designated are spelled out as ‘facility managers’, that all other CCL-required positions are spelled out (including, for example, Administrator) under the "Job Title," and that an updated form be submitted for each location by October 31, 2024. The County stated that some of the limitation(s) in properly reflecting these positions may be due to the need to have it cleared by the staff's union beforehand and that, relatedly, the same constraint(s) may be affecting the finalizing of job duty statements for care staff to acknowledge. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 2) Also discussed were the missing full or seven-day reports which are the follow-up reports to the County’s 24-hour notifications. Per the County, management is paying close attention to the October reports to ensure compliance: the 24-hour reports are being done in a timely manner but the intermediate step involving a supervisor de-brief is where the reports are getting held up. The County are actively working on a pilot program set to start at the end of November or the beginning of December, 2024, which is meant to help track reports through a more automated system. It is CCL’s expectation that the outstanding full or seven-day reports for previously-submitted 24-hour notifications (for September, 2024) will also be submitted to CCL by October 31, 2024—the number of missing full or seven-day reports are as follows: Pasadena House – 11; Madison - 27, and Chicago – 10 (for a total of 48). It is also CCL’s expectation that an immediate correction plan be put in place to be in compliance with Title 22 Regulations. Regarding training requirements—specifically, Section 84065(i)(1)(D) which discusses the need for an assessment of the efficacy of training—CCL noted, based on interviews, that direct-care staff may not have a sufficient understanding of the training topics covered despite having received the training. CCL advised that post-testing or return demonstrations to assess for competency may be developed by the County, themselves, so long as those assessments are documented in each staffer’s file. The County stated that management will check-in with the supervisors about this protocol and also added that the supervisors do meet with their staff every month, are probably doing at least some type of performance evaluations, and that they may just need to do better at documenting. CCL is requesting an implementation plan to be compliant with Title 22 Regulations, and that this plan should be submitted by October 31, 2024. Additional training support: CCL advised that the Ombudsperson’s Office only provides training on the Foster Youth Bill of Rights but not on anything more specific like medications, for example. CCL provided the Ombudsperson's Office portal and link to sign up for Bill of Rights training. The County asked if CCL, apart from the Ombudsperson’s Office, provides more topic-specific training—CCL advised that it does and that this training will be scheduled for the County by the end of November or the beginning of December, 2024. On the SWH Program Statement being made accessible to staff: the County stated that they are still working on the employee handbook—along with this process the care staff have been given electronic access to the Title 22/Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Regulations digitally and parts of the Program Statement on which staff get trained. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 3) Regarding the POC for the Personal Rights citation on the Chicago House on inventory check/searches. The POC was submitted to CCL on 10/03/2024, this procedure is still under review by CCL. Regarding the POC for the Personal Rights citation on the Madison House, the County will check on the progress of training for staff which is expected to be completed by 10/11/2024. Regarding the POC for the overcapacity citation on the Pasadena House, this POC was submitted to CCL on 10/02/2024 and is still under review. A copy of this report is being emailed to the County for signature.

On 10/24/2024 at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie, conducted a case management inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to inquire about incident that was reported to the Department on 10/15/2024 and occurred on 09/21/2024. LPA met with LaShon Tate, Supervisor who helped facilitate the inspection. 2 residents, and 4 staff are present in the facility. LPA completed a walk through of the facility inside and outside. LPA conducted one staff interview. Further follow-up is required to resolve case management. LPA Goldie provided a copy of report to facility staff. Document signed by Engagement Social Worker Karla Garcia-Maldonado..

met_with: Danielle Chan Supervisor Esteban Baul Engagement Social Worker-Facility Manager
narrative:
The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff are not properly trained.” Two of five staff members interviewed stated they were behind on training. One staff stated they did not receive initial training upon hire. Record review of staff training log and program statement indicates that 10 of 11 staff have not received initial 90 day required training. Five of the staff have not completed Mandatory Reporting training. Six staff have not completed the De-escalation training. Therefore, the evidence supports that this allegation is substantiated. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 , 84065 Personnel Requirements (i)(3) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to facility staff, Name, TITLE.

The Department investigated the allegation. “Staff are denying minors mental health treatment.” Two of two clients interviewed stated mental health services have been offered to them. Five of five staff corroborate that outside vendors come into the facility to offer support services to the clients in care and mental health services are offered to the youth during their initial Child and Family Team meetings. Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the allegations occurred or not. Based on the investigation, the records reviewed, and the interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. In regard to the allegation, staff are not providing a safe environment for minors in care, both clients interviewed stated they feel safe in the facility. One client stated that staff help when kids are yelling by talking to them. Regarding the arrest alleged by the reporting party, upon review, this did not occur at this location. A supervisor of the facility stated there have been no arrests of clients for altercations between clients. And record review of incident reports supports this statement. Five of five staff corroborate the facility is safe. Statements by staff include “we engage with youth to keep them safe”, “we set up the environment to be safe”, “we keep others safe by directing them away from escalated youth”, and “safety checks are conducted every thirty minutes.” Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the allegation occurred or not. Based on the investigation, the records reviewed and the interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to facility staff Danielle Chan Supervisor.

The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted by LPAs Connie Goldie and Tina Thorn at the facility on 09/03/2024. LPAs conducted a Health and Safety inspection which was led by staff, Ka Xiong, Engagement Social Worker (ESW). LPAs conducted one staff interview with La Shon Tate, Supervisor. During the course of the investigation LPA conducted 4 additional staff interviews and two client interviews and reviewed the following records placement roster, staff training log, and serious incident reports. Two clients declined to be interviewed. Continued on LIC9099C

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review ,licensee did not ensure ten of eleven staff received training as identified as initial training within 90 days which poses/posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care

narrative: On 11/21/2024 at 03:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Connie Goldie arrived unannounced at Sacramento Welcome Home Chicago House for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Deficiencies Inspection. LPA met with Danielle Chan, Supervisor. During case management inspection on 10/24/2024 LPA Goldie spoke with LaShon Tate, Supervisor regarding an incident report received by the Department on 10/15/2024 that occurred on 09/21/2024 in which a client was restrained. Due to recent licensure the Department is aware that staff have not completed restraint training for manual restraints. La Shon Tate stated she was not working that day but, confirmed that no staff have received training to conduct physical restraints at this time. LPA Goldie called and spoke with Danielle Chan, Supervisor who was on duty the day this incident occurred. Ms. Chan confirmed a staff who hasn’t received restraint training grabbed one of client’s (C1) arms and the security guard who is also not approved grabbed the other arm when client became aggressive with staff. Additionally, LPA identified that the full incident report was received seventeen days late which is out of compliance with regulation requirements. The agency is being cited for two Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, violations, 84365 (a) Emergency Intervention Staff Training and 80061 (b) Reporting Requirements. See LIC809D, An exit interview was conducted where the citations and plan of corrections were discussed. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above.

On 12/18/2024 at 10:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Connie Goldie arrived unannounced at Sacramento Welcome Home Chicago House for the purpose of conducting a Case Management- Deficiencies Inspection. LPA met with Ka Xiong, Facility Manager. On 12/03/2024, during a physical walk through of the facility, LPA Goldie observed smoke detectors in bedroom 1 and bedroom 3 which are hard wired to be cut. S2 stated that the fire department had made an inspection earlier the same day and required youth in bedroom 1 to be relocated to bedroom 2 as the smoke detectors were not functioning. LPA requested if additional smoke detectors were available and staff (S1) stated yes. LPA requested that the new smoke detectors be installed immediately which they were by end of the inspection by S2. The facility is being cited for a Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6 violation, 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds . See LIC809D, An exit interview was conducted where the citation and plan of correction were discussed. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above.

On 12/18/2024, at 11:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to inquire about a concern that was reported to the Department on 12/03/2024. LPA met with Ka Xiong, Facility Manager who helped facilitate the inspection. Five staff and four clients are present in the facility. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility inside and outside. LPA conducted one staff interview. LPA requested staff schedule for November 2024 and staff contact phone numbers. Further follow-up is required to resolve this case management. LPA Goldie provided a copy of report to Ka Xiong, Facility Manager.

The Department investigated the allegation, “Facility operating outside of the scope of their license.” During the physical plant inspection, LPA observed a Fisher Price toy set up in the living room on an end table with bins of pre-school toys underneath. Staff stated the facility is now an all age, all gender home-0-18 years as it has become the intake house. The facility is licensed provisionally to provide temporary shelter care services up to 10 day to children 6-17 years old. Record review of census indicates on 11/22/2024, 12/02/2024 and 12/03/2024 children under six were placed in care at the shelter. (C2, age 4 months, C3 age 1 year, C4 age 3 years and C5 age 3 years) Therefore, the evidence supports that this allegation is substantiated. Based on LPA's observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 2 , 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.
