deficiencies.description:
Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status 80010(a) A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, licensee is out of compliance and did not operate within the scope of their license as C2, C3, C4 and C5 are under six years old which poses/posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The county will submit an updated program statement to include accepting children under six. This will also need to describe how they will ensure safety and compatibility for all youth in care. This will include an updated LIC200 by plan of correction due date of 01/18/2025.

met_with: Ka Xiong, Facility Manager Guillermo Torres, Facility Manager
narrative: On 01/08/2025, at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to inquire about an incident that was reported to the Department on 12/24/2024. LPA met with Ka Xiong, Facility Manager who helped facilitate the inspection. Five staff and one client are present in the facility. Gloria Hancox, Child Development Specialist, assisted LPA with a walk through of the facility inside and outside. LPA conducted two staff interviews. LPA obtained medical documentation for incident that occurred on 12/16/2024.. Further follow-up is required to resolve this case management. LPA Goldie provided a copy of report to Guillermo Torres, Facility Manager.

On 01/08/2025, at 4:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to inquire about an incident that was reported to the Department on 12/26/2024 and occurred on 12/24/2024. LPA met with Guillermo Torres, Facility Manager who helped facilitate the inspection. Four staff and two clients are present in the facility. Gloria Hancox, Child Development Specialist, assisted LPA with a walk through of the facility inside and outside. LPA conducted three staff interviews. LPA received staff schedule for 12/24/2024 PM shift. Further follow-up is required to resolve this case management. LPA Goldie provided a copy of report to Guillermo Torres, Facility Manager.

On 02/11/2025, at 10:00 AM, the CA Department of Social Services’ (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. The attendees were: from County, Cathi Johnson, Sac County Administrator, Alondra Neira,Program Planner, and Alicia Wasklewicz,Sac County Administrator, from CCL, Margo Castaneda, Regional Director, Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, Hillary Hall, Licensing Program Managers and Tina Thorn, Chad Cabigon, and Connie Goldie, Licensing Program Analysts and from CDSS’ System of Care Branch (SOC), Levi Huser, Ashley Bray, and Alicia Bernstein. The following items were discussed— What’s working well: Ms. Johnson stated that the County is continuing to focus on training of staff in various areas and two houses have placement. Duty statements will be reviewed with staff, signed, and placed in their files. CCL stated facility staff are pleasant, workers of the day are helpful during inspections and youth are observed to be engaged. CCL requested copy of duty statements by 02/21/2025. Administrator Update: Alicia Wasklewicz, administrator applicant provided Group Home Certificate to CCL on 02/11/2025. CCL clarified expectations that Administrator will provide oversight as needed. Program Statement Update: CCL received Program Statement updates as requested on 01/31/2025. CCL is in the process of reviewing received documentation. CCL’s review of revisions will be completed by 02/21/2025. Continued on LIC809C.

page 2 Pasadena House License Status: The County stated the Pasadena House license will be maintained until further notice. County will communicate when this transition occurs. Trauma Informed Care (TIC): CCL requested a list of which staff are not currently trained in TIC. County stated they will provide a copy of the training log highlighting staff who still need to complete this training. CCL requests this be submitted by 02/18/2025. CCL asked if security guards will receive restraint training. The County stated security guards will not be restraint trained and will not put hands on youth. Reporting Requirement Update: CCL discussed the continued issue of late and/or missing reports for all TSCF facilities. The County stated that their records are not consistent with CCL reported numbers and requested that CCL attach which reports are missing going forward. Increase of Unauthorized Absences: CCL discussed observation of increased unauthorized absences and asked how staff attempt to prevent youth from leaving. County shared that staff follow youth to the property perimeter line when leaving due to safety concerns. It was also stated staff ratios can determine if a youth is followed. CCL advised the county to include reason for not going further than property line on incident reports. Levi Huser from Systems of Care Branch offered an opportunity for collaboration to discuss ideas on reducing law enforcement contacts. LIC809 Office Meeting Review: Licensing Program Analyst and Licensing Program Manager will have a Teams Meeting with the County to review the LIC809 report for the monthly collaboration meeting each month in order for any revisions to be made immediately as necessary. The reports will then be emailed to obtain a signature. Ashley Bray from Systems of Care offered to assist with creating individual safety plans with a harm reduction approach in order to be proactive. Ms. Bray suggested County staff and licensing staff participate in the meeting. The office meeting concluded at 10:40 AM.

The Department investigated the allegation, “Facility is in disrepair.” During the physical plant inspection conducted on 10/24/2025, LPA observed a broken cabinet above washer and dryer which S1 stated had been broken since August 2024. LPA observed garage door exit to the backyard to have two pieces of plywood hammered on the outside making the door inaccessible. S1 stated the plywood was applied on 10/19/2024 by facility maintenance and it was estimated to be replaced in 2-3 weeks. Additionally, cloth storage space drawers for clients were visibly soiled in bedrooms #1 and #2. During a subsequent visit on 12/18/2024, LPA observed that garage exit door was still not repaired, and plywood pieces were still present. Therefore, this allegation is substantiated. Based on LPA’s observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 7, 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Regarding the allegation, “Staff are not safeguarding residents’ belongings”, a youth, C3, stated their belongings were placed outside including a laptop, clothing, two backpacks and brushes, due to head lice and were unable to be accessed for a week or two. Three staff corroborated that these belongings were placed outside for this reason. A laptop requires being secured to be safeguarded. Record review of program statement indicates that belongings not in youth’s possession are stored in the garage. Based on LPA’s observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3 80026 Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Valuables of Residents are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

Regarding the allegation, “A youth displayed inappropriate sexual behavior in front of another youth”, two clients declined to be interviewed. Six of six staff interviewed stated they were unaware of any youth masturbating in front of another youth in the home. Therefore, due to clients’ refusal to be interviewed, it is not possible to determine whether the allegation occurred or not. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon arrived at the agency to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 02/06/2025 at 4:30 PM. LPA Cabigon spoke with Danielle Chan, Engagement Social Work Supervisor, to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegations stated above. LPA Connie Goldie conducted this investigation. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted by LPA Connie Goldie at the facility on 10/24/2024. LPA conducted a Health and Safety inspection and conducted four staff interviews. LPA completed a record review of work requests submitted to facility managers, program statement and intake paperwork for C1, C2, C3 and C4. During the course of the investigation, six youth interviews and six staff interviews were completed. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

deficiencies.description: Buildings and Grounds. "The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview and record review repairs were not done in a timely manner to fix the garage door making it inaccessible for an extended period which posed an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A memo shall be sent to those Program/Shelter personnel responsible for such matters that gives clear directive to address any identified disrepair(s) to the facility's physical plant in a more timely manner. Documented receipt of this memo shall be provided by 02/14/2025.

deficiencies.description: Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Valuables of Residents. "[A client's]...personal property, and valuables...shall be safeguarded in accordance with the requirements..." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview and record review licensee was out of compliance when C3’s laptop was placed outside for more than 24 hours which posed a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A facility-wide memo will be sent to all staff who may provide direct care and/or supervision to clients as a reminder of this provision/requirement. Documented receipt of this memo shall be provided by 02/14/2025.

narrative:
On 01/14/2025 the CA Department of Social Services’ (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. The attendees were: from County, Cathi Johnson, Alondra Neira, Tashna Ward, Alicia Wasklewicz, and Veronica Carrillo, from CCL, Margo Castaneda, Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, Hillary Hall, Connie Goldie, Tina Thorn, Chad Cabigon, and from CDSS’ System of Care Branch (SOC), Kelley Hartman, Levi Huser, and Alicia Bernstein. Topics discussed at the meeting were: What’s working well: The County expressed having two TSCF’s is much more manageable. They have also had a lower census on average as of late between the Welcome Home locations which has been helped by the recent capacity expansion through outside partners. Temporary move from Chicago House to Pasadena House: Due to an infestation of carpet beetles the facility is being fumigated. Designated Administrator: CCL noted that Alicia Wasklewicz passed the Administrator Exam; County was informed that Regional Manager (RM) Castaneda requested the expedited processing of Ms. Wasklewicz’s administrator certification. CCL reiterated expectations for a facility administrator: to be on facility premises for the number of hours necessary to manage and administer the facility in compliance with applicable laws and regulations, and to be readily available for the responsibilities and oversight of the facilities. CCL also reiterated the need for staff to be designated to act on the administrator’s behalf with the overall management of facilities in the administrator’s absence. CCL emphasized that these designees also need to be able to provide Plans of Correction for citations issued during inspections—County confirmed that these facility manager designees have been given this authority. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 2) Plan for Pasadena House license: The County will continue to keep the license until further notice. Training Requirements: Follow-Up: County will be sending the template for staff training. Security Guards – Fingerprint Clearance Needed: CCL advised that all security guards positioned in the home need to be fingerprinted and obtain criminal record clearances through Guardian due to the frequency, consistency, and recurring nature of their presence. The due date for the completion of fingerprinting is 01/31/2025. Reporting Requirement Update – Incident Reporting CCL discussed the continued issue of late and/or missing reports and acknowledged it is vastly improving. County stated that they are continuing to address this and with Ms. Wasklewicz as administrator, her presence in the Houses more frequently should help address the reporting. The County also expects to start testing the SMILE system this week with the goal of launching in the end of February. Inventory Check/Searches: CCL followed up on the submission of the County’s Prudent Parenting activation form related to searches for CCL to review. The County will be submitting the form. CCL/SOC pointed out that Prudent Parenting is usually in reference to decisions that a substitute caregiver makes to afford youth something that resembles a more “normal” way of life such as allowing youth to participate in certain activities without prior approval from their authorized representative. SOC discussed that the Prudent Parent Standard is a general framework through which providers can respond as necessary to help support youth, but it might not always be appropriate, and its use should depend on the population and/or individual youth in question. Facility Overview: Both LPAs stated seeing an increase in engagement between youth and staff participating in various house activities. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 3) Additional feedback: SOC reminded County of standing offer to provide consultation and guidance and encouraged County to reach out, as necessary. Training materials have been sent to County from SOC that may be helpful and could be integrated in the Shelter’s program. County to submit Program Statement updates by 01/31/2025, to include clarification on the mandated initial vs. annual training, as well as policies and expectations related to contracted security personnel who work onsite at the SWH locations. Closing discussion on restraints: The County stated that all staff will start Phase 2 of the TCI training in February, 2025, and that they anticipate completion in March, 2025. CCL advised that a manual restraint should only be executed by a trained staff and should only be resorted to in a health and safety consideration for a child or staff, that it is more about good training that truly helps staff be proactive with early interventions, how to identify early on what the specific youth’ triggers are, and how staff can equip themselves with enough techniques to de-escalate a situation. Additionally, it should also be helpful for the County to be familiar with the temperament and tendencies of their direct-care personnel so as to better inform management on staffing decisions and training considerations. A copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced case management inspection on 3/6/25 at 1:35 PM and met with Esteban Baul, Engagement Social Worker. LPA informed Mr. Baul to discuss an incident report dated 2/12/25. LPA Hill obtained documentation related to C1 (see LIC811 dated 3/6/25) and questioned Mr. Baul about the incident. LPA Hill informed the facility that additional investigation is needed at this time. Exit interview conducted and document was provided.

Present: CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager Licensing Program Managers: Hillary Hall, Jodean Hall, and Rosa Rodriguez Licensing Program Analysts: Chad Cabigon, Tina Thorn, and Connie Goldie Sacramento Welcome Home County Partners: Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Tashna Ward, Alicia Wasklewicz Systems of Care: Alicia Bernstein, Ashley Bray and Levi Huster On 03.11.25, the following was discussed during the CCL collaboration meeting with Sacramento County regarding the Temporary Shelter Care Facility. Both the county and CCL reported on what’s going well: Alicia Wasklewicz collaborated with Systems of Care representative and obtained resources and expressed gratitude for the connection. LPAs for each facility reiterated that the staff have been engaged with clients and responsive to LPAs. LPA Goldie reported on progress with Program Statement Review. LPA stated that she was able to access forms easily. LPA also stated that most of the revisions were a matter of gaining clarification, requesting transcripts, and having County provide more explanation regarding how the processes will be implemented. LPA Goldie gave a briefing on revision requests, namely the under 6 and discipline policies and of requesting transcripts for staff to ensure requirements are met. The County expressed that obtaining transcripts is proving to be a longer process depending on the time frame in which the staff took the required courses. The incident report submission process was discussed, with the county’s new system, SMILE being implemented 03.17.25. C. Johnson explained that the county’s new system should reduce the reporting time frame by providing email alerts to submit required reports and will provide more reminders to support staff. Continued 809C

The county was informed that, going forward, they will be cited if incident reports are turned in late. CCL shared information about our Technical Support Program that will provide support and training for the facility. T. Ward reported 12 staff are fully trained in Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (TCI). There are still staff needing to be trained. It was reported that enough staff are trained to ensure there are 2 people per shift available to do restraints if necessary. The expectation is that all staff are trained by April 1, 2025. County reported that on March 22, 2025, Foster Hope is set to take over operations at the current Madison House. Youth will move to Pasadena and Chicago House to allow Foster Hope to get situated. The County expressed a desire to keep Pasadena House as a home to relocate youth if Chicago House needs to be evacuated for emergency reason or if something needs to be fixed at Chicago House. It was also expressed that Chicago House may be used to conduct staff training and/or for youth visitation when needed and if not occupied by youth. SOC asked if County wanted their harm reduction policies/forms reviewed. A. Bernstein provided email address to the County. Regional Manager M. Castaneda concluded the meeting after offering time for more questions or comments.

The Department investigated the allegation, “Youth in care are being restrained by untrained staff.” Three of seven staff interviewed stated they have utilized “bear hugs” described as “open arms wrapped around a youth” and going underneath the arm of a youth and giving them a hug” when youth are unsafe. An additional staff disclosed that they have observed staff give youth “bear hugs” in the name of self-defense and another staff stated that “bear hugs” were taught in a self- defense class. Record review of training log did not indicate a self-defense course. A youth also disclosed witnessing a staff put hands on a youth forcefully to move them. Based on LPA’s observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be substantiated. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 8, Emergency Intervention Staff Training 84365(a) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” Administrator, Alicia Wasklewicz, provided the plan of correction via telephone for this citation. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

The Department investigated the allegation, “Reporting requirements are not being met.” It was alleged that reporting requirements are not being met in relation to restraints not being documented and submitted to the department. Staff interviewed stated that they understand the procedure and that it is a mandatory part of their job to report any restraints that occur during the staff member’s shift. Six out of seven interviews reported that all incidents of restraints had been documented and submitted timely to the department. LPA reviewed records and not all staff have completed the incident reporting training. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie arrived at the facility to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 04/07/2025 at 02:45 PM. LPA Goldie spoke with Esteban Baul, Facility Manager to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegation stated above. LPA Connie Goldie conducted this investigation. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted by LPAs Connie Goldie and Tina Thorn at the facility on 01/14/2025. LPA Thorn conducted a Health and Safety inspection and conducted four staff interviews. LPA Goldie completed a record review of staff schedules and youth rosters for November and December 2024. During the course of the investigation, eleven confidential interviews were completed. Continued on LIC9099C

deficiencies.description: Emergency Intervention Staff Training 84365 (a) No facility personnel must use emergency intervention techniques on a child unless ... have successfully completed the emergency intervention training required in Section 84365(b). This requirement was not met as evidenced by Based on observation, interview and record review untrained staff have restrained a client without emergency intervention training as required per regulation which posed an immediate threat to health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will send email to staff to communicate that manual restraints can only be performed after completing the TC1 phase 1 and 2 training successfully. Adminstrator will submit a copy of the email by end of day 04/08/2025 along with the upcoming dates scheduled for TC1 training.

narrative: On 04/25/2025, at XX:XX PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie arrived at facility to conduct an unannounced case management inspection. LPA Goldie spoke with Daniele Chan Engagement Supervisor and Michael Gilbert Facility Manager who assisted LPA with the inspection. During previous inspections, on 02/06/2025 and 04/17/2025, it was learned that staff are not following runaway protocol as stated in Plan of Operation/ Program Statement. Youth stated they are not being followed to the perimeter of property and staff corroborated that they do not consistently follow this process. The facility is being cited for Title 22 80022(k) Plan of Operation are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Plan of Operation 80022(k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and  interview , the shelter did not follow plan of operation pertaining to runaway portocol which pose(d) a potential threat to health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: At the next staff meeting a review of the Unauthorized Absence Policy will be provided to all staff. A copy of the agenda along withe a virtual log attendee sheet will be provided to CCL via email to Connie.Goldie@dss.ca.gov by POC due date.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 5/1/25 at 2:10 PM and met with Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor. LPA Hill discussed with Ms. Chan and incident that is still pending completion regarding an incident dated 2/12/25 in which the agency's security guard restrained a child in care at the facility. LPA Hill conducted interviews and obtained additional information regarding efforts made by Sacramento County in this ongoing investigation as well. This investigation is still ongoing at this time. While at the facility, LPA Hill learned that there are seven children present in the facility but the facility is only licensed to provide care and supervision for no more than six children at this location. LPA Hill was made aware that there is a sibling set of four that were admitted on 4/25/25, and three other clients have been in the facility more than ten days. LPA Hill cited the facility per Title 22 of the California Code of Regulations Chapter 1, General Licensing Requirements, Section 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity & Ambulatory Status as the facility is not to operate beyond their licensed capacity which is six at this location. LPA Hill informed Ms. Chan that the facility cannot operate beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license. Exit interview was conducted and the citation, along with the appeal rights were provided to Ms. Chan.

deficiencies.description:
Limitations on Capacity & Ambulatory Status.
A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions & limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: LPA Hill learned that there are currently seven children in care at the facility, a sibling set of four were admitted on 4/25/25 and three other youth have been present for more than 10 days, prior to the sibling set being admitted which poses an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Documentation of CPSU's placement finding efforts shall be provided to CCL by end of business on 05/2/2025.

met_with: Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor Michael Gilbert, Facility Manager
narrative:
Regarding the allegation, “Staff did not ensure that the facility was free of pest in a timely manner,” seven of nine confidential interviews stated that pest concerns were not initially handled efficiently. Record review of documentation indicates C1 and C2 were treated for bug bites on 01/01/2025 and 1/10/2025. After learning a potential bed bug exposure occurred on 01/02/2025, staff did look for evidence of bugs present but did not observe presence of pests. According to documentation, staff did not take preventative steps until 01/10/2025 after another child received bites. On 01/12/2025, Orkin Pest Control was contacted and observed the presence of bed bugs and beetles on 01/13/2025 and the youth were evacuated the same day to another location. The shelter was fumigated. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1, 800879(a)(1) Buildings and Grounds are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff are providing unnecessary searches of minors.” Five of nine confidential interviews stated inventory checks are requested but, youth can refuse to comply. Two of nine interviewed stated youth are not allowed inside until an inventory check is completed. Due to inconsistent statements made corroboration was unable to be reached. Regarding allegation “Staff did not safeguard belongings” it was alleged that a youth’s belongings were placed outside in trash bags that were not fully closed, leaving them exposed to the elements and damp conditions. Confidential interviews did not corroborate that this occurred. One of six youth interviewed stated their stuff was put outside but, then taken by a staff to have professionally cleaned. Another stated that they didn’t know what was done with their stuff and a third stated staff placed their belongings in a bag in the garage. One of five staff stated clothing was laundered professionally the day youth vacated the home so it could be treated. The Department investigated the allegation, “Facility’s washer is in disrepair.” Two of nine confidential interviews stated washing machine was broken In January. One interviewee stated it was broken for 2-3 weeks in January 2025. One stated they were unsure if washer was broken. It was stated that a laundering service picked up laundry while the washer was out of service once a week. It is unknown if a request was made for repair of the washing machine prior to 01/10/2025. Based on record review, the washing machine was reported to be broken on 01/10/2025 and a new one was ordered the same day and delivered to the facility on 01/14/2025. Although these allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie arrived at the facility to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 04/25/2025 at 04:00 PM. LPA Goldie spoke with Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor and Michael Gilbert, Facility Manager to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegation stated above. LPA Connie Goldie conducted this investigation. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted by LPAs Connie Goldie and Tina Thorn at the facility on 01/14/2025. LPA Thorn conducted a Health and Safety inspection and conducted four staff interviews. LPA Goldie completed a record review of staff schedules and youth rosters for November and December 2024, and medical report for C1. During the course of the investigation, ten confidential interviews were completed. Continued on LIC9099C

deficiencies.description: Buildings and Grounds 80087(a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. (1) The licensee shall take measures to keep the facility free of flies and other insects. This requirement was not met as required: :  Based on observation, interview and record review, the shelter did not ensure that facility took immediate preventative steps with the knowledge that bed bugs may be present which posed an potential threat to health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facilities management provided plastic bins for youths belongings after this infestation occured and are utilizing them currently. An emergency binder will be created to adress procedures when a youth enters care with potential pest ailments and a copy will provided to CCL by POC due date.

met_with: Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor Michael Gilbert, Facility Manager
narrative: page 2 LIC9099 The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff did not provide adequate supervision to ensure safety of youth.” All interviewed youth admitted to being exposed to vaping and/or marijuana use in the facility. There was also substantial corroboration through obtained statements that youth were exposed to, or possibly even recruited for, CSEC (Commercially Sexually Exploited Children) activities. Staff interviewed stated they communicate with youth about safety and making healthy choices and provide harm reduction strategies when youth are determined to participate in unsafe activities. Upon observation of drug use, staff attempt to confiscate contraband. There was not enough evidence to clearly and directly attribute these instances to a lack of supervision on the part of facility staff. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie arrived at shelter to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 04/25/2025 at 03:45 PM. LPA Goldie spoke with Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor and Michael Gilbert, Facility Manager to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegation stated above. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was conducted by LPA Chad Cabigon on 02/06/2025. At the shelter, LPA Cabigon obtained the following documentation: PMIs (Placement Matching Information), Youth Intake Screening Tools, Health & Education Passports, Daily Progress Logs, and a youth’s Care & Goal Plan as well as a Safety Plan. During the investigation, eighteen confidential interviews were conducted between 02/06/2025 and 04/17/2025. Continued on LIC9099C

narrative:
On 05/13/2025 the Sacramento Regional Office of Community Care Licensing’s (CCL) Children’s Residential Program and the Sacramento County Department of Child, Family, and Adult Services (DCFAS) held the monthly Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) collaborative meeting over the Teams platform. In attendance were Margo Castaneda, Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, Connie Goldie, Chad Cabigon, Sarina Buchannan, Zaria Turner, Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewicz, Tashna Ward, and Veronica Carrillo. The following items with respect to the Sacramento Welcome Home (SWH) locations were discussed: What’s Working Well: Both the County and CCL stated there is much more collaboration going on which has been very beneficial. SMILE has made a huge impact on getting IRs timelier. Alicia Wasklewicz has made a tremendous impact being at the homes. Provisional License: CCL informed the County that the provisional status of the Pasadena and Chicago Houses will be extended to 11/30/2025—the updated licenses will be provided to the County shortly. Under 6 Program Statement: CCL informed the county that the review of the Under 6 program statement is in progress and requested access to few more documents the LPA was not able to open. Request granted during the meeting. Incident Reports: The SMILE system has been a big success. County is still working on a few inconsistencies and duplication of reports. The county will reinforce to the staff the policy of IRs. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

Harm Reduction: As previously stated, any harm reduction plan must be approved by CCL before its implementation. It was also discussed that the harm reduction plan must be specific per youth, and CCL recommended that County reach out to the SOC (System of Care) Branch and to the case carrying LPA and their Licensing Program Manager for collaboration. Unauthorized Absence: County clarified that after four hours of a youth being gone, they pack up their belongings for safe-keeping. County explained that the runaway youth does not necessarily lose their bed if another youth comes into the facility unless that youth tells the facility beforehand that they do not plan to return within 24 hours. County also shared that they continue working on having direct-care staff be more consistent about following youth to the end of the Homes’ property lines when clients elope. Reporting Requirement 10-day overstay: By way of reminder, CCL requests County include both the assigned LPA and the LPM (Licensing Program Manager) when sending out the overstay reports. Over-Capacity: County shared part of the challenge has been that their TSCF-partner providers may refuse to accept youth for staffing reasons or due to the level of care and/or compatibility concerns for certain cases. County explained they are working with other providers for additional locations. Another obstacle is when placement is found for the youths but they refuse. Restraint Training: County explained that there is a small group that needed to re-take a required test before transitioning to the next phase causing a delay. By the end of today, the Administrator will be sending a list of fully trained staff and/or a scheduling plan that shows at least two staff per shift are certified to utilize manual restraints if needed. County reiterated its aversion to staff applying restraints on youth and has come up with a Best Practice Acknowledgement form that they are requiring staff to sign before staff are cleared to use such interventions—these forms are being sent out starting this week. CCL asked if County can identify any additional support that CCL can provide; no other items were discussed at this time. A copy of this report is being provided to the County.

On 05/28/2025, at 09:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPA Goldie was greeted at the door by James Hill, Security Guard. Alicia Wasklewicz, Program Administrator(PA) assisted with the inspection and stated 5 staff and 4 clients are present. One client is at school. LPA toured facility with PA and observed a 3 dual occupancy bedroom, 4 bath single story home with a large living room that has adequate seating for clients/staff. The temperature was observed to be a comfortable 70 degrees. Bedrooms had appropriate furnishings and linens as required. LPA observed kitchen to have 5 days of non-perishables and refrigerator/freezer with 2 days of perishables. Refrigerator temperature read 42 degrees Fahrenheit. Dining area has a seating area for clients that is adequate. Family room has additional area for activities. LPA observed soap and towels in bathrooms. The water temperature was observed to be compliant in kitchen, and although bathrooms temp measured at 127 degrees F, a warning sign was posted above the sink. LPA observed hygiene projects to be available to clients. LPA observed a secured shed in the backyard. Backyard was clear of debris. LPA observed a standing ashtray in the backyard. LPA communicated that licensed facilities are unable to have designated smoking areas on the property. Ms. Wasklewicz contacted facilities and requested removal. LPA observed facility van to be in safe driving conditions, headlights working, tire tread appropriate and all seat belts working. LPA verified that all staff are background cleared. LPA conducted three client youths. One youth declined to be interviewed. Continued on LIC809C

LPA received the updated LIC 500 and LIC 610C during inspection. The following deficiencies are being cited today- Two Type B Heath and Safety Code and one Type B Title 22 violations. An additional inspection will be necessary to complete the Annual/Required inspection. An exit interview was conducted and documents were discussed and provided to Ms.Wasklewicz, along with appeal rights.

deficiencies.description:
Health and Safety Code 1565(b) If a facility employs staff, the facility shall porvide training on the plan to each staff member upon hire and annually thereafter.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview and record review, the Emergency Disaster Plan was not posted and staff have not received training on the plan which poses a potential  health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will complete a training with all staff surrounding the Emergency Disaster plan and provide signed agenda to CCL by POC due date.Addidtionally, the Administrator will folow up with an Emergency disaster drill by POC due date.

deficiencies.description:
Buildings and Grounds 84087 (c)The licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview and record review, it was observed and verified that staff and youth have smoked on grounds and a standing ashtray was present on facility grounds which poses a potential  health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facilities is removing the standing ashtray by 05/30/2025. The Administrator will send a memo to all staff reminding them about this regulation. It will clearly state smoking is prohibited on the grounds by youth and staff. A copy of this memo will be provided to CCL by POC due date.

narrative: Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview and appeal rights were discussed with Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor. A copy of this report along with the appeal rights were given to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On May 21, 2025, at 09:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michelle Silvas arrived at Sacramento Welcome Home – Chicago House, to deliver the findings of the allegations listed above. LPA met with Danielle Chan, Engagement Supervisor, who assisted with today’s inspection. LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility inside and out. 3 staff and 2 youth are present. LPA conducted the initial 10-day complaint investigation at the facility on February 12, 2025. LPA conducted nine confidential interviews between 2/12/25 – 5/5/25. It was alleged that a staff member has given a youth a “wedgie”, made fun of a youth’s confidential information and shared it with other youth in the home and has tried to initiate a fight with a youth. Eight out of nine confidential interviews stated that they have never seen a staff member give a wedgie to a youth in care. Nine out of nine confidential interviews stated that they have never observed a staff member try to initiate a fight with a youth in care. Eight out of nine confidential interview stated that they have not observed a staff member share a youth’s confidential information with other youth in the home. Continue LIC9099-C

met_with: Pedro Shamar Lewis, Engagement Social Worker
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an unannounced case management inspection on 5/20/25 at 2:30 PM and met with Pedro Shamar Lewis, Engagement Social Worker to discuss the conclusion of a case management inspection initiated March 6, 2025, with a subsequent inspection conducted May 1, 2025. The initial inspection was related to an incident report dated February 12, 2025, in which C1 was restrained by a security guard (SG) contracted by the Licensee and S1. LPA Hill conducted interviews with direct care staff at the facility, a representative of the security agency, and an Engagement Supervisor as part of this investigation. LPA Hill did attempt to reach out to SG but was not able to obtain contact information due to the security company indicating they would not provide SG's information until the Department of Consumer Affairs, Bureau of Security and Investigative Services (BSIS) completed their investigation and review . LPA Hill did attempt to obtain additional information from BSIS but it was not available. Interviews conducted with the Sacramento County staff working in the facility indicate that at the time of the incident, S1 was not trained to provide manual restraints or provide restraint assistance at the facility and should not have physically engaged. As a result of the case management inspections conducted February 12, 2025 and May 1, 2025, the agency was cited per Title 22 Regulation Section 84365(a) Emergency Intervention Staff Training as no facility personnel are to use emergency intervention techniques, including manual restraints on a child unless the training instructor has certified in writing that the facility personnel have successfully completed the emergency intervention training. S1 had not completed the required training and the instructor had not certified it was completed at the time of the restraint. **Continued**

In questioning the role and training for security guards in the facility, it was indicated that security guards are to "observe and report only" and are not to provide any physical intervention, manual restraint(s) and/or assistance, or direct supervision of the youth in care, nor are they trained on the trauma informed responses or practices utilized by direct care staff. While reviewing the facility's program statement, it was not clear about the specific role(s) security guards play in the facility. In addition, the plan of operation is silent on what the security guard(s) are not allowed to do. As discussed during meetings and in-person discussions held between Community Care Licensing staff and Sacramento County, the security guards are to "observe and report only" but this is not explicitly indicated. The Plan of Operation/Program Statement are not clear about security guard training related to the agency's emergency intervention and/or trauma informed practices. LPA Hill did issue a Technical Advisory (LIC 9102TV) regarding this and did request that this be updated and provided to the Licensing Program Analyst reviewing the Plan of Operation and Program Statement. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided to Pedro Shamar Lewis, along with appeal rights.

On 06/03/2025, at 9:37 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie met with Esteban Baul,(S1) Karla Maldonado S2 and Pedro Lewis (S3) Engagement Social Workers, (ESWs) to continue unannounced/required Annual inspection. S1 stated that four staff and six youth are currently in the facility. One client is at school. Upon arrival, LPA Goldie learned that there are seven children present in the facility but the facility is only licensed to provide care and supervision for no more than six children at this location. LPA Goldie was made aware that eight youth are currently in census, one of which arrived this morning. Lashon Tate, Supervisor stated the facility has had more than six youth in care since 05/31/2025. LPA Goldie conducted four staff interviews, S1, S2, S3,and S4. See confidential names list LIC811. La Shon Tate, Supervisor, assisted LPA Goldie with record reviews. LPA Goldie reviewed staff training, five youth records and conducted a medication review. The following deficiencies are being cited today: Two Type A Title 22 California Code of Regulations Chapter 1, Division 6, Chapter 5, 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and 84070(b)(15) Children's Records and two Type B Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Article 6, Section 84661(b) Reporting Requirements, and 84668.1(c)(2)(A) Intake Procedures. See LIC809D. Annual inspection is complete. LPA conducted exit interview with Ms.Tate at 04:55 PM. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to the administrator.

met_with: Alica Waskliewicz Administrator Danielle Chan, Supervisor.

On 07/16/2025 at 01:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie, made an unannounced, subsequent visit for the purpose of closing out a Case Management, regarding an incident that was reported to the Department on 06/20/2025, involving the death of a client. LPA Goldie met with Shawn Singh, Engagement Social Worker LPA Goldie interviewed the Program Administrator S1, Engagement Social Workers S2 and S3, clients C3 and C4, and a detective badge #1003 between 06/20/2025 and 07/01/2025. met_with: Shawn Singh, Engagement Social Worker Danielle Chan Supervisor
narrative: On 07/16/2025 at 01:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Connie Goldie arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management regarding an incident that was reported to the Department on 06/19/2025 and occurred on 06/18/2025. On 07/17/2025, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie made a subsequent case management visit for the purpose of following up on an incident that was reported to the Department on 06/19/2025 and occurred on 06/18/2025.
