investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an initial complaint inspection on 7/8/25 at 9:10 AM and met with Alicia Wasklewicz, Program Manager. LPA Hill discussed the complaint allegation with Ms. Wasklewicz, and it was discussed that C1 (see LIC811 dated 7/8/25) arrived at the facility on 6/11/25 and due to overcapacity, there were no bedrooms available so C1 was placed in the living room to sleep from 6/11/25 through 6/16/25. Ms. Wasklewicz did acknowledge that C1 was not provided a bedroom during these days. As a result of the complaint allegation and interview conducted with Ms. Wasklewicz, the allegation that client was not provided appropriate bedroom accommodations is SUBSTANTIATED meaning the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. The facility was cited for violation of Group Home Regulation, Section 84087(b)(4) Buildings and Grounds as no room commonly used for other purposes shall be used as a bedroom and it was observed that C1 slept in the living room for the days indicated. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to the facility, along with appeal rights.

deficiencies.description: Buildings and Grounds. Bedrooms shall meet, at a minimum, requirements including that no room commonly used for other purposes shall be used as a bedroom. This was not met as evidenced by Based on interview conducted with the Program Manager, C1 was not initially given a bed to sleep in as the facility was over capacity and did not have a bed available from 6/11/25 through 6/16/25, when a bed became available which is a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Currently all clients are in bedrooms and are not sleeping in unauthorized areas. The agency shall provide a written plan of correction thataddresses client needs when admitted and ensure there is sufficient accommodations for clients, including bedrooms.

narrative: On 03/13/2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Tatyana Shulz and Chad Cabigon met with (NAME) in the County of Sacramento office at 3701 Branch Center Rd., Sacramento, CA 95827. The following report was delivered: Community Care Licensing (CCL) confirms the receipt of application documents for the Pasadena facility submitted in person by Division Manager Cathi Johnson on 03/06/2024. Those documents were the following: LIC 200, LIC 309, LIC 400, LIC 610C, and LIC 9054. The following forms/elements of the application are either in need of more information or have yet to be submitted: -on the LIC 610C: additional, local agency-specific names and contact numbers are needed for the fields where “911” was inputted. -LIC 215 (Applicant Information) -LIC 308 (Designation of Facility Responsibility) -LIC 500 (Personnel Report) -LIC 501 (Personnel Record -LIC 508 (Criminal Record Statement & Out-Of-State Disclosure) -LIC 999 (Facility Sketch) -Sections in the Program Statement (B docs) that need to be revised to include the new facility. Ms. Carrillo is advised that these documents are due on 03/22/2024. Ms. Carrillo was advised that the submission of the facility sketch, in particular, was time-sensitive because it is a requirement to obtain the fire clearance.

On 04/09/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a Prelicensing Inspection at this location as part of the licensure process for a Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA met with County of Sacramento Division Manager Cathi Johnson. LPA was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. The facility has two client bedrooms with each room having two beds; the bedrooms contained the required bedding observed to be in good condition; there is one common or shared full bathroom for the children's use situated between the bedrooms--the bathroom was in good repair, hygienic products were observed to be on hand, and the fixtures provided hot water. The temperature in spaces/rooms that clients occupy was within the required range. There are multiple refrigerators and/or freezer units all observed to be in good working condition and provided temperatures within the required range for perishable items. There is also sufficient storage space for dried goods or non-perishable items. The facility currently has a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable food items for at least three days and one week, respectively. Also observed within a secured staff office were lockable cabinets for confidential files and medications and a first aid kit which contained the required items. Potentially hazardous cleaning agents and chemicals were stored appropriately in the laundry area which was securable. The backyard was found to not have any potentially hazardous areas or items; the pathways were unobstructed. There is a detached covered garage on the property which was being used as additional storage for overstock groceries and other miscellaneous items. Ms. Johnson was advised of the following, as conditions of licensure: that not more than two children shall share a bedroom; children of different sexes shall not share a bedroom; no bedroom shall be used as a public or general passageway to another room, bath, or toilet (the larger space adjacent to the dining area and the staff office will have to be utilized to get to the staff office--there is no alternative entrance to the staff office); the use of cots or bunk beds shall be prohibited; sufficient personal storage space in the bedrooms shall be provided (a minimum of two drawers or eight cubic feet of drawer space is required for each child). A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Johnson.

met_with: Nykesha Sinegal-Thompson, ESW; Brittany Taylor, ESW
narrative: On 05/01/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this pending TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) in response to reported operational concerns. LPA met with Brittany Taylor and Nykesha Sinegal-Thompson, Engagement Social Workers, who facilitated a tour of the physical plant; Ms. Sinegal-Thompson also facilitated an LPA interview with one youth; LPA inspected the House's stock of food items. Further inspection may be required; a copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

On 05/24/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a second prelicensing inspection of this facility and was met by Division Manager Cathi Johnson and Admin. Services Officer Hazel Magett. A tour of the facility was conducted with focus on items/areas that needed to be addressed during the last prelicensing inspection, namely: 1) Personal storage bin/dresser space for clients' personal belongings--both bedrooms were observed to have sufficient storage space as prescribed by the Regulations; and 2) Fixtures that delivered hot water above the temperature limit required by Regulations--such water fixtures have been identified prominently with warning signs (one for the bathroom vanity faucet and one for the kitchen faucet). No other deficiencies were observed during this inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

On 09/10/2024, at 11:00 AM, Regional Manager, Margo Castaneda, Licensing Program Managers, (LPMs) Jodean Hall, Hillary Hall, and Rosa Rodriguez and Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Connie Goldie, Tina Thorn and Chad Cabigon conducted an in-person Office Meeting. Present from Sacramento County's Chicago House, Pasadena and Hilltop/Madison Temporary Shelter Care Facility Homes is Cathy Johnson, Division Manger, Alondra Neira, Program Planner, CPS, Veronica Carrillo, Program Manager, CPSU, Tashna Ward, Program Manager Alicia Wasklewicz, CPS Planner. Present from Systems of Care is Ashley Bray, Staff Services Manager II and Kayla Haith, Health Program Specialist II. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss CCL's concern regarding issues around the non-compliance in the facilities and to collaborate and problem solve together for the success of the programs. The primary areas of concern discussed, and outcomes provided include the following: ·Administrator/ Designation of Authority o It was discussed that a qualified administrator shall be on the premises for the number of hours necessary to manage and administer the facility in compliance with applicable laws and regulations. There needs to be someone readily available for the responsibilities and over site of all three facilities. There also needs to be staff designated to act on the administrator's behalf in the overall management of the facility when the administrator is not at the facility. These designees also need to be able to provide plan of corrections on site during an inspection. o CCL requested a written plan by 9/25/2024. Continued on LIC809C

· Reporting Requirements o CCL is receiving 24-hour notifications as required but, the full reports continue to be received past the regulatory requirement of seven days following the incident. o County staff communicated that they have streamlined the approval process to become compliant with full report. o CCL requested a written plan by 9/25/2024. · Training opportunities o CCL identified training concerns in the following areas: emergency intervention procedures, personal rights, medication, and job descriptions. o CCL offered training support by CCL staff and the Ombudsperson office. · Services Provided o Child specific services, Intake Assessment, CFT's and community resources are some of the services being provided. o Further collaboration will be ongoing. · Additional items discussed: o CCL suggested that a copy of Title 22 regulations, the Program Statement and a copy of the policies and procedures be located at the facility and available to staff. o The County shared that they are in the process of creating an employee handbook. o Administrator shared that two additional supervisors are being added which will provide supervision in the homes for all shifts. Written plans shall be submitted by email to all CCL attendees. A copy of this report was emailed to Cathy Johnson, Division Manager for signature.

On 09/13/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility). LPA was let in to the facility by a security officer to whom LPA’s badge was presented identifying his capacity as a licensing official for the California Department of Social Services (CDSS). LPA was subsequently received by Engagement Social Workers (ESW) Kaeley Vang, and Mike Gilbert; one more floor staffer was present—a Child Development Specialist (CDS). LPA interviewed both ESWs before Social Work Supervisor Danielle Chan arrived onsite to facilitate a tour of the interior and exterior grounds of the shelter’s physical plant. Ms. Chan also assisted LPA with a records review. Two youth files including medication records were surveyed; per staff, the facility currently has only two clients. No hard copies of the shelter’s personnel files were physically maintained at this location; Ms. Chan did access staff records online and was able to present certain records for LPA to review. An interview was conducted with the only available youth on the premises. A subsequent inspection may be required to complete this Post Licensing inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On 09/26/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection at this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) to complete the Post-Licensing Inspection that was started on 09/13/2024. LPA was met by Danielle Chan, Social Work Supervisor, with whom the following report was discussed: This facility has two shared client bedrooms with each room having two beds and containing the required bedding and furniture observed to be in good repair. There is one common or shared full bathroom situated in between and adjacent to the client bedrooms that was found to be in good repair, with a toilet that flushed and fixtures that provided hot water. There are multiple refrigerators and/or freezer units on the premises between the facility's dwelling unit and a detached garage that were observed to be in good working condition, provided temperatures within the required range, and stocked more than enough supplies of perishable items for the facility's capacity. There is also sufficient stock of dried goods or non-perishable items. Also observed within a secured staff office adjacent to the living room or common area were lockable cabinets for confidential files and medications. Potentially hazardous cleaning agents and chemicals were stored appropriately. There is a laundry area secured but accessible to clients as appropriate. The backyard was found to not have any potentially hazardous areas or items; the pathways are unobstructed. The facility is being cited for the deficiencies referenced in the following D-pages. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description: Intake Procedures. "The license shall: [meet the requirements specified in 84668.1(c)(1)-(8)]. These requirements were not met as evidenced by:” Based on observation, interviews, and a records review, one of two sets of client files did not have the required items specified in 84668.1(c)(2)-(7) which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee submitted a form, "SWH: Intake & Admission Checklist," to CCL to be used by the County of Sacramento to help in obtainment of required client information during intake. Staff training on this document has yet to be completed; CCL review of this form is underway.

deficiencies.description: Children's Records. "The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: [refer to 84070(b)(1) -(18)].” This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interviews, and a records review, at least one of two sets of client files did not have required items referenced in 84070(b)(8),(9),(12)-(14),(17),&(18) which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee submitted the "SWH: Intake & Admission Checklist" to CCL intended to be used in obtainment of required client information; staff training on this document has yet to be completed; CCL review of this form is ongoing to ensure all other required elements of a client's file is being addressed.

deficiencies.description: Safeguards for Cash Resources. "Each licensee shall maintain accurate records of accounts of cash resources, personal property, and valuables entrusted to his/her care..." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interviews, and a records review, one of two sets of client files did not have inventory logs for cash resource and/or personal property & valuables which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee submitted a form, "SWH: Intake & Admission Checklist," to CCL to be used by the County of Sacramento to help in obtainment of required client information during intake. Staff training on this document has yet to be completed; CCL review of this form is underway.

deficiencies.description: Personnel Records. "The licensee shall maintain the following personnel records: [c]omplete job descriptions on all [facility positions, and a] description of all staff assignments, including...lines of authority & staff responsibilities." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interviews, and a records review, staff files did not contain signed acknowledgments of job duties/descriptions/responsibilities/assignments which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee to submit a plan of correction addressing this deficiency.

deficiencies.description: Personnel Requirements. “The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when children are present…” This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interviews, the facility, at times when clients are present, did not have a "lead" or any staffer onsite who was properly designated and/or qualified as a facility manager which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Refer to to Section 23, Job Descriptions, of SWH Program Narrative--under ESW position.
Licensee to submit a plan of correction addressing this deficiency.

deficiencies.description: Discipline Policies & Procedures. "Staff, children, and authorized representatives shall receive copies of [the discipline] policies & procedures, [and s]igned copies of such...shall be maintained in the child's record." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interviews, and a records review, none of the client files contained signed copies of the facility's discipline policies & procedures which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee to submit a plan of correction addressing this deficiency.

deficiencies.description: Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. "A child and [the] authorized representative(s) shall receive a copy of [the removal and/or discharge] policies & procedures, [s]igned copies of such...shall be maintained in the child's record." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interviews, and a records review, none of the client files contained signed copies of the facility's removal and/or discharge policies & procedures which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee to submit a plan of correction addressing this deficiency.

deficiencies.description: Personnel Requirements (Training). "[S]taff...shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training as specified in [subsections 84065(i)(1) and (2)..." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interviews, and a records review, all four sets of staff files reviewed had incomplete mandatory training which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per email correspondence from C. Johnson dated 9/23/24 SWH management to arrange additional training sessions to ensure completion of all required initial training for applicable staff; documentation of which will be sent to CCL by 10/18/2024.

met_with: Danielle Chan, Social Work Danielle Chan
narrative: On 10/02/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility). LPA met with Social Work Supervisor Danielle Chan who was informed that the purpose of the inspection was to issue a citation for deficiency first observed on this LPA's inspection on 09/26/2024--on that day, the facility housed five clients which is one over the Program's approved capacity of four. The facility had been over-capacity at that point for eight days. The Shelter remains over its licensed capacity as of today's date, 10/02/2024--with six total youth currently in the facility as of the time of this writing. Sacramento Welcome Home - Pasadena House is being cited on the following D-page.

deficiencies.description:
Limitations on Capacity & Ambulatory Status.
"A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions & limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and a records review, the Shelter was found to have housed a number of youth that was over the approved capacity. This poses an immediate Health, Safety or
Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: SWH will continue to work with CPSU to identify expedited placements to reduce the likelihood of overcapacity and to bring the facility into compliance by 10/31/2024.

met_with: Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewics, and Tashna Ward
narrative:
On 10/08/2024 Community Care Licensing (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly Sacramento Welcome Home (SWH) TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. In attendance were Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewics, and Tashna Ward from the County and, from CCL, Rosa Rodriguez, Jodean Hall, Hillary Hall, Connie Goldie, and Chad Cabigon. After introductions, the following was covered: CCL acknowledged and thanked the County for the submission of its Written Plan, received by CCL on 09/25/2024, in response to the items covered during the first collaborative meeting held on 09/10/2024. The County has since assigned two new program supervisors to the SWH locations and is looking to fill a third supervisor position pending the Sacramento County Board of Supervisors’ approval which is expected to pass on 11/05/2024, bringing the total number of program supervisors to five (currently, there are four). Regarding the plan to re-designate an administrator, it was noted that Alicia Wasklewics is set to go through the administrator training/certification at the end of this month (October, 2024). CCL clarified that the required facility manager designation is specific to each shift per House/location when children are present. Being that there are only four supervisors covering all the Houses, there are times when no supervisor is available at a given location. The County stated that they have implemented an assigned Worker of the Day or “WOD” to cover those locations and/or times when a program supervisor is not available. CCL requested that on the schedules (on the LIC 500 or Personnel Report) it is specified who the WODs and supervisors are and that those designated are spelled out as ‘facility managers’, that all other CCL-required positions are spelled out (including, for example, Administrator) under the "Job Title," and that an updated form be submitted for each location by October 31, 2024. The County stated that some of the limitation(s) in properly reflecting these positions may be due to the need to have it cleared by the staff's union beforehand and that, relatedly, the same constraint(s) may be affecting the finalizing of job duty statements for care staff to acknowledge. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 2) Also discussed were the missing full or seven-day reports which are the follow-up reports to the County’s 24-hour notifications. Per the County, management is paying close attention to the October reports to ensure compliance: the 24-hour reports are being done in a timely manner but the intermediate step involving a supervisor de-brief is where the reports are getting held up. The County are actively working on a pilot program set to start at the end of November or the beginning of December, 2024, which is meant to help track reports through a more automated system. It is CCL’s expectation that the outstanding full or seven-day reports for previously-submitted 24-hour notifications (for September, 2024) will also be submitted to CCL by October 31, 2024—the number of missing full or seven-day reports are as follows: Pasadena House – 11; Madison - 27, and Chicago – 10 (for a total of 48). It is also CCL’s expectation that an immediate correction plan be put in place to be in compliance with Title 22 Regulations. Regarding training requirements—specifically, Section 84065(i)(1)(D) which discusses the need for an assessment of the efficacy of training—CCL noted, based on interviews, that direct-care staff may not have a sufficient understanding of the training topics covered despite having received the training. CCL advised that post-testing or return demonstrations to assess for competency may be developed by the County, themselves, so long as those assessments are documented in each staffer’s file. The County stated that management will check-in with the supervisors about this protocol and also added that the supervisors do meet with their staff every month, are probably doing at least some type of performance evaluations, and that they may just need to do better at documenting. CCL is requesting an implementation plan to be compliant with Title 22 Regulations, and that this plan should be submitted by October 31, 2024. Additional training support: CCL advised that the Ombudsperson’s Office only provides training on the Foster Youth Bill of Rights but not on anything more specific like medications, for example. CCL provided the Ombudsperson's Office portal and link to sign up for Bill of Rights training. The County asked if CCL, apart from the Ombudsperson’s Office, provides more topic-specific training—CCL advised that it does and that this training will be scheduled for the County by the end of November or the beginning of December, 2024. On the SWH Program Statement being made accessible to staff: the County stated that they are still working on the employee handbook—along with this process the care staff have been given electronic access to the Title 22/Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Regulations digitally and parts of the Program Statement on which staff get trained. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 3) Regarding the POC for the Personal Rights citation on the Chicago House on inventory check/searches. The POC was submitted to CCL on 10/03/2024, this procedure is still under review by CCL. Regarding the POC for the Personal Rights citation on the Madison House, the County will check on the progress of training for staff which is expected to be completed by 10/11/2024. Regarding the POC for the overcapacity citation on the Pasadena House, this POC was submitted to CCL on 10/02/2024 and is still under review. A copy of this report is being emailed to the County for signature.

LPA investigated an allegation that Staff spoke inappropriately to a minor. Interviewed County staff corroborated that a security officer, employed by a security agency contracted by the County of Sacramento, who was posted at this Sacramento Welcome Home location got into a heated verbal altercation with a youth after that youth threw activity material that hit the security staff. The verbal exchange was characterized by “a lot of cussing” and inappropriate statements made by the security officer to the youth including threats of violence. Based on LPA’s interviews and a record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation is found to be Substantiated. CCR Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 06, Section 84072(d)(19) is being cited on the attached 9099-D. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report, as well as the Appeal Rights, is being provided to the facility.

would not have been directly observed by any non-County individual being that only the security officer and the youth in question were involved and no one else was present outside of the three residential staff who intervened when the verbal altercation took place—though there were other youth residents on the premises, those clients were in the bedroom(s). LPA found no indication that County residential staff did not intervene appropriately and in a timely manner—the youth and the security officer were separated and did not come to blows despite apparent posturing from both individuals. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, and of the Appeal Rights, is being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 01/16/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) to close the complaint investigation. LPA met with Danielle Chan, Social Work Supervisor, to whom the following findings were delivered: LPA opened the complaint investigation on 09/26/2024 at the facility, during which time a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the Shelter’s physical plant was conducted and the following records were requested for review: a client's intake documents, contact numbers for specific staff, and information pertaining to the security agency involved. LPA interviewed children, residential staff and additional County personnel, as well as youth advocates. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights.
"The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal right...[t]o be free...from...the infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, [or] threat." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, a contracted security officer engaged in an inappropriate verbal altercation with an escalated youth that included that security officer making threats of violence on the minor. This poses a potential Health and Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Contracted security personnel are to be considered subject to criminal record clearance--fingerprinting of security officers is to be completed by 01/31/2025. Clarification, via a Program Statement update, on expectations related to security personnel's roles will also be submitted.

narrative: Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations above have been substantiated. 4 out of 5 confidential interviews stated that the facility has been operating over capacity on and off during the month of October 2024, due to population fluctuations and the abundant need for this specific facility type. Also, during review of the client roster for October 2024 it was confirmed by the LPA that there was a 5-year-old child placed at the facility from 10/20/2024-10/24/2024, it was also confirmed by staff members that a minor under 6 was placed at the facility for that length of time. Also, during today's visit on January 17, 2025 LPA observed the facility to be over capacity by one. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On January 17, 2025 at 10:50am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced visit to deliver findings to the above Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) and met with Kaeley Vang, House Manager. Prior to the meeting LPA Shulz, conducted the 10-day inspection of the facility on 10/30/2024. No deficiencies were cited during that inspection. LPA Shulz requested, the staff roster, staff training hours, and the client roster for the month of October. LPA Shulz conducted 5 interviews between 10/30/2024-1/08/2025. Continue to LIC 9099C

deficiencies.description:
84668.1 (c) (1) Intake Procedures
Ensure that placement of the child in the facility shall not result in the facility exceeding its licensed capacity.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations and interviews conducted, the licensee did not ensure the facility operated in accordance with their licensed parameters during the month of October 2024 which poses a potential Health and Safety risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will submit a written statement on how the facility plans to operate within the capacity of their license and submit it to LPA at Tatyana.Shulz@dss.ca.gov by close of business on 1/24/2025.

deficiencies.description:
84600 (c) General
Temporary shelter care facilities shall not accept for placement children who are under the age of six years, unless the facility is licensed for that age group...

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations and interviews conducted, the licensee did not ensure the facility operated in accordance with their licensed parameters during the month of October 2024 which poses a potential Health and Safety risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will submit a written statement on how the facility plans to operate within the capacity of their license and submit it to LPA at Tatyana.Shulz@dss.ca.gov by close of business on 1/24/2025. If the facility wants to provide services to clients under 6 an updated Program Statement will need to be submitted to the department for approval.

narrative:
On 02/11/2025, at 10:00 AM, the CA Department of Social Services’ (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. The attendees were: from County, Cathi Johnson, Sac County Administrator, Alondra Neira,Program Planner, and Alicia Wasklewicz,Sac County Administrator, from CCL, Margo Castaneda, Regional Director, Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, Hillary Hall, Licensing Program Managers and Tina Thorn, Chad Cabigon, and Connie Goldie, Licensing Program Analysts and from CDSS’ System of Care Branch (SOC), Levi Huser, Ashley Bray, and Alicia Bernstein. The following items were discussed— What’s working well: Ms. Johnson stated that the County is continuing to focus on training of staff in various areas and two houses have placement. Duty statements will be reviewed with staff, signed, and placed in their files. CCL stated facility staff are pleasant, workers of the day are helpful during inspections and youth are observed to be engaged. CCL requested copy of duty statements by 02/21/2025. Administrator Update: Alicia Wasklewicz, administrator applicant provided Group Home Certificate to CCL on 02/11/2025. CCL clarified expectations that Administrator will provide oversight as needed. Program Statement Update: CCL received Program Statement updates as requested on 01/31/2025. CCL is in the process of reviewing received documentation. CCL’s review of revisions will be completed by 02/21/2025. Continued on LIC809C.

page 2 Pasadena House License Status: The County stated the Pasadena House license will be maintained until further notice. County will communicate when this transition occurs. Trauma Informed Care (TIC): CCL requested a list of which staff are not currently trained in TIC. County stated they will provide a copy of the training log highlighting staff who still need to complete this training. CCL requests this be submitted by 02/14/2025. CCL asked if security guards will receive restraint training. The County stated security guards will not be restraint trained and will not put hands on youth. Reporting Requirement Update: CCL discussed the continued issue of late and/or missing reports for all TSCF facilities. The County stated that their records are not consistent with CCL reported numbers and requested that CCL attach which reports are missing going forward. Increase of Unauthorized Absences: CCL discussed observation of increased unauthorized absences and asked how staff attempt to prevent youth from leaving. County shared that staff follow youth to the property perimeter line when leaving due to safety concerns. It was also stated staff ratios can determine if a youth is followed. CCL advised the county to include reason for not going further than property line on incident reports. Levi Huser from Systems of Care Branch offered an opportunity for collaboration to discuss ideas on reducing law enforcement contacts. LIC809 Office Meeting Review: Licensing Program Analyst and Licensing Program Manager will have a Teams Meeting with the County to review the LIC809 report for the monthly collaboration meeting each month in order for any revisions to be made immediately as necessary. The reports will then be emailed to obtain a signature. Ashley Bray from Systems of Care offered to assist with creating individual safety plans with a harm reduction approach in order to be proactive. Ms. Bray suggested County staff and licensing staff participate in the meeting. The office meeting concluded at 10:40 AM.

On 01/14/2025 the CA Department of Social Services’ (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCL) and the County of Sacramento held the monthly collaborative meeting over Microsoft Teams. The attendees were: from County, Cathi Johnson, Alondra Neira, Tashna Ward, Alicia Wasklewicz, and Veronica Carrillo, from CCL, Margo Castaneda, Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, Hillary Hall, Connie Goldie, Tina Thorn, Chad Cabigon, and from CDSS’ System of Care Branch (SOC), Kelley Hartman, Levi Huser, and Alicia Bernstein. Topics discussed at the meeting were: What’s working well: The County expressed having two TSCF’s is much more manageable. They have also had a lower census on average as of late between the Welcome Home locations which has been helped by the recent capacity expansion through outside partners. Temporary move from Chicago House to Pasadena House: Due to an infestation of carpet beetles the facility is being fumigated. Designated Administrator: CCL noted that Alicia Wasklewicz passed the Administrator Exam; County was informed that Regional Manager (RM) Castaneda requested the expedited processing of Ms. Wasklewicz’s administrator certification. CCL reiterated expectations for a facility administrator: to be on facility premises for the number of hours necessary to manage and administer the facility in compliance with applicable laws and regulations, and to be readily available for the responsibilities and oversight of the facilities. CCL also reiterated the need for staff to be designated to act on the administrator’s behalf with the overall management of facilities in the administrator’s absence. CCL emphasized that these designees also need to be able to provide Plans of Correction for citations issued during inspections—County confirmed that these facility manager designees have been given this authority. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 2) Plan for Pasadena House license: The County will continue to keep the license until further notice. Training Requirements: Follow-Up: County will be sending the template for staff training. Security Guards – Fingerprint Clearance Needed: CCL advised that all security guards positioned in the home need to be fingerprinted and obtain criminal record clearances through Guardian due to the frequency, consistency, and recurring nature of their presence. The due date for the completion of fingerprinting is 01/31/2025. Reporting Requirement Update – Incident Reporting CCL discussed the continued issue of late and/or missing reports and acknowledged it is vastly improving. County stated that they are continuing to address this and with Ms. Wasklewicz as administrator, her presence in the Houses more frequently should help address the reporting. The County also expects to start testing the SMILE system this week with the goal of launching in the end of February. Inventory Check/Searches: CCL followed up on the submission of the County’s Prudent Parenting activation form related to searches for CCL to review. The County will be submitting the form. CCL/SOC pointed out that Prudent Parenting is usually in reference to decisions that a substitute caregiver makes to afford youth something that resembles a more “normal” way of life such as allowing youth to participate in certain activities without prior approval from their authorized representative. SOC discussed that the Prudent Parent Standard is a general framework through which providers can respond as necessary to help support youth, but it might not always be appropriate, and its use should depend on the population and/or individual youth in question. Facility Overview: Both LPAs stated seeing an increase in engagement between youth and staff participating in various house activities. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

(PAGE 3) Additional feedback: SOC reminded County of standing offer to provide consultation and guidance and encouraged County to reach out, as necessary. Training materials have been sent to County from SOC that may be helpful and could be integrated in the Shelter’s program. County to submit Program Statement updates by 01/31/2025, to include clarification on the mandated initial vs. annual training, as well as policies and expectations related to contracted security personnel who work onsite at the SWH locations. Closing discussion on restraints: The County stated that all staff will start Phase 2 of the TCI training in February, 2025, and that they anticipate completion in March, 2025. CCL advised that a manual restraint should only be executed by a trained staff and should only be resorted to in a health and safety consideration for a child or staff, that it is more about good training that truly helps staff be proactive with early interventions, how to identify early on what the specific youth’ triggers are, and how staff can equip themselves with enough techniques to de-escalate a situation. Additionally, it should also be helpful for the County to be familiar with the temperament and tendencies of their direct-care personnel so as to better inform management on staffing decisions and training considerations. A copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

Present: CCL: Margo Castaneda, Regional Manager Licensing Program Managers: Hillary Hall, Jodean Hall, and Rosa Rodriguez Licensing Program Analysts: Chad Cabigon, Tina Thorn, and Connie Goldie Sacramento Welcome Home County Partners: Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Tashna Ward, Alicia Wasklewicz Systems of Care: Alicia Bernstein, Ashley Bray and Levi Huster On 03.11.25, the following was discussed during the CCL collaboration meeting with Sacramento County regarding the Temporary Shelter Care Facility. Both the county and CCL reported on what’s going well: Alicia Wasklewicz collaborated with Systems of Care representative and obtained resources and expressed gratitude for the connection. LPAs for each facility reiterated that the staff have been engaged with clients and responsive to LPAs. LPA Goldie reported on progress with Program Statement Review. LPA stated that she was able to access forms easily. LPA also stated that most of the revisions were a matter of gaining clarification, requesting transcripts, and having County provide more explanation regarding how the processes will be implemented. LPA Goldie gave a briefing on revision requests, namely the under 6 and discipline policies and of requesting transcripts for staff to ensure requirements are met. The County expressed that obtaining transcripts is proving to be a longer process depending on the time frame in which the staff took the required courses. The incident report submission process was discussed, with the county’s new system, SMILE being implemented 03.17.25. C. Johnson explained that the county’s new system should reduce the reporting time frame by providing email alerts to submit required reports and will provide more reminders to support staff. Continued 809C

The county was informed that, going forward, they will be cited if incident reports are turned in late. CCL shared information about our Technical Support Program that will provide support and training for the facility. T. Ward reported 12 staff are fully trained in Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (TCI). There are still staff needing to be trained. It was reported that enough staff are trained to ensure there are 2 people per shift available to do restraints if necessary. The expectation is that all staff are trained by April 1, 2025. County reported that on March 22, 2025, Foster Hope is set to take over operations at the current Madison House. Youth will move to Pasadena and Chicago House to allow Foster Hope to get situated. The County expressed a desire to keep Pasadena House as a home to relocate youth if Chicago House needs to be evacuated for emergency reason or if something needs to be fixed at Chicago House. It was also expressed that Chicago House may be used to conduct staff training and/or for youth visitation when needed and if not occupied by youth. SOC asked if County wanted their harm reduction policies/forms reviewed. A. Bernstein provided email address to the County. Regional Manager M. Castaneda concluded the meeting after offering time for more questions or comments.

On 04/07/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon completed an unannounced case management inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) that was initiated by LPA Tina Thorn on 04/01/2025. LPA Cabigon met with Sandra Gomez, Social Work Supervisor, to whom the following report was delivered: For the inspection on 04/01/2025, interviewed facility staff reported to LPA Thorn that there were eight clients placed in the facility at the time of that inspection. A client roster was also obtained at the time which corroborated the facility having gone over its capacity. Staff stated that they were not aware of any clients who would be exiting the facility at that time. The facility failed to ensure their licensed capacity was not exceeded; the Shelter is being cited on the attached LIC 809-D per Title 22 of the California Code of Regulations Chapter 1, General Licensing Requirements, Section 80010(a). For today's inspection (04/07/2025), upon arrival, LPA Cabigon observed three clients on the premises, all of whom were, according to staff, being taken out by a community resource partner--no clients were interviewed during this inspection. Per staff, the facility's current census was four with one client who was listed as having absconded. LPA Cabigon was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. In clients' bedrooms, there was not enough personal storage space observed; the Shelter is being cited on the attached LIC 809-D per Group Home Regulations, Section 84088(c)(4)(A). A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Limitations on Capacity & Ambulatory Status.
"A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions & limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interviews, and a records review, the Shelter was found to have housed a number of youth that was over the approved capacity. This poses an immediate Health, Safety or
Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per SWH, the fac. came back into compliance on the same day, 04/01/2025. Documentation of which will be provided by 04/09/2025. Moving forward, placement supervisors will be reminded to exhaust all placement options inc. other TSCFs, emergency foster homes, etc.

deficiencies.description:
Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies.
"The licensee shall provide [a minimum of two drawers or eight cubic ft. of]...storage space...to accommodate [children's]...personal belongings. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, the facility did not have sufficient personal storage space for each client in care. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will supply sufficient storage space for each client bedroom as specified in Regs. Onsite inspection will be done by 04/11/2025 to confirm that the storage spaces have been provided. .

narrative: On 04/10/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon initiated a case management follow-up to clear a deficiency for which a citation was issued on 04/07/2025. LPA visually inspected youth' bedrooms and observed that additional bins/moveable dressers have been provided to clients in care, bringing the facility into compliance with respect to section 84088 (c)(4)(A)(1) of the Group Home Regulations. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On 04/10/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon initiated a case management inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility), the purpose of which was to address this SWH (Sacramento Welcome Home) location going over capacity. LPA was met by Rashenda Williams, Engagement Social Worker, who facilitated client interviews and a tour of the Shelter's interior area. Per interviews with youth and staff, a fifth client came into care last night, 04/11/2025, putting the facility over its approved capacity of four. Sacramento Welcome Home - Pasadena House is hereby being cited on the attached LIC 809-D per Title 22 of the California Code of Regulations Chapter 1, General Licensing Requirements, Section 80010(a). Copies of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Limitations on Capacity & Ambulatory Status.
"A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions & limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation." This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews the Shelter was found to have housed a number of youth that was over the approved capacity. This poses an immediate Health, Safety or
Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Documentation of CPSU's placement finding efforts shall be provided to CCL by end of business on 04/10/2025.

narrative: The Department investigated the allegation, “Staff did not provide adequate supervision to ensure safety of youth.” All interviewed youth admitted to being exposed to vaping and/or marijuana use in the facility. There was also substantial corroboration through obtained statements that youth were exposed to, or possibly even recruited for, CSEC (Commercially Sexually Exploited Children) activities. Staff interviewed stated they communicate with youth about safety and making healthy choices and provide harm reduction strategies when youth are determined to participate in unsafe activities. Upon observation of drug use, staff attempt to confiscate contraband and discourage the use. There was not enough evidence to clearly and directly attribute these instances to a lack of supervision on the part of facility staff. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur; therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon arrived at shelter to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 04/30/2025. LPA Cabigon spoke with Brittany Taylor, ESW, to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegation stated above. The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspection was initiated by LPA Chad Cabigon on 02/06/2025. At the shelter, LPA Cabigon obtained the following documentation: PMIs (Placement Matching Information), Youth Intake Screening Tools, Health & Education Passports, Daily Progress Logs, and a youth’s Care & Goal Plan as well as a Safety Plan. During the investigation, 13 confidential interviews with youth and eight interviews with staff were conducted between 02/06/2025 and 04/17/2025. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative:
On 05/13/2025 the Sacramento Regional Office of Community Care Licensing’s (CCL) Children’s Residential Program and the Sacramento County Department of Child, Family, and Adult Services (DCFAS) held the monthly Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) collaborative meeting over the Teams platform. In attendance were Margo Castaneda, Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, Connie Goldie, Chad Cabigon, Sarina Buchannan, Zaria Turner, Cathi Johnson, Ali Neira, Alicia Wasklewicz, Tashna Ward, and Veronica Carrillo. The following items with respect to the Sacramento Welcome Home (SWH) locations were discussed: What’s Working Well: Both the County and CCL stated there is much more collaboration going on which has been very beneficial. SMILE has made a huge impact on getting IRs timelier. Alicia Wasklewicz has made a tremendous impact being at the homes. Provisional License: CCL informed the County that the provisional status of the Pasadena and Chicago Houses will be extended to 11/30/2025—the updated licenses will be provided to the County shortly. Under 6 Program Statement: CCL informed the county that the review of the Under 6 program statement is in progress and requested access to few more documents the LPA was not able to open. Request granted during the meeting. Incident Reports: The SMILE system has been a big success. County is still working on a few inconsistencies and duplication of reports. The county will reinforce to the staff the policy of IRs. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 809-C)

Harm Reduction: As previously stated, any harm reduction plan must be approved by CCL before its implementation. It was also discussed that the harm reduction plan must be specific per youth, and CCL recommended that County reach out to the SOC (System of Care) Branch and to the case carrying LPA and their Licensing Program Manager for collaboration. Unauthorized Absence: County clarified that after four hours of a youth being gone, they pack up their belongings for safe-keeping. County explained that the runaway youth does not necessarily lose their bed if another youth comes into the facility unless that youth tells the facility beforehand that they do not plan to return within 24 hours. County also shared that they continue working on having direct-care staff be more consistent about following youth to the end of the Homes’ property lines when clients elope. Reporting Requirement 10-day overstay: By way of reminder, CCL requests County include both the assigned LPA and the LPM (Licensing Program Manager) when sending out the overstay reports. Over-Capacity: County shared part of the challenge has been that their TSCF-partner providers may refuse to accept youth for staffing reasons or due to the level of care and/or compatibility concerns for certain cases. County explained they are working with other providers for additional locations. Another obstacle is when placement is found for the youths but they refuse. Restraint Training: County explained that there is a small group that needed to re-take a required test before transitioning to the next phase causing a delay. By the end of today, the Administrator will be sending a list of fully trained staff and/or a scheduling plan that shows at least two staff per shift are certified to utilize manual restraints if needed. County reiterated its aversion to staff applying restraints on youth and has come up with a Best Practice Acknowledgement form that they are requiring staff to sign before staff are cleared to use such interventions—these forms are being sent out starting this week. CCL asked if County can identify any additional support that CCL can provide; no other items were discussed at this time. A copy of this report is being provided to the County.

Though actual rendering of services were inconsistent, interviewed youth indicated that mental health services are generally made available or facilitated by the Shelter as necessary; actual referrals are within the purview of the County’s case-carrying placement or permanency Social Workers who are not part of the residential staff at the Shelter. No youth reported any instances of not being taken to acute care when medically necessary though there has been at least one instance where Shelter staff should have sought for services sooner on behalf of a minor. Regarding a possible mishandling of medication administration, though LPA was not able to independently verify that a youth was taken to emergent or acute care, there was sufficient corroboration between the interviewees that this was done, and that this was done to have the youth evaluated following staff deciding to hold a psychotropic medication. The medication being whithheld was due to concerns about adverse drug interactions as the youth was suspected of being under the influence of an illicit substance at the time. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted; a copy of this report and of the Appeal Rights are being provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 04/30/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) to deliver the findings of, and close, the complaint investigation. LPA met with Brittany Taylor, ESW, to whom the following report was delivered: LPA investigated allegations that 1) Staff did not meet a minor’s medical needs, and 2) Staff mshandled a minor’s medication. LPAs Connie Goldie and Tina Thorn initiated the complaint investigation on 01/14/2025 at the facility, during which time a tour of the Shelter’s physical plant was done and records were requested. The following items were reviewed as part of the investigation: JV220 series forms, Centrally Stored Medication Logs, Medication Administration Records (MAR), medical facility records, a Youth Care & Goal Plan, a client’s Placement Matching Information (PMI), a youth’s Health & Education Passport, and email correspondence between the facility and outside providers. Interviews were conducted with multiple youth, staff, and personnel from outside agencies with attachments to a client’s case. (CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE, 9099-C)

narrative: On June 10, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived at Sacramento Welcome Home-Pasadena at approximately (Time) for the purpose of performing a collateral visit. LPA was greeted by Sarah Morrow, Engagement Social Worker who granted LPA access. LPA conducted a collateral visit to facility for the purpose of interviewing C1 in regards to another open complaint at a different facility. C1 was moved to another placement in the week previous. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with at the facility.

On 04/08/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a Prelicensing Inspection at this location as part of the licensure process for a Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). LPA met with County of Sacramento Division Manager Cathi Johnson. LPA was given a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. The facility has three client bedrooms with each room having two beds; the bedrooms contained the required bedding and furniture which were observed to be in good repair; most of the rooms had sufficient storage/drawer space for clients' personal belongings. There is one common or shared full bathroom in the hallway that leads to the bedrooms. There was a carbon monoxide detector observed in the hallway. All the bathrooms were generally in good repair, with toilets that flushed and fixtures that provided hot water. The temperature in spaces/rooms that clients occupy was within the required range. There are multiple refrigerators and/or freezer units all observed to be in good working condition and provided temperatures within the required range for perishable items. There is also sufficient storage space for dried goods or non-perishable items. The facility currently has a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable food items for at least three days and one week, respectively. Also observed within a secured staff office were lockable cabinets for confidential files and medications. Most of the potentially hazardous cleaning agents and chemicals were stored appropriately in a secured cabinet. The backyard was found to not have any potentially hazardous areas or items; the pathways are unobstructed. The following items will need to be addressed for the issuance of the provisional license: all cleaning agents/chemicals are to be secured; a weekly food menu is to be posted; the hallway bathroom's shower fixture (valve) is to be repaired; a separate log is to be kept for each psychotropic medication; a part of the east fence-line in the backyard is to be repaired (loose planks, exposed nails); personal storage space in the bedrooms shall be provided (a minimum of two drawers or eight cubic feet of drawer space is required for each child); curtain rods in the bedrooms are to be repaired/secured. A copy of this report is being provided to Ms. Johnson.

On 04/26/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection of this pending TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) in response to operational concerns reported to Community Care Licensing. LPA met with Liz Jones, Engagement Social Worker (ESW), who facilitated a tour of the physical plant. LPA discussed with ESW Jones what rooms or spaces may be used by youth for meetings (CFTs, intakes, etc.) or other purposes that require privacy (therapy services, etc.). Also inspected was the selection of food that the facility had on-hand for clients. Further inspection may be required at a later time. A copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

On 05/01/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced case management inspection of this pending TSCF (Temporary Shelter Care Facility) in response to a recently reported unusual incident entailing events that occurred starting on 04/19/2024 and into 04/20/2024. LPA interviewed Engagement Social Worker Rashenda Williams and two youth. Further inspection may be required.

On 05/24/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a second prelicensing inspection of this facility and was met by Division Manager Cathi Johnson and Admin. Services Officer Hazel Magett. A tour of the facility was conducted with focus on items/areas that needed to be addressed during the last prelicensing inspection, namely: 1) the clients, for their bedrooms, have been provided with roll-out under-the-bed plastic bins for additional storage, 2) the hallway bathroom shower fixture has been repaired, 3) part of the east fence that was in disrepair has been fixed, and, 4) there now is new furniture and a new configuration in the common/living room area that adds dining space. Curtain rods in two of the client bedrooms need to be more properly secured. No other deficiencies were observed during this inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the County of Sacramento.

On 06/13/2024 a virtual meeting was held on the Microsoft Teams platform between CCL's Sacramento Children's Residential Program and Sacramento County CPS; the attendees were Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Tina Thorn, Uchenna Ajaero, and Chad Cabigon, Licensing Program Managers (LPM) Jodean Hall, Rosa Rodriguez, and Hillary Hall, and Regional Manager Margo Castaneda on behalf of the State, and for the County, Division Manager Cathi Johnson and Program Planner Ali Neira. The purpose of the meeting was to formally introduce the assigned LPAs and LPMs for the various locations of the County's Temporary Shelter Care Facilities (TSCF). Those assignments are as follows: -LPA Thorn and LPM H. Hall for Hilltop House -LPA Ajaero and LPM J. Hall for Chicago House -LPA Cabigon and LPM Rodriguez for Pasadena House Also discussed was the Care for Children Under the Age of Six Years. The understanding is that Progress Ranch Treatment Service's TSCF will be the program contracted by Sacramento County to accept children under six years of age pending CCL's approval of Progress Ranch's update to its Plan of Operation. Progress Ranch has submitted preliminary records/supporting documentation requested by CCL which are currently under review. The County stated that talks are ongoing with Foster Family Agencies regarding the allocation of emergency placement beds in Resource Family Homes to help address placement overflow and ensure the TSCF's compliance with capacity limitations. In addition, Regulations pertaining to incident reporting were reviewed by way of a reminder that, apart from the 24-hour notification requirement, a full written report should be submitted within seven days of the reportable special or unusual incident.

Based on observations and interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the allegation that Unlicensed care is being provided is Substantiated. An exit interview was conducted, the Appeal Rights were discussed, and a copy of this report is being provided to Program Manager Carrillo.
investigation_findings: 13On 05/03/2024 at 4:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon met with Veronica Carrillo, Program Manager at the Branch Center Rd. narrative: Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility on this date and conducted a case management inspection following a record review. LPA and LPM met with and interviewed, Rashenda Williams, Engagement Social worker and LaShon Tate, Supervisor. LPA and LPM interviewed one client at the facility on this date. LPA and LPM completed a Health and Safety Inspection of the facility. The staff interviewed reported there were 7 clients currently placed at the facility. A client roster was requested, and would be sent electronically. A handwritten roster was provided to LPA and LPM with client's names and ages, indicating 7 clients were placed at the facility on this date, 7/18/24. One client had arrived on this date, putting the facility over their licensed capacity of 6 clients. Staff were not aware of any clients who would be exiting the facility, aside from one client scheduled to leave for a family visit on 7/19/24. The facility failed to ensure their licensed capacity was not exceeded when an intake was completed on the seventh client placement. The facility is cited per the Interim Licensing Standards for Temporary Shelter Care Facilities, Article 06. Continuing Requirements, Section 84668.1: Intake Procedures, (c) The licensee shall: (1)Ensure that placement of the child in the facility shall not result in the facility exceeding its licensed capacity. A signed copy of this LIC 809 and LIC 809D form were provided to the facility on this date.

deficiencies.description:
Section 84668.1: Intake Procedures, (c) The licensee shall: (1)Ensure that placement of the child in the facility shall not result in the facility exceeding its licensed capacity. This regulation was not met as evidenced by:
Record review and interview indicated seven clients were placed at the faciilty when the licensed capacity is 6.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility is implementing policy of having clients transported to a different facility, when an additional client arrives putting the facility over capacity.  Verification of policy will be provided to LPA by 8/16/24

narrative: Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility for a case management inspection and record review. LPM and LPA interviewed four staff/security and attempted to interview three clients who declined to be interviewed. LPM spoke with supervisor LaShon Tate via telephone and requested log of trainings for all facility staff. LPM did not observe a menu posted, but when asked, one was printed and provided to LPM and it was subsequently posted on the refrigerator. LPM conducted a Health and Safety Inspection of the physical grounds. LPM observed trace amounts of marijuana on the floor of the bathroom which was reported to be left by the clients the previous night. While LPM was conducting interviews, the bathroom was cleaned by an outside cleaning service. A total of three bedrooms for clients are available, with a current census of 5 clients. Four staff were on site, plus one security personnel, when LPM and LPA arrived. Additional security arrived for their shift and switched out for current staff. Personal rights postings were observed. An intake room which is locked, had storage for client medications. LPM observed 3 days of perishable and 7 days of non-perishable food on site, both in the kitchen refrigerator and locked garage refrigerator. The facility did not have a current license posted, or a posting regarding complaint procedures. Facility is being cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 84009(a): Posting of License (a) The license shall be posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Facility is also cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 84072.2(a)(3): Complaint Procedures: (a) The licensee of a group home shall develop, maintain and implement written complaint procedures by which children or their authorized representatives are permitted to file complaints, without fear of retaliation, with the facility administrator regarding facility staff or operations. (3) Such procedures shall be posted in a location in the facility which is accessible to children and their authorized representatives. A signed copy of this LIC 809 and LIC 809D were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Section 84009(a): Posting of License 	  
(a) The license shall be posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: faciiity did not have a publicly accessible  license posted.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will post license which was emailed to Director on 5/31/24.
