Complaint procedures were not posted for clients or authorized represetantives to see
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will post compaint hotline by POC due

narrative: On 08.21.24 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a Case Management inspection following a review of incident reports sent to licensing agency. LPA met with Rashenda Williams, Engagement Social Worker and La Shon Tate and Engagement Social Worker Supervisor was on the phone on speaker. While conducting a review of incident reports LPA Thorn found 23 incident reports (IRs) that were submitted to the licensing agency after the required seven days following the occurrence of the event. The time period for when the IRs were reviewed was between 04.29.24 to 08.16.24. Agency is issued one citation for violating Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1. 80061: Reporting Requirements: (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) … a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. A signed copy of this 809 and 809D were provided to Facility. Exit interview conducted and appeal rights provided.

deficiencies.description:
Section 80061(b): A report shall be made to the licensing agency within the next business day during business hours. A report shall be madeto the licensing agency containing the information in (2) below shall be submitted to 
agency within 7 days following occurrence of event. The requirement was not met as evidenced by LPA's review of incident reports. The facility did not report incidents within the required time period. This poses a risk to the health, safety, and personal rights of clients
in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Involved Staff will complete Incident Report. Staff  will then give  to supervisors and then it will be sent to management to review and send to CCL within the required time period.

met_with: Esteban Baul, Engagement Social Worker and Sandra Gomez, Program Supervisor
narrative:
Statements from interviews and video recordings reviewed by LPA Thorn and LPM Hall provided consistent information regarding the allegations that staff did not intervene when a minor was hitting another minor with an object, staff spoke inappropriately towards a minors, and staff yelled at a minor in care. An incident occurred in early July where two minors in care engaged in a verbal and physical altercation which continued over the course of two days. During one afternoon, the minors began throwing kitchen items at one another and at the wall. One staff recorded a portion of the altercation on their phone. Staff interviewed stated they were removing items that could be used as a weapon, however, on the video, there were items within reach of the minors that were later used as weapons. Staff who were interviewed reported trying to verbally deescalate the conflict, but the words used by staff in the video were not effective in calming or redirecting the minors. One staff was heard raising their voice at the minors in the video, but was not seen in proximity of the minors, physically intervening or redirecting the minors. In one of the videos reviewed, a staff member can be seen and heard screaming and arguing in face-to-face proximity with the minor. A staff member admitted that they did become inappropriate with the youth during and after the recorded statement that was made in the second video. A Program Supervisor stated that they had to intervene when the staff was arguing with the minors. Five staff Interviews, one client interview, and 1 security staff interview were consistent that there are staff members that engage in inappropriate and antagonistic interactions with the youth. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. Citation is being issued for violating Title 22 Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 84072(d)(1) Personal Rights A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and LIC-9099D were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.

An incident occurred in early July where two minors in care engaged in an altercation. Records and interviews indicate the minors were supervised by staff and ratio was maintained. The conflict between the minors was ongoing over a two-day span with multiple staff observing the behaviors of the minors. At some point during the altercation, it became physical between one minor and one staff. The minor says they were pushed by the staff, but the staff on shift indicate the staff had been spit on by the minor and the staff folded their arms fold across their chest and was trying to create space from the minor. In a separate incident, a video shows a staff member lunging forward in the direction of the minor during a heated argument, however, it is unclear whether there was any physical contact. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced on 09.11.24 for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. Findings were delivered to the facility’s new location of 7697 Madison Ave, Citrus Heights, as the facility relocated since the opening of the complaint. LPA met with Esteban Baul, Engagement Social Worker and Sandra Gomez was on her cell phone speaker, participating with the delivery of findings. LPA Thorn conducted the complaint investigation. LPA Thorn and LPM Hillary Hall opened the investigation with the facility on 07.18.24 and met with Rashenda Williams, Engagement Social Worker, and LaShon Tate, Supervisor. LPA Thorn conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed 10 staff, 2 clients, 1 County Social Worker, and one other confidential interview. LPA reviewed records from the facility including: Placement Roster, Serious Incident Reports, Staff Roster, and 4 videos. Continued on 9099C

deficiencies.description:
84072 Personal Rights (d) (1) Each child is accorded personal rights to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interviews, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above when staff addressed minors using a disrespectful tone and words, which poses/posed a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff will participate in a training about the personal rights of clients and sign a document stating they did receive the training. Management will send proof of this documentation to LPA that all employees have participated in this training by 10.11.24

met_with: Danielle Chan, Program Supervisor Via phone, and Kaeley Vang, Engaagement Social Worker at facility.
narrative:
Statements from interviews, and records reviewed by LPA Thorn provided consistent information that staff were not providing a safe environment for minors in care and that staff were not properly trained. Videos obtained show staff yelling at minors and minors engaged in physical altercations while staff did not intervene, which created an unsafe environment for the minors in care. Staff training logs show that ten of eleven staff were missing mandatory reporting training and that only three of eleven staff completed de-escalation training. There was no evidence that the eleven staff working at this facility completed Trauma Informed Training or the required number of training hours outlined in the facility’s Program Statement. Three staff corroborated that more training is necessary for them to feel as though they are prepared to meet the needs of the minors in care and reduce the numerous incidents at the facility, including multiple unauthorized absences, drug use inside the facility, and physical aggression between peers, which were reported to the Department. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 , 84065 Personnel Requirements (i)(3) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and LIC-9099D were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted84065 Appeal rights were provided.

The allegation is that staff are denying minors mental health treatment. All staff interviews indicated that services are requested for minors immediately during minor’s intake. All staff and Program Supervisors reported that sometimes there are issues that arise around county social workers who do not authorize or approve services timely, however, the services are never denied for any reason by the facility staff. Staff stated that minors sometimes refuse services. LPA reviewed records of the only three youth who were present at time of the inspection, who had been there for over 24 hours. All youth had names of their placement county social worker and the date that facility requested services and a CFT. All minors declined to be interviewed by LPA, however, during two visits to the facility, LPA observed at least one service provider arrive to work with a youth, and during one visit a staff was seen to be counseling a minor who was having trouble handling conflict. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the new location, as the facility has relocated since the complaint was opened. The purpose of the visit is to deliver findings for the complaint investigation. LPA Thorn spoke with Danielle Chan,Program Supervisor and Kaeley Vang, Engagement Social Worker. LPA Thorn conducted the complaint investigation. LPAs Tina Thorn and Connie Goldie opened the investigation with the facility on 09.03.24 and met with Esteban Baul, Engagement Social Worker, and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA Thorn interviewed three staff members and the Reporting Party. LPA Thorn reviewed records including Placement Roster, interviews conducted by LPA Goldie, Serious Incident Reports, 4 videos, and training logs for staff. Continued on 9099C

deficiencies.description: Personnel Requirements 84065 (i)Notwithstanding Sections 80065(f)(1) through (6), new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete ...(3)Training shall include, at a minimum, all of the following topics... This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review ,licensee did not ensure ten of eleven staff received training as identified as initial training within 90 days which poses/posed a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Administration will ensure the trainings are scheduled within two weeks and supervisors will ensure that staff will complete scheduled
trainings by POC due date. A copy of signed agenda will be provided to CCL by POC due date to bring the facility into compliance.

met_with: Ka Xiong, Engagement Social Worker and Danielle Chan, Program Supervisor
narrative: All staff interviewed reported that the policy is for the youth’s personal belongings to be packed up the day the youth left. The youth’s belongings were inventoried at the time of admission. Per the records, the youth did not add items to their inventory after the admission date. There were inconsistent statements in interviews regarding what items the youth was missing. Records indicate the youth either never agreed to inventory all their items or did not have them in their possession upon admission into the program, releasing liability from the facility. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the Madison facility on 01.10.25 for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Ka Xiong, Engagement Social Worker and Danielle Chan, Program Supervisor, on speaker by phone. LPA Thorn conducted the complaint investigation. LPA initiated the investigation with the facility on 10.21.24 and met with Sandra Gomez, Program Supervisor and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed three county social workers, the reporting party, one youth, and five staff. LPA reviewed records including prior complaint history, Serious Incident Reports, Inventory logs, admission agreement handbook, and staff training log. All staff and Program Supervisors reported that any items belonging to the youth would have been packed up on the day the youth was detained and that they had no knowledge of the youth having the items that are listed as missing. In one reported incident, one youth left the facility and not all their belongings were accounted for.

narrative:
On March 05, 2021, at 1:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza conducted a tele-visit pre-licensing inspection. LPA Mendoza met with Natasha Bourbonnais, Human Services Manager II, from the County of San Mateo, Human Services Agency Children and Family Services. Also present was Julia Barbosa, facility House Manager. The facility is requesting a capacity of 6, ages 6-17 years old, ambulatory only. The facility will operate as an Emergency-Temporary Shelter Care Facility (E-TSCF) under the current state of emergency related to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). LPA Mendoza toured the interior of the facility. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The census today is zero (0). LPA Mendoza observed the following during the inspection: The facility is a one story building. The facility's main entrance is locked, and visitors must be buzzed into the reception area to enter the building. There is a receptionist's window, and once the visitors are identified, they are buzzed into the facility's inner offices. Proceeding right, there are front offices for personnel and staff and file rooms and meeting areas. To the left, from the receptionist's window, there are restrooms, nurse's office/triage, therapist's offices. COVID-19 safety protocols/safety measures are posted throughout the facility. The facility consists of 6 single bedrooms, three bathrooms, and two shower rooms. The five bedrooms, two bathrooms, and two shower rooms are all located in on long hall. The third bathroom is located in the living room area. The six-bedroom is located right behind the living room area. All bedrooms are fully furnished and are equipped with twin beds. All bathrooms were checked and were in operating conditions.

The bathrooms are fully stocked and have all required COVID-19 hand washing signs posted in them. The administrator's office is in the living area and provides a line of sight supervision of those in that area. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Medicines, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions will be made inaccessible to children in care. Children have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows which are all in good repair. The outdoor activity space is free of obstructions. There are no weapons in the facility. Sharp knives are stored in a locked cabinet and inaccessible to children. There will be adequate supervision will be provided for children in care. Staff will ensure three nutritious meals and snacks. Food supply will be ample in the home. Children will be accorded personal rights. All Licensing posting requirements were met. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable and meet statutory requirements. The home will operate within the capacity and limitations of the license. An exit interview was conducted, and LPA Mendoza will email the report to Natasha and Julia. The facility agrees to sign the report and will send it back to LPA Mendoza.

facility_name: SAN MATEO COUNTY RECEIVING HOME TSCF
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia scheduled a Technical Assistance (TA) meeting at the request of the applicant, San Mateo County. Attendees to the meeting were: Nelson Martinez, Isabel Diego, Monica Pavia, Marjana Jackson, Alicia Bernstein, Gina Jones, Shamika Payne, Hong Luu, John Fong, Natasha Bourbonnais, Aimee Salazar-Nunez, and Samantha Johnston. facility_name: SAN MATEO COUNTY RECEIVING HOME TSCF
narrative: On March 11, 2024, at 8:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted a pre-licensing inspection. San Mateo County Receiving Home submitted an application for a Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) license for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 6 - 17. This inspection was conducted with Administrator, Aimee Salazar-Nunez, and included observation of the following: The facility is a one story building, which includes several dayrooms and offices and open spaces for play/activities; the facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; chemicals are stored and locked; locked and centrally stored medication cabinet observed; observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; individual beds were observed with clean linens; additional bedding and linens observed; dayrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings; food storage space observed; nonperishable foods observed; perishable foods observed; dining area/kitchen equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients; additional space was observe for meals; hot water measured at 111 degrees; all smoke detectors were tested by a fire inspector and appear to be in proper working order; carbon monoxide detector observed; fire extinguishers are properly charged; facility maintains a current fire certificate; appropriate forms are posted in view of facility clients; facility does not have any open bodies of water; and, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA during inspection: 84661 - Reporting Requirements. The county child welfare agency shall prepare and submit to the Department a written report no later than 24 hours after the child’s placement reaches the 10-day limit, in addition to all requirements in this section. This application is ready for licensure. LPA Pavia will license the TSCF as of today, 3/11/24. License will be emailed in the next 24-48 hours.

facility_name: SAN MATEO COUNTY RECEIVING HOME TSCF
narrative: On 6/14/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Administrator Aimee Salazar and informed of the purpose of the visit. There were no children currently in care. LPA reviewed one child record and observed it to be complete. 5 staff files were observed to be complete. LPA discussed facility operations with Administrator, who stated staff working at the agency's short-term residential therapeutic program also work here at the temporary shelter care facility. LPA also discussed the quarterly overstay logs, and Administrator confirmed the next report will be sent to LPA at the end of this quarter. LPA toured the facility site and observed the facility to be maintained in safe condition, furniture was observed to be in good condition, dangerous items such as chemicals, medications, or sharp objects were observed to be stored where only accessible to staff, and the bathrooms and kitchen were clean and sanitary. No deficiencies were observed during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator.

facility_name: SAN MATEO COUNTY RECEIVING HOME TSCF
narrative: On 3/25/25 at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins arrived to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Aimee Salazar and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA toured the physical plant and observed the facility to be clean, kitchen and bathrooms to be maintained in sanitary condition, and storage areas well-stocked with food, linens, and activity/craft supplies. Chemicals, medications, and sharps were locked and inaccessible to clients. Hot water measured within the permitted range. The first aid kit was complete. All bedrooms had individual beds and clean linens. LPA inspected one client file, five staff files, and documentation of emergency drills. LPA observed all files to be complete. All staff have a background clearance and eligibility to work at this site. All staff have valid first aid and crisis intervention certifications and have received training relevant to the served population. The facility is conducting regular emergency drills. LPA interviewed two staff. Interviews reflected staff are well trained on facility policies and procedures and client rights. No deficiencies were observed during this inspection, and no citations were issued. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Administrator.

met_with: Heather Wolfe, Lead Direct Care Staff
narrative: On November 7, 2023, at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), JoAunne Griffin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management – Incident. On November 6, 2023, the Department received an Emergency Response Referral Information, dated November 5, 2023. Emergency Response Referral Information indicates that C#1 was hospitalized on November 2, 2023, after being found unresponsive. C#1 passed away on November 5, 2023. During the investigation process, LPA interviewed related parties and reviewed Incident Reports. Statements indicated that C#1 went on an unauthorized absence on October 16, 2023, and bed was closed on October 18, 2023. Information obtained indicated that although an Incident Report was completed by facility staff, it was not forwarded to Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) for review. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards TSCF, Section 84661 (e)(1) Reporting Requirements. Facility did not report unauthorized absence of C#1. An exit interview was conducted. A copy was left at the facility with the Heather Wolfe, Lead Direct Care Staff

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements                           (e)The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE or alternative documentation containing all the information required in LIC 624-LE, regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child residing in the facility. (1) The licensee shall make an initial report to the Department no later than the next business day following each incident.  This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Facility staff did not report C#1 unauthorized absence.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: On 11/07/2023, Plan of Correction was discussed. Training will be provided to all staff pertaining to Incident Report reporting requirements. Copy of training and sign-in sheet will be submitted to LPA via email no later than 12/05/2023.

Confidential statements obtained from Y1, Y2, staff members and other related parties in addition to review of corresponding incident, medical and Police reports indicate a lack of evidence to support allegation that Staff did not prevent youth in care from using felony drugs in the facility. Statements obtained indicate denial of staff having knowledge or was aware C1 possessed Fentanyl when C1 entered the restroom. Facility staff responded appropriately and submitted an incident report to required parties upon discovery. Based on confidential statements and documentary evidence, the allegation is determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies per California Code of Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report was provided to Facility Representative.
investigation_findings: 13On January 17, 2024, at 3:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin met with Janet Jackson,Facility Manager to discuss the investigative outcome. On July 21, 2023, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received a complaint referral alleging neglect as a youth resident reportedly overdosed on fentanyl while at the facility. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigations Branch, Investigator Olivia Spindola. On July 27, 2023, Special Investigator Assistant, Rocio Flores completed the initial complaint notification at the facility and informed of the investigation. The investigation revealed on July 21, 2023, while at the facility, Client #1 (C1) went in the facility’s restroom and after several minutes, Staff #1 (S1) entered the restroom when C1 did not answer the restroom’s door (see LIC 811, dated 1/17/2024). Staff members (S1 and S2) found C1 unconscious on the restroom’s floor. S1 and S2 administered Narcan and CPR to C1 and call 911. C1 was transported by ambulance to the Hospital Emergency room for medical care. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted a case management inspection March 6, 2024, at 10:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 16 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. In the inspection, 3 out of 15 Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 2 youth were interviewed (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated March 6, 2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from a meeting related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the youth case plans, support plan, emergency access & placement referral form (DCFS6017), and foster child’s needs and case plan summary (DCFS709), the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Rosas observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance with their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to House Manager, Janet Jackson.

investigation_findings: 13On February 17,2023 at 12:15 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation and to deliver the findings. During the investigation. LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information in reference to the allegations. The Licensee denied the allegations. Based on confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence, there is no evidence or witnesses to support that “Staff did not prevent minors from engaging in CSEC activity; Staff did not prevent minors from engaging in a physical altercation; Minor was bit by another minor in care; and that the staff did not seek medical attention for minor”. Documentary interviews were congruent that staff followed protocol, proper supervision and methods of crisis communication were implemented for their health and safety, to prevent the minors from engaging in CSEC activity. iTrack Special Incident Reports-(SIRs) were written and submitted within the proper time frame and authorized representatives were notified.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted a case management inspection April 16, 2024, at 10:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 17 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 1 youth files were reviewed. In the inspection, 3 out of 17 Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 1 youth were interviewed (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated April 16, 2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from a meeting related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the youth case plans, support plan, emergency access & placement referral form (DCFS6017), and foster child’s needs and case plan summary (DCFS709), the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Rosas observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance with their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to House Manager, Credell Jackson.

There are three (3) Bedrooms: Each bedroom is equipped with two (2) twin size beds, clean linen, blankets, adequate drawer space (six (6)) one (1) walk in closet, sliding windows and drapes; observed to be in good condition. The personal rights are posted on the back of each bedroom door. LIC 809 Page 2 of 3

Bedroom # 1, BR #2 and BR #3 currently the bedrooms are not occupied. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms inspected and found to be clean. LPA ensured that all toilets flushed, and tested water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Bathroom #1 is a full sized bathroom (sink, toilet shower and a tube) located in hallway. Bathroom #2 identified as staff bathroom; is a half bath with a sink toilet and a shower, located in the staff office. This is also a shower is not being utilized. The staff will accompany children local recreational activities. LPA observed that facility ensures that CDC Guidelines are implemented (i.e wash hands with alcohol based hand sanitizer, display colorful preventative hygiene posters, disinfect commonly used areas and items (remote controls, mouse’s, playing, cards cell phones, practice “cough etiquette”. The facility will operate within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. The facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will ensure to report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to children. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others; and the Licensee will ensure to report client injuries requiring medical treatment. LPA reviewed the following during the inspection: Staff Records Review LPA reviewed four (4) staff records. Staff Interviews: LPA conducted a confidential interview with four (4) on duty staff. Clients Records Review: Currently there are no clients in placement. Client Interviews: Currently there were no clients in placement to interview. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that staff ratio present for the six (6) clients in placement. LPA confirmed that all staff have required criminal record clearance. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response; which meet qualification. LPA observed staff Annual Training that include the training transcripts for all staff and the First-Aid and CPR training were up to date. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA concluded the Annual/Required Inspection on this day 12/17/2024. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be provided via email to the facility House Manager Credell Jackson. LIC-809-C/ Page 3 of 3

facility_name: VALLEY OF THE MOON CHILDREN'S HOME
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez contacted, Valley of the Moon Children’s Home via telephone (in accordance with PIN 20-05-CRP) and spoke with Program Manager, Sky Gray. The purpose of the call was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. The Department has investigated the complaint alleging lack of supervision resulted in temporary shelter facility child displaying inappropriate behavior toward another temporary shelter facility child. During the investigation, LPA interviewed four clients and five staff. One client stated they recalled seeing two clients inappropriately touching each other outside but could not provide a timeline or the client’s identities. The alleged victim recanted his statement when speaking to this LPA; however, did make the allegation to his current caregiver. Due to the conflicting information revealed in the interview process, the agency has deemed the allegation to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Program Manager for a signature.

facility_name: VALLEY OF THE MOON CHILDREN'S HOME
narrative: Commencing on the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett conducted an Annual/Required inspection and met with Program Manager Sky Gray. The facility was toured, inside and out. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are no bodies of water on the property. There are no guns or weapons present. LPA Hiett reviewed 4 staff records and 8 client records all of which were compliant with relevant regulations. The facility has both an East and a West wing. Each wing has four Halls radiating from a central milieu area. Each hall contains four bedrooms, two bathrooms, and a utility or games room. All halls, and both buildings, are built to the same floor plan. The water temperature for all buildings is preset with a maximum of 110 degrees. There are outside play yards with climbing frames and play structures with wood chip flooring. There were no hazards. Administration and admissions offices are housed in a separate building on the same campus. Between the wings is a central area, containing a kitchen and dining area. The facility has a commercially licensed kitchen, which is staffed with a chef and residential service workers. Cleaning is done by residential services workers on a 7-day basis; disinfectants and cleaning solutions are stored in the back of the kitchen area and are transported by service workers by cart as needed. The facility stores all medications centrally at the nurse's office. Medications are distributed to residents from there. A first aid kit is in each hall and the medical office has first aid kits for use when youth are off facility. The lockers are padlocked, both staff and resident know the combination. All required postings are present. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were in all areas. LPA Hiett reviewed the facility's pre-intake procedures, intake procedures, discharge procedures, reporting requirements regarding the 10-day placement limit, daily reporting requirements and AB 388. No Title 22 deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility.

facility_name: VALLEY OF THE MOON CHILDREN'S HOME
narrative:
On 7/21/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett received an email from Program Manager Sky Gray requesting a conference call regarding a personnel issue. At 12:30PM, LPA Hiett spoke via telephone with Program Manager Gray and HR Manager Tony walls. During this call, Ms. Gray described inappropriate staff behavior involving C1 (see LIC811). Per Ms. Gray, on 7/10/2021, staff member S1 directed C1 (see LIC811) to the bathroom to clean himself after he defecated and soiled himself. Upon leaving the bathroom, C1 was naked from the waist down. Ms. Gray stated that S1 then went over to S2 and S3 and made degrading remarks about the size of C1's penis. Staff did not make any report to CCL or other appropriate agencies about the incident. Per Ms. Gray, S4 (see LIC811) came forward and spoke with supervisor S5 (see LIC811) and reported the incident to her. S5then reported the incident to Ms. Gray on 7/19/2021. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, regulation 87072(d)(10) "Personal Rights: To be accorded dignity in his/her personal relationships with staff and other persons." Based on records reviewed and interviews conducted on 7/21/2021, S1 was found to have made inappropriate comments that compromised the dignity of C1. In addition, the facility was cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, regulation 80061: "Reporting Requirements: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. (E) Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. " {continued on LIC812-C}

Based on record reviews conducted on 7/21/2021, LPA Hiett determined that no incident report had been submitted to CCL and that notification of the event was not made within the required 24 hour time frame. Interviews with staff indicated that none was familiar with California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, regulation 87072 (Personal Rights) and that no training on this topic had occurred. Interviews further revealed that staff were not familiar with Incident Report guidelines and were unaware that an incident of this type needed to be reported as outlined in in regulations. An exit interview conducted and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli made an announced visit to the facility and met with Administrator Sky Gray and Program Manager Easter-Dawson. facility_name: VALLEY OF THE MOON CHILDREN'S HOME
narrative: LPA Hood reviewed the program statement for the facility. The program statement requires that staff have sight of the youth every thirty minutes while they are in their rooms for safety reasons. Based on confidential interviews, exceptions have been made when warranted. Based on five of the six interviews, youth had received medical attention consistently within the facility. Based on record review and interview, there is a medical professional on site. LPA was not able to interview the youth that was involved in this allegation. Based on IB investigation, record review, and confidential interviews, the following allegations are found unsubstantiated: minor in care used an illegal substance due to lack of staff supervision, staff are not adequately supervising minors in care, staff do not provide trauma informed services to minors in care, and staff did not seek medical attention for minor in a timely manner. LPA Hood conducted an exit interview with Sky Gray, Director, at 1:11PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/1/2023 at 1:02PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. Investigation Branch (IB) Investigator Jorge Martinez completed the 10-Day visit to the facility on 3/24/2023. Based on thirteen confidential interviews and record review, IB found the allegation that "minor in care used an illegal substance due to lack of staff supervision" to be unsubstantiated. During the course of the investigation, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted six confidential interviews. LPA Hood reviewed pertinent incident reports, staff schedule, program statement, pertinent client files, and the IB report. LPA Hood reviewed the staff schedule, based on record review the staffing was consistently within ratio. Based on five of the six interviews there were not concerns with staffing supervision.

facility_name: VALLEY OF THE MOON CHILDREN'S HOME
narrative:
On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conducted an Annual/Random inspection and met with Program Manager Sky Gray. The facility was toured inside and out. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are no bodies of water on the property. LPA Bertoli reviewed 3 client records, all of which were compliant with relevant regulations. Staff records were reviewed separately at the HR office. The complex has both an East and a West wing. The East wing houses their STRTP, which does not have any residents at this time (anticipated date 2024), and the TSCF facility is in the West wing. The TSCF wing has four halls radiating from a central milieu area. Each hall contains four bedrooms, two bathrooms, and a utility or game room. All halls are built to the same floor plan. The water temperature was tested at 115 degrees. There are outside play yards with climbing frames and play structures with wood chip surface. There were no hazards. Administration and admissions offices are housed in a separate building on the same campus. Between the wings is a central area containing a kitchen and dining area. The facility has a commercially licensed kitchen, which is staffed with a chef and residential service workers. Cleaning is done by residential services workers on a 7-day basis; disinfectants and cleaning solutions are stored separately in the back of the kitchen area and are transported by service workers by cart as needed. (cont on LIC 809-C)

Since the kitchen/dining area connect to both wings/facilities, access is controlled electronically by computer and by card keys that staff have with them. Clients from each facility will have different meal times and clients will not be allowed to commingle with clients from the other facility. The facility stores all medications centrally at the nurse's office and the Medication Room, which is in an office connected to the dining hall. Medications are distributed to residents from there. A first aid kit is in each hall and the medical office has first aid kits for use when youth are off facility. The lockers are padlocked, both staff and resident know the combination. All required postings are present. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were in all areas. LPA Bertoli reviewed the facility's intake procedures, discharge procedures, reporting requirements regarding the 10-day placement limit, daily reporting requirements and AB 388. No Title 22 deficiencies cited at this time. An Advisory Note was issued as 4 staff had been previously been associated to the facility, but all 4 were separated as of 1/1/2019. This appears to be an error created by Guardian. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility.

On September 14, 2020 at 2:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection via Facetime at above location for the purpose of conducting a follow up investigation. LPA spoke to the Administrator, Theresa Foster to further discuss Special Incident Report #718055 regarding a possible Neglect/Lack of Supervision Violation. The Incident Report was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on September 7, 2020. The incident occurred on 09/06/2020. While on Wayfinder TSCF property, Client #1 purchased drugs from an unknown man standing at the bus stop located behind the facility. The transaction occurred through the gate of the facility. After the transaction, Client #1 proceeded to pass the drugs out to four (4) other clients at the facility, at which time the drugs were consumed by all five clients. Four (4) clients were seen by the facility nurse, one (1) client refused to be seen by the nurse, and the Mental Health Clinician spoke with all five (5) clients regarding the dangers of taking drugs. During this visit LPA spoke to staff and obtained statements. LPA was also informed that Client #1 is no longer placed at the TSCF. Based on the information obtained there is insufficient information to determine that a Neglect/Lack of Supervision Violation occurred at this time. Further information is needed and additional interviews will be conducted. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was sent to the facility. Visit was conducted via Facetime due to COVID-19 Public Health Emergency.

investigation_findings: 13On April 7, 2021, Regina Martin, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) spoke with Kristal Audoma Facility Director/Administrator for the purpose of delivering complaint findings. The above-mentioned allegation was investigated by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Christine Ferris. On July 15, 2020, CCLD received a complaint referral alleging facility staff sexually abused youth. Information obtained during the investigation including interviews and review of related reports from Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department and Los Angeles Police Department did not provide enough evidence to support allegation. Staff #1 denied that he engaged in an inappropriate sexual relationship with Child #1. Child #1 provided inconsistent statements during the investigation. Interview statements obtained denied any knowledge of an inappropriate sexual relationship between Staff #1 and Child #1. There was no evidence presented to suggest that Child #1 was at Staff #1 home. It has been determined that the allegation is

narrative: Specific location of the alleged sexual acts was not provided. C2 and C3 both deny having sex with either staff. The investigation confirmed the facility has surveillance cameras that are monitored 24/7 by the facility security team. Security also patrols the property and conducts perimeter checks, and there have been no reports of anyone witnessing any staff having sexual relations or acting inappropriately with any residents. Based on inconsistent information, no witnesses to the allege offence, and no corroborating evidence, the allegation is deemed Unsubstantiated at this time, meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On April 7, 2021, Regina Martin, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) spoke with Kristal Audoma Facility Director/Administrator for the purpose of delivering complaint findings. The above-mentioned allegation was investigated by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Christine Ferris. On August 14, 2020, CCLD received a complaint referral alleging Staff is having sex with minors. Information obtained during the investigation including but not limited to, interviews with related parties Child #1 (C1), Child #2 (C2), Child #3 (C3) and staff members did not offer enough evidence to support alleged claims. It was reported the alleged sexual acts were not witnessed by C1 but rather C1 was told by C2 and C3 that each had sex with a staff member (identified by first name only) “outside”. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative: Interview statements indicated that Child #1 made inappropriate sexual comments about Staff #1, but there were no comments recalled made by Child #1 regarding any sexual acts with Staff #1. There was no evidence presented to suggest that Staff #1 and Child #1 engaged in an inappropriate sexual relationship. narrative:
On July 22, 2021 at 12: 20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an announced visit at Wayfinder TSCF for the purpose of a Case Management-Licensee Initiated Inspection to increase the capacity. LPA met with the Chief Program Officer, Veronica Arteaga, TSCF Director, Kristal Audoma, Associate VP of Residential Clinical Services, Ani Sargsyan, and the Director of Mental Health, Kaela Stambor and was granted access to the facility. The facility is currently licensed to provide care for 26 children, ages 0-17 years old, ten (10) children may be infants ages 0-2 years, six (6) may be non-ambulatory. The facility is requesting to increase the total capacity to 38 to provide care for 26 children, ages 0-17 years old, seven (7) infants ages 0-2 years, as well as 12 Non-Minor Dependents ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). The current census is 16. A tour of the STRTP and TSCF buildings began at 12:40 PM and LPA observed the following: STRTP Building: Is a two-story building which has a small kitchen, an open living/dining room, a laundry room, a staff lounge, 2 staff offices, a nurse’s center, a therapy room, a recreation/activity room, and a computer room. This building will house clients ages 0-17 and it is currently not occupied. The first floor will be utilized for children ages 0-12. This floor has 2 infant bedrooms equipped with 3 cribs each, 1 mom and baby bedroom equipped with a twin bed and a crib, 2 toddler bedrooms equipped with 2 toddler beds including rails in each room, and 4 bedrooms are designated for young children, 3 room are double occupancy and equipped with 2 twin beds and 1 room is single occupancy and equipped with one twin bed. All bedrooms have adequate closet space and lighting. There are bathrooms located inside of each of the bedrooms and 6 additional bathrooms located throughout the building. The second floor will be utilized for children ages 13-17. This floor has 9 bedrooms, 9 bathrooms and a room that is for storage. There was adequate drawer and closet space. 1 DCFS Co-locator staff office. LPA observed this building to be equipped with badge readers on the elevator doors and stairwell doors that open between floors. All exit doors open freely. Report continued on LIC809C

TSCF Building: Is a two-story building which has a kitchen area, an open living/dining room, 2 staff offices, 1 DCFS Co-locator staff office, a laundry room and a storage room. This building will be used to house the requested 12 Non-Minor Dependents ages 18-21 and it is currently occupied by clients ages 0-17. The first floor has 6 bedrooms and the second floor has 5 bedrooms, all bedrooms have attached bathrooms, adequate closet space, and windows that open freely. There are 3 additional bathrooms located throughout the building. There are no weapons in the facility. The swimming pool area is locked and meets licensing requirements. All prescribed medications are centrally stored in locked in cabinets or in a locked refrigerator located in the Nursing Center and medications are only accessible to employees supervising stored medications. Cleaning supplies are kept locked and made inaccessible to clients. The facility is equipped with a fire alarm system, smoke alarms, and carbon monoxide detectors. All fire extinguishers are charged. There facility has working telephones for client's personal use. All exits are free and clear from hazards. The following documents were previously submitted: a new LIC 200, a new Facility Sketch (LIC 999), a LIC610 C (Emergency Disaster Plan), and a Board Resolution approving the capacity increase. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with the Chief Program Officer.

narrative:
On January 31, 2023 at 8:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an unannounced visit at Wayfinder TSCF for the purpose of a 2 Year Required Visit. LPA met with Administrator, Veta Talton and was granted access to the facility. The facility is currently licensed to provide care Temporary Shelter Care Services up to ten (10) days for 26 children, male and female ages 0-17 years old, seven (7) children may be infants ages 0-2 years, ambulatory only. The facility also licensed to provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W & I code 16501.1(C)(1). The current census is 4. LPA observed the following: The facility is a two story building located in a residential area. Each floor contains a small kitchen, an open living/dining room, a laundry room, and 2 staffing offices. The first floor has two (2) infant bedrooms each equipped with 3 cribs; one (1) mom and baby bedroom equipped with a twin bed and a crib; three (3) double occupancy bedrooms each equipped with two twin beds; one (1) single occupancy bedroom equipped with one twin bed; a CSPS/Case Manager office; and a staff’s lounge. The second floor has six (6) bedrooms each equipped with two twin beds; a recreation/activity room; a computer room; a therapist office; a DCFS co-locator office; and a storage room. All bedrooms have adequate closet space and lighting. There are bathrooms located inside of each of the bedrooms and 6 additional bathrooms located throughout the building. LPA observed the building to be equipped with badge readers for the elevator and stairwell doors that open between floors. Additionally, the facility has a nursing center, a gym, an a locked/gated swimming pool, which meets licensing requirements, on the premises. Report continued on LIC 809C

LPA conducted a physical plant inspection and found the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA observed the facility’s main kitchen to contain one week supply of non-perishable foods and two days supply of perishable foods, including nutritious snacks. All prescribed medications are locked and centrally stored in the Nursing Center and made accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. The first was checked and found to be complete. The hot water temperature is within 105 -120 degree Fahrenheit. The facility is equipped with a hardwired fire alarm system, and there are combination smoke alarm/carbon monoxide detectors in each room, all of which were operational at the time of this inspection. All fire extinguishers are charged. All trash cans have tight-fitting lids. All exits are free of hazards and all doors open freely. Cleaning supplies are kept locked and made inaccessible to clients. There are no weapons in the facility. LPA observed the facility to have adequate linen supply and hygiene products. There was ample seating in the living/dining room area. The facility has an operable telephone on the premises. Meals are prepared in the main kitchen during the week and prepared on the premises during the weekends. Activities available include toddler toys, reading books, games, etc. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements and Emergency Plan were met. The Program has a total of (seventeen) staff and personnel files are located in the administration building. LPA will return on a later date to review staff records. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative:
On January 4, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at Wayfinder TSCF for the purpose of a Case Management-Licensee Initiated Inspection to decrease the capacity. LPA met with the Administrator, Veta Talton and was granted access to the facility. The facility is currently licensed to provide care for 38 clients, ages 0-17 years old, seven (7) children may be infants ages 0-2 years, ambulatory only, as well as 12 Non-Minor Dependents ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). This facility is requesting to decrease the total capacity to 20 to provide care for 20 children, ages 0-17 years old, five (5) children may be infants ages 0-2 years, ambulatory only. The current census is four (4). During the tour of the TSCF building LPA observed the following: TSCF Building: Is a two-story building located in a residential neighborhood. The first-floor houses clients ages 0-12 and contains the following: a small kitchen in the middle of the room, an open living/dining room area, a staff lounge, the Facility Manager’s office, the Assistant Director’s office, a CSPS/Campus Security office, therapy room, a laundry room, nine (9) bedrooms, and multiple bathrooms. Bedrooms #1 is an infant bedroom equipped with three (3) cribs, three (3) portable play yards, and one (1) changing table. Bedroom #2 is an infant bedroom equipped with two (2) cribs, two (2) baby swings, and one (1) changing table. Bedroom # 3 is a mom and baby room equipped with two (2) cribs, one (1) twin bed, and 1 changing table. Bedrooms # 4 through #8 are double occupancy rooms and each room has two (2) twin beds. Bedroom #9 is a single occupancy room and has one (1) twin bed. All bedrooms contain a bathroom, have adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 2)

The second-floor houses clients 13-17 and contains the following: a small kitchen in the middle of the room, an open living/dining room area, the Administrator’s office, the Assistant Administrator’s office, the Program Assistance Office, the Mental Health Teams office, the DCFS co-locator’s office, a therapy room, an activity storage room, a laundry room, a game room, six (6) bedrooms, and multiple bathrooms. Bedrooms #10 through #16 are double occupancy rooms and each room has two (2) twin beds. All bedrooms contain a bathroom, have adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting. LPA observed this building to be equipped with badge readers on the elevator doors and stairwell doors that open between floors. All exit doors open freely. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarm were tested and were in working condition. Additionally, the facility has a nursing center, a gym, an a locked/gated swimming pool on the premises, which meets licensing requirements. Licensee previously provided the following documents: a new LIC 200, $25.00 capacity decrease fee, corporate resolution, emergency evacuation plan. Based on observations from today’s inspection the following is required before the capacity can be decreased. A total of 2 cribs will need to be taken down and removed. A total of 9 twin beds will need to be taken down and removed. A new facility sketch will need to be submitted. A Fire Clearance. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left at the facility. (Page 2 of 2).

narrative:
On February 13, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at Wayfinder TSCF for the purpose of a Case Management-Licensee Initiated Inspection to decrease the capacity. LPA met with the Administrator, Veta Talton and was granted access to the facility. The facility is currently licensed to provide care for 38 clients. This facility is requesting to decrease the total capacity to provide care for 20 children, ages 0-17 years old, five (5) children may be infants ages 0-2 years, ambulatory only. The current census is two (2). During the tour of the TSCF building LPA observed the following: TSCF Building: Is a two-story building located in a residential neighborhood. The first-floor houses clients ages 0-12 and contains the following: a small kitchen in the middle of the room, an open living/dining room area, a staff lounge, the Facility Manager’s office, the Assistant Director’s office, a CSPS/Campus Security office, therapy room, a laundry room, nine (9) bedrooms, and multiple bathrooms. Bedrooms #1 is an infant bedroom equipped with two (2) cribs, two (2) portable play yards, and one (1) changing table. Bedroom #2 is an infant bedroom equipped with two (2) cribs, two (2) baby swings, and one (1) changing table. Bedroom # 3 is a mom and baby room equipped with one (1) crib, one (1) twin bed, and 1 changing table. Bedrooms # 4 through #6 are double occupancy rooms and each room has two (2) twin beds. Bedrooms #7 and #8 are single occupancy rooms and each room has one (1) twin bed. All bedrooms contain a bathroom, have adequate drawers, closet space, lighting, and windows. Room #9 will be used as a playroom and LPA observed the room to have a flat screen television mounted to the all. There was no furniture in the room. Report continued on LIC 809C

The second-floor houses clients 13-17 and contains the following: a small kitchen in the middle of the room, an open living/dining room area, the Administrator’s office, the Assistant Administrator’s office, the Program Assistance Office, the Mental Health Teams office, the DCFS co-locator’s office, a therapy room, an activity storage room, a laundry room, a game room, six (6) bedrooms, and multiple bathrooms. Bedrooms #10 and #11 are single occupancy rooms and each has one (1) twin bed. Bedrooms #13 and #14 are double occupancy rooms and each room has two (2) twin beds. All bedrooms contain a bathroom, have adequate drawers, closet space, lighting, and windows. Room #12 will be used for storage. LPA observed the room to have one (1) desk and one (1) chair. Room #15 will be used for storage. LPA observed the room to contain stacked mattresses, extra desks, chairs, and a broken-down crib. Room #16 will be used as an activity room. LPA observed the room to have shelves stacked with games and toys. LPA observed the building to be equipped with badge readers on the elevator doors and the stairwell doors that open between floors. Al exit doors open freely. There are no weapons in the facility. Additionally, the facility has a gym on the premises and a swimming pool area which remains locked and meets licensing requirements. There is a Nursing Center, all prescribed medications are centrally stored in locked cabinets or in a locked refrigerator located in the Nursing Center. All medications are only accessible to employees supervising stored medications. Cleaning supplies are kept locked and made inaccessible to clients. The facility is equipped with a fire alarm system, smoke alarms, and carbon monoxide detectors. All fire extinguishers are charged. There facility has working telephones for client's personal use. All exits are free and clear from hazards. Licensee previously provided the following documents: a new LIC 200, $25.00 capacity decrease fee, corporate resolution, emergency evacuation plan. Based on observations from today’s inspection the following is required before the capacity can be decreased. A Fire Clearance. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left with the Facility Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On December 28, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Wayfinder Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) for the purpose of delivering findings for the above allegations. LPA met with Administrator, Veta Talton. During this investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews, gathered documentation, reviewed records and reports. Based on information obtained and due to inconsistent statements, there was insufficient corroborating evidence to support the allegations: staff drinking alcohol while caring the supervising minors in care; staff transported minors while under the influence of alcohol; facility staff members made inappropriate comments to minor; facility staff member inappropriately touched minor. Therefore, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On April 15, 2025, at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation. Prior to entering the facility LPA Gray conducted a health and safety risk assessment. During the investigation, LPA Gray interviewed all available relevant parties and gathered pertinent information in reference to the allegations. The Licensee denied the allegation. Based on confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence, there is no evidence or witnesses to support allegations. Statements indicated that C1 plan indicated that additional food should be provided and to call for medical assistance as needed. Statements indicated that during incident C1 expressed that they were not feeling well. C1 was provided apple juice and apple sauce, and staff called for medical assistance. Statements indicated that foods were purchased for C1’s condition and made accessible for consumption when needed. Statements indicated that C1 was not denied access to food at time of incident. Statements indicated that children in care are provided breakfast, lunch, dinner, snacks, and can ask for additional food.

narrative: Due to the evidence obtained during the investigation, LPA determined that the allegation is substantiated; means that based on the preponderance of the evidence meaning that it is more likely than not, the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision are substantiated. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision 80078 (a). Staff did not provide care and supervision that met the needs of clients in care. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and Appeal Rights were left with the Administrator, Veta Talton.
investigation_findings: 13On April 14, 2025, at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the complaint investigation. Prior to entering the facility LPA Gray conducted a health and safety risk assessment. During the investigation, LPA Gray interviewed all available parties and reviewed documentary evidence. Statements and review of documentary evidence were consistent. Confidential statements and an internal investigation indicated that staff refused to provide care services to minors. Statements indicated that clients arrived at the facility with medical issues that required medical attention and with instruction on how to treat their medical issues. Documentary evidence indicated that staff were issued final written warnings that outlined their role expectations and that their refusal to provide care and supervision to clients was unacceptable and they were instructed to adhere to the corrective actions. Documentary evidence indicated that staff are no longer employed due to resigning from positions.

deficiencies.description:
(a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Statements and documentary evidence indicated that due to client’s medical condition, staff refused to provide care and supervision. This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of Correction (POC) was discussed. Prior to the investigation the facility conducted an internal investigation, followed reporting protocol, and provided evidence that S2, S3, and S4 received disciplinary actions and corrective measures were applied. The Licensee provided documented evidence that S2, S3 and S4 resigned and are  no longer employed, neither is associated with any of the agency’s facilities.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA interviewed the program director, the housing director , the nurses assigned to the client and the youth counselors assigned to child . LPA attempted on three occasions to reach the client's social worker but was unsuccessful. LPA also reviewed the email chain between Wayfinders and the Department of Children & Family services. Wayfinder staff repeatedly requested assistance from DCFS because they were not properly trained to feed Client #1 or maintain her feeding tube. The emails also indicated that the client had insufficient feeding supplies with her when she arrived on site. LPA reviewed the daily observation log for Client #1 and noted that although she was in the facility for three days, she was only given one shower and on the first day she was not fed from 3:05 AM until 1:00 PM while staff waited on authorization from nursing. The shift notes indicate that insufficient feeding supplies hampered efforts to feed C1 properly and on the day of discharge she was not fed due to a missing g-tube connection. Based on the information that was obtained, the allegations are resolved as "substantiated" meaning that the preponderance of evidence standard has been met.

deficiencies.description:
Care for Clients Who Rely Upon Others to Perform All Activities of Daily Living		  
Prior to accepting a client into care, the licensee shall complete the following: A method for determining the client's needs. The liceensee failed to meet this requirement by accepting a child that they were not equipped to care for
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a self directed plan of correction as to how they will prevent future occurences of this nature,

narrative: On July 25, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), C, White made an unannounced visit to Wayfinder Family Services - TSCF for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Inspection, as the Department was made aware an unapproved Director/Administrator Change. LPA met with Staff, Steven Frausto. During today’s inspection, LPA was informed the previous Director/Administrator (Veta Talton) is no longer overseeing the program. Staff member, Steven Frausto stated he was promoted to the new Director/Administrator of the TSCF effective 06/01/2025. LPA spoke with the Vice President, Clinical and Housing Services stated the previous Director/Administrator (Veta Talton) is being used as a backup administrator at this time and that Staff member, (Steven Frausto) is in the process of obtaining the required Group Home Administrator Certificate. Additionally, LPA confirmed with Staff member, (Steven Frausto) that he does not currently hold a Group Home Administrator Certificate. LPA informed Staff member, Steven Frausto, that the facility is being cited for failure to have a certified administrator employed. The following deficiency is being cited for violating California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6 Regulation 84064(b) Administrator Qualification and Duties. (see page 809 D) Exit interview completed, appeal rights issued, and a copy of this report was emailed to Staff member, Steven Frausto.

LPA Goldie toured THPP with Office Manager, Yuen Chiang, Compliance/ IT Director, Erin Zamora and Compliance Supervisor , Marie Alvarado and observed the following: The THPP has a waiting area, fire exit plan, fire extinguisher, smoke detectors, and personal rights posters upon entry. There are two private offices for the THPP staff. Within the suite there is a conference/training room which is used as a meeting room for THPP/THP+FC staff . Additionally LPA observed four sound proof "hotel rooms" utilized for participant interviews, a work suite and a mini conference room and 3 visitation rooms for THP+ FC clients. One of the visitation rooms caters to participants with an infant. Staff files and participant files are all electronic for purpose of confidentiality. A kitchen is on site for staff. Care Tool was completed. The following domains were completed: physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness and staffing. Prior to today’s visit, the application for the relocation was received and reviewed by the Regional Office. LPA Goldie did not observe any deficiencies in regard to Physical Plant during today’s inspection. The agency is ready to be licensed for the Transitional Housing Program pending amended LIC200 to include THP+ FC and forms, LIC500, LIC401, LIC401A and LIC610. An exit interview was conducted at 2:45 PM with OM Chiang and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Eunice conducted a case management inspection to the above facility for the purpose of ensuring compliance with Interim Licensing Standards, Health and Safety Code and Title 22 regulations regarding the mandate that facilities have a current valid license before operating a Department of Social Services, Community Care Licensing Division facility. On January 31, 2023, an application and licensing fees were received for Aldea Foster Family Agency, Adoption Agency and Transitional Housing Placement Plan facilities. On February 1, 2023 the Department conducted relocation inspections for Aldea Foster Family Agency and the Aldea Adoption Agency. On February 14, 2023, the Department conducted a pre licensing inspection for Aldea Transitional Housing Placement Program. During that inspection, it was discovered that the 3 Aldea facilities were conducting business although the licensing procedures were not finalized for their relocation. Ultimately, the Department did license all three facilities on February 23, 2023. The civil penalty for operating unlicensed is $200.00 per day. In the spirit of collaboration with entities that care for the State’s vulnerable client population the Department will assess penalties for 2 days when in fact, all 3 Aldea community care facilities were operating unlicensed over one week. This occurred due to a set of circumstances/oversight by Department staff and the fact that the Aldea community care licensing agencies employed a new Program Administrator. The Program Administrator has complied with the Department's requests for required documentation and now knows the licensing requirements for facility relocations.

There is an additional mandate due to the Aldea facility moves. The Department is requiring the 3 Aldea community care licensed facilities to amend their Program Statements. Please ensure they reflect the new addresses for of each of the 3 new locations. Please provide the amended Program Statements by March 31, 2023. On March 8, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst Dawn Eunice delivered this LIC 809, LIC 809D, Appeal Rights, and LIC 421A civil penalty report.

narrative:

Physical Plant: LPA observed the necessary documentation, such as the Facility License, Personal Rights, and Grievance Policies. Cleaning/Disinfectants were secured. Smoke Detectors/Carbon Monoxide were tested and observed in working order. Fire Extinguishers were charged and in 3 locations in the facility. Multiple First Aid Kits were observed throughout the facility to be fully stocked. Fridge was below 45 degrees and Freezer was below 0. Hot water was tested at 110 degrees. Common areas were easily accessible with plenty of seating space for staff. Operations: Reviewed participant names and living units. The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: · Annual fees: $0.00 has a credit of $453.00 · Administrator Certificate for: Kimberly Catanzano · Facility Sketch, LIC 308, LIC 400 An exit interview was conducted with Supervisor of Resource Family Approval, Narda Oldfield, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
