Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual continuation inspection at the agency and met with Administrator Krystal Johnson who assisted with the inspection. LPA began the inspection but could not continue due to computer issues. LPA continued the annual elsewhere. LPA reviewed four staff files with HR staff Stephanie Gamboa (HR) over Microsoft Teams due to her working remotely as well as LPA. HR showed LPA all staff files and documents LPA requested. LPA found that all files were kept confidential and were organized. LPA found one staff to not have the required proof of education to meet requirements in their file, one staff is not associated to the agency as required, and staff have not received the one hour minimum abuse reporting-specific training as required, however, all staff reviewed did acknowledge their responsibility to report abuse. All other requirements were met. On today's date, the agency is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Sections 86019(e)(2) and 86065(f)(1), and Health and Safety Code Section 1565(a). An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as the signatures on this report.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual inspection at the agency and met with Karen Lustig, Social Worker Supervisor (SWS), and Krystal Johnson, Administrator who assisted with the inspection. LPA and SWS conducted a walk-through of the agency, which is located in a commercial building. LPA observed two conference rooms, four visitation rooms, two break rooms, one physical file room for old files, 28 offices, and three storage rooms. Staff and Client files are kept electronically, hallways and exits were clear, the agency was clean. There were four fire extinguishers which were two months past due for inspection. During this inspection the agency sent an email to the fire officials to correct this. The listed Administrator Shahrukh Chishty is no longer the Administrator, Krystal Johnson is. LPA instructed SWS and Administrator to have the agency send in to CCL the required proof of qualifications detailed in CCR Title 22 regulations section 86064(a) and LPA can change the named Administrator. LPA also learned that the agency plans to change locations around June or July of 2022. LPA advised the agency of the requirements that must be met and completed before the move takes place. LPA reviewed all 7 client files and found: one client did not have a Needs and Services Plan as required. The other six clients reviewed had Needs and Services Plans and all requirements were met for those. All clients but two were missing Health Assessment forms, TB tests, and any other medical information. Various reasons were given for this such as the client refused, the client didn't give paperwork to the agency, the appointment slots are backed up, and for one, there was no explanation. Additionally, there were no signed discharge and removal policies in any client file. The files were complete otherwise. On today's date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 86270(a)(2)(F). Advisory notes were also issued, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

On May 11, 2021, at 12:30 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza attempted to conduct an unannounced case management inspection. LPA Mendoza arrived at 3701 Lone Tree Way, Suite 7 Antioch, CA and Administrative office was closed. LPA Mendoza made several phones calls to Administrator, Patsy Phillips and CEO Wayne Phillips from 12:30 to 1:40 pm. No answer and both voicemail's were full. LPA Mendoza also text messaged both individuals and no response. LPA left copy of the report along with LPA Mendoza's business card. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on a death incident. The facility contacted Community Care Licensing (CCL) Desk Duty line on May 10, 2021, at 11:09 am. On Friday, May 7, 2021, at 6:02 pm, a participant (P1) (please refer to LIC 811, dated 05/11/21 for confidential names) left the THPP residence, (P1) left behind her two children. (P1) started walking toward Sunset Lane in Antioch. There was a report of gunfire in the neighborhood. Police responded. It was a drive-by shooting. The police found a female victim, and it was (P1). (P1) was pronounced deceased at the site of the shooting. Antioch Police Department notified the facility. The facility reported the incident to CCL via telephone on 05/10/21. Both children are currently with their grandmother. The above incident is currently under investigation by Antioch Police Department, case # 21-3661. CCL is currently in contact with the assigned Detective on this case. Also, is currently requesting the police report and coroners report. During inspection, LPA Mendoza requests the facility to submit an incident report (LIC 624-LE), P1's Needs and Service Plan/TILP, All staff phone numbers, LIC 500 (Staff Schedule) to LPA Mariah Hawkins no later than Friday, 5/14/21. PLEASE CONTINUE TO LIC 809-C...

At this time, further investigation is still needed. LPA Mariah Hawkins will follow-up with the Administrator on this visit.

met_with: Director Dr. Phillips, CEO Wayne Phillips
narrative:
On 5/13/21 at 11:40AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit at the licensee office to address deficiencies observed during an investigation of the transitional shelter placement program (THPP). LPA met with Director Dr. Phillips and CEO Wayne Phillips and informed of the purpose of the visit. COVID-19 safety precautions were taken at visit, including masks, disinfectant, hand hygiene, and social distancing. At visit, LPA was greeted by administrative staff upon entry and informed that Director was on the phone. Director greeted LPA at 11:53AM but did not come back out to meet with LPA until 12:03PM, at which point Director informed LPA that she and CEO would be traveling to their personal residence to search for files LPA requested that they were not able to locate in the office. LPA was escorted to the downstairs conference room to wait for their return. Director and CEO returned at 12:48PM. On 2/19/21, LPA initially requested that the following documentation/information be provided to LPA for the complaint investigation: Youth Roster with the names and dates of birth for youth R1 and R2 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) and R2's twins, R1 and R2's county workers' numbers, and entry dates; Staff Roster with the numbers for the case managers, clinicians, and overnight staff; Incident Reports (IRs) for R1's unauthorized absences; IRs for R1's hospitalization at Children's Hospital in Oakland; Meeting Notes from the recent CFT with R1's social worker. Some of the information requested, including youth's names and dates of birth, staff contact information, and social worker information, was requested to be submitted because Director was unable to provide this information during the visit. At that time, Director stated all would be submitted to LPA by the following day. LPA followed-up on 2/24/21. No response nor documentation had been received by 3/16/21, and LPA followed-up again on that day by phone and email. LPA follow-up again on 3/23/21 and left messages for both Director and CEO. On 3/26/21, Dr. Phillips faxed over the signed visit report from 2/19/21 and two copies of the same incident report for an incident on 2/20/21. On 4/6/21, LPA followed-up again to request the remaining documents be submitted. [CONTINUED ON LIC 809-C Page 2]

On 4/13/21, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Zaid Hakim sent an email to Director restating the need to submit the remaining documentation. On 4/27/21, the documentation had still not been received. LPA spoke to the Director and the licensee's administrative staff to request the remaining documents be submitted to LPA, and Director confirmed that everything would be sent over. On 4/30/21, Director requested that LPA resend LPA's previous emails requesting the documentation for Director to refer to and so Director could have a list of the requested items. LPA reminded Director that the requested items were listed on the report from 2/19/21 and also resent LPA's previous emails. As of today, 5/13/21, the remaining documents have still not been received. Director and CEO returned to the office to continue with visit with LPA at 12:48PM and had retrieved the client files from their personal residence. LPA reviewed the files at 1PM and observed the following to be missing: identification information, any medical records, medical consent forms. Resident R1's (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 5/13/21) file did not contain any paperwork documenting R1's date of birth or R1's needs and services plan or TILP. R2's file contained an application, progress notes, and staff visit check sheets, but there also was no needs and services or TILP. Both R1 and R2 were minors at placement. Additionally, the files were disorganized -- there were seven copies of only one incident report in R1's (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 5/13/21) file, and the reports for the other reportable incidents that Director informed LPA on 2/19/21 had occurred were not in the file; there was an incident report for R1 in R2's file -- and the files were not kept in the office. The other incidents involving R1 that Director had informed LPA on 2/19/21 had occurred included multiple unauthorized absences and a hospitalization at Children's Hospital in Oakland. Director and CEO were unable to provide details of these incidents as no reports were generated for any of the incidents other than the one from 2/20/21, and none had been submitted to the licensing agency within 7 days of the incident, nor was initial next working day notification made. Additionally, during an investigation at the THPP, it was learned that overnight staff S1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) did not have a key to the participant unit but did not contact the licensee about the issue. Instead, S1 suggested to R1 that R1 stay the night at S1's personal residence or travel to a friend's house. S1 did not offer to drive R1 to the youth's friend's house, and S1 did not know who the friend was nor confirm it was safe for R1 to stay the night with them.

On 5/13/21, LPA interviewed R2's social worker (SW) Lanz Bañes. R2 was recently killed in a shooting. Refer to LIC 809 Case Management, dated 5/11/21. SW informed LPA that no notice was made to him about the death until he was contacted by R2's family. The THPP did not provide notification to the authorized representative. The THPP is required to submit the written report by tomorrow (5/14/21). LPA will provide Director with the correct licensing form to use to document the incident. Lastly, during today's visit, LPA observed at 11:45AM that the facility license was not visibly posted in the office where visitors can view it. LPA was unable to locate the license. Director informed LPA that they have misplaced their copy of their license and need a new one. Based on the above, the following citations/advisories are being issued at today's visit. Refer to the attached advisory notes and LIC 809-D pages of this report. 1. Due to not furnishing most of the requested documentation and client, staff, or social worker information after multiple requests, a citation is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80044 Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency. Please also note that a similar deficiency was previously cited on 6/18/18. 2. Due to not giving notification of incidents nor submitting written incidents reports to the licensing agency of reportable incidents, including R1's multiple unauthorized absences and hospitalization, a citation is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86061 Reporting Requirements. 3. Due to incomplete client files that were missing medical records, needs and services and/or TILPs, identifying information, a citation is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86070 Participant Records. Please also note that a similar deficiency was previously cited on 08/14/19. 4. Due to not storing the client files in the office and instead at Director's personal residence, a technical violation advisory is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86070 Participant Records. 5. Due to staff S1 not ensuring R1 was safe to stay at an unidentified friend's house and not being able to accord the youth with safe home accommodations, a technical violation advisory is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86072 Personal Rights. 6. Due to not contacting the authorized representative of the death of a youth in care in a timely manner, a technical violation advisory is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86061 Reporting Requirements. 7. Due to not having the license prominently posted, a technical violation advisory is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86009 Availability of License.

An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Director Dr. Phillips, whose signature on this report confirms receipt.

met_with: Director Dr. Phillips; CEO Wayne Phillips
narrative: CCLD has recommended testing, particularly if there has been a known exposure, and has provided guidance on preventative measures, such as wearing masks. PIN 20-19-CRP (combined with ACL No. I-62-20), issued August 13, 2020, states on Page 3, "Foundationally, the residence of a child in care is not a public place, and should be treated as their home, with reasonable effort made to ensure that the experience the child has is as normal as possible. Children therefore are not required to wear face coverings while in their residences, whether that residence is a home-based setting or a congregate care facility." It would be reasonable that this expectation be the same for testing. A facility cannot deny a youth re-entry into their home unit. If the facility is informing the placement agency that they cannot meet the youth's needs due to their behaviors, the facility cannot discharge the youth immediately unless the youth is removed during emergency situations by authorized personnel. The facility must provide the placement agency notice of at least seven days or, following the local placement agency's policy, fourteen days. Based on observations and interviews, the facility required a social worker to pick up R1 from the hospital. The facility provided the reasoning that the facility would not pick up R1 because the hospital was out of county. R1 had been hospitalized on a 5150 psychiatric hold. The facility staff did not respond to the emergency and follow R1 or ensure R1 was safe and then refused to pick up R1 to bring R1 back to their home at the THPP participant unit. Staff also did not facilitate the arrangement of transportation, given the social worker no choice but to pick up R1 themselves. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. There are two citations. Due to not following discharge procedure requirements, a citation is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86068.4 Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. Due to not responding to R1's emergency and ensuring R1's safety, a citation is being issued per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86065 Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Director Dr. Phillips, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/13/21 at 11:40AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit at the licensee office to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Director Dr. Phillips and CEO Wayne Phillips and informed of the purpose of the visit. COVID-19 safety precautions were taken at visit, including masks, disinfectant, hand hygiene, and social distancing. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff, youth, and authorized representatives. Based on observations and interviews, the Director left resident R1's (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) social worker (SW) a voicemail message stating that R1 could not return until R1 received a negative COVID-19 test result. On a previous incident, the facility informed R1 that R1 would need to exit the program after an unauthorized absence for a period of two weeks unless R1 received a negative test result, which R1 did receive.

deficiencies.description:
86068.4 Removal and/or Discharge Procedures. (c) When the licensee determines the THPP can no longer meet the needs of the participant, the licensee shall notify the authorized representative...provide written notification...within seven days.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations and interviews, the licensee did not follow discharge procedures by not allowing a youth re-entry into their unit and requiring they send a negative COVID-19 test before coming back home. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The youth is no longer in placement at the facility.

Licensee agrees to submit an amendment to their program stating that prior to implementing new policies that are not granted by temporary emergency waivers, such as those addressing  COVID-19, will be submitted to CDSS for... ...approval, as required by California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80022(j). This will be submitted to LPA Hawkins by 5/31/21.

deficiencies.description:
86065 Personnel Requirements
(a) The THPP shall have qualified social work personnel available on a 24-hour basis to respond to any emergency.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, the licensee did not respond to an emergency situation involving a resident in care by not providing or facilitating transportation for a youth to return home following an emergency. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit an updated emergency protocol/procedures as an amendment to their program, ensuring the procedures address transportation in emergencies. This will be submitted to LPA Hawkins by 5/31/21.

narrative: On Friday 8/27/21 at 9:57AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit for the required annual inspection. LPA made pre-visit screening calls to the main office line and to CEO's direct line and left messages with LPA's callback number. LPA was greeted by office staff S2 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) and met with Administrative Assistant Linda Peete, who Dr. Phillips stated could represent the facility on their behalf today when LPA called Dr. Phillips upon arrival to the office. Dr. Phillips informed LPA that there are currently no residential units under the program. There are also no residents in care. Notification had not been sent to Licensing about the unit(s) no longer being used. At 10:03AM, LPA observed that there was no license posted in the office. An advisory was previously issued regarding this on 5/13/21. LPA printed a copy of the license at visit, and provided to staff to post in the office. At 10:30AM, Administrative Assistant informed LPA that only 1 client file was currently available and that the other files may be in Dr. Phillips' office or at home. Administrative Assistant was able to estimate that there were about 6 youth placed at the program within the last 3 years. Administrative Assistant informed LPA that only 3 of 6 staff files were available for review. LPA reviewed 1 of 6 client files and 3 of 6 staff files and will coordinate with Director for a follow-up inspection. LPA is requesting that Director Dr. Phillips provide LPA the most current LIC 500 and LIC 610, as well as any LIC 9020s Register of Clients, per Title 22, Section 80071(a)(1), for the past 3 years, per Title 22, Section 80070(g). LPA issued six (6) advisories per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 86009 Availability of License, 86031.5 Notification, 86061 Reporting Requirements, 80071 Register of Clients, 80019 Criminal Record Clearance, 86064 Administrator Qualifications and Duties. A follow-up inspection is required to continue the review of facility files that were not available during today's initial inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On Wednesday, September 8, 2021 at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility (THPP office) for the scheduled annual continuation. LPA scheduled the visit with Director Dr. Phillips and spoke on the phone to confirm the visit the day prior. This annual continuation is to complete the file review, as not all files were available during the initial inspection on 8/27/21. LPA used the Inspection Tool to complete the annual inspection. LPA reviewed all client files and staff files provided in the office. All files reviewed were incomplete. Staff files did not all contain the necessary documentation, such as criminal record clearance, health screening, and training documentation/certifications. The THPP was unable to provide the file for the current social worker. Client files were inconsistent. See LIC 811 Confidential Names for the following: - R1's file was missing admission agreement, identification page, authorized representative contact, photo ID, medical assessment, consent forms, immunization record, needs and services / treatment plans, inventory of cash resources and personal valuables. - R2's file was missing all of the above except the admission agreement and consent forms. - R3's file was missing all of the above except some program notes (meetings, stipends). - R4's file was missing all of the above except admission agreement and some program notes (meetings). - R5's file was missing all of the above except admission agreement, treatment plan, and identification page. 5 other files were reviewed from clients placed before 2018, and all files were missing multiple items. Additionally, residents with children did not have evidence of 1st aid training in their file. LPA issued citations per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86070 Participant Records and Section 80066 Personnel Records as well as an advisory per Section 86075 Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Director Dr. Phillips, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrative Assistant Linda Peete; Administrator/Director Dr. Phillips
narrative:
On Wednesday 10/13/21 at 10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a POC visit at the licensee administrative office. At 10:45AM, LPA met with Administrative Assistant Linda Peete, whom Director Dr. Patsy Phillips verbally authorized, over the phone to LPA, to represent the licensee and sign the reports on Director's behalf. LPA informed both of the purpose of the visit. There are no participants currently in the program. The purpose of the visit was to review the following corrections, per the plans of corrections (POCs) developed on 09/08/2021. The POCs were given an official due date of 10/06/2021, which was also written on top of the copy provided to licensee for clarity. 1. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86070(b) Participant Records. Type B. The POC was: (1) to submit a copy of the needs and services / TILP their program uses and that will be used for future clients; (2) to submit a training plan that details for current and future staff the program's procedures for ensuring client files contain all necessary documentation, including a list of the necessary documentation. This is the second time this citation has been issued within the past 12 months, so for the repeat violation, LPA issued an immediate civil penalty of $250 with a penalty of $50 per day that will accrue until the correction is completed. 2. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80066(a) Personnel Records. Type B. The POC was: to submit a training plan that outlines in detail the list of documents needed in each personnel file, how they will be organized in the personnel file, and the procedures by which the THPP will obtain these files. This can serve as an addendum to the program plan. For failure to meet the POC due date, LPA issued a civil penalty of $100 per violation per day since the due date. SEE NEXT PAGE

Additionally, POCs were not received for prior citations issued on 05/13/2021. However, LPA did not make the POC visit within the required time frame. As of today, the corrections have still not been made, so citations were re-issued, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22. 1. 80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements. Type B. Missing incident reports for resident unauthorized absences were not submitted to Licensing. The POC remains to submit any pending or unsubmitted reports and to develop a training guide for current and future staff that lists the types of incident reports, reportable incidents, and to whom and within what timeframe to submit. This is the second time this citation has been issued within the past 12 months, so for the repeat violation, LPA issued an immediate civil penalty of $250 with a penalty of $50 per day that will accrue until the correction is completed. 2. 86009(a) Availability of License. Type B. The license was not posted in the administrative office. When licensee stated they did not have a license, a one-time copy was printed, and an advisory was issued. Today, LPA observed the license is still not posted in the office. The POC is to visibly post the license in the office. 3. 86064(a)(2)(A) Administrator Qualifications and Duties. Type B. The administrator was not available during the THPP's business hours, and no staff member with administrator's qualifications was designated to cover administrator's duties. Administrative Assistant was off-duty and was called in to the office in place of Dr. Phillips, and neither a LIC 308 nor Linda's file were on site. Linda also does not have full access within the office, so, per staff, some files may be in Dr. Phillips' office or elsewhere. The POC is to demonstrate there is always coverage by qualified and authorized staff. Dr. Phillips arrived at 12:40PM. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Dr. Phillips, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 8/18/22 at 2:42PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the transitional housing placement program office for a 2 Year Inspection. LPA met with Director Dr. Patsy Phillips and President Wayne Phillips and informed of the purpose of the visit. An initial visit was made on 8/5/22, during which Director and President confirmed multiple times that they would be arriving, but after an hour and 15 minutes, they had not shown and stated they had not left their current location, which they stated was "right around the corner," to make their way toward the office. On 8/18/22, LPA provided an expected window of arrival of noon to 2PM, but at 1:42PM today when LPA arrived, neither the Director nor the President were present. They were called and confirmed they would arrive, but did not arrive until 2:35PM. The worker at the office indicated that she is not authorized to act on behalf of the licensee in any formal way and cannot sign the visit report. Upon arrival, Director informed LPA that she is technically on medical leave and the facility is not operating, which had not been reported to the Licensing agency. LPA is issuing 2 citations per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80044 Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency and 86064 Administrator Qualifications and Duties and 1 advisory per 86161 Reporting Requirements. See attached LIC 809-D and LIC 9102. Licensee was previously cited for Inspection Authority on 5/31/21 and for Administrator Qualifications (Section 86064(a)(2)(A)) on 10/13/21. Due to the repeat violation within 12 months of this section, LPA is issuing an immediate civil penalty of two-hundred and fifty dollars ($250). The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct this inspection. There are no residents currently in the program, and the facility does not currently have any participant units. The program also does not currently have any social work / case management staff. The following additional deficiencies were found: 1) The facility does not have an emergency and disaster plan and could not furnish it during the inspection. Staff have not been trained on the emergency and disaster plan. Fire drills have not been conducted quarterly nor in over 3 months. Documentation of fire drills could not be furnished during inspection. LPA is issuing 2 citations and 1 advisory per Health and Safety Code Section 1565. See attached LIC 809-Ds and LIC 9102. 2) The Director and President stated the plan of operation may be in the office, but it could not be furnished during the inspection as LPA nor staff were able to locate it. LPA is issuing 1 advisory per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86022 Plan of Operation. See attached LIC 9102. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Director Dr. Patsy Phillips and President Wayne Phillips, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 11/03/22 at 11:14AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to confirm closure. A forfeiture letter was mailed to the licensee on October 25, 2022, and the facility was officially closed on October 28, 2022. There is no one at the office as no one responded to knocks on the door, and no one answered calls to any of the facility and licensee phones. A copy of this report will be provided to the licensee by certified mail.

On 7/29/21 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman along with Public Health Nurse Helen Shi (PHN) and Alexis Peters Core Program Director (PD) conducted a Tele Inspection of the facility via Microsoft Teams due to the facility has one client and one staff with positive COVID-19. It was observed that COVID-19 posters were posted inside and outside the front entrance of the staff office, no clients were present. The client that tested positive has a roommate. The facility is working on contacting the roommate so he can quarantine also. PD stated she is waiting to hear from her corporate office on their procedure for having clients that tested positive. PD stated the staff are on a rotation so that no more than five staff (including three administrative staff) are in the office at the same time. The following recommendations were made: The facility update their local public health today with the client's status of testing positive. The facility check with the clients to see if they have enough food, disinfectant and PPE to last during their 10 day quarantine. If not, the facility is encouraged to provide them with this to avoid the clients going out or using public transportation. The facility will contact the clients to advise them to contact their doctor prior to going to the doctor or instead of going to the emergency room or clinic. The facility will advise clients to view CDC videos on the use of PPE. The facility will advise clients to not have any visitor's during their quarantine. LPA emailed this report to the Program Director with the request to sign and email it back today.

narrative: On June 24,2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez conducted an annual required inspection at the Transitional Housing Program (THP) Administrative Office. The office consisted of a lobby, large conference room, 3 private offices, youth room/small meeting room, storage room, chat room, kitchen, eight cubicals for the Life Coaches/Social Workers, two administrative cubicals, and a business center/ printer area. LPAs noted the following to be posted; license, evacuation map, accreditation, emergency plan, personal rights, and covid information. Currently they have 35 participants in placement. All apartments are located within two hours from the administrative office. There are four Life Coaches/Social Workers. Each Life Coach/ Social Worker has less than 12 participants in their caseload. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA and LPM reviewed five participants files, three staff files, ten apartment files and conducted seven staff interviews. LPA and LPM completed the Care Tool Domains: Physical Plant, Disaster Preparedness, Staffing, Client Records, and Operations .There was a deficiency noted at todays inspection. The facility did not have documentation of the Medical Assessment for its participants. Due to the new implementation of the Interim Licensing Standards Regulation section ILS 86069 (b) this section is a requirement. Exit interview was conducted with Alexis Peters, Program Director. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights will be e-mailed to Program Director.

On September 25, 2024 at 9:59am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced case management deficiency inspection to the above listed facility, for an SIR dated 07/13/24 and received by the Regional Office on 09/06/24.LPA Wilson was met by the Core Program Manger (CPM) During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 07/13/24 the youth (C1) was involved in a car accident with a driver who was under the influence, and which resulted in vehicle damage, and law enforcement involvement. The youth was reported uninjured and did not receive medical attention. Per the (CPM), the SIR was reported late to the Regional Office on 09/06/24 due to being out of town and missing the time to submit it.. (CPM) was aware of the late reporting and stated that division staff had virtual training on incident reporting and complaint procedures on 09/11/24 using Teams.LPA Wilson was provided a copy of the training agenda and handouts with email invitation to TAY and Division staff. (CPM) also shared the recording of the training, which LPA Wilson observed. A (1) deficiency Type B has been determined at this time. The following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC 809D) An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee. (CPM ) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

deficiencies.description:
80061	Reporting Requirements		  
(b)	Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in…(2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA observations and interviews conducted the licensee did not ensure incident report dated 07/13/24 was reported to the CCL regional office within (7) days, which poses a potential danger to the health safety and personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Licensee will ensure a plan of correction which addresses chain of command for review and approvals for SIR.
Licensee will ensure SIR sent to CCL Regional Office is completed, signed and dated with approvers identification.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Program Manager Leticia Woodruff to follow-up on an incident that occurred in one of the certified units on Dec. 6, 2024 (0001326-FN). The Department received a special incident report on Dec. 12, 2024. Per Ms. Woodruff, the office was unaware of the incident until Dec. 12, 2024. Per the narrative, P1 had two male visitors in her apartment and the visitors got into an argument. They took the argument outside and one of the visitors fired a total of five gunshots. It is unclear if the shooter meant to hit the other visitor or was just trying to scare him. P1 initially denied that the two males were her guests. However, her roommate identified the two males caught on camera as visitors to P1. Also neighbors reported seeing those two males exiting the apartment of P1. Once the two males were identified by witnesses as being seen entering and exiting her apartment P1 finally admitted that they were her visitors. P1 was terminated from the program on the basis that the participant rules state that participants are responsible for the actions of their guest and because those actions were endangering Aspiranet's lease. There was an incident report issued by Oxnard Police Department on Dec. 6, 2024 indicating that a person was arrested in connection with the shooting. LPA was provided with copies of the police report, the discharge and termination notices, the participant rules signed by P1. The documents will be placed in the office file. LPA found no violations nor deficiencies on the part of the licensee. No citations were issued. Exit interview was conducted and the program manager was provided with a copy of this report.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward arrived at the facility at 9:00 AM to conduct the annual required inspection. LPA attempted to open the LIC 809 and the CARES tool but was unable to due to technical issues. LPA will complete the inspection on a future date.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Program Manager Leticia Woodruff to conduct the annual required inspection. LPA Jones-Steward observed that all client files are kept in a secure area in Ms. Woodruff's office. Personnel files are kept electronically. The Administrator Office is equipped with cubicle spaces for all staff, three conference rooms for privacy and therapeutic services. There is a kitchen area that is equipped with a smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detector. The license was posted in the program manger's office. LPA advised that a copy should also be placed in a more public area. LPA Jones-Steward reviewed participant and personnel files and also toured two certified units located in the City of Oxnard. LPA interviewed two participants in their living unit. Each unit had two occupants, each with their own bedroom. The kitchen and bathroom equipment in each unit are in working order. There are working smoke detectors, carbon monoxide detectors and fire extinguishers in each unit that was inspected. There were no security bars on windows. There are four Life Coaches with a maximum caseload of 11 participants, and two social worker supervisors. All ratios are within Title 22 guidelines. The facility was cited under Title 22 86069(a) for failure to obtain medical assessments as required. Exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were given.

On March 22, 2021 at 3:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an in-person Case Management inspection at the above Transitional Housing Placement (THPP) administrative office to follow up on a death incident that occurred on March 19, 2021. LPA met with Wendy Naruse, Program Manager. On March 19, 2021, the Department received a special incident Report from Aspiranet Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) reporting that in the morning of March 19, 2021, a 20-year old male client was found unresponsive in his THPP apartment. A young lady who identified herself as the client’s girlfriend reported that she found the client face down on the floor in the morning, unresponsive and called 911. Officers from the Bakersfield Police Department, the Kern County Coroner, Bakersfield Fire Department and Paramedics responded within minutes. Bakersfield Fire Department pronounced the client deceased at the scene. According to the Police officers at the scene, it appears that the client died from a drug overdose. During this inspection, LPA obtained copies of the following documents: Staff roster (LIC 500); Client roster; NMD#1's records – SIRs/LE Contact Reports; Admission Agreement; Pre-placement Appraisal and assessment; current TILP and NSP; ; Health & Education passport; Wellness Screening; Certificate of Compliance; Facility Sketch; and Social Worker notes in the past 2 weeks. A signed copy of this report was provided to the THPP representative.

met_with: Victoria McClain, THPP Administrator and Wendy Naruse, Core Program Manager
narrative: On June 29, 2021 at 2:35 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced Annual/Required inspection at the above named Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for non-minor dependents (NMDs). LPA met with Victoria McClain, THPP Administrator and Wendy Naruse, Core Program Manager. Currently, the THPP office is staffed by six (6) Life Coaches (Case Managers), three (3) Program Managers and an Administrator. During this inspection, LPA reviewed all 10 personnel records. All personnel have obtained criminal record clearances and child abuse index checks. All personnel are associated to the THPP's facility number. A Case Management - Annual/Required Continuation inspection is required to complete this evaluation. A signed copy of this report was provided to the THPP representative along with LIC 859 (Review of Staff Records).

met_with: Victoria McClain, THPP Administrator and Wendy Naruse, Core Program Manager
narrative:
On June 30, 2021 at 3:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced Case Management - Annual Continuation at Aspiranet- Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP for non-minor dependents (NMD)). The purpose of the inspection was to complete the annual inspection initiated by the LPA on June 29, 2021. Administration On June 30, 2021, a tour of the THPP administrative office was conducted with Ms. McClain & Ms. Naruse. The THPP administrative office shares the same suite with Aspiranet - Foster Family Agency. The office is conveniently located for the public. The office has a reception area, file room, copy area, conference room and individual offices for the Administrator and Program Managers. Case Managers and other personnel share office spaces. Currently, the THPP office is staffed by six (6) Life Coaches (Case Managers), three (3) Program Managers, one(1) Administrator and several administrative/office personnel. THPP participant records are kept in steel filing cabinets located in the file room which is kept locked at all times. Per Administrator, the THPP personnel records have been transferred to Aspiranet Headquarters in San Francisco, CA and are no longer maintained at the facility site. An Advisory Note-Technical Violation was provided to the licensee. The administrative office has telephone service at all times. The program has 38 remote sites and 63 participants in placement. Per Administrator, the program has no non-ambulatory participants in placement. Participant Records On June 30, 2021, LPA reviewed 6 participant records. LPA inspected the following documents: Social Security Card; California ID/Driver's License; Birth Certificate; Personal Rights for NMD; Expectations, Alternatives, Consequences; current Needs and Services Plan and Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP) ; Admission/Placement Agreement; and Certificate of Compliance. (cont.)

Staff Records On June 29, 2021, LPA reviewed 10 personnel records. A review of Licensing Information System (LIS) on June 29, 2021 indicates that personnel have obtained criminal record clearances and child abuse index checks. LPA inspected the following documents: proof of education; verification of related work experience; training log/certificates; First Aid/CPR Certificates. No deficiencies cited at this time. LPA provided 3 Advisory Notes - Technical Violation. A signed copy of this report was provided to the THPP representative along with LIC 9102TVs (Advisory Notes-Technical Violation) and LIC 858 (Resident's Record Review).

On October 19, 2021 at 4:35 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Aspiranet Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) to follow up on a death incident involving Participant#1. LPA met with Wendy Naruse, Core Program Manager. On October 18, 2021, Aspiranet Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) reported to the Department that an 18-year-old male participant was found deceased in his apartment. The facility reported that at approximately 1:30 PM on October 16, 2021, the apartment manager notified the facility that the Bakersfield Police Department and Kern County Coroner were present at the participant’s apartment. Though facility staff responded immediately, the police and coroner had left by the time they arrived. The facility program manager contacted the participant’s roommate, also the participant’s twin brother, who reported that on October 16, 2021, he called 911 and attempted chest compressions after observing his brother unresponsive, face up on the floor in his bedroom. The cause of the participant’s death is unknown at this time. During the inspection, LPA requested the following documents: Pre-placement Appraisal; Personal Statement; THPP Application and Assessment; most recent home inspection; Certificate of Compliance; TILP and Needs and Services Plan; Kern Behavioral referral; case plan; case notes. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with LIC 811 (Confidential names list.)

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen McGee conducted a case management inspection at the above named Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) office on 01/20/22 at 2:45 PM. LPA met with Administrator, Victoria McClain. The inspection was in regards to the licensee's application to increase capacity from 74 to 100. Prior to this inspection, the Department received the following documents from the licensee: LIC 200 (Application), a copy of the board resolution approving the capacity increase; and the appropriate licensing fee. During this inspection, LPA noted that there are no physical plant changes since the last site inspection conducted on 10/19/21. Currently, this THPP program has 55 participants in placement. Per Administrator, all participants are ambulatory and they all live in single housing units (apartments or single family dwellings). The program is staffed by 1 Administrator, 1 Program Manager, 1 Social Work Supervisor, 5 Social Workers, 2 Housing Specialists, and 1 Employment Specialist. The program maintains an appropriate social worker/participant ratio. Personnel records are kept at Aspiranet – Human Resource Department and participant records are kept locked in the file room at the THPP office. No deficiencies cited at the time of inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the THPP representative.

On June 15, 2022 at 9:45am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Lofton conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above-named address. Aspiranet Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) is relocating its office from 1001 Tower Way Suite 250, Bakersfield, CA 93309 to 4900 California Ave., Tower A #410A, Bakersfield, CA 93309. LPA met with Core Program Director Victoria McClain and conducted a tour of the new office. The office has a reception area, conference room, individual offices for program director, program manager, and supervisors. It also has an THPP office area with six (6) desks available for life coaches, and desks for an employment specialist and housing specialist. There is also a storage room, a staff lounge, and a file room. The door to the file room will remain locked at all times. The office is equipped with two fire extinguishers. LPA verified the fire clearance dated 6/7/22. The LPA observed the Foster Youth Rights Posters, Copies of CCL License, Emergency Disaster Plan for Children’s Residential Facilities and Facility Sketch at the facility ready to be posted. A copy of this report was left with Victoria McClain for records.

On 8/11/2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Aspiranet THP program for the purpose of a Case Management incident. LPA met with Administrator and discussed the incident identified below. 1. Non- minor dependent (NMD) having a medical incident which resulted in child being taken to hospital and placed on hold- Administrator stated that NMD was enrolled within program from 6/2/2022 to 6/17/22 and it was identified during the time of NMD filing their application that NMD had a history of substance abuse. Documentation taken identified NMD to have been sober for approximately 8 months prior to being enrolled in program. However, during the time of being enrolled within the program NMD had several medical incidents that warranted child going to hospital involving drugs. Administrator stated that agency was able to transition NMD to a rehabilitation live in facility acronym TAY and NMD was ultimately discharged from program. LPA obtained copies of pre-appraisal , application and incident reports. Agency notified all parties and provided proper care to NMD prior to being discharged from program. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was left with Administrator.

On November 02, 2023 at 8:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles made unannounced visit to the Aspiranet Transitional Housing Placement Program for the purpose of a Case Management incident. LPA met with Administrator, Victoria McClain and discussed the Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on 10/23/23 with regards to non-minor dependent (NMD) (refer to Confidential Names List LIC 811, dated 11/02/23) overdose of pills. LPA Robles conducted a telephone interview with the Administrator on 11/01/23. Per Administrator, the incident that happened in July was an ideation from NMD and does not have plans of suicide. After the release of NMD from the hospital, she was allowed to have a friend stay for seven (7) days with her in the apartment. Per Administrator, the pill NMD took was never disclosed to them and it happened in a party as it was NMD’s birthday. An Intensive Care Coordination (ICC) meeting was held on 10/30/23 and facilitated by TAY Mental Health, in response to the incident and a safety plan was created. TAY Mental Health has enrolled her in the program called Positive Action Towards Hope & Healing (PATHH), which is an intensified services and increased face to face visits weekly. Additionally, Life Coach (LC) will increase weekly check ins to ensure NMD has support and services needed. LPA obtained copies of Needs and Services Plan, incident report addendum and case notes. The incident was reported to all appropriate parties. No further follow-up is needed. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to the facility Administrator.

On May 1, 2024, at around 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted a case management inspection at the Transitional Housing Program (THP) Office and met Administrator, Victoria McClain. The purpose of the inspection was to make a follow-up regarding the Special Incident Report (SIR) that the Department received on 04/17/24. The SIR indicated that on 04/10/24, participant reference #1 (P1) see LIC 811 (Confidential Names List) notified her Life Coach and County Social Worker (CSW) regarding her recent emergency room visit last 04/08/24 due to a rash. On 04/19/24, LPA called the THP and gathered the information that there was no report either by email or phone call to the Department within 24 hours from the occurrence of the incident or finding about the incident, made by the facility prior to the Department's receipt of the written incident report. CCR 80061 Reporting Requirements: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) ... a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) ...shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. A deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 809D and LIC 811 were provided to the administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee states that they will ensure all reportable incidents will be reported to the Department within 24 hours upon its occurrence or next business day and submit the written report within 7 days following the occurrence of such event.  A letter to that effect will be submitted to the Department by Plan of Correction (POC) date (05/10/24).

narrative: On 5/2/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with the representative above regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on April 4, 2024. The SIR stated that the Non-Minor Dependent (NMD)t#1 (C1) (see confidential names form LIC 811) had suicidal ideation with a plan to jump in the Kern River. Children 48. Based on record review and interviews, the NMD met with a life coach and disclosed the information of her thoughts to jump in the Kern River. The LC was advised to contact the mental health team to assist the client. NMD was transported to a hospital for evaluation but was later released the same day due to client denying such statement. The agency has been providing the NMD with support services such as therapy,face-to face meetings and a confirmed placement assessment meeting. In addition, a Columbia Suicide Rating Scale (C-SSRS) screening was completed. The NMD's results were negative for current risk. Overall, the NMD is adapting well into the program and there has been no concerns with the health and safety of her placement. The representative above provided the LPA with copies of the NMDs confidential records for review via email. No further follow-up required. A copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811 was provided to the facility representative above.

On June 21,2024, Licensing Program Analysts Angelina Garibaldo conducted a required 2- year inspection at the THPP administrative office. LPA met with Victoria McClain, Core Program Director and Wendy Naruse, Core Program Manager. During this inspection, a tour of the THPP administrative office was conducted with Core Program Director. The office is conveniently located for the public. The office has a reception area, conference room, cubical space of life coaches and individual offices for the Administrator and Program Managers. Currently the THPP has 53 non-minor dependents (NMD) in placement. All participant records are maintained in locked file cabinets in the administrative office. The THPP personnel records are kept electronically and maintained by Human Resource office. The administrative office has telephone service. During this inspection, LPA reviewed three (3) participant records and three (3) personnel records. board member meeting minutes, Disaster Preparedness Plan, administrator's record, and background clearances. There was (8) citations, one (1) Advisory Notes-Technical. See LIC 9102 TV issued during today’s inspection. A signed copy of this report and was provided to the licensee along with LIC 9102 TV. Exit interview conducted.

met_with: Wendy Naruse, Core Program Manager and Victoria McClain, Program Director
narrative:
On June 25, 2025, at 9:23 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted an unannounced annual inspection to the Transitional Housing Program (THP) administrative office. When LPA arrived, LPA met with Wendy Naruse, Core Program Manager, Program Director Victoria McClain arrived shortly. The THP has thirty-six (36) remote site living units fifty-one (51) and participants in placement. The THP office shares the same office with Aspiranet Foster Family Agency (FFA). The administrative office is conveniently located for the public on the fourth floor of a commercial building. The LPA toured the office and observed the Foster Youth Rights Posters, Copies of CCL License, Emergency Disaster Plan for Children’s Residential Facilities and Facility Sketch were posted in a prominent location. The administrative office has a file room, copy area, conference room and individual offices for the Program Directors and Program Managers, and kitchen/break room. THP participant and staff records are kept electronically. The administrative office has telephone service on the premises. Cont...

LPA obtained and reviewed the following documentation: LIC 500 Personnel, Client Roster LIC 610C and Emergency Disaster Plan Board of Directors Minutes Annual compliance Review consisted of the following five (5) domains: physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, staff and client files. Staff were interviewed. During this inspection, LPA Garibaldo issued one (1) Technical Violation related to client records. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report, LIC809, LIC809C, LIC9102 and LIC811 was provided to the Program Director.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rodriguez met with Core Program Director, Joshua Mishou. The visit was conducted due to an incident occurring on October 11, 2021 (see 811 for confidential names). The incident report was received by the Department via email on October 19, 2021. The report was not received within the 7-days by Community Care Licensing as required by regulations. Further, LPA obtained additional information and documentation from licensee regarding the incident. Please see attached 812 for additional information. Based on the above, there is a preponderance of evidence to substantiate a violation of regulation based on California Code of Regulation, which is being cited on the attached LIC 809D An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and Appeal Rights were provided to the Core Program Director.

On February 14, 2023, LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Wayne Aoki conducted an unannounced Required 2- Year Annual Inspection at the Aspiranet Fresno THP+FC office at 1320 E. Shaw Ave., Suite 140. The agency has a capacity of 74 with 35 participants on this date. This LPA met with Core Program Director, Joshua Mishou and discussed current operations and status. Currently the THP employs one Administrator, 3 Life Coaches, 1 Supervisor and 1 Housing Specialist. one Social Work Supervisor to supervise the non minor dependents in the program. LPA reviewed client and personnel files on this date. 5 client files reviewed and 5 personnel files. Staff interview conducted. Procedures for locked and secured files observed. A review of staff files on this date indicate that all facility staff have received child abuse index clearances and fingerprint clearances. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. A copy of this report is left at the agency with the Core Program Director.

On May 20, 2025 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Melissa Renovato, conducted an unannounced Random Annual Inspection at the Aspiranet Fresno THP+FC office at 1320 E. Shaw Ave., Suite 140. The agency has a capacity of 74 with 27 participants on this date. A walk through inspection of the facility was conducted. This LPA met with TAY Program Director, Joshua Mishou and discussed current operations and status. Currently the THP employs one Administrator, 3 Life Coaches, 1 Supervisor and 1 Housing Specialist. LPA reviewed client and personnel files on this date. 5 client files reviewed and 5 personnel files. 2 Staff interviews conducted. Procedures secured files observed on the online database. On March 8, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), C. White arrived at Aspiranet - Los Angeles Transitional Housing Placement + Foster Care Administrative Office for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA met with Katherine Strang, Core Program Supervisor. LPA was granted access to the suite and toured the entire facility. The program is licensed to provide THP+FC services to forty-five (45) non-minor dependents. The current census is 30. The facility is located in a commercial building on the 4th floor. The location serves as the satellite/sub administrative office and houses the administrator as well as the THP+FC staff and client records. The office is set up as follows: reception area, several offices, staff break room, small conference room. Entry office/reception area: which is utilized by the following programs: THP +FC, Foster Family Agency, and Wraparound Services. Each program has their own staff. There are four (4) offices are designated to the THP+FC program, which are used as follows: Office #1: houses the life coaches and the housing specialist. The room has multiple cubicles each equipped with a desk, chair, phone, and a computer. There are two additional sub offices located in this room. One sub-office is used by the program secretary. The second sub-office is used to store THP+FC client files and Wrap Around Service files. LPA observed the room to have several individual locked file cabinets, three of which are designated to the THP+FC program. This room remains locked at all times. Office #2: is used for surplus storage. Office #:3 houses the Administrator. Office #4: houses the Core Program Supervisor. Report continued on LIC 809 (Page 1 of 2).

Staff break room: equipped with a sink, refrigerator/freeze, a coffee machine, and a microwave. Small conference room: equipped with a wooden desk. This room is utilized for interviews and private meetings with clients. Additionally, there are other offices and cubicles in the suite which are designated to the two (2) other programs. This program utilizes the remote site housing model and ensures the following services will be applicable: 1.) Participants have their own bedroom; 2.) No more than two participants share a bathroom: 3.) No more than two participants share a refrigerator; 4.) On-site supervisor available 24/7 to support, assist and oversee the needs of the participants: 5.) Assigned Social Workers assist and meet with participants a minimum of once a week (face-to-face); and 6.) Supervision, if needed, for the distribution of prescription medication. The organization also utilizes the iTrack system to report Special Incidents to CCL. LPA observed the following postings: Personnel Report; Facility sketch; Emergency Disaster Plan; COVID-19 Information. A total of ten (10) client files were reviewed. Each client file contained copies of important documents including, but not limited to, the following: Admission Agreement; signed/dated quarterly Needs and Services Plan; TILP; Allowance and Saving logs; Health and Education Passport; and Personal Rights forms. LPA observed the Needs and Service Plans to be completed within 30 calendar days from date of client placement. LPA will return at a later date to review staff files. LPA obtained a copy of the facility personnel report, LIC 500 and client roster. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations, including capacity limitations. No deficiencies were observed or cited at the time of this inspection. A copy of this report was left with the Core Program Supervisor. (Page 2 of 2).

On June 22. 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White made an unannounced visit to Aspiranet-Los Angeles for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Incident. LPA met with the S1 to discuss the details of the SIR #845431 received by CCL on 02/24/2023 regarding a “Possible Suicide Attempt”. During the visit LPA conducted a confidential interview and reviewed client files. LPA was informed that the incident occurred on 02/23/2024 and C1 was transported to the hospital. On 02/26/2023 C1 was placed on a 14 day psychiatric hold, however C1 was discharged from the hospital on 02/27/2023 and returned to placement without any further incidents. S1 informed LPA due to incident an emergency CFT meeting was held and updated C1’s safety plan. Additionally, LPA was informed that per court order dated 05/18/2022 C1 was found to be a NMD under WIC Section 300 Subdivision B. LPA also confirmed that the licensee did submit an addendum to CCL on 03/01/2023 providing a status update of C1. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA concluded the Case Management-Incident and a copy of this report was left at the facility with the Core Program Supervisor.

On March 28, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), C. White arrived at Aspiranet - Los Angeles Transitional Housing Placement + Foster Care Administrative Office for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA met with Jamie McCall, Core Program Director. LPA was granted access to the suite and toured the entire facility. The program is licensed to provide THP+FC services to forty-five (45) non-minor dependents. The current census is 26. Facility overview: The facility administrative office is located on the 4th floor of a commercial building. The office has a reception area, several staff offices, a staff break room, and a conference room. The program utilizes the remote site housing model to house clients. Reception area: is used by the following programs: THP +FC, Foster Family Agency, and Wraparound Services (each program has separate staff). 4 Offices are designated to the THP+FC program: Office #1: is located to the right of the reception area. This room has multiple cubicles each equipped with a desk, chair, phone, and a computer. The cubicles are utilized by the program’s life coaches and housing specialist. There are two sub offices located in the room. One sub-office is used by the program secretary. The second sub-office is used to store THP+FC client files and Wrap Around Service files. LPA observed the room to have several individual locked file cabinets, three of which are designated to the THP+FC program. Office #2: is used for surplus storage. Office #:3 is designated for the Core Program Director. Office #4: is designated for the Core Program Supervisor. Staff break room: has a sink, refrigerator/freezer, coffee machine, microwave, and plenty of cabinets. The staff break room is used by all programs located in the in the office. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 1 of 2).

Conference room: is equipped with four tables, 3 desk, and 16 chairs. The room is utilized for private interviews, staff meetings, and meetings with clients. The program ensures clients have the following services: 1.) clients have their own bedroom; 2.) No more than two clients share a bathroom: 3.) No more than two clients share a refrigerator; 4.) there is on-site supervisor available 24/7 to support, assist and oversee the needs of the clients, 5.) each client has an assigned Social Worker to assist them; 6.) program Social Workers meet with clients (face to face) a minimum of once a week, and 7.) the program assist clients with the distribution of prescription medication when needed. LPA observed the following postings: Personnel Report; Office sketch; Emergency Disaster Plan, Covid Management Plan. At the time of this inspection, the program has a total of twenty six (26) clients. LPA reviewed a total of ten (10) client files. Each client file contained copies of important documents including, but not limited to, the following: Admission Agreement; Needs and Services Plan; TILP; Allowance and Saving logs; Health and Education Passport; and Personal Rights forms. The program has a total of ten (10) staff. LPA conducted 3 staff interviews. LPA will return at a later date to review staff files. LPA obtained a copy of the facility personnel report, LIC 500 and client roster. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations, including capacity limitations. No deficiencies were observed or cited at the time of this inspection. A copy of this report was left with the Core Program Director. (Page 2 of 2).

On this date, an unannounced annual inspection is conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Rachel Bruce and Priscilla Zamudio.. Met at the facility by Administrator, The agency currently serves 8 THP+FC youth, and two life coaches/social workers; one housing specialist and one Administrator A general overview of their program and a tour of the facility was provided. This facility has a reception area, waiting area, and office space for staff. Observed fixtures and furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for this operation. Also observed locked cabinets for client and staff files in order to ensure confidentiality. Discussed daily ongoing functions including incident reports. Participant's living units are inspected monthly. Facility ensures that cleaning solutions and other dangerous items are inaccessible to infants of minor parents. Facility ensures that firearms or other weapons are not stored in THP+FC living units. Facility ensures that fire extinguishers and carbon monoxide detectors are in proper working order. Participant and Personnel Files reviewed on this date. All appropriate items observed. A review of personnel records on this date indicates that facility personnel are appropriately fingerprint cleared. Reviewed incident reporting guidelines. Facility appears to be in compliance with reporting requirements including that of suspected child abuse or abuse of adults. No deficiencies observed on this date.If you have any questions regarding the process or tools, please send them by email to inspectionprocess@dss.ca.gov. For additional information regarding the inspection and its tools and methods, please visit the PROGRAM website at www.cdss.ca.gov/inforesources/community-care-licensing/inspection-process.

On 07/31/2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Brinae Pointer and Miriam Flores traveled to Aspiranet THP Plus to conduct an annual inspection. Met with Program Director, Jacqueline Villacana. The agency currently serves 11 THP NMD, two life coaches, one Program Director, one House Specialist/Administrator. At about 10:40AM, an inspection of five client files was conducted. At about 11:15AM, an inspection of four staff files was conducted. At about 12:30 PM, Disaster Preparedness Plan was reviewed. At about 2:40PM Plan of Operation Section was reviewed. At about 3:00PM LPA, Pointer conducted a facility inspection. At about 3:30PM, LPA Pointer conducted a staff interview. This facility has a reception area, waiting area, conference rooms, and office space for staff. Observed furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for this operation. Also observed locked cabinets for client files in order to ensure confidentiality. The exit interview was conducted at 3:35 and a copy of this report was given to the Program Director, Jacqueline Villacana. It is requested that the licensee submit the following updated forms to CCL: LIC 308, 309, 610C by August 9, 2024. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date.

The third allegation is whether NMD was using marijuana in the apartment. Agency documentation of face-to-face meetings and inspections of the apartment document this did not occur. However, since NMD did not respond to requests to be interviewed, it is not possible to make a that determination. Based on the investigation, records reviewed and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.

narrative: On 6/9/2022 at 12:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez conducted an announced inspection to the above named facility to conduct an inspection to its new relocation THPP and THPP Plus site. The Foster Family Agency (FFA) is relocating its office from 6 South El Dorador St #510 CA, Stockton to 2423 W. March Lane, Suite 201 Stockton, CA. LPM Rodriguez and LPA Lor met with Director. All the required posters were met. The posters include the fire clearance, facility sketch, tax certificate, foster youth rights, accreditation poster expired 3/26/22, and emergency evacuation. The front reception consisted of 2 computers and 2 desks. The facility consisted of 2 offices equipped with a desk and chair used by 1 Director, 2 Social Workers, 8 desks, chairs with 8 computers used for Social Workers, 1 conference room with a large table and 16 chairs, a visitation room equipped with 3 desks and 3 couches, 1 break room equipped with 1 refrigerator, 1 microwave, 1 water dispenser, and a large file room equipped with 12 tall file cabinets and a large printer. The hour of operation will be from 8am-5pm Monday through Friday. There were 1 first aid kit, 2 fire extinguishers, 1 carbon monoxide, 1 smoke detector tested by fire department, and 2 emergency exits. An exit interview was conducted with Director and a copy of this report will be emailed to cromero@aspiranet.org.
